reviews.reviewTitle: BEWARE! Plastic gears between motor & burr
reviews.reviewText:
I will say that I loved the grinder while it worked. Consistent grinds, and the glass container was less static-y than some others I've used with plastic containers.

After about 14 months (not even being used every day, maybe 5-6 grinds a week), one of the plastic drive gears broke. See my picture above. It started making a horrible noise, then bits of the gear fell out on to my counter.

Bodum does not sell replacement parts, so in the trash it goes. I tried emailing their US support & they never responded.

reviews.reviewTitle: Purchased July of 2013, didn't even last for 2 ...
reviews.reviewText: Purchased July of 2013, didn't even last for 2 yrs. Main drive gear shattered, see image. All drive gears are plastic when they should be metal,(preferably high quality metal !), especially for an appliance that costs over $100. Operated for 10 seconds per day x 610 days equates to ONLY 1.69 total hours of use. Corporate greed strikes again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fine grinder if you can figure out how to clean it!
reviews.reviewText: Grinds consistently and finely. It's easy to operate and fast. Two issues prevent it from being excellent. First, there are always coffee grinders that fall out of the machine after grinding and removing the glass cup. And static electricity builds up in the cup, which keeps some of the grounds on the side when you empty the cup. The only way I've found to fix the static electricity issue is to wait at least 10 minutes after grinding to remove the cup. Second, the instructions are very minimal and not helpful. After 7 months, my grinder stopped grinding. It would make a whirring sound but wouldn't grind. I looked in the instructions to find a fix and there was no trouble-shooting information. I was about to send it back to Bodum when I went on line and found a video that showed how to disassemble the machine and clean the clog. It turns out that grinding french roast, which is very oily, on a fine setting clogs the machine over time and you have to take it apart and clean the burr and the chute. I saw a great video online that recommended running 1/4 cup of rice through the machine regularly to clean it out. I cleaned out the chute with a thin bottle brush, tapped it gently against the sink to remove the remaining grinds, then ran rice through it. It works fine again.

Beautiful styling and good performance - for 18 months, when the motor burned out, complete with smoke. While we only ran it for about 30 seconds at a time, I recall it had a ridiculously short duty cycle, with a 5 minute cool down requirement. Sounds like marginal design at best. Caveat emptor!

Replaced it with a Baratza Encore, which isn't as flashy but is much better built, and has motor thermal protection.

reviews.reviewTitle: I contacted Bodum customer service (not an easy process, no customer service phone number available
reviews.reviewText: Worked well for a grinder that cost ~ $100 , while it worked. Fairly consistent grind and only needed cleaning every 2 months even though I normally use oily dark roasts. But finally the plastic retainer ring that holds the upper burr broke. It was not available for replacement on the Bodum site. I contacted Bodum customer service (not an easy process, no customer service phone number available, email only). I was told that I would have to check their website replacement parts page to see when the part would be available ( no option to backorder or be notified when the part would become available). Was also told that the inexpensive plastic retainer ring was not sold as a seperate part, but could only be purchased with the upper burr. I couldn't believe that one of the most likely to break inexpensive plastic pieces on a product that cost $100 was both unavailable and must be purchased as part of a more expensive piece. Needless to say I was disappointed and will not purchase any more products from this company. For those of you experiencing this same problem, I ended up repairing the part myself using J-B plastic bond and trimming excess bonding material to size with a sharp knife and sandpaper. Note: added extra bonding material to junction of the break at the end of both long edges where the tolerances are not as critical as the inner and outer edges.

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't buy this good looking TOY--6 gm coffee per grind
reviews.reviewText:
On the Amazon web site I liked the "burr grinder" and the ("not slicing but crushing line") and the design looked great with large bean hopper, non-static borosilicate glass ground coffee receptical. I also liked the very quick next day delivery Amazon promised and which Amazon performed.

It arrived and I set it up--very simple, looked good. Then I read the instructions--my paraphrase: "After 20 seconds of grinding (the maximum period) allow it to stand for 5 minutes so that the grinding motor will not overheat. Then you may grind again--up to a maximum of 20 seconds, etc."

I set the machine to "fine" and selected "20 seconds." It ground 6 grams. I didn't believe it!

I waited 5 minutes and did another 20 second grind. It produced 7 grams!

I want a grinder which produces at least 60 grams for a breakfast brew,

THIS MACHINE IS A TOY FOR DOLL COFFEE PARTIES, NOT A COFFEE GRINDER FOR HUMANS.

I'm returning it today.

Mike

Ok, so originally gave it one star because it only half ground the beans, regardless of the setting. Two days after I initiated the return I found a collar piece that sits between the hopper and the Burr. It just sits there mind you. It must have fallen off when I unpacked it from the box. Now, when it wouldn't grind correctly I must have read the instructions a dozen times to see if I missed something. The company must consider this small collar, that just sits on there, part of the grinder because it was not listed anywhere. Basically it was just "put the hopper on, add beans, and go." If it had been listed as a part, or at least a footnote to make sure it was sitting there, I could have saved myself a headache. That's why I knocked off a star on this updated review. All that being said, now that I have it assembled correctly it works like a charm. I ground everything from powder fine to chunky percolator grounds just to be sure. The catch basket could seal a little better in my opinion, but if it wasn't for the lack of instruction/confusion I would have went five stars. Now I have to go cancel the return...

After a little over two year it was grinding at only 10% of original capacity, used once a day. Followed all the cleaning instructions. No improvement. Burrs maybe dull. So called Bodum and asked if I could buy replacement burr (which easily pops out as part of the cleaning process) they said they do not supply any operating parts. Period. I asked, ok so the burr is dull what do you do? The answer? Trash it and buy a new machine...... Advice I will follow, only it will not be a shoddy Bodum product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Update: Over time it grinds much less and less with the same settings.
reviews.reviewText:
Update 12/10/2017

I downgraded this rating to 3 stars; after 8.5 months it now grinds about 50% of what it used to in a single 20-second run, requiring us to run it twice. I have cleaned the burrs in the unit so that is not the problem. Thinking of opening it up to see if the pathway below the lower burr is clogged. Both burrs should be easily removable for cleaning and inspection. >_>

Another update, same day:

I removed the bottom, slid the motor/drivetrain assembly down. The drive was full of coffee grounds and everything else inside was coated with grounds. The hopper itself was not clogged at all. I used a canned duster to blow off most of the grounds, not bothering to fully disassemble. The grinder now produces about 90% of the coffee grounds it used to on a single run. I suspect if I put the time into tearing it down completely I'll find a whole lot of grinds in between the gear faces and if I rebuild it, it would be back to 100%.

What does this tell us? They need to work on sealing the mechanism better to prevent dust/grounds ingress into the drivetrain. Bumped my rating back up to three but I am still disappointed at what I saw when I opened it up. Shame on Bodum!

---
Original 4-star review:

I used to grind my coffee at the supermarket using the large burr grinders, or at home with a blade grinder, and never noticed much difference between the two. Since I relocated and the local supermarkets here don't clean their grinders (ever) I haven't bothered in a while but I missed my espresso so I bought one of these burr grinders.

Now that I grind the beans within a couple of minutes of making espresso I now notice the difference in depth of flavor and strength of the espresso, and I find that this little grinder actually makes a more consistent grind than the large units at the supermarket, and grinding within minutes of brewing does actually make a difference.

What I like about the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder:

* It produces a consistent grind
* It is easy to clean
* It offers a good capacity for espresso lovers
* It grinds quickly

What could be improved:

* The coffee grinds cling to the side of the cup due to static. This could be alleviated if there were a metallic film on the glass or if they were to laminate a screen into the glass to dissipate the static charge, albeit adding a significant cost to manufacture
* The unit could benefit from a contact switch or other method of sensing whether the cup is in the unit (I've hit the button, forgetting to put the cup in place to catch the grind)
* the grind selector can be adjusted only while the unit is operating, and is integrated into the hopper. I would like to see the adjustor made discrete and adjustable before beginning a grind
* the cup could benefit from being shaped with a spout or a simple angle to make pouring into an espresso filter possible
* reading others' complaints about lack of replacement parts, I am disappointed that Bodum do not make parts available for servicing the unit. While the unit functions fine so far I am disappointed in that

Bottom line: although a burr grinder is an unexciting purchase I am very pleased with the unit and am enjoying the results much better than previous (blade) grinders I have owned. Also, regarding the burr vs. blade grinder debate I am now a believer. :)

Update 16 months later: I need to run it about 5 times in a row to grind enough. I've torn it down a couple of times for a thorough cleaning and reassembled it and it restores the functionality by about 80% but I can't be bothered to do it again. I'll be looking at other options. Give this unit a miss! Downgrading to 2 stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: High hopes, initial happiness, ultimately disappointed. Oily beans a problem.
reviews.reviewText:
I'm a Bodum fan, with lots of their glassware. I like their design aesthetic, and they certainly applied it to the Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder. I bought it eight months ago, and at first I was happy with the purchase. I now regret buying it. I'll tell you why after I tell you why I started out so positive:

What I like:
1) Great design, as mentioned.
2) Glass grounds container works great.
3) Not too noisy. (Though not super quiet, either.)
4) Metal burr assembly.

Here are the problems:
1) 20 second on, five minute off duty cycle. I have a Bonavita coffee maker (love it) and there is no way 20 seconds grinds enough coffee. Do I wait for five minutes (painful) or risk damaging the Bodum (painful). I don't need a painful choice in the morning!
2) Ground coffee builds up under the burr sleeve (what I'm calling the stationary metal grinding surface that surrounds the rotating burr) which causes the grind to get finer and finer.
3) The gear train that connects the electric motor to the nice metal burr is plastic!

So here is what happens. Over days and weeks, throughput goes down. Rather than 40 seconds of grinding, I need 60 (that would be 11 minutes ... too long, so I only give it two or three minutes between grinds.) Then I figure out that I need to really clean it, taking it apart as much as I can without tools. Now it gets better, but not to original performance. Then a few odd sounds and now the motor is running but the burr isn't turning.

This is a product that should just work. Hey, Bodum, how about a version with beefy enough components that it can run for five minutes straight? Or just one minute straight? I'd pay more for that. I'd say it worked the way I want for about 20% of my ownership of it.

Until the product is more robust, with more consistent performance, it isn't worth buying in my opinion.

UPDATE: I connected with Bodum, which took some persistence, but ultimately they stood behind their product and I have a new one. I took the old one apart and will upload a picture explaining what went wrong. Taking it apart told me a lot; they didn't cut corners on the inside, but did make a fairly rookie engineering mistake, with a weak point in the gear train that was pretty obvious. Still, I was impressed with what I saw inside. Fix the mistake, put a bigger winding on the motor so it doesn't overheat, charge another $20, and they have a winner!

UPDATE 2: i did upload pictures, and they were up for a while, but I notice they are gone now. Oh well. I found a flaw in the plastic geartrain.

UPDATE 3: I like Peet's coffee (mocha java) and figured out it is a big part of the problem. It is just too oily for this grinder. The throughput is slow and it builds up. When I use a medium roast (Blue Bottle) it works much better.

Piece of Trash. Motor runs fine with NO COFFEE in it. Put in beans and it jams. Took it apart and cleaned it out, lifted the upper part of the grinding head off and made sure it was clean. Same thing. Packaged up for return. This thing is a boat anchor. Probably got a bad one and others are just fine, but this one is terrible.

I had a good manual grinder, that I unfortunately broke. I bought this electric grinder to save myself a little time and effort and the reviews suggested good value for money with good grind quality as well.

This is a good coffee grinder in terms of grind quality (I use a medium coarse grind for the french press), speed, and noise. I haven't had it long enough to comment on durability, but I would expect it to last at least a couple years without issues.

However, as other reviewers have noted, the collection box is poorly designed and causes a mess, and worse, wasted grounds. The box doesn't fit flush to the machine, leaving a small gap on the top through which the grounds fly out from. A simple overhang on the box would have solved this issue, and I've taped a piece of cardboard to the box top, which seems to help. Once you do get the box in, it wedges in quite tightly, making the removal process cumbersome. You always run the risk of pulling out too hard and sending grounds all over the place.
The instruction manual is poorly done and needs an update. It needs to include the plastic piece that goes on top of the grinder; it is not mentioned on it at all. Also, you need to have the grinder completely assembled before changing the grind setting, which is also not mentioned. Spent some time thinking I might have a defective piece.
These are issues with simple fixes that should be addressed; it would make it worth the price paid at that point. Right now, I regret not having bought a good old manual grinder. It DID have a nice romance to it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Matte finish fails after about 2 years, body turns into Sticky Mess.
reviews.reviewText:
Works well but the spray on matte finish they use on plastic the body to give it texture fails after about two years. Mine has only ever been wiped down with a damp rag and sits on a counter near nothing else, so their is no real reason I can see for this other than poor finish/material choice.

Now the body is a sticky mess.

Today out of desperation, I have found if I use 200 proof denatured alcohol, I can start to remove the outer finish and get to shiny smooth plastic underneath. At this rate, the sticky finish is coming up it will take a couple of hours to clean up but to make this thing something other than nasty, it is about all I can come up with.

The wise person wound spend their money elsewhere.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked great for two years; died out of warranty, can't get it repaired
reviews.reviewText:
The Bodum Bistro worked fine for two years without a single stall, unlike my new, far more expensive Rocky Rancilio.

So why do I now have a more expensive grinder that gives me more grief? Because the Bodum motor died just after clearing the two year warranty period, and I have no option to get it fixed at my own expense. I was pleased to reach customer support without time on hold, and can't quarrel with the polite refusal to give warranty coverage after twenty-five months. A two year warranty is a two year warranty; que sera, sera.

What gripes is their unwillingness to repair it on my dime. It's an environmental issue, and a fuss-and-bother issue. This hundred dollar paperweight can't responsibly be dumped in the trash. I can't get it fixed to use as a backup, and can't donate a non-functional machine to Goodwill. (Or shouldn't) I'll have to let it sit on the shelf until the next 'recycle your old machines and electronics' event in my neighborhood. Irritating.

I own a previous version of this grinder and it has served me well for nearly 10 years. This version is terrible compared to the previous version. Since I am unable to return this item for a refund, I'm posting a 1 star review. The container that holds the grinds has a small opening that makes it difficult to dispense the grounds. The reviews indicate that this grinder is quiet, but it is quite loud actually. And the top lid for the device doesn't attach easily, making it an issue each morning to get it to snap on. Overall, terrible product, especially compared to the better products I have used and enjoyed from Bodum.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder that I received was either defective or not well designed
reviews.reviewText:
The grinder that I received was either defective or this line of grinders is poorly designed. Though not a deal breaker, the seal on the hopper lid was chewed up at both the 9 o'clock and 3 o'clock positions. A poor seal on the hopper means you can't store beans in the hopper without them getting stale and/or losing flavor

The deal breaker that made me return this was that it would only produce 1 teaspoon of ground coffee when setting the coarseness level to "espresso" and the timer to the maximum of 20 seconds. The instruction manual says that you need to wait 5 minutes in between each 20 second run cycle to let the motor cool down. So in order to grind enough coffee for a single shot of espresso took 10 minutes. I can get over a tablespoon of espresso with a tiny hand grinder in about 3 minutes.

I had very good luck with the Bodum Antigua that i bought over 15 years ago. It was truly amazing in the amount of coffee it could grind in a short period of time and the wide variety of coarseness settings. Eventually the cup that catches the grinds wouldn't stay in place any more and I had to strap it in with a large rubber band or strip of double-sided Velcro.

First, this thing is made in China. However, it seems to be very well made and appears to be durable. The grind adjustment is the hopper itself and is variable from super coarse to powder, I use a stovetop espresso maker so I like a pretty fine grind. The grounds container is borosilicate glass and does not exhibit the static (grounds sticking to the container) like plastic ones do. The grounds stick mildly but with gentle tapping on the container, you will win the battle of grounds expulsion (as long as the open end is facing down). Now, the really cool part. As can be seen in the main image, the power switch is in the lower left side, just aft of the grounds catcher. On the top of the unit, just in front of the hopper is the timer and the on/off switch. The timer can be set from one second to twenty second or anywhere in between. Set the timer, there are markings for 5, 10 and 20 seconds, turn on the power and push the on/off switch. If for any reason, you need to terminate the grinding before the machine has completed the timed grind, just push the on/off switch again. At first, I didn't think I was going to like this feature, but it is actually what makes this grinder even cooler than it looks. My only complaint about the timer is that it has no resistance (of course, resistance is futile) and it is quite easy to change the timed grind when moving the machine if you put a finger or a thumb on the timer as the machine is being moved. Just have to check it every time you use it especially if there is more than one person in the household. Some reviewers talk about noise, I suppose if you don't want to wake someone sleeping nearby, wait until you can see the whites of their eyes and then, Punch it! It is packaged well so it should arrive unscathed from its travels. If you purchase one of these, Enjoy!

Received in December 2015 and have MAYBE used it 8-10 times and the inner grinding ring became lodged inside after a 15 second grinding session and was difficult to remove, but after eventually being carefully removed, it now will not fit back inside the grooves and the entire unit is useless???? I decided to try to turn it on and try a 5 second spin to perhaps get things aligned or something, but it will not even work? The red power button lights up, however pressing the smaller top grind button does nothing and will not grind now? This is ridiculous for the amount of money it cost and such hassle involved. Just contacted Bodum, we shall see if they even do anything about it, I read the last page in their manual in fine print and it is saying something about a "guarantee certificate" needing to be completed at time of purchase and how it is required for any guarantee service......you know, duh, who doesn't sit down with the fake little diplomas that come with products and fill out and drive to the post office to buy a stamp and mail out the day you open it. That is something every responsible consumer does and shame on you if you don't. I'm sure they don't say this because they assume "normal" people with lives disregard this all together and would carelessly toss out all the erroneous junk mail which ships with products these days. Will report back on their customer service and whether or not they lost me and countless others as customers for life.

UPDATE: Bodum did offer to replace this unit about a day later after it broke, very nice company ;)

reviews.reviewTitle: Surface became gummy sticky after years
reviews.reviewText:
I bought it about 6 years ago. As a grinder, it's very good.
My biggest compliant is the rubberized body. After like 2 or 3 years, it became sticky. It's hard to clean and using water will not remove the sticky feel. I tried Lysol wipes, didn't help. I now avoid touching the body as I only need to operate the cup, the lid and the switches.

I don't know if they have changed the body material now, if not, they'd better change it.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Steel Burr is Great but the Glass Catcher is very frustrating.
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this machine for a while and it sees use maybe 2-3x a week. The grind is consistent. The stainless steel conical burrs are wonderful and they grind beans with ease. The different settings for grind consistently/level and time to grind, are great. The grinder features an on/off switch and a "press to grind" button for grinding.

Bodum advertises this: "Borosilicate glass catcher reduces static that causes jumping coffee grounds" and this couldn't be more untrue. This is my biggest gripe with this product. The glass catcher is not static proof, it's quite the opposite. Once you grind your beans into the catcher, you will notice that there is A LOT of leftover grinds, that no matter how hard you hit the bottom of the catcher, will not leave the catcher. Over time, this just builds up until you're forced to manually stick a paper towel or your hand into the glass catcher to physically remove the leftover grinds. The grinds also stick to the bottom of the glass catcher "cap."

The machine makes a lot of noise when grinding, so much so, that you have to step away from it. It's not made from expensive materials so it feels kind of cheap.

This is definitely an "entry-level" grinder, meaning if you're not going to be using it extensively, it's worth the investment. But if you're going to be using it a lot, the grinds getting stuck to the glass catcher will get annoying real quick.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not as good as I remembered
reviews.reviewText: I've purchased three of these grinders. The first one I used every day for about two years until it died. It worked well and I felt I got my moneys worth out of it. In fact I was pleased enough that I bought one as a gift for a friend that only grinds coffee occasionally. For my own use I replaced the Bodum with a more durable Capresso grinder. Recently (2016) I bought another Bodum for the purpose of grinding coffee in my office, because my coffee addiction is totally under control and I figured the light duty, good looking Bodum would fit well in my office. Unfortunately this unit seemed very flimsy, more so than I remembered from my original one, bought sometime in 2012 -2013. Frustratingly, it would not grind on any setting below the middle mark. Setting it any finer would result in the sound of plastic gears skipping and no coffee being ground. I took it apart to investigate and it seems that a mechanism designed to protect the gears was allowing this skipping. I tried a few different types of beans wondering if what I was using was somehow too hard, but the problem persisted. I kept on using it for a few months but finally got tired of drinking coffee that was ground too coarsely. The whole idea of having a setup in my office was to avoid terrible coffee in the first place and the grind I was getting from the Bodum was ruining my otherwise decent quality setup. So I gave it away on the company bulletin board and bought a Baratza Encore like I should have done in the first place.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do the right thing for your beans
reviews.reviewText:
Wow. My first cup of home-made burr-ground coffee showed me just how silly I'd been to buy good coffee beans and grind them with a blade grinder for so many years. The additional flavor I'm getting out of the same beans is amazing. If you love coffee, I am telling you to get one of these! It's a joy to start each morning with a cup of Joe made from freshly ground coffee.

After comparing many products in this price point I chose this product because of the reviews, and I just thought it looked awfully cool. I would have loved it in chrome, but couldn't see spending twice as much especially when I had just enough Amazon points to buy the black one.

The lid has a guide for how long to grind your coffee to get the right amount, but you might have to experiment. I typically use a dark roast, like Sumatra from Costco, and I like my coffee strong. Still, I had to reduce the recommended time by half.

The glass collector does a great job of keeping coffee from sticking and flying, but I decided to take a short cut. My small coffee filter holder fits in the slot, so I just grind the coffee directly into the filter. BTW, I am still using this fabulous coffee maker that I bought in 2009. It's great if you don't make a large volume of coffee and like your coffee to be brewed at the the right temp. Zojirushi EC-DAC50 Zutto 5-Cup Drip Coffeemaker

I was concerned about the reviews concerning pebbles and gear failure. I don't know if the company has made improvements, but they claim to have a safety mechanism to shut off the machine in this case to prevent damage. Even though it seems to be a common problem, I've never found a pebble in my coffee and I've been using beans for many years.

I am attaching a little video of my very first experience grinding with this lovely little machine. Hope you find my review helpful!

UPDATED 15 Nov 2017: Today it happened for the first time in my coffee grinding life. There was a pebble in the beans. My grinder came to a premature stop with an agonizing groan. It took an ice pick to get that sucker out, but I won the battle. The best part is that after I did a thorough cleaning, put the grinder back together, and plugged it in, it worked just fine. I tried a different coffee from the big box store. I am going back to my Sumatra.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hard to clean. Rubber coating gets tacky and gross with age.
reviews.reviewText:
There are inaccessible compartments in this machine that collect coffee grinds and dust that turn stale and end up in future batches of your ground coffee. It also stinks up the machine. You literally have to strike and bang around the the whole unit to get most of the remnants out which often dislodges a couple teaspoons of caked up powder and coffee grounds.

Bodum could have used textured plastic on the outside but instead opted for a premium-feeling rubberized texture that gets extremely sticky and tacky after a couple of years. It's nice when it's new. I could find no tricks with common household products to remedy this and every particle of dust in your home will stick to it like a magnet. Mine was black so it looked like hell. The whole thing felt like handling a piece of double-sided scotch tape. I cleaned the exterior with a damp microfiber cloth reserved for kitchen appliances and never with any chemicals so this is a quality issue.

I'm done with this brand. They make a good french press but that's about it. My Bodum mini electric kettle burnt up after a few dozen uses due to a faulty two-stage safety switch that failed to engage. It nuked itself. I later found out this is common. Bodum customer service never responded to my email. I ended up selling the grinder to recover a few bucks and ditched the smelly plastic kettle.

I didn't keep the unit long enough to experience the stripped gear issue. I'm so very sorry for the customers that had this problem and who wasted their money. Had I known of this earlier I would have thrown it away instead of passing the problem onto someone else.

No pride goes into these products, just fancy design and finicky moving parts. Buy something else like an entry-level Baratza. Uglier but built well with replaceable parts and from what I've heard, genius customer service. That's where I'm heading next. You should come to.

reviews.reviewTitle: It broke in less than a week. Their customer service is pitiful. Do not buy.
reviews.reviewText:
I was looking forward to using this grinder, and expected it to be an awesome addition to my kitchen as well as improving my coffee experience. It did not live up to expectations.
Firstly it is LOUD. Much louder than expected, and slower as well which means you have to hear it that much longer. But the real dealbreaker was when the bottom coffee receptacle broke.
While hand drying it with a towel. The center if the bottom of the receptacle simply crumbled like a cheap piece of candy into my hand, leaving a dime sized circular hole. I was uninjured luckily, but the glass container was useless at that point.
There is a customer service phone number included with the instruction booklet, which I called. I could not tell if it was for Bodum, because it goes to a recorded message that offers no option to speak to anyone from Bodum, and honestly sounds like a scam number. The recording does not identify that you have reached Bodum, it may have been abandoned by the company and picked up by scammers afterward. Their current customer service is evidently by email only, which I used. It took them a full week to get back to me, and the response was to suggest that I purchase a replacement at a web link.
The grinder was less than a week in my home, so basically it took less time to break than to get a response from customer service. I would not recommend this grinder to anyone, simply not worth the hassle.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice Coffee Grinder, and Good Price to Boot.
reviews.reviewText:
Only had it for 2 days, but so far so good. It's an actual "Conical Burr" Grinder, that works great and it cost as much as it should. Unlike all the other overpriced grinders out there. Now let's see how long the motor lasts, and I'll update if is less than a year.

Pros:
The Price!!! I challenge anyone to find a new "conical burr" grinder for $40.
Nice compact design, which fits nicely next to my coffee machines.
Not as noisy as other models as I've had in the past, which is a plus in the morning.
The lid on the hopper is very air-tight, even though I wouldn't store more than what I need to grind for the day in there.

Cons:
Instructions could be more useful. Seriously... You're flying blind with the level of instructions in this, so you better have an understanding of basic engineering and be familiar with how burr grinders work.
The grind reservoir is very tight fitting on mine, which makes removing it a pain in the you know what.
Finally, the grinds are very static, which makes for a bit of a messy cleanup.

reviews.reviewTitle: Seemingly easy to use and clean, but durability is an issue
reviews.reviewText:
Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder, Black
Just arrived and I've used it to make several cups of coffee. First impressions: Ridiculously easy to use and clean, grinds perfectly, looks nice, no static electricity issue, no mess. Even better I got it as an Amazon Warehouse Deal for $20 less than if I bought it "new" from Amazon.

Update: I originally gave this 5 stars, but am now downgrading my rating. After a month, the glass container fractured at the bottom. I did not drop it. Just happened from normal use. I read some other complaints about this happening and so it seemed the glass was either too thin at the base or too brittle. Unfortunately, the warranty does not cover glass breakage. Bodum, however, does sell replacements which, with tax and shipping, runs over $16. This did not seem right to me where I did nothing and the glass broke on it's own. I contacted Bodum, but they ignored my claim that there was a product defect and dismissed my request for a free replacement as not covered by the warranty. So much for valuing happy customers! I decided against buying a new container as there was no reason to believe another would not also fail.Luckily, however, one of the Amazon purchasers who had this problem had another better solution - a Tablecraft (H159) 10 oz Stainless Steel Dredge - sold here on Amazon for $5. Just remove the cover of the Dredge and substitute the cover from the Bodum container. Everything fits perfectly and there is no static electricity. The stainless steel must discharge the static electricity. It's such an easy durable fix that I wonder why all grinders aren't made like this to begin with.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's still going strong and we like it relatively well aside from a few issues noted ...
reviews.reviewText:
We purchased this coffee grinder 3 1/2 years ago. It's still going strong and we like it relatively well aside from a few issues noted below. I did a lot of research on grinders and review-reading before choosing this one, but it was our first higher-end burr grinder so in all fairness I can't compare it to others. Part of why I chose this one is because our french press is also Bodum.

Static is a significant issue in the cup after grinding, which makes removal of the cup and removal of the ground coffee a bit messy. We bought a small cosmetic (blush) brush that we use only for the purpose of brushing our grounds out of the cup. Just a drop of water on the brush makes coffee ground removal fairly clean and easy.

The only performance issue after daily use is that while using it on largest grind/french press setting (for us that is always), the bean vessel begins to vibrate and rotate clockwise which stops the grinding (it's also how you remove the vessel). That is, the motor/timer is still running, but the beans are no longer grinding and you lose track of how much you have/need. So, we have to place our hand on top of it now to hold it steady to keep it from turning past french press on the furthest end of the grind range.

My only other complaint would stand for any other grinders that I am aware of, at that is regarding the clear bean vessel; I wonder why they don't make the vessel at least a smoke brown or grey color so the beans are not subjected to quite as much light.

I have recommended this grinder before because I suppose it has done alright with daily use. If I were to buy another, I would research more and might be inclined to purchase something else.

I bought this in November 2011 & it is now on its deathbed. It did a good job grinding for pour-over coffee (my preferred brewing method). I will not be buying another Bodum to replace it but that doesn't mean I'm completely unhappy with it. It was my first burr grinder & I was not sure if I should make that kind of $ investment. Burr grinders are DEFINITELY the way to go if you are serious/picky about your coffee. And they are a necessity if you want to make a really good espresso.

The Bodum is kind of quirky in that you are only supposed to grind 20 seconds & then let it cool down for 5 minutes. That was actually kind of a pain since I usually grind a bigger batch than that - daily. It also made a mess on my counter top every morning; grinds get caught inside the machine & come out the bottom & I mean out of the bottom of the housing in ADDITION to needing a whack to get the grounds out of the chute. The "chute whack" was not a big deal to me but the grounds coming out of the housing? What a mess & there was no end to them.

When this machine started dying, I took it completely apart by unscrewing the housing, etc. The inside around the motor & everywhere was FULL of grounds. That may be part of the reason it's dying. I was always diligent about maintenance/cleaning the machine, burrs, etc. every 1-2 weeks so it's not like I did not take good care of it. You shouldn't have to take the whole machine apart to clean but if you own this machine, you really should. Mine probably would have lasted longer had I known this.

It was a very noisy machine but I've heard worse. Static could be a slight problem but really all you need to do is wait a couple minutes for the static to dissipate before you pour out your grounds; I do that with any grinder. The glass jar was a nice feature for cleaning, etc.

I think there are better, more durable burr grinders around this price range. When I bought it, it was $76 (black version) which I think is a fair price for the quality.

Long story short I purchased my wife a hand grinder and she became a coffee snob only wanting to drink fresh ground coffee beans. I looked around and couldn't find a decent grinder that didn't cost an arm and a leg so I purchased this one based on the Amazon reviews. We have been completely happy with it. You have to mess around with the settings so you get the right grind for you but once you figure it out you can just dump in the beans and push the start button.

This grinder has a couple settings, one being the coarseness of the grind and the other being the duration. Once you figure out how coarse you want the grind you can adjust the time so the correct amount of ground coffee ends up in the lower cup.

Both containers, the one for beans and the one for ground coffee are somewhat sealed by rubber grommets which helps keep any unused coffee fresh for a longer period of time.

When my black plastic Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder started to die after about 4years, the black covering having long past gone from the sticky/yucky phase to just the visually gruesome, I decided to try a Capresso Infinity through an Amazon Warehouse "Like New" deal. "Like New" apparently means something different these days and I returned the Capresso with its broken pieces to Amazon for a full refund. While I had the Capresso I did note that it had a mechanical timer that would need to be re-set every morning. The Bodum uses a separate dial to set time and a push button to engage. No mechanical timer to wear out or slow down prematurely and no fiddling with time settings in the morning.

So instead of ordering another black Bodum, which looks great when new but has a coating that soon deteriorates into grossness, I ordered the metal (cast aluminum) chrome version, which is actually silver in color. The heavier metal body does seem to run quieter than the black plastic Bodum, and about the same as the plastic Capresso Infinity that I briefly used. Reduced burr spin speed plus the plastic gearing used in the Bodum, and I assume in all burr grinders in this price range, probably also help reduce noise levels.

One of the nice things about Bodum burr grinders is the glass grounds container which looks good and is useful to catch any falling grounds when the grinder is not being operated. When grinding coffee beans, with the glass container removed, one can just hold a paper coffee filter under the chute and press the button. I do a medium grind setting into a #4 cone filter and a 16 second grind time.

So while not perfect I don't think there are a lot of choices better.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent grinder for French press coffee
reviews.reviewText:
I recommend this conical burr grinder if you like French press coffee. The coarse settings are excellent, and you will get very little sediment with the French press. Here is a hint: darker roasts tend to fragment more than lighter ones. To compensate for this, I use the coarsest setting (with the French press symbol) for French roast beans, and the fourth most coarse setting for lightly roasted beans, Medium and full city roasts will do best with settings in between. Also, follow the brewing instructions on Bodum's website: 7 grams of coffee to every 4 oz. water. Steep for 4 minutes before pressing. Stirring is unnecessary. I recommend an electric kettle that brings the water to 200 degrees F. The right grind is critical for brewing outstanding French press coffee, and this machine delivers it. There are several conical grinders on the market that do not grind coarse enough for French press (and a few are quite expensive).

I've had less success in grinding for certain drip methods with this machine, and would not recommend this mill at all for espresso brewing (it does work well for moka pot/stovetop espresso, though).

One other thing I really appreciate about the Bistro is the relative lack of static and flying grounds.

Worth the money if you like French press coffee.

This little thing is a champ. My husband consumes unnatural ammounts of coffee. We both work at a big chain coffee shop and have the option of grinding our coffee there but the course of the grind is always wrong and inconsistant, you can't choose to grind different course options per brewing method as you have to pick just one grind option per bag, you get other coffees mixing in, it was just no good. With this thing, you can have a French press in the morning and espresso at night, each optimally ground per the method chosen. The grind is always consistent. Its grinding coffee so it's not quiet but it never wakes me up in the early mornings. Its never so loud that it's unbearable while standing next to it. The machine itself if quiet. Testing it without beans proves that. It has a large hopper which can hold about a half a pound of beans. Its a real winner and my husband uses it almost always 2, sometimes 3 times a day. It takes up about the same space as two average coffee mugs next to each other. Its got a special place in our coffee toolbox for sure. I will update if anything changes.

After daily but light use, the on/off button fell out of the machine. Then a couple of days later the Burr grinder began making loud noises and it was unable to grind coffee beans! We are careful with our kitchen appliances, but the life of this grinder extended just beyond the companies return policy. We have purchased and enjoyed Bodum products in the past! Ah well, good thing we have a reliable Hario hand coffee Mill. I do not recommend this product!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great addition to your coffee crafting
reviews.reviewText:
I love this burr grinder. It's the first one I've purchased because they tend to run pretty pricey. However, I had to give this one a try since the reviews were so great, not only on Amazon, but on other coffee guru websites. This is perfect for my pour over and french press coffee mastering journey. I would recommend this for sure.

Updated 12/13/18: This grinder is still going strong and I still love it. I've read a few reviews about how purchasers don't like it because of the glass catcher or it's hard to clean. While the glass catcher has less static, I've solved any static issue by using a stainless steel dredge as my catcher. It's the perfect size for this grinder and I have zero static. As far as cleaning it, I don't find it hard at all. I've seen the rice trick, but used it only twice. The rice is still messy and you have to clean it afterward anyway. What I do is take off the hopper, use a stiff brush to clean what I can, then I use a compressed air canister to blow out any remaining grinds inside the unit. Put the hopper back on and I'm ready to go. I use this at least once a day and have had it over a year now.

I purchased this Bodum Grinder in Mar 2012 for the same price $99 as today. I use this every day for the last 5 1/2 years with no issues. I have just now noticed an electrical smell when I run the grinder more than 20 seconds. This caveat is also mentioned in the instructions. Beware of grinding too fine using the finest setting to the far right as used for French Press. There is a tendency for the vibration to turn off the grinder safety disconnect as the hopper lever is trying to disassemble itself as is required for periodic cleaning. I have noticed as well not to use oily or dark roast beans as they tend to clog the burrs and make the grounds stick to the sides of the boro-silicate glass catch bowl.I would definitely recommend this grinder especially for French Roast users. I clean my hopper and burrs every month and wash the stainless burrs in hot soapy water then dry thoroughly.

reviews.reviewTitle: I really loved this grinder - seamless grind settings
reviews.reviewText:
DO NOT BUY.

I really loved this grinder - seamless grind settings, relatively quiet, didn't spit static-y coffee grounds all over the counter, compact, nice design and colors, etc. Setting aside all of the other negative reviews, and there are many (reliability, internal component quality, etc.), my issue is with BODUM Customer Service.

The grounds carafe is glass. Eventually, it will break, and you will need a replacement. Contacting Bodum Customer Service (they don't make it easy through their website), this is their response: "Thank you for contacting BODUM. Unfortunately the glass container for the Bodum Bistro Coffee Grinder is out of stock at the moment. We are sorry we can't be of further assistance." Seriously?? Scrapping a $100+ coffee grinder for a $5-10 list price glass carafe is classic consumer waste.

Sorry, but do not buy.

Grinds coffee beans.
Things I like: grinds fast, fairly uniform flakes that play well with a french press.
It's somewhat bigger than the old Braun it replaces, but I got used to that pretty soon.

*UPDATE*
Well, after about 18 months, it died. Push the grind button and nothing happens. It's most likely an electrical fault (switch, motor?), otherwise I'd at least be treated to some horrific grinding noises. Their "limited" warranty is for 1 year. Maybe they know something about their product that they're not sharing? At the price you'd expect better quality, or at least a longer warranty.Or maybe they're just coasting on their good reviews.

Usage: Pretty much every day, for breakfast. Very occasionally a couple of additional times when guests were around. The current was on all the timer, mostly. (I do not recall any warnings to always switch it off; but it's hard to remember to do this, especially before you've actually had a chance to drink any of the coffee.) So let's say 500-600 grinds in total. The Bodum replaced a Braun that kept going for ~10 years before its (screeching) death. I had wanted to replace it; unfortunately Braun had stopped selling them, at least in this market. Is this what they mean by creative destruction?

Now what? I guess it's ground coffee from the shop, until I figure this out.

I ended up buying this one: Ariete -Delonghi Electric Coffee Grinder - Professional Heavy Duty Stainless Steel, Conical Burr - Ultra Fine Grind, Adjustable Cup Size, 15 Fine - Coarse Grind Size Settings
It's better designed, much quieter. The only thing I miss (maybe) is the continuous grind time adjustment; but then I figured out that adjustig the amount of water you use makes up for it. At the moment I have more confidence in it lasting, but we'll see.

reviews.reviewTitle: Messy, and only grinds enough for 1-2 cups at a time.
reviews.reviewText: Messier than my previous coffee grinder. The grinding creates a static electric charge and the ground coffee tends to fly around when you open the lid to dump out the ground coffee. this happens for all grinders, but it's worse for this model than for other grinders I've used. Also, you can only grind enough for 1-2 cups at a time, as the grinder overheats and gives off a burnt smell if you try to grind more. This last point is the main drawback in my opinion. I'd like to grind enough for an entire pot of coffee, and I don't have half an hour to spend doing that.

I have now had this grinder for over a year and it is still working beautifully. In the year that I have had this grinder, I have grinded the equivalent of about 25 - 30 12 oz bags of coffee. The machine fires up immediately and has no problem switching between espresso, pour over, and French press grind settings which I have provided a picture of.

A couple of underrated features of this Burr grinder are the lid and the cord. Weird right? The lid has a handy guide which tells you just how long to set the grind timer for each grind setting depending on the volume or weight of the beans placed in the machine. This has really helped me get a read on the amount of beans I need to place in the hopper for a single cup of coffee. Of course it is no subsitution for weighing the beans yourself. The cord is a great feature because you are able to wrap up all of the extra cord that you don't need and it sits nice and flat on the bottom of the machine. It really helps add to the aesthetics of the grinder.

One thing that has amazed with this machine is how durable it is. When my girlfriend took the liberty of helping me clean the machine, she ran water through the hopper and through the grinding mechanism which of course normally spells doom for an electric grinder because of the components. I thought I was out of a grinder whenever she did that because it wouldn't grind for the next couple of hours. After it had set out for a while and dried off, I was able to immediately fire it up again and it worked as if nothing happened.

My only grievance with the machine is that it is extremely hard to keep the important parts clean. My best option for cleaning out the grinding pieces themselves was to take a toothpick and pick out built up residue and then use a damp cotton swab to "wash off" what was left.

I would definitely purchase this machine again!

Obviously, if you've done your research on grinders, you're aware that the ceramic grinder is supposed to be the best. Since I'm not into spending 200 dollars on a coffee grinder I've had to be more resourceful in finding a good grinder for my espressos. I've invested in a manual grinder that was ceramic for around 15 dollars and it worked great for about 5 months until it broke. It also took about 5 or more minutes to grind for 1 shot. Well after that grinder broke I decided to invest a little more into this electric grinder. I was skeptical because it was not ceramic and it was priced cheaper than the "better" ones.
When I received the grinder I was a little taken back because of the plastic timer knob on the grinder. It kind of gives it a cheap look and feel so I was worried that the rest of the grinder followed suit. But after using it I found that it didn't really matter because I grind my coffee for the same amout of time each time so I don't do any adjusting anyway. Although I did try at 10 seconds initially then found 15 seconds suited me better. The rest of the grinder, though, is not cheap and it works great. The grinds I get out of this grinder seem to match what I got out of the manual ceramic grinder, except alot quicker. My espressos look and taste fantastic and I feel smarter for spending so much less for this than one of those 200 dollar grinders.

Bought this to replace Cuisinart grinder which I believe is a better value than the Bodum. Bodum says glass container reduces static which is not true at all. No instructions on assembling, although once you figure it out it is not hard. Odd, because it comes with a booklet with names of parts and 2 1/2 pages of instructions and then about 70 pages of that info in various llanguages. Rather than selecting how many cups of coffee you are grinding for you have to figure out how much will be ground in 5,10,15, or 20 seconds. Which means if I wanted to make 12 cups, I would have to grind for the max of 20 seconds, and WAIT 5 MINUTES to grind another 20 seconds (according to the instructions).
Yes it is quieter than the Cuisinart, but it's messier and twice the price. I regret this purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: An effective burr grinder that looks great and is affordable
reviews.reviewText:
I researched a lot when buying my first burr grinder and I am happy with this purchase.
I am a daily french press/drip coffee consumer, so manual grinders were out of the option.
This grinder doesn't take up too much space and is handsome to look at. While it is still made of plastic, it doesn't feel cheap either. It does make a bit of noise and can take longer time than blade grinders but that's normal. Static electricity definitely builds up but I just wash the coffee bowl once every 4-5 uses or so and it seems fine.
Most importantly, I get great coffee with this grinder.

Caveat: This is a "day two" review, so I'll come back and update after I've used it for a while.

First impressions: Quality materials and build. The unit is both good looking and has a nice "feel" - solid and well designed, with close tolerances between device sections, and nice textures. The exterior (I ordered the black color) has a matte finish with a smooth, slightly rubberized feel that is very nice. The glass container that catches the ground coffee (yay, glass, static control!) fits snugly in the unit, and the thick rubber collar around it makes it easy to keep a grip on it. A great combination of design and materials. 1 star.

Instructions: The manual looks impressively thick. Then you open it and realize that there are a whole bunch of languages and about three pages for each language. :) That said, the info they provide is sufficient.to understand and use the grinder. 2 stars.

Use: The device setup and use is easy. Add beans to the hopper, turn it on, set the timer, set the grind (from comments here, set to finest grind and then back off to desired setting for best results), and hit the start button. If the beans run out before the timer runs out, stop the unit by hitting the start button again. Slide the glass grind container from the unit and either remove top and spoon out perfectly consistent ground coffee, or pour into my ground coffee container. The fact that you are supposed to only do one 20s run of the grinder w/a five minute wait is a non-issue, as I can grind more than enough coffee for my needs in one 20s run. I have zero issues w/static, a common issue w/some grinders. 3 stars.

Noise: Grinding makes noise, of course, but the noise from this unit is contained and not annoying. A non-issue, which is very nice. 4 stars.

Grind results: I've only ground espresso so far, and on the second-lowest setting it creates a very fine grind better than I have found from any in-store grinder. Still need to experiment with a range of coarse to fine settings, and find my favorite espresso setting, but clearly this thing provides a very consistent grind. 5 stars.

Durability/reliability/consistency over time: Unknown (at least for my use/my unit) at this time. No rating.

At this price point I'm very impressed with this unit.

Will initial love fade over time, or can my Bodum and I find happiness that lasts into our golden years? Only time will tell.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lack of customer support and a crap product
reviews.reviewText: Worked well for around three months. Randomly stopped working one morning, thoroughly cleaned the whole machine but couldn’t figure out what the issue was. Tried multiple times to contact Bodum customer support never getting a reply (email or instagram) or being able to find a working phone number. Not worth the price, very disappointed in this product. I understand sometimes you just get a “lemon” but the lack of customer support was very off putting.

A great machine on all aspects but one: We've had this grinder since December 2011 and it has been sticky, looking awful and getting worse, starting a few months from time of purchase. We are ashamed to let guests handle it. It is covered in glued dust, crumbs, coffee grind, fingerprints... See the pictures. Bodum should have taken it off the market, recalled and refunded this item. It is so easy to make a washable and durable finish! Shame on them!

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes a HUGE mess every time - guaranteed!
reviews.reviewText: I hated this grinder so much I've already given it away. It was the messiest grinder I've ever used and actually had to bring my vacuum cleaner into the kitchen every time I'd use it. The static caused the coffee grounds to fly everywhere when opened no matter how much time passed. The cannister should have been made out of non-static glass not plastic. Don't waste your money unless you have enough money to hire a maid too. Ridiculous product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Critical grinding components made of plastic.
reviews.reviewText:
Quit working after a week!

It's a very pretty device, however not very practical. As other reviewers point out, it does create a great consistent grind, which improves coffee taste. Unfortunately Bodum made a few design flaws: while the grinding apparatus is all steel, plastic is used to lock the grinding gears together. The outer part of the mill is allowed to wobble against the spiral screw that draws in coffee beans.

This becomes a problem as the wobble, or movement, became to increase over the week. initially i didn't notice the wobble, but just as it stopped grinding i noticed there was quite a bit of play. What happens now is the grinder routinely gets jammed by a bean and the grinding apparatus is out of place due to the wobble.

I think the plastic simply wears away. This was a bit heart breaking since I put up a logical argument, to my wife, for upgrading from our regular blade coffee grinder. I was very hopeful since I love the Bodum aesthetic. For now it's back to my blade grinder, but I do want a burr coffee grinder. It dramatically changes the taste.

Anyone know of a decent solidly constructed burr coffee grinder?

reviews.reviewTitle: Needs some Patience. Add water to hopper. Why? Read on to find out!
reviews.reviewText:
It's good overall. The grind time seems a bit short. The maximum time is 20 seconds and then you are supposed to let it rest for 5 minutes. I don't think this is long enough for most people unless you use the French Press setting or make smaller servings. For example, to make a full pot for me (40 ounces of water) I use 60 grams of beans and set the grinder to one notch coarser than the drip coffee setting. It takes two 15 second grinds with this machine to get it done. I wait a minute or two between grinds but some days I'm in a rush and grind it back to back. People with 12 cup machines might need to grind even up to 3 times for one pot. That seems a bit ridiculous. I usually give the machine a good tap to make sure all the ground coffee drops into the glass collection jar.

The quality of the machine seems high with nice materials that work well together. I wish the hopper lid had a bit more of an edge to it but it is heavy enough to set on top without a full seal and it will keep your jumping beans in no problem. The glass collection jar is nice as it knocks down the static charge BUT YOU CAN ADD ONE MORE STEP TO MAKE IT VIRTUALLY DISAPPEAR. Simply drop 2 - 3 drops of water in the hopper before you start and it will keep the burrs clean and cut the static down to basically zero.

reviews.reviewTitle: Noise and Static, just like AM radio
reviews.reviewText:
I had high hopes for this based on extensive research and positive reviews. It did grind coffee very well, however it was quite a bit louder than expected. There was also quite a lot of static which caused the glass cup to be covered in coffee grounds. My counter was continually covered with grounds. Another annoyance was that I had to press the button, set to the max 20 seconds, three times to get enough ground coffee to brew a 10 cup pot.

I ended up returning it and purchased the Oxo which has performed flawlessly. It's much quieter, has much less static, and one cycle provides enough grounds for a pot.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good daily grind but quantity is low
reviews.reviewText:
We bought this to replace an aging (9 years of daily use) Capresso Infinity Burr. The Capresso grind, operation and longevity were excellent but we selected the Bodum over the Capresso this time based on its glass receptacle and the reviews of significantly less static induced grounds flying on the counter.

The Capresso was consistently making a morning counter top mess. The Bodum while not perfect, is near perfect on containing the grounds. We live in a very dry climate, this static "feature" may not be an issue in a more humid setting

The Bodum's grind is good for both espresso and drip; and all features work well.

Bodum's instructions to wait 5 minutes before grinding again after a 20 second grind seems arbitrary. Since we use the grinder with a Capresso Ultima to make single serving crema we simply get several cups ground at once rather than one grind per cup.

While the Bodum controls work well, I liked the Capresso Infinity controls better.

On both brands you turn the bean receptacle to select the grind.

Capresso...Turn one dial to the grind duration and release.
Bodum...Turn master switch on; select the grind duration with a rotating dial; press the grind start button once; when grind completes, turn master switch off.

Despite the extra controls I like the Bodum. Time will tell on the longevity...so far so good

---UPDATE--- 3 years later. It no longer can grind using any of the espresso settings to the left of medium. After the max grind cycle hardly any ground coffee is produced. A full cycle above the middle setting barely gets 2 TBL spoons, the amount for one cup in my Capresso. I've taken apart and cleaned and all looks OK but the quantity produced is terrible. On the plus side the glass container does a great job in capturing most of the grind and does not have the static problems of other grinders.

reviews.reviewTitle: Kicked the pot after five years!
reviews.reviewText:
This is a post-mortem review. I bought this in January 2012 and it just died December 2016...let's call it five years. Not bad for a product used almost daily. So I don't have much to complain about. Couple of things....the glass receptacle for collecting the grounds broke almost immediately. And the rubbery finish is hard to keep clean. In fact, it was after cleaning it recently that it kicked the coffee pot. How could wiping it down kill it? Could be coincidence, or maybe it was just on the edge and turning it off to wipe it thoroughly was enough to make something finally fail. But honestly, five years for a kitchentop appliance? I may try to repair it...because that's the kind of guy I am.

Now I have to replace it. Do I get the same thing or try something else? What do you think? The Cuisinart CBM-18N Programmable Conical Burr Mill looks appealing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Exceptionally messy - but it is durable
reviews.reviewText: I've had mine for about 4 years now - and am really wanting to replace it because I cannot get a fine enough grind (for my tastes) for espresso. Maybe I need to replace the burrs. However, my biggest complaint is that it is exceptionally messy. Coffee grinds stick to the main unit and then fall out on the counter in huge clumps whenever I remove the glass container after grinding - I have to clean the counter every time I use this grinder, which I did not have to do with my previous burr grinder. I didn't want to spend $500 for a grinder, but I'm starting to think it's worth it after my experience with this one. The hype that there is less static is purely that - just marketing hype. Be prepared for a big mess on your counter daily.

reviews.reviewTitle: Slow, noisy, inconvenient, but affordable and makes terrific coffee
reviews.reviewText: First of all, this coffee grinder does produce wonderful-tasting ground coffee. According to everything I've read, it takes a burr grinder to make really good coffee, especially espresso. It's important to use this type of grinder for espresso, as regular grinders grind unevenly and can produce some particles so small they clog up expensive espresso machines. This Bodum machine grinds evenly, but the drawback is that it takes FOREVER! You can't just dump in your coffee beans and expect it to work, because it will immediately clog up and stop. Instead, I get the thing running, usually setting it at 10-seconds, gradually adding a few beans at a time while it is running. That means it takes awhile to grind enough coffee for an electric drip machine. On the other hand, it only takes a few seconds for an espresso machine. And it is NOISY! This grinder should be cleaned--with the little brush that is supplied--after every use, but that is a quick, easy little chore. Final summary: slow, noisy, inconvenient, but makes terrific coffee. Well worth the extra time and effort. Just don't fill it with coffee beans the first time you use it (like I did), or it won't work and you will have to dump the beans out.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not for the espresso lover. Quit after 3 weeks
reviews.reviewText: I bought this to make espresso for my espresso machine. Unfortunately it pretty much stopped grinding fine espresso after 3 weeks of us. I cleaned it to a T, so I know it wasn't clogged. It was annoying in the 1st place that it ground so little. Only enough for 1 1/2 espresso shots at a time. Then you have wait 5 minutes to grind more. It worked fine for coarse settings like french press. But with 2 people who like double espressos for breakfast every morning, it was a 20 minute process. I cleaned it well with a brush, made sure nothing was jammed. And it still quit grinding anything more than a dusting on the espresso setting. Very disappointed!

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds coffee well, but the glass broke after seven months, despite light use
reviews.reviewText: First coffee grinder I've ever had. It grinds the beans well, and the coffee tastes really good. But the glass (about 8 oz.) into which the ground coffee goes seems to have been defective, as it broke after a very light tap (while I was trying to get the last bits of ground coffee out). This was after just seven months of use. And the online warranty information says that the glass is not covered. I will replace the glass and continue to use the grinder, but this is lousy warranty coverage.

A wonderful grinder! I've been using a small blade grinder for years and the first time I brewed a cup using this grinder I was amazed at the flavor difference! My husband uses a French press and can easily adjust the setting for a course grind. The only issue I've had is static, I've tried tapping the side of the glass to settle it down, but it "jumps" out of the canister. Nothing I've tried has helped the static and it is really bad, more than just an annoyance, but I just deal with it. Grinds do collect now and then where the glass jar sits in the grinder because the coffee "jumps" out of the top when I pull the jar out. Overall I recommend this grinder! The static is minor compared to the quality I get from this machine!

So for an entry to mid level Burr grinder this does what it's supposed to. I mostly got it based on the price point for my budget and that a couple local reputable roasters in my area recommended it for pour over coffee. I've had it now for a couple weeks and use it mostly on the weekends for the aforementioned pour over where I'm still trying to find the best coarseness setting. I also use it for auto-drip grinding during the work work (medium setting).
My only complaint is the catch container does not handle static very well at all and there is always clinage and grround dust escaping. I am usually grinding about 20-25 grams from a medium to coarse grind and it happens every time. Also after removing the container if you move the grinder at all some residual grounds fall through and make a little mess but that's probably normal for this design.
Overall it produces even grounds as expected and is such an improvement over a normal blade style grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Messy, but works well for price.
reviews.reviewText:
There is absolutely zero way to make this grinder not be messy. Every time I use it, it sprays perfectly ground coffee all over the counter and the static electricity between the grinder and grounds cup ensures that a little bit more will get stuck to the outside of the grinder.

If you’re in a place like an office kitchen, avoid this. If you’re home and don’t mind wiping your counters down whenever you use it and are on a reasonably tight budget, this might be suitable.

As for me, I don’t think I can return it, but I will be picking up another brand that’s been a tad more reliably to me in the past.

I never believed the grinder would make such an obvious difference. I've had this product for almost 5 years and its performance has been trouble-free. I've used paddle grinders flat burr grinders and the conical produces a positively noticeable difference! This product is well-thought-out with the different colors will fit any kitchen it even has a Bodum little glass carafe for the ground coffee. It seems to dramatically reduce the static (ground coffee explosion when pouring into your brewer). Phenomenal value that you will not be disappointed! Your coffee connoisseur will love it and fresh ground beans really are better. it even has a lighted on-off switch for those environmentally aware Java lovers!

reviews.reviewTitle: Died in just under a year
reviews.reviewText: I made the mistake of not heeding the high amount of negative reviews, and bought this grinder last year. 11 months in to the 12 month warranty, it up and dies on me. I try to contact customer support since I'm still within the warranty, describe the issue and all, and they wait three weeks to respond, and then tell me they wont accept the claim without a video of it not working. What kind of nonsense is that?

reviews.reviewTitle: Convenient, fast, and not too loud
reviews.reviewText: This is much better than the Capresso model I used for years -- this one is quieter, cleaner, and easier to use. The top is sealed, so you can store about 1/2 pound of whole beans in the cone. The glass jar is nice -- stays cleaner than plastic, and is less static-y, but there is still some static, so your counters won't be pristine. But there is less of the jumping-bean problem than other grinders. The container for the ground beans has a top on it, so you can grind some coffee the night before -- if you don't want to wake anyone the next morning -- and the ground coffee will stay pretty fresh because the top provides a pretty good seal. It takes a bit of trial and error to grind just the right about of coffee, because the amount is measured in seconds of grinding time. Strange, but it works. About 15 seconds provides the right amount of coffee for water up to level "6" in my coffee machine.

I do like the unit but there should be two things fixed.

1. There should be a highly visible indicator of what level of grind it is set to. (Very hard to read/notice and the indicator is in an awkward spot).

2. The grind bin is very slick and could be easier to grab when pulling out. Also doesn't sit back in exactly right without fiddling with it.

That being said, it's a fantastic grinder. Consistent grinds, quick and holds plenty of beans. We use it for espresso and wire mesh brews. If I did it again, I'd probably go for the one with the glass container instead of all plastic.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great value for the quality of this burr grinder
reviews.reviewText: If you're not looking to spend twice the price for the "premium" version of this grinder, this is a great alternative. I have both and highly recommend them for quality and value. This standard version is a little harder to see the grind setting dial and the plastic grounds container isn't as nice as the glass jar but it is absolutely worth the price. The plastic catchment container does hold a large volume of coffee grounds. The first one I purchased had an electrical problem and took forever to grind the beans. Since I had the similar Bodum premium grinder, I knew this was not standard. Amazon replaced the effective unit and the second one works perfectly!

This burr grinder has some great features that I haven't seen on other grinders. I love the glass container system for the ground beans. The straight down path for the grounds and tensioned seling lid on the collection container work beautifully. There is little to no ground coffee mess. I really like the seperate timer dial and a simple on-off button to grind. This especially works great if you tend to gring the same amount, time after time. The styling is the best I have seen for burr grinders too. Others tend to be very agricultural looking. And...to top it off, it was the least expensive of all the mid to high end burr grinders. Oh, I forgot to mention that the grind is very consistent and ranges from very coarse to very fine. It should cover all coffee and espresso needs. Now, let's hope it lasts a while.

reviews.reviewTitle: Defintely Buy This Grinder! Will Last For Many, Many YEARS!!
reviews.reviewText:
As you probably already know, good coffee starts with fresh beans and of course a good burr grinder. Many years ago I bought a used one and after 6 years it was still going strong, being used at least twice per day (on weekends 3-4 times), every day for 6 years until I received another burr grinder as a gift and use this as my travel and back-up grinder. Remember, it was used, albeit lightly, when I bought it.

I purchased a new one from Amazon for my fiance when she moved into her new home. Again, this workhorse does exactly what it's supposed to do, looks very nice and is robustly built. Can't say enough about this grinder and I'm considering buying another to use in my office.

reviews.reviewTitle: Burr grinder is the best type and this is an excellent product by Bodum
reviews.reviewText: Burr grinder is the best type and this is an excellent product by Bodum. It is most practical for daily use especially the cannister and the push button grind as a function of the timer setting. Push the button, grind the coffee, fill the basket, and replace the cannister. I turn off the grinder with my thumb while pushing the cannister back into place in one motion. This is a quality unit designed and construction by a practical company. I expect it will last a long time with a little care and feeding. One problem is the top lid does not completely seal in the back due to a small defect on the lip of the bin.

very efficient and fast. Makes great clean coffee, no grinds seen in my cold brew or french press. The only thing which I dont like , is the top container is quite large to put a large amount of coffee in it. However the grinder can only handle a smaller output (which does fill up the container at the bottom). If you have left over beans and wanted a larger amount, you have to wait 5 minutes in between turning it on again, or it can ruin the machine (read it in the manual). SO that part, is sort of annoying. I dont store my coffee in the top container either- I use an air tight coffee container specifically to keep it fresh.

reviews.reviewTitle: oH my !! Needs cleaning every morning !
reviews.reviewText:
Well.I was a user of Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder past 10 years. It working very well.
Purchased this younger bother. Everything working fine like big brother except,,,.
There is a gap between main body and the catching plastic container.
Eventually, after grind beans, huge spread of the coffee powder around the machine.
No statistic but huge amount of spreaded coffee powders around tha machine !
This one is NOT good for everyday use !
Yes, this one works fine but please expect heard cleaning every use !

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grind, good quality was my expectation
reviews.reviewText: Burr Grinder far exceeded my expectations in every way but it blew coffee everywhere due to what I think is a design flaw. Amazon replaced it with no problems with a different type machine. I was disappointed but Amazon made it right. Cannot give a higher recommendation unless the receiver drawer is closed off much better.

I love the look and function of this device. It has many pros. The glass container, the easy to adjust grind settings and the simple on/off. But that is where things end for me.

3/5 times the unit locks up. I have a professional grinder and this has never happened. Not in my life. This grinder just gives up at the slightest hint of a problem and makes the most horrid sound. I fix this by dynamically adjusting the grind setting while it's grinding but that's kind of annoying.

Also, this grinder is pretty messy. It keeps a lot of coffee in the chamber that all falls out later on, and even though the carafe is glass, I still have a major static problem. More so than my old grinder with a plastic chamber.

As it stands, I love the way this looks and the features, but I'm planning on getting rid of it and finding something less irritating.

reviews.reviewTitle: If you hate static, THIS is the grinder for you!
reviews.reviewText:
I can't say you'll never have any static, because that depends largely on your bean of choice, but I can tell you that no matter what bean I am grinding, the static problem is SO MUCH BETTER than with any plastic-bin grinder! Easy to disassemble, clean and reassemble, and not overly loud. MUCH quieter than the Melitta it replaced for me, and if you're still using a blade grinder, you'll think you have ear-plugs in.
I honestly can't put into words how pleased I am with this grinder. If you pass on this, you'd better be spending a ton of money, although I doubt you'd get any better of a grinder.
