Had this over six months now, just for the record, and please: DON'T review an item right after you get it! Wait until you know how it's going to perform after some real use!

i gave up my grinder of 20+ years for this one, thinking the blades would be even sharper. It turns out i get a MUCH better grind from my old one than this one. i get half-ground beans all the time, no matter how i adjust. incredibly disappointed. The grind is very bulky & make coffee weaker. Do not recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder is great value for the money
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is great value for the money. Yes, you can get better, but you'll pay a lot more. In terms of getting a consistent grind for everyday coffee, this is probably the best priced burr grinder out there. The finest setting is not really fine enough for great espresso, but you can make drip, French press, and most other preparations quite nicely.

9/16/2012

If it doesn't work for you then your needs are way beyond the intended use of the machine. I use it daily to grind my morning coffee. I like a course grind for a French press, which it does very well. For the money it is an outstanding machine.

Read the other reviews...I don't need to repeat what they have said.

Update 9/25/2012

Do not remove the bean hopper when it has beans in it. They will go everywhere.

Also, if you turn the grind adjustment just past the most course setting the grinder will not work. Just back it off a touch and it will work fine. Not a bug, it just means the bean hopper isn't attached securely enough.

Update July 23, 2013

Still running fine. I have used it twice daily. That is about 620 grinds of 20 seconds each. The price is now down to 20 cents per usage. Great product!

Update March 4, 2014

Still working fine. I still use it twice daily. I notice that the required grind time is slightly longer than it used to be and it will no longer grind as course as I would like. For anything other than a french press the grinder still has a lot of life left. So here is the math. I have ground roughly 1,150 batches of coffee. I paid 112 for the drinker. Since it still works fine for a finer grind I will donate it to the local thrift store and use it as part of my tax deductions. So the per use cost is down to 9 cents. Can't beat the price versus life combination. Not sure I will buy the same grinder again. I need a fairly course grind so this is not the best choice.

I might add that I buy green beans from Sweet Maria's [...] and roast them at home in a Fresh Roast 500. After accounting for the purchase of the roaster and grinder, the per batch cost is much lower than buying pre roasted beans and you will not believe the taste difference. Sweet Maria's buys beans directly from farmers all over the world so you are doing a great service for the local populations in far-flung locations. YOU WILL NEVER BUY STARBUCKS AGAIN after roasting your own beans.

11/18/2014

It finally died. I figure about 12 cents per pot of coffee to grind my beans. Pretty hard to beat that...

reviews.reviewTitle: Have had it a week and have NO complaints
reviews.reviewText: I enjoy a good, fresh cup of coffee and had been using a hand grinder but wanted something easier and quicker to use. I was a bit skeptical about this Bistro electric grinder because the price was a bit high for me. I am glad I went with this one as opposed to one of the cheaper ones that were more in the $40 range. This grinder works great and I am giving it 5 stars because it is fast, easy to operate and actually much quieter than I was expecting. There is a wide range of grind levels and the grind is consistent! I can't speak for quality for espresso machines because I have only used mine for drip coffee, pour overs and french press. I also can't speak for quality in the longevity aspect since I have only had my grinder for a week now.

reviews.reviewTitle: I do not recommend this grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I have used this coffee grinder for 5 years, during which it did its job and produced consistent grounds. However, we have switched to organic coffee, whose beans are a little harder to break, and when that happened, the grinder broke. Opening up its gearbox, I noticed that all the gears inside, including the one which broke, are made of plastic, which made me wonder how long this was built to last. It seems to me that the built quality, although irreproachable on the outside, cuts corners inside. It makes me feel terrible to throw away a wonderful machine, with parts working well, all because of a tiny plastic gear.

For this reason, I do not recommend this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: looks great 1st attempt not so good.
reviews.reviewText:
i loved the look and feel of this thing. unfortunately it didn't work on the first go. the button that starts and stops it was broken. I will update as soon as i receive and use my replacement.

update 1/11/14 i have had the replacement for about a week(in Green). so far so good. i use the third finest setting for my espresso machine and as far as that setting goes very consistent. will update with photos later.

update 1/18/14 i am still enjoying the grinder but a few things to take note. The coarse grind is inconsistent. if your a french press connoisseur look elsewhere. you will have some sludge in your press unless you sift through it. still love it for espresso and drip. Also i have read that the glass container reduces static, well i can say that in the dry winter here in salt lake it is still very very clingy. the backing on the grinder where the grind container sets against is very flimsy, which is a non-issue if your not moving it by it. also if your worried about aesthetics, the green the colors doesn't match. Being a man i don't care as long as it grinds my beans :). it isn't the easiest grinder to clean either. while i love the texture of the plastics everything sticks to it including oils on your hand(with light colored grinders). none of these issues have caused me to dock stars. I think the start/stop button feels a little flimsy. so i am very careful with it especially after my first go around. Also as some have commented that a fair amount of grinds get stuck in it. You can tap and shake it, most of the grinds will come out, Most. I would recommend a can of compressed air(do it outside its messy). Also read on some reviews that this machine is not adequate enough for espresso. while this is a subjective topic, i disagree the grinds seem very consistent and fine. If its not extracting well enough you can try increasing tamp pressure, decreasing run time and increase the amount of grounds slightly. I have been getting some good espresso very full and flavorful with a nice layer of crema. also do not use distilled water(two reasons taste and some machines can't read the water level due to lack of conductivity).

update 11/14/15
Still working no issues

ps. i love amazon :)

reviews.reviewTitle: Very happy with this burr grinder!
reviews.reviewText:
I love everything about it, and I especially love the glass grounds cup. One thing I didn't like about a lot of other grinders I looked at was the coarseness selection mechanism, as a lot of them were kind of flimsy or had to be oriented in a certain way when attaching the hopper. This one sort of clicks into place. I wasn't keen on the plastic top to the hopper at first, but it is good quality and keeps everything dust free. It also has a nice join so the lid is not just wiggling around up there.

The start button is timed, so you don't have to hold it down for the duration of the grind. It is not like a wind-up kitchen timer in that it doesn't tick down to zero. It is less likely to break this way and I can keep it on the setting I use each morning.

I really do like this product a lot I have a coffee maker that has the same Coppertone and so I got the bean grinder right next to it so it really complements my kitchen rather than the standard black and white coffee makers and grinders it really is easy to use not as loud as the previous one I don’t think there is such thing as a silent grinder out there but very attractive so I really like it

I have returned 2 previous Grinder from the competition for poor performance.

Quantity and consistency is same all the time do not take a lot of space well made a great Swiss product runs like a Rolex watch.
My wife complains that it is too noisy in the morning if it can be toned down that would be perfect but for now it was a great investment Love it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Does the job, despite slightly quirky controls
reviews.reviewText: After lots of research, I selected this model. I definitely wanted a burr-style grinder, and this one had decent reviews for a not-outrageous price. I've been pleased overall. The usability could be better, but once you read the directions, not too bad. It's also a tad messy, but I suspect that's just the nature of the device. It's easy to clean, and I make a point to tap it before removing the jar to remove loose grounds, and then tap the jar lid again for the same reason. Doing that seems to keep the mess to a minimum.

Joining the ranks of those who have been disappointed by the failure of the plastic gearing. Others have submitted very detailed experiences, I'll just say mine is the same. You know when you think, "I'm going to spend extra, buy something quality, it should last." Well, after just two years, the appliance became very loud and only produced half the grounds. Loud enough that I wondered if it was safe to operate. Contacted BODUM, they basically said sorry, nothing they can do. At basically $100 to purchase, that puts it at $50/year. Pretty expensive, if you ask me. My previous blade grinder lasted over 10 years, couldn't have been more that $25. I know, blade grinders and burr grinders, apples/oranges. But if you're looking for value, this might not be the one. Spouse really likes that it's quieter, so we're going to give it another try, just bought a new one (fool me once...). We'll see, fingers crossed. You can bet we're going to register this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Thank you, Bodum, for this great burr grinder!
reviews.reviewText: I read a lot of reviews before I selected this grinder, and have been very happy with it for 2 years now. Yes, the motor shuts off after 20 seconds. PUSH THE BUTTON AGAIN IF YOU NEED TO! The motor doesn't overheat if you do. And yes, there are some fine grinds that static electricity causes to stick to the counter and the machine a bit, but it's no big deal if you're careful. A little wipe-up, not a big stinking mess. My husband grinds for drip coffee and I grind for espresso, and we've both been very happy with this burr grinder. We previously had a blade grinder, and it was a noisy nightmare that had very inconsistent results in the grind quality. This grinder makes a moderate level of noise, as I'm sure most would, but it's somewhat muffled and not a high, shrieky, unbearable sound. I'm very noise sensitive, and I've not been bothered by the sound of this machine at all. We're cheapskates, and I initially balked at spending this much money on a grinder, but I got tired of having to have Starbucks grind mine for me, and having them get stale before I used them. I've not regretted the money I spent on it AT ALL. In short, this is one of the best appliance purchases we've made in 28 years of marriage! I think you'll be pleased with this product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not fine enough for Gaggia classic commercial basket
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this to use with my Gaggia classic. Several reviews indicate that the fine grind works perfectly with their Gaggia machines. However, I find it not true. The finest grind is not fine enough to use with the commercial basket. The flow is too fast (10-15 seconds) no matter how hard I tamper the coffee. I guess the grind will be OK to use with the pressurized basket but I haven't tested it yet. I also found online some information about modifying this grinder so that it gives a finer grind. It does not look like the easiest thing to do and there's risk of breaking the machine. I'm thinking about returning and purchase one that can be used with the commercial basket.

Update: I tried with the pressurized basket and the flow is still too fast. Will return.

reviews.reviewTitle: Burr grinder blades wear out too quickly
reviews.reviewText: The Bodum grinder works fine out of the box. Very early into use of the machine, the grinder blades begin to wear such that it takes longer and longer to produce a sufficient amount of coffee. Not wanting to buy a whole new coffee grinder, we ordered a blade replacement. However, the replacement blade was out of stock for months. When it finally became available and we received the replacement it seemed to wear out faster than the original. There are probably better coffee grinders on the market.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fresh ground coffee at home, a dream come true!
reviews.reviewText:
It looks great, isn't too loud, works great and makes our coffee tastes better than ever since we can now grind just the right amount before brewing. Totally awesome! Bodum is the best for French Presses and burr grinders.
Update 5/12/18: While this grinder is great I changing the rating to 4 stars because when it comes to brewing coffee for the family the timer feature doesn't go beyond 20 seconds and so you have to push the button a few times to grind all the beans. If the timer had a longer setting or an always on feature it would be a perfect grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke in less than 6 months - Spend a bit more
reviews.reviewText: I was gifted some really good whole bean roasted coffee. I needed a coffee grinder, and this one was rated well, and not too expensive. Even with the roasted coffee I was given, the grinder would get stuck on coffee beans. I was periodicly finding plastic pieces in the grinds, obviously from the coffee maker. It got even worse when I started roasting my own coffee. And now, less than 6 months later it is completely broken. The plastic part holding the burr has broken off of the metal burr and now it just spins, without grinding any coffee. Making it completely useless.

reviews.reviewTitle: Unbelievably nice wee thing that makes excellent ground coffee
reviews.reviewText:
I roast my own coffee and I love this machine - more than any single feature though, I have to say: this was my first Burr Grinder and the upgrade in flavour from a regular smashy-smashy grinder was unbelievable: so worth the $100.

But even after that: I've worked in coffee shops and restaurants and for size and convenience it's hands down the best grinder I've ever used - only slight complaint is that if you wanna switch hoppers while the hoppers are full of beans, it's a bit of a process to clear out the beans and refill -

So, we bought a second one so we could have light and dark beans.

After three years (of maybe 4-5 grinds per day) the original one packed in so we bought another *immediately*

They're that good.

reviews.reviewTitle: There Is A Problem With The Timer
reviews.reviewText: This is wonderful appliance except for one major problem: The timer is inaccurately calibrated. On the first unit I purchased, when I set the timer for ten seconds the Bodum ground coffee beans for barely four. When activated, the twenty second setting remained on for less than ten. I returned the grinder for replacement and although the timer now remains on for a bit longer than the first unit, the ten second setting only grinds coffee for six seconds. I read in another review how if you hold the bean container while grinding, the grinder will remain on longer but this seems a lot to ask of a user given the price and pedigree of the appliance. Calls and email to Bodum customer service were unavailing although one representative I spoke with did say that she had heard complaints about this previously. Even she seemed unconcerned, however. All she advised was to return the unit to Amazon which I did with not entirely satisfactory results. It seems to me that Bodum may have a design issue with the burr grinder which needs their attention.

ok, so maybe its a bit of a problem if you need a lot of coffee and you have to wait 5 minutes between 20 seconds bursts of use. but its enough for a 4-cup line on a standard coffee pot. another reviewer said the concern about overheating stems from the fact that there are plastic bits in the motor. fair enough. none of us can afford an all-metal motor. does a fine job on dark roasts without clogging up, if i need more than 20 seconds worth of coffee, i just turn it on a few times as i pass through the kitchen the night before or whatever. had a capresso burr grinder for years and stopped using it because it always gummed up on dark roasts and was really hard to clean. had to chuck it out b/c it was so impacted i couldn't even take it apart.

6 years update: really sick of cleaning up mess when you pull out collection container. anti static properties of glass container are not really that great. spills coffee down the shoot when you pull out collection container. IS AS LOUD AS A CHIPPER SHREDDER....which i failed to appreciate until i got sick of running room with my fingers in my ears and was willing to try anything else. got a capresso 565 instead which is amazingly quiet, since reviews were good--it also less static in its plastic collection container, and has longer grind time. you get what you pay for.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bought it, loved it, broke it, but wait there's more..........
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this after deciding that grinding beans was better on taste & cost considerations. It got a lot of really good reviews, especially the static issues that plague the all-plastic models.

Anyway I ordered it on May 4, and after delivery used it every day since. The final return date passed on June 19 and this morning (July 4), I started grinding beans and it started making a very bad sound.

I thought it might be a stone, but after cleaning it out, not only did the bad grinding sound remain (even with the grinding section removed), but a rattling was heard. I turned the unit upside down and out popped two small white platic pieces that may, or may not, be gear (or clutch?) teeth.

Long stort short: I called Amazon and spoke to a gentleman somewhere in India, and after a 5 minute hold, he came to the same conclusion I assumed: It would be pretty much impossible to get Bodum repair service in a timely manner (and I was ready to grin and bear it). To my utter surprise (with no prompting or complaining from me)he issued an RA ticket for the defective unit and arranged an overnight shipping of a replacement grinder.........

Amazon.com is currently my Hero Of Internet Retail!!

I hope this defect was a fluke because it's otherwise a nice unit.

Howard Emerson
Huntington Station, NY

Doesn't work for espresso. It won't grind fine enough to make an espresso. Very disappointing. I thought it was my espresso machine but after running months of tests with different coffee bean and different espresso machines, the conclusion is that this grinder doesn't grind fine enough. Now I'm stuck with it :(

reviews.reviewTitle: Price/performance Ratio Far Better than Expected
reviews.reviewText:
After over a dozen years of faithful daily service, my Solis finally died a noisy death. I couldn't find a replacement motor, so I decided to shop for a new grinder. The Bodum Bistro (red) was the less expensive of two grinders that I'd reduced my choices to, and based on the positive reviews, I decided to take a chance on it, rather than spend half again as much on the only other product in competition for my cash. I've only had it two days, but am already more than satisfied, and actually quite impressed.

I don't do espresso at home, so I cannot speak to the finer end of the grind spectrum, but I do make press coffee daily, so a consistent semi-coarse grind with minimal dust is essential to a good cup. This thing delivers. The specified grind (labeled by a little press-pot icon on the adjustment marks) is a bit coarse for my tastes, but two marks finer is just about perfect. Eight seconds is about right for a mug, and there's very little sludge left at the bottom of the cup. It's hard to imagine a better grinder without spending substantially more money.

Construction is excellent. Parts fit securely and precisely, and the overall feel is that of a quality product. The glass receptacle does an excellent job of keeping static cling minimized, and the seal formed by the rubber lid seals well against the grinder's output chute, keeping grounds where they belong, rather than on the counter, and noise down to a non-objectionable level--actually a significant improvement over my much cherished Solis, even before the overworked bearings started to squeal like an angry pig.

I'm absolutely thrilled with my purchase, so far, and if this lasts half half as long as the Solis did, I'll still consider this a great bargain amongst conical burr grinders. Hats off to Bodum for what seems to be a great product for a very reasonable price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fantastic grind at a great price
reviews.reviewText:
I have been using this grinder for 2 months now, and have run through around 6 pounds of coffee. In this time, it has surpassed my expectations.

The grinds are very precise with even grounds throughout all of the adjustable levels. I am honestly surprised at the quality and evenness of the grounds. This is on par with higher cost grinders for a fraction of the cost. Comparing this to a blade grinder or a flat burr grinder like the Mr. Coffee BVMC-BMH23 is no comparison at all. The additional cash over the cost of the Mr. Coffee is worth every penny and makes a world of difference.

The conical hopper has not bound up once stopping the beans from sliding into the grinder. I was hesitant about having a glass bin that holds the grounds, but it seems like it will not easily crack or break, and seems to cut back on the grounds sticking to the sides better than plastic bins.

I tend to grind from fresh beans, but it seems like the seal on the hopper lid and the seal to the bin would help to maintain freshness of beans if you would want to fill the hopper all the way up.

Cleaning and maintaining has been easy. Cleaning the burr internals is as simple as using a brush to wipe down what little grounds there are and making sure the burrs are in good shape.

It took a couple grinds in the beginning to get the time set right to grind the proper amount of coffee, but the timer works well and seems to maintain consistent grind times.

The solitary knock against the grinder is that the most course grind is still a bit too fine for French press. It is course enough that grounds do not get through the French press filter, but fine enough to cause a slight bit of clogging.

reviews.reviewTitle: Then be careful to not inadvertently adjust it past the finest or coarsest grind settings or the upper grinder and ...
reviews.reviewText: Had one small problem when it arrived that is not covered in the owner's manual. The bean hopper was not attached, it was wrapped in plastic, and a piece of cardboard was between it and the upper adjustable conical grinder section, which was loose. I finally figured out that the hopper had to pressed down against the upper grinder and into the housing while twisting the upper grinder section until it engaged a very small plastic channel in the housing. Then be careful to not inadvertently adjust it past the finest or coarsest grind settings or the upper grinder and bean hopper will pop out. After six-grinds it is performing well. I like the quality of the finest grind setting for making espresso. If any problems later develop an update will be posted.

loved this grinder but six months into using it once or twice a week, it stopped working. now how do I get it replaced? forget trying to work with Bodum. they keep telling me I have to send them a video of what it's doing wrong and I have no idea how to email a video. I can text it but they are telling me they cant do it. I am really disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: We are drink great coffee now that we have this grinder. I Highly Recommend To My Friends.
reviews.reviewText:
I shopped, then watched countless videos on coffee grinders and decided on the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Burr Grinder.
After using this for a month I can say I am really sold and would recommend this for anyone. Selling Points:
1. The burr speed is low which does not burn the coffee.
2. The sound level is low and does not wake the whole house.
3. I can fill the hopper for multiple grinds without worry. The top lid seals well and the bottom cup also seals to both of the housing.
4. Adjustable Timer allows me to repeatably get just the amount I want each time.
5. Grind Size Adjustment is easy.
4. The collection cup is glass so there is no static buildup holding the powder to the sides.
The down side if you can call it that is we are drinking great coffee but much more of it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Unreliable and nowhere near fine enough for espresso
reviews.reviewText: the grinder gave up on me after 2 months. i heard a higher pitch to the motor and then the beans just started moving very slowly. a 20 second grind time only yields about 3g of grinds. sure easy solution: clear out the grinds cos its choked right? wrong. i cleared it out numerous times and i could even physically see a clear path for the grinds to fall into the container. but when i tried grinding the beans again, the same problem reccured immediately. to make things even worse, even when it was working properly, the finest setting yielded a watery espresso (about 8s for 36g yield). Unacceptable espresso by any standards and i urge you to stay away if youre looking to use this for espresso. it works fine for drip coffees lie aeropress v60 chemex etc. but not for anything finer than aeropress. terribly disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: I am so disappointed in this product
reviews.reviewText: I am so disappointed in this product. It is wonderful when it works. The first time I ordered the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder when it arrived I opened the box and found coffee grounds already in the grinder. So I sent it back and ordered another one. I ordered this on my birthday in February originally. The replacement came promptly. However, it quit working in the middle of April. The metal parts are held in place by plastic parts that have failed or are manufactured poorly. Causing it not to be able to grind beans at all. It literally slides through the different grind settings while trying to grind the beans. It appears that others have had to return this product as I received someones else's return the first time. I went to return this item again and I am already passed the return date of March 23. So be mindful if you want to try this Bodum Grinder that you only have a little over 30 days that you can return this product. Ended up being quite costly as it worked about 2 months and its definitely a disjappointmenting purchase.

After a fair amount of research I decided to land on this conical burr grinder. I've owned it for about a year now and use it every single day. It does a great job of evenly grinding the beans and has held up with no problem. It has a nice little chart on the lid that let's you know how to grind the beans based on the application intended. I set it to 17 seconds, and boom, enough grains for my 10 cups of coffee in the morning. It looks pretty stylish on the counter as well. Will continue to keep using it every day!

Finally a coffee bean grinder that works as advertised. Very pleased with the performance of this burr grinder compared to a couple of other name brand products in the comparable price range. I previously had a Cuisinart grinder that just didn't get down to the finer grounds for espresso, I also had a Capresso that burned out on me in less than a year. Both suffered from static which sent fine grinds all over the place after grinding, I liked the Cuisinart a little more as it seemed more robust. The inability to produce a true fine grind with consistent sized grounds led me to this Bodum Bistro grinder.
This grinder satisfies all my grinding needs, almost. It grinds perfect beans from a fine espresso to a coarse grind for presses, quite happy as I use several methods of brewing coffee. I love coffee and use an espresso machine or a french press or a single cup filter drip depending on my mood. Hence I needed a machine that could grind these different formats well, this Bodum Bistro does it. There is a bit of static (minimal) even with the glass beaker, but it is all contained in the beaker thanks to the lid. There are no dust grounds anywhere outside of the beaker after grinding and removing it!! I should also mention that it's not as loud as the others mentioned, but it's certainly not quiet either.
Why the 4 stars then(4 1/2 is more like it actually)? It's the timer function that knocks it down a tad. It has a maximum of 20 seconds before they recommend you let it cool for 5 minutes before grinding again. This really hasn't been a problem, per se, as I usually brew single cups in the ways I stated earlier. However, the 20 second time limit is not enough to grind an amount useful for a 10 cup drip coffee maker. So you might have to prepare beans in advance if using a larger drip brewer, I've actually used the machine in 2 20 second grinds back to back without ill effects so far(I rarely have to brew a whole pot of coffee). But like I said they recommend a cooling down after 20 seconds...

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent for me as I make coffee all day long, one cup at a time.
reviews.reviewText:
I use a Keurig one-cup coffee maker that uses K-Cups, but recently decided I wanted to grind my own coffee. After reading the reviews, I got the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder. I tend to let appliances intimidate me. Sometimes I'll keep them for years before reading the instructions and getting on with using them. This was not intimidating at all. Plug it in, toss the whole beans of your choice in the top, adjust it to grind from fine to coarse, your choice, turn it on, and hit the grind button.

I have mine set on 10 seconds. That makes a little more than I need for a cup, but it makes it easier to scoop out. You just pull out the little glass container once the grinding stops, scoop out your freshly-ground coffee, and put the little glass container back in its slot. You can have the pleasure of playing around with the settings all you want. It's easy. Even though I like to put as few things on my counter tops as possible, this is one appliance I'm happy to display. I chose black because I wanted a classic look. They have a variety of colors, black, white, red, and what appears to be lime green, enough choices to please anyone. I highly recommend this burr coffee grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Plastic Gears Led to Early Death
reviews.reviewText: I have had this coffee maker for exactly one year and 2 weeks. Yesterday morning when I went to use it, it made a horrible noise and would not grind. A bit of research revealed that the plastic gears inside had crapped out. Since Bodum has the usual one-year warranty, I'm out of luck. For $90 (what I paid for it on Amazon), this is ridiculous. My previous grinder lasted close to 10 years before finally giving up the ghost, and I only grind about two cups' worth of coffee once a day. And trust me, there was no pebble in my coffee beans, which I inspect as I pour in, not to mention they came from from a major US retailer that screens out such things. As far as the grinder's performance BEFORE its untimely demise, it seemed to work fine. However, the borosilicate glass is rather a joke, since it actually seems to make static cling worse, not better. The main benefit to me of this coffee grinder is that it's quieter than most (and cuter). But having it die after just a year cancels out the slight advantage of those things. I recommend you skip it.

Love this thing! I searched far and wide...high and low for a high quality grinder at a reasonable price. I found it in this one! Works very well...not cheaply made like some others. The coarseness of the grind can be adjusted and dialed in to suit your needs. It holds a couple of days worth of beans in the hopper so it makes grinding beans a lot less tedious. The machine does cause some static that causes grounds to stick to the glass receptacle at times, which can cause a bit of the grinds to go wherever they want and cause a bit of a mess. Not nearly as bad as the ones with plastic receptacles, which spill grounds all over the place. I would certainly buy this one again.

I grind coffee twice a day, minimum, and have been using this grinder since April 2011.
The light in the on/off switch has started to flicker in it's age, but the grinder shows no signs of age otherwise.
Despite what other reviewers have said, on the coarse setting, I have no problems making a very nice FP coffee, and on finer settings some wonderful pour-over, and siphon coffees.
If my Bistro died tomorrow, I would replace it without hesitation.

*** Edit - 8/26/19 ***
RIP Little grinder. We've been through a lot, you and I. It's been 8 years, and while your body could still chug on, your hopper and grind catcher have seen better days. The fine folks at Bodum have seen fit to stock those parts, but with a shipping cost that equals a new grinder, you can rest easy, old friend. You don't owe me a thing. Countless pounds of beans, many styles of coffee. You will be missed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not what I expected in quality or service. I don't recommend it.
reviews.reviewText:
Very spiffy, attractive grinder but really disappointing. The controls do not offer a reliable range of coarse - to - fine ginding, and I have wasted a good deal of good coffee trying to figure out where to set the control to get a good cup in my chemex. Old cuisineart not at all fancy looking but easily and reliably did what was needed. I'll have to return this Bodum and keep looking.

Update on this review: After getting the grinder replaced, and the second one was just as bad as the first, I asked Bodum for a refund. The refused, saying there are no refunds if the package has been opened. I continued to push them, and they agreed to give me a refund. I returned the second grinder at my expense, and more than a month later, they have not responded. I called them with the UPS tracking number and proof that it was delivered and they say they are going to send my request to their corporate headquarters. So if your grinder works well, that's great, but if not, good luck!

reviews.reviewTitle: Easier to use than ground coffee or blade grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I just want to add a point to the discussion that surprised me and I have not read explicitly stated.

My previous experience was using a blade grinder (Krupps) and ground coffee.

The blade grinder was a pain to use. Small quantities were ground at one time and it was messy to use to transfer the coffee from the grinder to the basket of the drip coffee maker.

Ground coffee was easier to use than the blade grinder coffee but still required measuring with a coffee spoon to get the right amount. For me, this was typically eight tablespoons.

The easiest way to make the morning coffee is to use this grinder. At the start of the week or whenever, load a supply of beans in the bean reservoir. Each morning grind for about 12-15 seconds. The ground coffee drops into the removable, covered glass container. Pour the ground coffee into the basket for the coffee maker from the glass container. Once a week or so clean the coffee grinder.

I was pleasantly surprised to find that in addition to preparing better coffee, the coffee preparation process is easier for me. Of course, your experience may differ!

This replaces a coffee grinder I broke out of frustration. In the former grinder the beans often became "bridged" over the feed to the burrs, i.e., they would not fall down from the hopper into the grinder proper. It's as if gravity was suspended. With the Bodum Bistro grinder, I have experienced no such gravitational aberrations. I get a clean grind every time. I am also using less coffee. The Bodum produces uniform particles, from fine to coarse, my choice. With the former grinder, I often got a mixture of powder and a non-uniform grind. I get such good results with the Bodum that I've returned to using my French press. I like, too, that the grounds receptacle is made of glass, not plastic. The benefit here is there is no static electric charge that turns the grounds receptacle into a mini atomic collider with the resultant random particle discharge. This is a cool little machine, folks. Hawkmeister sez... Five Stars.

I bought this in March of 2016. I used it 4-5 times per week for 5 seconds over 2 years. I loved it, even bought my dad one and recommended it to friends. Now I wish I hadn’t because all of a sudden the grind button just stopped working!! No warranty past a year and now the $100 grinder I bought only lasted 2 years with minimal to average use.

I expected this to last way longer for the price and brand. I won’t be buying another bodum product ever again and I’m embarrassed to have purchased this for someone else.

reviews.reviewTitle: Much as I love coffee, I
reviews.reviewText: I live in a small one room cottage. I wanted to replace my non-working blade coffee grinder, with a burr grinder that was not too large for my small counter space. This grinder takes about the same counter space as two blade grinders, which works out well. I was concerned that the beans stored in this grinder would always emit the smell of coffee in my small place, but it does not. The lid is tight enough to keep the smell inside. Much as I love coffee, I.did not want to smell beans all the time. This burr grinder turns out consistent batches, and I find that my coffee tastes fuller than with a standard blade grinder. The fact that it holds a supply of beans, actually saves time in not having to measure out coffee beans. Not a lot of time, but it makes a difference when you are hurrying to get done for work. I am very pleased with this purchase.

Never used the static-free borosilicate glass container, because it broke washing it by hand.
Tried to buy just the glass container and everywhere we looked they were SOLD-OUT.
I would say I am not the only one that has this issue. I gave it a one star because I used the good overall as part of the reason I bought this grinder. The glass container and the plastic gears are obvious issues.

I ended up finding a cup in the house very close to the same size as the glass container and put the plastic lid on it and it works almost perfectly.

I do like the size and ease of use.

Overall I would not recommend because of the glass container and plastic gears.
Good luck finding a quality grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Glass jar bottom shattered after 5 weeks of use while spooning out grounds.
reviews.reviewText: This product grinds the coffee fine. After 5 weeks of use, the glass jar that catches the coffee grounds shattered while I was spooning coffee grounds into my filter. The jar is glass and obviously breakable. If I had dropped it or even banged on it, okay glass breaks, but SPOONING out coffee and the bottom shatters after 5 weeks of use? I paid $85 for this and would expect to get more than 5 weeks of use out of it. I have never even done more with the jar than pull it out, spoon out grounds and put it right back in its place. I ended up paying $9 for a replacement jar plus $8 shipping for a total of $17 added to the original $85 cost. Amazon has the replacement jar listed for $42.49 which is ridiculous so I ordered straight from Bodum. I'm hoping the rest of this product is more durable.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grind, much quieter, saves me coffee!
reviews.reviewText:
I upgraded to this grinder after using a Cuisinart DBM-8 burr grinder with hopper for many years. The Cuisinart was VERY loud and we would only use it when nobody in the home was asleep. (Also, it would make our dog spaz out!) We thought (through those years) that it did a good job, and we always preferred fresh ground beans over store ground. However, after using this Bodum burr grinder, we now realize how much we missed over those years! This grinder is MUCH quieter, the grind is MUCH more consistent, and it's easier to clean the grounds container.

We use the auto drip setting and the grounds are perfect for our machine with cone filter. We use good beans and find that about 5 sec per 2 cups works well. For example, 20 seconds of grounds = 8 "cups" of water in our drip machine, and results in nice, dark coffee. (Realize that 8 "cups" in our drip machine results in about 3 or 4 regular sized coffee cups of drink.) When making 10 "cups" a bit stronger, we run 20 sec then 10 sec and don't experience any problems with grinder heating or shutdown.

We find that a 12 oz bag of coffee in the old grinder would last a week, where the same amount in this Bodum grinder lasts almost twice as long, with better tasting coffee. I think the problem with the old grinder was the poor grind quality, which required more beans to produce dark, end-result coffee.

We have noticed some static in the glass container since fall/winter air dryness have arrived, but it's not a show-stopper based on the other advantages of this machine, and it's very easy to simply run it under cold water after emptying the grinds into the filter. We love it and are very happy with the purchase!

I bought my grinder in 2011 from Amazon. I used it on a semi regular basis for 1 year then it sat on the shelf for 2 years. I used it for a month, then the motor burned out. There are two switches, one to turn on the power (but not the grinder) and a button to turn on the grinder with the timer.

Ever since it was new, if I kept the grinder plugged in and the power switch turned on, the unit became warm even though the grinder was not on. They warn you not to keep the unit plugged in and the switch on. That in itself is inconvenient. One morning I left the unit plugged in and the power switch on. While I was at work, the unit turned on and started grinding by itself. When I got home it was still running but the motor was binding. The push button that turns the grinder off and on was not working. I had to unplug the unit and throw it away. I am very lucky it didn't burn my house down.

This unit has a flawed electrical design that I cannot endorse.

let me just start off by saying that I work at Starbucks so I'm around coffee all day long and I have to say that I love this coffee grinder. Before I got it I had to have my coffee ground up in the store which means first of all it's no longer fresh by ge time I would brew it and secondly it would only last about a week before going stale. This purchase helped me get rid of that problem. Perfect grind every time so far and I've had it for about a month and a half. The only think I don't like is that there is no way to remove the hopper if it's full to remove the beans and put a different coffee in. You have to either vacuum it out or grind it out which really sucks when the hopper is full. Other than that it's a great value.

We had been using an old grinder that would never grind the beans finely enough for our espresso maker.
We were using the stores grinders too and not satisfied even on the finest grind. We think it is
sleek and like the glass container which eliminates static. Less messy for sure. Some people mention the
noise level. Well it is grinding beans. I find that it is not as loud as our previous and it doesn't bother us.
I did notice that you need to wait 5 minutes between 20 second grinds to not overheat the motor. And that you can
only change the grind coarseness while it is running. So that can create some course, some fine in the same
container. I jammed the grinder once when the container that catches the coffee was not sitting back in
its' position. I noted the sound change immediately (so the sound is good to recognize problems)
and then was able to easily take it apart to clean out the jammed coffee grounds. I think my son changed
the grind without having the machine on, so it was stuck on a coarse grind at one point. Once I figured this out, I
turned it on, turn it to coarse grind and back to fine. It calibrated itself. I also like how it has a timer. That way
you can grind just what you want. You get used to your needs (10 seconds, 15, etc.).
I don't know if we had a variety of grinds happening on a regular basis if I would like this machine. Fortunately,
we use the old grinder for coarse now and save this one for espresso. Would definitely recommend this machine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Burr Grinder For the Price!
reviews.reviewText:
If you want to take your coffee-brewing experience to the next level, do yourself a favor and purchase a quality burr grinder. The level of consistency and control you have over the grind will GREATLY enhance your pot of coffee; you'll be amazed at the results you achieve versus coffee brewed using grinds from a traditional blade grinder.

I purchased the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder in November of 2011 and have used it almost daily ever since. I've had zero problems with it and find it to be extremely reliable. I brew my coffee using multiple methods and find this grinder to be perfect for all applications (drip makers, stove-top pots, AeroPress, pour-over and cold-brew).

THINGS I LIKE

1) The price was great. This is obviously a subjective statement, but after two years of daily use, I feel this grinder is a great value.
2) It's relatively easy to take apart and clean. The main container at the top comes off with a twist and from there you can remove the burrs grinders and clean them off.
3) Reliability. Like I said, I've used it almost every day for two years and have had zero problems.

THINGS I DISLIKE

1) It's pretty loud. I don't really expect a coffee grinder to be quiet, but I've heard others, and this one is definitely on the high side.
2) Timer settings need to be a little longer. I always have to hit the grind button twice to produce enough coffee grounds to brew a 10-12 cup pot of coffee.
3) It produces quite a bit of static after you grind your coffee, but in doing some research, this seems to be a problem that lots of burr grinders have.

The good:
Well made, easy to use. I especially like that the grind and timer settings are separate from the activation button so you can leave the settings as you want them and press the button to start. Same quantity and grind every time.
The bad:
Almost useless, mostly pictograph instructions. The top burr, which fell out as I was unpacking the grinder, is designed to ride loose above the bottom burr. There is NOTHING in the instructions (in 9 languages!) that suggests this, nor how to place it in the machine. Had to go to youtube to find a how-to video.

reviews.reviewTitle: No problems after 2.5 years of use, excellent value and consistency
reviews.reviewText: I bought this Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder 2.5 years ago to replace a Capresso unit that cost about 40% more, but routinely clogged and was difficult to clean. The Bodum unit did not have this issue. In fact, I never once had to clean it in the 2.5 years of several-times daily useage. It is capable of very fine grinds, which I used daily to grind coffee for my esspresso machine. Another virtue of the Bodum unit is it's small, thus takes little space. I have no complaints, particularly given the price.

If you review the questions on this product, you will see that there is a question about the Bodum Bistro Grinder quitting grinding after just a few seconds of use. The company handles this little inconvenience by referring to stones "accidentally" occurring in the grinding process. Well, all the coffee beans I buy must be composed of 50% stones because I have yet to get through a twenty-second (or even a ten-second) cycle without those pesky stones–which I have yet to identify, by the way–stalling the grinder. With tax I spent around $70 on this machine. I notice that today it is on sale for $93 and change. Save yourself money and much frustration; don't get ripped off.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bought based on feedback found here
reviews.reviewText:
I read a ton of reviews before making this purchase. The one key item that caused me to buy the Bodum Bistro was the comments about static and the glass cup for receiving ground coffee. The glass doesn't build up as much static and you're not making as mess pounding the bottom of the upturned cup trying to get the coffee out.

I was not used to the idea of using a timer to portion out my coffee. After fooling with it for a while, I have determined, at least for me, that 5 seconds = roughly 2 Tablespoons ground coffee. About what I use for a single cup. So making a pot of 4 cups takes the full twenty seconds of grinding. If you tend to consume a full 10-12 cup pot of coffee each day, this grinder may not be the right size for you. It is the perfect size for me since I tend to make 4 cup pots as that is what fits nicely in my travel cup.

Some have mentioned that they thought this grinder was noisy. It was surprisingly quiet to me for a grinder. I can run this in the quiet of morning and it doesn't seem "loud" to me at all. I'm not standing there biting my lip wishing it would hurry up and be quiet.

I only use it for drip coffee, so I haven't checked the superfine espresso grind or the course French press grind. It works for what I need it to do. I'm pleased with this grinder from Bodum, it feels sturdy and well made and at a good value for what I spent.

reviews.reviewTitle: Has lasted over five years and is still going
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this grinder five and a half years ago. It has been used 5-6 times per week for its entire lifespan, and it still works. It sounds like it's starting to fail, which is why I'm here looking for a new grinder today and noticed how long ago I purchased it. I haven't tried any competing products, so I don't know if they're somehow significantly better, but I can say I'm very happy with this and will likely purchase another. Its grinds have been very consistent, and I don't think I've ever performed any maintenance or anything on it.

At first I was concerned about the 20 second time limit that people have mentioned. It's really a moot point - for french press coffee, the entire holding container fills in 20 seconds so it's really pointless to need to run it longer than that.

The issue with static is real, however. Nothing a damp cloth can't fix. The constant cleaning, however, is why I deducted one star from this unit.

I use this at the office for french press and it is perfect. It makes enough for the largest size (12 cup) Bodum french press carafe.

I own a Gaggia MDF Burr Grinder at home and I can honestly say that this unit that costs 1/3 the price of the Gaggia actually grinders faster.

The plastic lid to the hopper is a little 'cheap' but (for now) it does create an air-tight seal. If you are a coffee snob, however, you won't be storing any beans in the hopper anyhow!

Overall, get this unit. Great burr grinder on a budget. I do not regret it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Pretty but jams if you put coffee in it
reviews.reviewText:
This is a gorgeous coffee grinder which doesn't work. If there are more than about two tablespoons of beans in the hopper, it immediately jams and has to be emptied before the motor will turn back on. Apparently I didn't do a good-enough job of reading the reviews before purchasing, because other people have mentioned this too. I contacted Bodum support, but they have yet to respond to my Zendesk ticket from several days ago and their phone number now just goes to a recording that says that they don't answer the phone any more. I'm returning my item now.

(for what it's worth, I bought the "new" all-aluminium model in the copper color; maybe the older partly-plastic models are better)

I loved this, until it broke after one month of daily 10 second grinds. The grind was perfect from the tough metal, but as others have mentioned here, it's inexplicable that plastic components are holding the metal in place. I read the bad reviews before buying and convinced myself that it would only break if you tried to grind a pound of coffee at a time... I was wrong. I see my arrogance now ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ hopefully I'm within the return window

Had this for a few weeks now. I grind at least one cappuccino worth every morning. I had always been a hand grinder purist, but for only 100$ I figured it was worth it to look at this guy. I have to say that I'm very impressed. I'm getting an insanely consistent and fine grind, and I'm not losing any oil or heating my grinds too much.

I've read a few reviews of how gears and such break down over time. So far, I see no cause for concern. I will say this tho, if so many people didn't use such oil laden beans like Starbucks, then grinders all over the world wouldn't be crapping out. It's not the beans themselves that wear on gears and burrs alike, but the oil in the coffee which coats all the parts and makes the machine work harder. Try switching to a lighter roast that actually taste like coffee. Your tastebuds and your grinder will thank you.

I normally keep my reviews very brief but I appreciate reviews written by others that include meaningful detail. I hope this one does that. I have owned several coffee grinders. Blade types are useless in my opinion and the Cuisinart burr grinder that I owned was a joke. Several years ago I purchased a Starbuck's Barista Burr grinder that did the job very well, however it spewed grinds all over creation. It died while I was grinding Starbuck's Espresso coffee beans that happened to have a rock in the beans. I bought the newest version of the same Starbuck's grinder about 3 years ago and enjoyed it except for the spewing of grinds all over the counter. I then read several reviews and watched a user's home video on Amazon for the Bodum Bistro and was impressed by what I read and saw. I bought the Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder and love it! It does a great job grinding coffee and there is no mess. It is easy to clean and I think it is attractive. The only strange feature is that it isn't supposed to be used for more than 20 seconds without allowing it to cool for 5 minutes before the next use. Weird, but hasn't been a problem for me. Happy grinding!

I had a Cuisinart before this Bodum and it was almost as expensive, but nowhere near as well designed/built or as reliable. Avoid the Cuisinart. This looks better, and has worked well for 22 months. The motor must heat due to the instructions of 1 cycle then wait 5 minutes, but I run 3 cycles in 2 minutes, 5 times a week, and it doesn't get hot. Bodum just doesn't want customers to think it is a commercial unit, which it isn't. Commercial units cost many hundreds of dollars. It is noisy on recently awakened ears to be sure. My only complaint is that the conical burr isn't removable for cleaning, and it is a real bear to clean. It has to be inverted and a toothbrush doesn't quite fit down to the base of the burr. A 4.75 is more accurately my rating, but I still give it 5 stars because at under $100, it is a solid value.

reviews.reviewTitle: The winner in my test of three conical burr grinders
reviews.reviewText:
I just wrote a blog post with a detailed review of this coffee maker as compared to three separate burr grinders (including a 7 minute video):

[...]

Below is the text of the review (if you copy & paste the URL above, you'll get pictures & can watch the video, etc.)

I'm exploring how to make great coffee.

The thing about making great coffee is that it means something different to everyone. Here's what it means to me: The coffee is dark and flavorful. It doesn't taste like it's watered down. It has a great aroma and makes me smile when I drink it. I guess this blog is really about how to maximize the `smile' factor.

I'm no coffee pro or snob. Just a guy who wants better-than-average coffee. My colleague Jeremia, who knows a heck of a lot more about coffee than I do, just informed me the other day that the lighter blends actually have more caffeine than darker blends, because the caffeine is roasted out of coffee the longer it roasts. Now there's a guy who knows his coffee. To thank him for that pearl of knowledge, I just bought him some raw Luwak coffee, straight from Indonesia. We'll see what he does with that bad boy.

Today I tested three burr coffee grinders to figure out which one was best: the Capresso 560 Infinity Conical Burr Grinder , Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder, and Mr. Coffee BVMC-BMH23 Automatic Burr Mill Grinder . Previously we had been using the Capresso 464.05 CoffeeTeam GS 10-Cup Digital Coffeemaker with Conical Burr Grinder but the coffee just wasn't coming out with enough flavor.

So here's the new plan: Test these 3 burr grinders, pick the one that grinds the best coffee, and then use a Zojirushi Premium Thermal 1.85 liter Carafe, Brushed Stainless Steel carafe along with a No. 6 filter size plastic filter cone (which fits perfectly inside that model carafe) and boil water on the stove to run through it. (My guess is that the CoffeeTeam GS didn't make "high smile factor coffee" because it didn't ge the water hot enough. Just speculation on my part though, all I can say is that it wasn't as good).

This new plan is actually going back to the old plan -- my wife and I were boiling water and running it through the filter cone + carafe before with great "smile factor" results, but the burr grinder we had been using, the Black & Decker CBM210 Stainless Steel Burr Coffee Mill/Grinder , was a pain because we had to hold the button down while it was grinding. It also made inconsistent sized grounds. So after trying the CoffeeTeam GS because I thought it'd be easier (wake up timer!) I'm back to the manual original burr grinder + boiling water + filter cone + carafe approach. This time, hopefully, with a better burr grinder.

The winner for me was the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder because of its hardened steel burr grinding mechanism, ability to easily turn it on & off, and glass holder receptacle. The Capresso 560 Infinity Conical Burr Grinder was quieter, but annoyingly, the timer can't be stopped -- you have to wait for it to time out. The Mr. Coffee BVMC-BMH23 Automatic Burr Mill Grinder was a total fail because of its inferior burr grinder design.

Please leave your own opinions and comments on my blog. Especially if you have tips on how to make higher smile factor coffee. Oh and by the way, I put agave sweetener in my coffee instead of sugar (available at Costco). Lower glycemic index = happier body.

reviews.reviewTitle: Glad I listened to Consumer Reports in 2011
reviews.reviewText: I bought this machine from Amazon in 2011 - eight plus years ago. Its been used almost every day and sometimes multiple times a day. I use different grinds for a moka pot, French press, and machine drip. Roasts range from light to full city plus- but mainly medium dark. The grinds I get from it are uniform and consistent. It is static free (as much as possible). It’s easy to use and adjust. Cons: it does retain about a gram of coffee and if shook a few grounds will spill out of chute. Today I gave it its first internal cleaning. Surprisingly it was not bad! Blew nooks out with air and used some cue tips. Consumer Reports recommendation was high in 2011 - and it still is recommended today. May not suit others but I’ve been pleased.

We are avid espresso drinkers that know Starbucks is the instant coffee version of espresso. We had a 14 year old Bodum grinder that finally stopped grinding and order this new version. Right away, we noticed our espresso was dispensing faster than usual and we weren't getting that "tiger skin" layer on the espresso shots anymore. We've tried over packing the portafilter, which helped a tiny bit. Unfortunately, this grinder doesn't meet our expectations for fine grinding for espresso purposes.

Grinds like a champ. Apparently grinds finer when compared to similar burr grinders like Cuisinart. Coarsest setting is adequate for french press, and the finest is definitely a fine enough powder for espresso. I use an Aeropress, so I basically keep it at the drip setting in the middle. I like how it has pictures at the different settings (espresso, drip, press) for quick adjustments. It's a fine looking machine, it's quieter than other models (Cuisinart), it has a glass container instead of plastic so it's better with static cling (still has it though). A little pricey, but so far so good.

reviews.reviewTitle: Unit doesn't function - No response from Bodum
reviews.reviewText: Really not happy with this grinder. I've had it for a little over a year and use it about 5 mornings a week. A couple of days ago I turned it on and nothing happened... The power switch shows that it's getting power, but it does not function when the grind button is initiated. I opened it up and saw this... Keep in mind that this is after opening it up and have a tablespoon or so of grinds fall onto the towel underneath it. I can't imagine having the coffee grounds floating around with all of the electrical components is good for the machine. I've reached out to Bodum customer support and got no response, so I guess I'll throw it out and get something from their competitors. Do yourself a favor and spend a little more on something of better quality.

This is a fantastic coffee coffee grinder--and it is beautiful to look at. I didn't want to buy another coffee grinder after using a little blade grinder many years ago--it was just so messy with grounds everywhere. Plus it was so noisy! The racket just wasn't the way to start the day. But freshly ground coffee makes a huge difference and I decided to look for a grinder that was relatively quiet, not messy and also nice to look at. I looked online periodically for weeks and found the Bodum Burr Grinder. This is the grinder you want. It comes in standard black or white but it is also available in beautiful colors. I went for the copper one but there is a fun bright green and a red one too. It looks great no matter which color and most importantly it grinds perfectly every time and its little glass canister empties cleanly with just gentle tapping.

My unit is about 6 years old Like another reviewer, I am experiencing the "plastic deterioration" problem. The housing on the outside has become sticky. Fortunately my unit is black so it does not show the dirt. I'm worried that the could be leaching something toxic It has been quite reliable. I really like the glass dispenser.

I've had this grinder for two weeks and I think it's great!! I've used a blade grinder for 25 years and this is just sooooo much better. Initially I was kind of miffed because the user manual is practically non-existant and worthless. If not for reading all of these reviews I might have been tempted to send it back. I don't drink expresso, so I can't speak to that, and I would certainly take the word of others who say this grinder is not ideal for expresso. I've watched several videos on this grinder and others by coffee experts who also agree this grinder doesn't grind fine enough for expresso, but is great for all other.

I've used it for drip, pour-over and press methods. I LOVE it! It's very quiet compared to the various blade grinders I've used. It looks great on the counter and I love that it's not messy at all. There's still a minimal amount of static cling, but I think this is the best you'll get if that kind of thing bothers you.

The price on this grinder today is a steal at $67 - I paid around $15 more which doesn't make me all that happy right now, but that's how things go.

The 20 second grinding limits per 5 minutes is not an issue at all, so don't fret over that.

This unit has a slick design (as most Bodum products do), and the conical grind really grinds well. There's no timer or amount selector so you have to mentally time it yourself. The grinds will stick to the sides, making it impossible to tell how much grinds you've gotten so far, and the second you pull the plastic grind catcher out, grinds will scatter and make a mess of the counter top.

reviews.reviewTitle: Unbeatable at this price- an upgrade from anything under $200.00
reviews.reviewText: Couldn't be happier! It's quieter, smaller, quicker, and easier to clean than my previous grinder. My Mr. Coffee burr grinder (disk) worked ok, and was only $50, but it was exceedingly load and having to clean up the spilt grounds as a result of the static build up on the plastic receptacle was enough of a hassle to motivate a change; not an issue with the glass bin here. It turns out conical burr grinding makes more of a difference than I used to care to admit. I was a bit concerned about getting this guy in white (it was the least expensive), but it remains spotless after continuous use and very little cleanup. If you're on the fence between this guy and a $40-$50 non conical burr grinder and can afford this, don't hesitate- this is well more than 3 times the machine.

We've had this grinder for a year and a half now and love it. It's well made. We've had no problems. A nice, consistent grind no matter the setting. Yes, there can be a bit of static electricity with the grounds (especially when the unit was new) but with a little care we've learned to dump the grounds into the Zojirushi with no problems.

We owned one of these for two years and it performed flawlessly. We loved the glass grounds cup, the large bean reservoir, and the consistent grind it delivered. Then I broke it. It ate a piece of metal, no idea how it got in there, and in a ham fisted attempt to repair it, I destroyed it. I actually think it could have been fixed fairly easily from the top, but I did not realize this at the time and disassembled it from the bottom, bad idea. Despite my botched repair, after contacting Bodum they sent me a new one! I actually think I was just outside the two year warranty period as well, but this company clearly takes care of their customers!

Biggest positives are that it's attractive, and it has many settings for how coarse or fine the grind. I also like the glass cup- see-through, easy to clean. Negatives: (this one not really negative, just doesn't perfectly fit my needs): This grinds much more coffee than I need for my personal use, so takes up more counter space than I'd like. I would have liked it to have a longer timer setting- to grind for a longer time if needed. The biggest problem is that the grounds make a mess when I pull out the glass cup. I have to use the grinder next to the sink and tap the grinder to let more loose grounds fall out, then brush them into the sink. Otherwise, after removing the cup, the grounds keep falling out with any tap or small movement of the grinder.

This is a great grinder. My wife and I have been using this for about 6 months. The grind quality is very good for single serve brewing or drip brewing. It grinds a predictable quantity of coffee for use to do single serving pour over coffee brewing or in an aero press or for drip coffee makers. The grinder is relatively quite. Easy to use. The glass container is relatively static free, so it is easy to pour coffee out. It does not make much mess on your counter and is easy to clean. Its modern design looks nice on our counter. I do not brew espresso, so I'm not sure how well it would do small grind for espresso maker. Footprint is relative small compared to other burr grinders. In my opinion, you would need to spend a lot more to get a better burr grinder that would also be a lot bigger.

Have had for about 2 months now - decent grinder - seems to be well made. Like that grinds container is glass and not plastic wish the beans holder was as well. Not a fan of the 5-minute delay between grinds (to protect grinder from overheating) but it has not been a big deal. The only challenge is when you would like to mix/blend different type of coffee beans, not very possible unless you pre-mix and hope you put enough in for only one grind. Once beans in you cannot take the bean holder off without beans going all over the place. If you are a one type of blend family than probably not an issue. It is a bit loud, but with a 20-sec max grind time not really issue unless you are living in a studio APT. My only worry is with an on/off button that you need to use every day - my guess is that that switch will ultimately fail long before the grinder does. Overall I like the design and size, and it seems to do the job needed.

reviews.reviewTitle: GREAT BURR GRINDER for a ROOKIE!
reviews.reviewText: I never thought I would buy a coffee bean grinder so I read numerous reviews to learn what options were available. I'm not a coffee "connoisseur," so simple and electric was important. I decided on a burr vs the blade, seemed logical it would "grind" finer and make the most of my beans. I wanted to see the beans, and the clear, airtight top fit the bill. MOST importantly, I agreed that I didn't want static cling coffee grinds to fight with first thing in the morning, and the glass borosilicate container is easy to clean out. I'm SO glad I bought the Bodum! I like the silicone texture on the exterior for a good grip. The simple design is nice on the counter and there are more levels of grind available than I'll ever use, but it's great to have the option! I agree, there can be a bit of "drift" of a few coffee grounds when you grind but I don't make a lot at one time (just a couple cups worth) so it doesn't seem too messy to me. I would definitely recommend this product!

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent grinder, well made and long lived
reviews.reviewText: I've purchased 2. One for my Son, and one for me. His is 5 years old, mine is 4. Both work flawlessly. Everything said about the anti-static glass, easy care, good grind quality and consistency is true for us. I grind for drip; takes 50 seconds to grind for 6 cups, so that's 2 and another 1/2 20 second grind cycles. no biggie. If I do them one right after another, I can smell that it's getting hot...to I just start the first grind and go do something else for a minute; come back and start the next grind. To me and my son, it's an excellent product.

Purchased this on 2/26/18 and stopped working 1/2/2019. I used it once maybe every other day at the most. I'd highly recommend purchasing a different electric grinder. Amazon will not help with the refund or replacement either, they have been redirecting me to Bodum's Customer Support number.

LISTEN TO THE OTHER REVIEWS! This unit is junk, and Bodum does NOT stand behind their fraudulent "1 year warranty" This thing sends coffee grounds flying around on my countertop no matter how carefully I operate it. Further, after less than 2 months of use, it wont even stay in the on-position for more than 3 seconds without me having to hold the bean container in place. Do not recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very good grinder but coarse setting could be better
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using this for several months. Overall it has worked very well for me except when using the coarsest setting for a french press (more on this later). I don't do expresso so I can't really comment on that. But for a regular auto-drip it produces an excellent and *consistent* grind. In the past my biggest issue with low end burr grinders is the inconsistent grind (for all settings). On the Bodum, it really is consistent.

Unfortunately I found the grind on the coarsest setting isn't as coarse as it should be (that is, compared to grinding with a store's machine or having Starbucks do it). See the uploaded pics from another reviewer (where he has a dime in the pic as a reference point), that's exactly how it is with mine. This results in a bit more sediment sludge in the last cups when using my french press. Nothing ridiculous, but I tend discard the last cup from the press. The Bodum produces far less dust/sludge than my previous low end grinders, so at least it's a big improvement over that. But I do wish the coarse grind was a bit larger.

Cleaning is pretty easy. If you don't have one of those cleaning brushes, get one! Occasionally I take it out to the backyard and blast the inside & nooks/cranies with canned air.

One last comment I wanted to make on the 20 second timer issue many people have complained about (i.e. having to let it cool down for 5 minutes). Oddly enough, a gent from Bodum USA customer service told me not to worry about that. He said not to worry about burning out the motor and it's perfectly fine to immediately restart the grinding for the last amount of beans still in the hopper. In my case, I only need about 5 additional seconds, so that's what I've been doing. It hasn't caused any problems for me (knock on wood). It's up to you if you wish to do the same. You may want to call customer service yourself and get their input.

This grinder is easy to use but it constantly jams up...as in like 3 times every morning lately. Absolutely cannot grind light roast coffee without jamming up. Annoying to “unjam” each time and creates a huge mess bc you have to turn the whole thing upside down, dig out the jammed coffe bean, and then reassemble. I’m not sure if the motor is just running down on us over time, but pretty sure it just doesn’t like certain types of beans. Spend a little more and get something you don’t want to throw out the window every morning.

Small, Compact, and consistent. I've used this for about 15 months every morning to make myself a double cup of coffee. I liked how little space it takes up. Turn it on, punch the button, and voila, constantly grinds with little mess. The rubber seal on the container works well to resist errant coffee grinds (although not perfectly).
Another plus is when you find a pebble in the beans (rare but it has happened to me). Did not wreck the motor and was not too difficult to disassemble and remove, although there were no instructions on how to do it, it seemed obvious to me.
However, can't give it more stars since after 15 months, when I went to push the start button nothing happened. I could not really figure out how to disassemble the thing to find out what was wrong, so it has to be consigned to the junk pile.
Too bad - otherwise, a good conical grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Glass grind receiver cup makes a difference
reviews.reviewText:
Best grinder I have ever owned. Stylish, convenient, consistent.

I have used blade grinders and the Mr. Coffee reservoir grinder for years.

My Mr. Coffee grinder served me well for more than 15 years, but due to the plastic used in the grind receiver cup, static charges tended to spew the coffee all over the counter when pored out. I got used to cleaning up the counter up to a foot or more away from the coffee pot with every use.

The glass receiver in the Bodum limits this issue almost completely. After cleaning the counter 300 or more times a year for 15 years, elimination of this chore alone merits the higher cost of the Bodum.

The grind from blade machines has haphazard consistency. The Bodum grind is as consistent throughout as I have ever seen with a home machine.

The timer is a nice convenience. Once calibrated to the amount you need, one push of the red button and the fresh ground is ready.

Does just what I want done conveniently, without making more work for me.

I use this daily. Best grinder ever. Cool looking. Holds exactly half a pound of beans, about 8.8 ounces. Grinds to perfection. Set it for the amount you need, press the button, adjust so you always have just enough fresh grounds for your espresso shot. The bin seals tight as well keeping the beans out of the circulating air.

This is a great grinder and relatively inexpensive for a burr grinder. The grind is extremely consistent and produces great coffee. The design is appealing and it has a nice tactile feel. One thing I really appreciate is the ground coffee receptacle. It is borosilicate glass with a rubber lid. The lid fits easily but firmly. The lids of other grinders I've had were made of plexiglass and were difficult to seat properly. I chipped several lids by dropping them and then having a nonfunctional grinder because I couldn't replace a small part.

It did not meet my expectations. The timer is not accurate or consistent. It is advertised that the borosilicate glass catcher reduces static that causes jumping coffee grounds. Turns out exactly the opposite. There is static cling to the container and I never knew that coffee 'jumps' until I tried to pour the contents into the filter. I had coffee all over my counter.

Very poor grinder. :(

reviews.reviewTitle: Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I read a whole bunch of previous reviews on this unit and they helped me a lot in the purchase. It's a good little grinder for its size, very consistent grind size and other than not being able to run it nonstop due to having to let it cool after 20 seconds of grinding, it's OK. Previously I had the "handheld" plastic topped grinders and this one is much more convenient. They tend to be kind of messy sometimes and this one isn't. Tap the coffee out of the container and you're all set.
Mostly I grind for my espresso machine and the super fine setting works quite well. I played with other grind settings just for fun and they worked just as well.
I recommend this for someone like me that can't afford the real expensive grinders, but want something that works well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great but is a complete mess
reviews.reviewText: I bought this grinder on the recommendation of a friend. The grinder does exactly what it’s supposed to do. However, all the coffee it grinds doesn’t make it into the glass container. After grinding, you pull the glass container out of the housing and coffee is everywhere. Also, if you tap the top of the grinder more coffee grinds will pour down the chute because they were stuck. Bottom line is that there are grounds all over the counter and floor every time you use it because it doesn’t contain them well in the glass jar. Good luck with the mess.

I bought this grinder July 2, 2016 even though it was a little pricey I thought it would last a long time. Well two years later it no longer works, I am wondering if the seller/manufacture will stand by it’s produce and give me a new one or at least a discount? Before it died I thought it was an excellent grinder.

We had an earlier version of this same grinder that worked faithfully every day for 7 years. We bought this model to replace it, but couldn’t get it to work. The beans just bounced around and didn’t feed into the grinder. It’s not user error, as internally it is identical to our old one. I guess I should have gathered this from the reviews, but they clearly don’t make these like they used to...

reviews.reviewTitle: ... received one of these for my wedding and absolutely love it! The best coffee grinder out there
reviews.reviewText: I received one of these for my wedding and absolutely love it! The best coffee grinder out there. However, I purchased one for my sister as a present and it just stopped working after 2 days. The lights are on but when you push the button to grind the coffee nothing happens.
