There seems to be only a one month return policy so if you are buying this as a gift, make sure you get it right before you give it as a gift so you can confirm that it actually works. I am super bummed because this is such an awesome product but it clearly isn't reliable.

My grinder stopped working after 18 months. I had always used it in compliance with the instructions. There are two issues, one is electrical. Towards the end of its short 18mo life, there was an electrical burning smell after about 15 seconds of grinding. Eventually the machine failed to turn on. Also, the coarseness setting changed so that it was no longer possible to produce course ground coffee for my french press. It would only grind at medium and fine settings.

reviews.reviewerName: I tell it like it is
reviews.reviewText:
After we started using a Cuisinart piece of junk from the big box stores to go with our Bunn STX brewer, a family member made the jump to grinding and brewing. Aggressively steering them clear from the Cuisnart mess maker, I did some research and narrowed it down between this and the Kitchen Aid professional series.

They absolutely love it. Nice even grind, but the best part is no mess. The key to the operation is the glass grounds bin. No static = no mess. The only thing that is slightly concerning is you can not run a cycle within five minutes or you risk damaging the motor. While this is not meant for commercial applications, it just something to consider. That's all I am saying. They have been using it for about six months without one glitch.

When it is time for us to take the plunge and get a better grinder, this will definately be a contender.

Wow, don't waste your money. Used several times a week for 2 months and the burrs jammed making this funny noise. My adult son messed with it and got it working again, only to have it jam up and stop working yet again. Plastic gears.do not last. A waste of $120.00 . Going back to the $35.00 grinder I had for 10 years What a disappointment!

reviews.reviewTitle: Could not grind fine coffee and customer service was much less than desirable.
reviews.reviewText:
The grinder would shut off if you adjusted the grind less than 50% of the scale. The finest grind setting that would work was just right for french press, but i bought it for espresso.

tried to contact customer service and Bodum's website has no contact phone number. I submitted an email through there website asking for someone to call after describing the problem and they would not help with out a video of the problem.

I chose to return the product after weeks of not having a grinder for my coffee because of poor quality and customer service.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder is finicky, make sure to watch it closely and turn it off before it backs up.
reviews.reviewText: The bin that holds the grounds isn't sealed so grindings will puff out at times. You also have to watch this and turn it off before the grounds pile to the grinder at the top (before the bin completely fills) or the grinder will stop working. I had to (after turning it off) poke a chopstick up to clean it out and get it working again. I'm not aware of a way to clean the grinder. I use this to grind wheat berries into flour.

reviews.reviewTitle: a reasonable grinder, but the timer is limiting
reviews.reviewText:
I've being using this for almost 3 years now, generally about twice a week making a pot of coffee on Saturday and Sunday.

The grind quality is okay, but 20 seconds (maximum timer setting) is not enough to grind for my 5-cup coffee maker, even on a reasonably coarse setting. The manual recommends leaving the grinder idle for 5 minutes after grinding for 20 seconds to avoid overheating the motor. After 3 years it takes longer than it did originally, so now it takes 3 "runs" to grind the coffee, resulting in 10 minutes to grind the coffee for one pot. I've tried cleaning it thoroughly but it didn't help.

Compared to some other burr grinders there is not much sound insulation. I guess when you look at the size the casing is basically just big enough to house the burrs and and motor, so it's not necessarily surprising that it's not as quiet as it could be.

While the glass container may be anti-static, the rubber/plastic cap isn't so there's still some "fly away" grounds that you have to tap off carefully.

I have had this grinder for about 2 years. It has worked wonderfully up until a week ago when it started making a horrible noise. It seemed there was a bean stuck in the gear so I tried to remove it. Once removed it seemed to work, but this continues to happen every time I load the grinder with beans and start again. I am very disappointed as the grinder has worked really well up until now. It has many settings for the different grinds for any type of coffee maker, but unfortunately this grinder is no longer usable and has to be thrown away. Seems it should last longer than 2 years, or at least have some kind of replacement option. When I called Bodum's customer service line to ask about options, an automated response said they were overloaded with calls and the call was disconnected. Very disappointing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very durable and powerful. Built for the long haul....
reviews.reviewText: We have had a number of burr grinders and all of them prematurely failed, either electrically or mechanically. This is now our second and and the first one was a gift from a friend and it lasted about 7 heavily-used years. The old one stopped working because grounds had jammed the discharge chute. This was our fault for not emptying the container when it became full. Had I known the problem, we would not have needed to purchase the new one. We use it to make a large amount of drip grind and then we store the grinder until we need more. It's good enough to keep me from looking for better!

I used this for a long time for espresso grind and drip grind, and was fairly happy with it. Now that I have switched to French Press (actually cold brew using Bodum's own model), I have to say that I am quite disappointed with the very inconsistent grind I get when set on the coarsest setting. I have taken to running the results through a screen to filter out the fine particles and I really end up with about 2/3 coarse and 1/3 fine. The fine I save in the freezer for when I want to use my drip machine again, and the coarse goes in the French Press (and works well). This added step is annoying so I am going to try to find a grinder that produces a much more consistent coarse grind.

So if all you want is a machine which will do adequate espresso grind and good drip grind, this will work. But I do not recommend it for coarse grind.

Purchased because of the laudatory reviews on Amazon. Item arrived on time, well-packed. But immediately out of the box it was defective! When the unit was turned on, the motor whirred but did not grind any beans and no grinders were moving. Unplugged and reset it multiple times, same result. The unit was well constructed of sturdy materials and the burrs were metal (as opposed to other brands with plastic burrs). Esthetically it was pleasing but it did not work, so repacked and reshipped it to Amazon. I purchased another Cuisinart grinder instead.
My review is for that particular unit and is no reflection on the brand, which I am led to believe is good.
The grinder worked just fine for one year, and then the motor stopped running. This is not the run I would have expected from a hundred dollar coffee grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: I bought this grinder in Feb. 2015 and it is wonderful
reviews.reviewText: I had tried blade grinders and even a couple of less expensive burr grinders, but the static they produced drove me crazy. I finally bought the Bodum, which was a little more expensive. I wish I had bought it years before. It has worked flawlessly. It is easy to change the grind, but I usually grind about half way between medium and espresso. It seems to give a very consistent grind on whatever setting I use. I cleaned it once just because I thought maybe I should. I produces virtually no static, which makes my coffee station on the counter easy to keep clean. Love it.

reviews.reviewTitle: No skimping on the important bits
reviews.reviewText:
Pros:
It works, and works well
Doesn't get too hot during grinding because it only needs like 20 seconds to grind
It's stylish

Cons:
None come to mind, maybe how some beans can end up not-ground and you have to (or at least should) manually clean them from the trap if you have a lot of time between grindings
Could use volume markings on the fill cone

This grinder is great. It wasn't horribly expensive, and has a good assortment of grinding options. Course and fine on this machine are totally different beasts. If you're thinking that 5 minutes of turning a hand-crank grinder won't get old every day; you'd be surprised. With this machine, your beans are done in 20 seconds (or more like 2 sets of 15 if you like 8 cups of coffee). It's stylishly designed, and the only real flaw is not having volumetric markings on the fill cone. I'm chucking my old hand grinder, this thing is perfect for me (not uber-connoisseur, but know enough about coffee stuff to not buy the cheapest, or anything outrageously expensive, as the taste won't vary a great deal once you buy fresh beans and grind them yourself before brewing). Would recommend to any of my coffee-lover friends!

reviews.reviewTitle: My life is so much better with this coffee grinder
reviews.reviewText: The reviews on this item are NOT wrong. I admit that I had a molina blade grinder for years and was reluctant to be "extravagant". However, when my molina would not grind evenly or consistently, not to mention having to stand there and hold it down, I finally gave in. So I read lots of reviews and purchased this grinder, and I cannot even begin to tell you how wonderful it is. It was worth every cent and more. It evenly grinds (I use rather oily beans)perfectly every time. But what I love the most is its settings, so that you can not only get the consistency you want, but the exact amount you need using the timer and their grind settings. Not only do I not need to stand there and hold the grind button down and "guess", but it saves me money as well as time. I highly recommend it!

I bought this grinder because of the positive reviews and because it was a burr grinder. We drink a lot of coffee in my family, mostly my husband who is a truck driver. I usually grind the coffee he takes with him on the road, because he is now spoiled and cannot drink anything but french roast Starbucks. I ruined him, he drank Folgers when I met him. I had replaced my Cuisinart burr grinder with this grinder, and am so disappointed. My Cuisinart burr grinder was great, could grind coarse enough for french press, and fine enough for espresso. This grinder cannot do that. The french press setting is TOO coarse, the drip setting is too coarse and the espresso setting is not even close to being fine enough for my machine. The coffee comes out pale and weak, and not good at all. I am irritated because this grinder is not exactly cheap, and really not the high quality I was expecting. I have tried contacting the company and have gotten no response. I think for the price, and the lack of customer service, and this grinders poor settings make it a waste of money. Now I am back in the same boat of trying to find an affordable burr grinder that works really well. Two thumbs down!

I have never written a product review like this. However, this is by far the worst product I have ever purchased on Amazon. It doesn't automatically stop, it clogs, its messy. Don't buy this. I am throwing it out and starting over- a complete waste of money

inverter! Works perfectly in our energy limited environment (on a boat operating this off of a 2KW inverter from a 610 aH 12VDC battery bank). Not too noisy and produces a consistent great grind.

The little glass cup that catches the grind broke after a few months at sea. But a substitute container is doing just fine.

Cleaning occasionally by running rice through the unit seems to help keep it running well.

A year of use and it is still running well.

reviews.reviewTitle: you'll be happy that you did
reviews.reviewText:
From others, I'd heard that the espresso grinder is as important, if not more so, than the espresso maker. Turns out that that's true.

Tried a Capresso branded grinder, but it worked poorly. This one works very well. Fast, relatively quiet, and makes a grind that works very well with my Capresso branded espresso maker. The glass beaker the ground coffee drops into makes world of difference as regards static issues with finely ground coffee. No more 'blast pattern' of coffee around the grinder. (I'm looking at you, Capresso)

Buy this one, you'll be happy that you did.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... returned it immediately because the static problem was intolerably bad. The grounds flew everywhere
reviews.reviewText: I tried my first burr grinder years ago and returned it immediately because the static problem was intolerably bad. The grounds flew everywhere. I went back to a blade grinder and was happy with the coffee I made that way. However, after reading repeatedly that an even grind makes better coffee, I decided to try again and ordered the Bodum Bistro. I just tried it for the first time. I put in the amount of beans that I normally use for my 48-ounce morning pot (drip). On the maximum time setting, 20 seconds, the grinder only got through about two thirds of the beans before shutting off. Since I didn't want to wait 5 minutes to grind the rest, I tried making my coffee with the amount it ground in 20 seconds. It isn't as strong as I like it. The grind is even and I didn't have a static problem, but the short duty cycle makes this grinder a poor choice for people who like to brew more than a couple of cups at a time, unless you like your coffee weak or don't mind waiting 5 minutes to grind two batches.

reviews.reviewTitle: A little loud, but excusable for the efficiency and ease of use.
reviews.reviewText: This is good mid level Burr Mill grinder. The settings are pretty intuitive and easy to fine tune. I purchased when I decided to go the cold Brew route at home. The unit is pretty loud, but the grind time is very short for what I need (3 or 4 10 second bursts.) I can have my coffee ground and in my cold Brewer in a couple minutes making great coffee. Worth the money if you're serious about your coffee up to a point.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder. Husband says I am a coffee snob
reviews.reviewText: Didn’t know what I was missing. Great grinder. Husband says I am a coffee snob. He is right. This grinder further protects my beans. I thought this would be quieter than my old blade grinder. It is not. If you are trying not to wake up the house with your early cup of brew, this grinder is not for you.

This is a revision of my previous review. After having used the grinder for over a month now, I regret it's purchase. It makes a terrible mess when removing the container that captures the coffee grinds. Grinds get get caught on the exterior of the plastic top of the container and fall on the counter surface. They even mess up the counter when transferring the grinds into my Technivorm coffee maker. The static charge cause the grinds internal and external surface adherence to get everywhere while handling and transferring. My advice....forget this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Flexibility to go from espresso to French Press with a simple twist.
reviews.reviewText: This was a replacement of a similar model also from Bodum so I was already a fan. After I ordered it, I found an article that showed me how to disassemble and clean my old one and I found out I didn’t even need to order the new one, but I decided to keep it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good value works well for espresso
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this to upgrade from a blade grinder, which was useless for espresso.

Positives

- Nicely designed, glass container is great.
- Works well for espresso. At setting "2" it produces a very even grind with almost no dust.
- The 20 sec limit commented on by others is no issue for me - it takes about 8 sec to grind enough for a single shot at espresso setting.

Negatives

- Finest grind settings are too fine even for espresso (clogs my filter)
- Coarsest grind is a bit too fine for french press, and contains quite a bit of dust. One star knocked off for that.
- Bean holder is a waste of time, unless you want stale coffee sitting in the grinder.

Overall for a conical burr grinder, for espresso, it's a solid purchase. Would buy again.

One of the best features of this grinder is the round glass beaker because it is easy to empty and clean. But the beaker is very fragile and, though a replacement is $8.95 on their website, they have been out of stock for months. After originally being told they would be available now, they say it will be three more weeks. This part should always be in stock!

reviews.reviewTitle: Super disappointing when you want to enjoy your weekend coffee ...
reviews.reviewText: I've been using this grinder for more than a year. Beans started to get stuck, and we cleaned it up patiently a couple of times, but now beans get stuck every time we use it. Super disappointing when you want to enjoy your weekend coffee once in a while.

We use this every day, and were frankly quite surprised at the improved quality of coffee. It is on the expensive side and my wife notices a bit of clean up sometimes but after reading reviews of many of these products, this seemed the best. We are satisfied as true coffee 'hounds', it is quite a step up in coffee quality

Addition comment after 4 months of use. We found that the french roast that we typically grind finally clogged up the works after all these months however we did not know what the problem was initially. Took it apart and cleaned it especially the tube where the ground coffee flows to the cup. It was completely clogged. Had to really pick at it and use a vacuum. Finished up by running some rice through the grinder which also helped to flush these out. Now seems to work fine.

reviews.reviewTitle: HEED THE WARNINGS! DO NOT BUY THIS THING.
reviews.reviewText: Heed the warnings in the bad reviews. I went against my better judgement and the advice of those who went before me. The static burr grinder ringer is held in place with a plastic retainer. This piece will give way and jam the beans in the grinder. I dealt with it because it didn’t start until 3-4 months of use and was an occasional annoyance. In 1 years time the unit has been renedered inoperable as it now jams during every grind. Looks good so it’s hard to want to through it out, but it is only a nice wrapper.

reviews.reviewTitle: Everything I need, without spending a fortune!
reviews.reviewText:
I've been drinking coffee for years now and know a good cup from bad. I bought this unit after doing lots of research online and going to local stores and inspecting the grinders up close. I found that most machines in this price range are using ABS plastic where the burrs are located. This to me is a big NO NO and a huge red flag. The ABS will break. This unit uses nylon or UHMW plastic at first glance. These plastics are more ductile and will last. Being a machinist, i am very picky with build quality. The burr set is conical and looks to be Stainless Steel or somesort of hardened steel. Nonetheless, both good options and the burrs look very nicely built. They have been machined and ground and look a lot like burr sets you'd see in units that are 2-3 times the price. The outside of the machine is wrapped in rubber and looks nice. The top hopper is a clear plastic, but seems strong, especially where it matters (the point where it meets the machine). The container receiving the grind is GLASS wrapped in rubber. This is great!! No static, which means, NO MESS! My first attempt at a burr grinder was poor. I just bought something from the local superstore without any research. It had flat burrs and rotated at the speed of sound, or so it seemed. Everything was plastic and grinds flew everywhere. Hated that thing!

I'd say the only thing that may bother some, is that the timer goes 20 secs. Now for me this is more than enough, but for others its not nearly the time they would need. Bodum recommends after 1 20sec run to leave the machine idle for 5 mins to prevent the motor from overheating(i read the manual). I thought this would be an issue for me, but my daily use only requires a 10 sec run at a time which delivers about 1/2 the jar or enough grind to yield about 3-5 cups(my small french press is 3cup capacity, which is really 1 mug). I am not grinding for espresso and have not tried the finest setting yet, but intend to and wish i had to make this review more complete, but my results so far are very consistent and from what i can see im sure itll do a fine enough grind for espresso and if not, im sure it can be modded easily enough to provide. I plan to start into the world of home espresso extractions, but not at this time as im still experimenting with other methods.

Also if you were to use for espresso, it looks to me that you could easily remove the bottom jar, pop the portafilter in place(obviously holding it) and run the machine. The grind should fall nicely into the portafilter.

UPDATE (JAN 10/2011): I'm still using my grinder after 2-3 months and I still love it! I've started grinding for espresso with great results. Glad to see that most everyone is as content as I am with this little guy! Clean up is a breeze, and its never once clogged up on me personally, although i read one review where someone said theirs did. Happy Grinding!

UPDATE (April 2012): Grinder is still working great. I have some concerns. The glass jar has a very thin bottom and if your using anything other than a softer utensil, will break. I found a small hole in mine after a lot of use with a spoon. I've since been using a wooden spoon. My fix for this hole was tape.

My espresso 'machine' up to this point has been a Presso. The bodum at its finest setting works great with the Presso. Any finer and you'd never be able to pull a shot without breaking the Presso (which i've done). I've since bought a machine and with the pressurized basket the grind is consistent enough and fine enough to yield good results. Since I enjoy tweaking equipment to some degree, my next step is a single walled basket and bottomless portafilter. The bodum will in my opinion not grind fine enough for this set up. I have a hario mini for now, but looking to buy a more expensive grinder for espresso. The bodum will be for drip and french press which I believe it does a great job at. One thing about the bodum as compared to more expensive units is the bodum is quite light in comparison. I feel if the bodum was a heavier machine with more use of metals rather than plastics, it could probably be set up to grind finer and be a wonderful machine overall. But at this price point this is what you get, and for the money, it does a nice job.

One other thing, I roast my own beans and when I first started roasting the bean consistency was not perfect due to the method. This resulted in the bodum actually skipping during operation. I stopped it quickly enough as to not destroy it, but was a little alarmed. Now that I've changed my methods for roasting, the beans are always consistent and the bodum grinds them no problem.

UPDATE Dec 2012: I still use the bodum daily. It is a superb grinder for the money and I am glad it has served me so well. I tested the bodum against the Hario Mini and my friends Baratza Virtuoso grinder and found that even though the Hario and Baratza will grind finer, the bodum produces the most consistent grind, hands down! Considering the Baratza is triple the price I'd say I was quite surprised. You can get finer grind from the bodum, but I don't take any responsibility for anyone modifying their machine. I took the top burr out, and found that there are two tabs (plastic section that houses the burr) that sit on the threaded section of the bottom burr which allow for the grind settings. You will notice 2 beveled edges. If you sand these down slightly the top burr will come closer to the bottom burr. I took measurements before starting with calipers and started working from there. This does work well, just be careful as moving the burrs closer could cause them to rub against each other.

The glass container and drop down grinding path now makes coffee making neater and and less annoying in the morning. It produces a very nice, even grind - good coffee from French Press through Espresso. And its quiet. The twenty second limit is slightly annoying though. I start my first grind immediately and then do the second grind just as the water comes to a boil. Overall, very pleased.
Update April 2015
Is still humming along just fine. It's great for all grinds except espresso. It works but it struggles with the finest grind and isn't quite adjustable enough in that range.
And I guess I wouldn't say no static. Winter time and low humidity does lead to some but the glass is still a major improvement

Grind consistency is off the charts for a sub $100 grinder. I am blown away. I wish the timer was more consistent because I often have trouble getting exactly the amount of grounds I want. Visually it looks great on the counter, best looking of most any grinder in this class. Overall it is a fantastic model.

reviews.reviewTitle: Coffee Grounds are EVERYWHERE EVERYDAY - FRUSTRATED.
reviews.reviewText: We waited a while to review this item. We are avid coffee drinkers and as hard as I tried to leave a higher rating for this coffee grinder - WE are so disappointed. Coffee grounds are everywhere - everyday. It's a mess and was very expensive for us. I've been on Amazon today looking at new coffee grinders due to our frustration. What a bummer - and this was expensive. Sorry.

I just got this grinder and it stopped grinding the beans hardly at all after the third use. I'm talking, like cutting the beans in half and spitting them out, no matter what setting it was on. First two uses were just fine, but after that, it has been useless. I don't want to give up on it just yet in case I'm doing something wrong. I've tried cleaning it, changing the settings, and even attaching the hopper on backwards just in case. Nothing worked. If someone has had the same issue and figured it out, please help! Thanks in advance.

We've been through several different burr grinders costing hundreds of dollars over the years and have never been satisfied. Until now. So far, the Bodum grinder answers all of our complaints and produces a quality and consistent grind. The hopper is large, which is nice and saves a bit of time in the morning. The grounds cup is easy to remove (and re-insert) without spilling. I like that the lid is completely separate, which reduces spilling and makes it easier to clean. The glass significantly reduces (but does not entirely eliminate) static, which is a marked improvement over our prior grinders. (Although the static is not entirely eliminated, what little static there is is confined to the insider of the container and DOES NOT spill all over the place. It's really not an issue.) My only minor complains are that it's louder than other grinders and it doesn't have a very long timer (though it's long enough to grind enough coffee a 3/4 pot for me and my wife). So far, so good. Highly recommended.
It worked great and today it stopped. Had it less than a year. Too much plastic in the grinding system and it breaks.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... adjustable with over 14 grind settings from coarse to fine Borosilicate glass catcher reduces static that causes jumping cof
reviews.reviewText:
Continuously adjustable with over 14 grind settings from coarse to fine
Borosilicate glass catcher reduces static that causes jumping coffee grounds
Proven as the best way to grind coffee, the burr grinder is adjustable to deliver the proper grind for your favorite brewing method
Timed grinding feature and quick grind button let you set the exactly the amount of time you need to grind the proper amount of coffee. Easy to clean, I would highly recommend

When my Braun coffee grinder quit working after 30 + years of faithful service I decided to check the Amazon offerings and read the customer reviews.
Soon I realized that there was not one coffee grinder under 100$ that had a 5 star rating, very disheartening!
Finally I decided to take a chance on the Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder and I am so glad I did :)
After about 2 months of daily use I can report that I am extremely pleased with this grinder, it not only looks beautiful in my kitchen, but it also works great and is
considerably less noisy than my old Braun ever was..
Once I figured out the best setting for my drip coffee maker I can count on getting the same grind every time - very important when you expect a good cup
of coffee in the morning to start the day!.

reviews.reviewTitle: Dependable burr grinder with a glass grind receptacle
reviews.reviewText:
I've had my Bodum grinder since November 2010 and it's still working like new. Living in dry Texas, static is a problem, which is why I tried the Bodum grinder for it's glass grind receptacle.

The 20 second grind limit is a minor problem when using my 12-cup automatic drip machine, but I use the 5 minute wait between grinds to clean and fill the coffee machine.

When I first started using the grinder, I would run it for two consecutive 20-second grinds. I did this for about 3-4 months with no problems. Then I read an article about improving your coffee that discussed avoiding long grind times so as to not burn your beans on overheated burrs.

Since then, I would grind for 20 seconds, go through the rest of my coffee prep tasks, then grind another 20 seconds. Not really much of an inconvenience.

I also learned from the article that grinders with conical burrs tend to work better. This grinder has a conical burr.

The grind produced is perfectly even; and the round shape of the receptacle makes it easy to sweep out the grinds.

I will definitely buy another when mine dies (though I hope my grinder lasts a few more years).

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent unit for a good price
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using this nicely designed and well made Bodum grinder several times a day for almost two years. It continues to perform perfectly and still looks like new. There are some engineering compromises that you should be aware of, however. The motor has no internal cooling and there is liberal use of nylon parts. So if you make huge pots of coffee, say, more than four cups of brew at a time, or drink a lot of Espresso, a more expensive heavy-duty unit would be a better choice.

Note: this grinder has a fuse to protect the motor and electronics in case the burrs get stuck for whatever reason. Replacing this fuse requires complete teardown and reassembly, but it can be done.

This grinder replaced my Capresso burr grinder. This Bodum is much, much better. It has a much more consistent particle size. The hopper is generous and can be removed for easy cleaning (good coffee beans are naturally oily). The best part is the glass receptacle, though. It's much less messy than the plastic Capresso. It doesn't have any corners that can trap grounds, and it doesn't have a static cling effect that always resulted in stray coffee grinds on my counter.

I haven't found a reliable "time" of grinding for my 8 cup Bodum french press. It's around 25 seconds, but the timer on the grinder tops out at 20. As a result, I have to measure the coffee into the pot each time. That's not a bad thing, though, as it produces a more consistent brew.

reviews.reviewTitle: Well designed but not good for espresso
reviews.reviewText: Product seems well built and well designed which it gets stars for, however, it is not able to grind the beans fine enough for making espresso with a good crema, which was my entire reason for buying it. Can see it being good for other brewing methods, but can't really argue that it's not meant for espresso since it has a porta filter symbol for the fine setting. Looking into sending back.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great looking unit with good performance and decent price
reviews.reviewText: Good looking unit with nice feel. Quiet compared to others I have seen and works well for medium to fine grind and pour over use. I can't comment on the coarse grind setting consistency as I don't use a french press. For the most part, the anti-static glass container works to keep the grounds from going all over. I run rice through once a week to clean the unit out and no issues cleaning despite not being able to remove the bottom burr (only top). I only grind 1 to 2 cups a sitting so never tax the motor or use 20 secs back to back.

reviews.reviewTitle: Budget Burr Grinder Disguised as High-End
reviews.reviewText:
TL;DR: This is a budget burr grinder with some redeeming qualities but does not provide the quality you need in a burr grinder; I would not buy again.

I give this 2 stars because, at the end of the day, you'll be getting a conical burr grinder. Anybody who takes coffee seriously will work a conical burr grinder in their routine.

However, as far as burr grinders go, this does a pretty awful job:
1. This grinder canNOT achieve a grind fine enough for an aeropress or espresso, even at its finest setting.
2. The grind size is very inconsistent, especially at the finer end of the spectrum.
3. While many claim that the glass receiver does not have a static issue - I can assure you it does, and a big one at that.
4. The amount of grounds left in the machine is just unacceptable - and they will cling to every square mm of this product's surface.

I will admit that for coarse grinding on a budget, this will get the job done. The only reason you should buy this product is if you:
A. Are on a budget but want Burr grounds, AND
B. only use coarser grinds (like for that of a french press or automatic drip

Anybody looking to get into quality coffee making and the true benefit of a burr grinder should steer clear. Anybody looking for a FINE burr grind should exit this page immediately.

Good marketing has put this on your radar, but you should really read the reviews before purchasing. You'll end up spending the money on that next level grinder down the road - I'm only waiting for mine to inevitably give out (as evidenced by other reviews) so that I can buy a new one.

reviews.reviewTitle: First coffee grinder of my life!
reviews.reviewText:
I was never a big coffee drinker until I entered grad school two years ago. Once I discovered the necessity of the black gold, I was hooked. I have two friends who are coffee snobs, one is a barista at Capogiro in Philly and one is a on again off again barista at his friend's coffee shop in Bala Cynwyd. Upon a recommendation from the latter friend (also my roommate) I started research Burr coffee grinders. He owns the Bodum french press, and I love that thing to death so I was happy with the reviews and modern style of the bodum coffee grinder. I wanted a green one but it was a surprising 10$ more than the black at the time. So far, the grinder has been a joy to work and live with. It is fast, efficient and I have had ZERO problems so far. I have owned it for maybe a month. Perfect espresso, perfect course ground, perfect for the first time user. My snobby roommate is more than satisfied as well.

Updated 10/8/2015: I have never had problems with my Bodum Bistro! It still grinds at all different settings, it's fast, a little noisy, but so efficient. It's a bit bulky to keep on the kitchen counter, so I store underneath in a cabinet, but it's so light that taking it out twice or so a week is easy. A previous roommate (NOT the one mentioned in my first review lol), did break the glass carafe it comes with, but I found that is easily replaceable. Now, I use a small pyrex glass dish, the type that comes with a plastic lid. I grind all my coffee for the week (I am not a snob), and store in the air tight pyrex. Doubling my collection and storage into one piece of dishware is far easier than using the glass carafe the machine came with. 4 years, no maintenance needed, I clean it about every 3 months, and knock out the coffee dust after every use. I have never used for anything but coffee beans. I love this machine!!

I've been using this grinder daily for over a year to make French press coffee in my Bodum Chambord 12 cup French Press Coffee Maker, 51 oz, Chrome. I get a consistently perfect grind. I did have a problem with one of the parts after a couple of months. I sent it to Bodum and had a new machine a week later. Their customer service department took care of me to my complete satisfaction.

Since I only use this for the coarse French press grind I cannot review it's other grinding (i.e. drip or espresso) capabilities though I did read it's not the best grinder for espresso. This doesn't matter to me though.

We are also pleased that it's available in red as many of our kitchen appliances are red. Keeping color coordinated is always a plus. :-)

This grinder meets my needs well. The grind is consistent and fine enough for my needs. I use it with an Aeropress. One minor complaint, in 20 seconds it doesn't quite grind all of the two Aeropress scoops. Easy solution, run a 20 second grind, then prepare your water and Aeropress. Once you are ready for the coffee simply hit the grind button one more time and finish off the last of the grounds, I usually let it run a few seconds after the beans are ground to clear out the loose grounds. It does take at least 10 good taps on the machine to get all the grinds out, don't want them sitting around till the next time I make coffee. The machine does not prevent you from restarting the grind immediately after the first 20 seconds is up, but I avoid doing that to maintain the longevity of the grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good entry level conical burr grinder
reviews.reviewText: Noise level is typical. Not easy to clean. Multiple small pieces. Pretty easy to use, however I think it's odd that there is an on/off switch, then a separate on/off button. Seems redundant. Great cost for value.

this is a fun little grinder that has given me ZERO issues
the static is expected as it is a grinder ... duh
make sure to tap the top of grind holder prior to removing from the grinder to reduce the mess

reviews.reviewTitle: Still think I made the right choice
reviews.reviewText:
I looked into Burr grinders for a while. I chose this one based on Amazon reviews of it and the others I was considering. It is pretty quite and well built. Also looks nice and takes up a small footprint.

There is still static build up even in the glass containers, so just something to be aware of considering they say glass is way better than plastic in this regard. My only annoyance is that grounds do remain in the chamber above the container, so sometimes they fall out when you are removing it for cleaning. Now I've learned to tap the machine a bit before removing it to avoid a mess, but still do occasionally get grounds on the counter.

Overall, I'd recommend it based on the price and features over the other ones.

reviews.reviewTitle: The new one is not as sturdy and you have to wait 5 minutes between grinds
reviews.reviewText: We bought this one to replace an older model which we used for probably l5 years. The new one is not as sturdy and you have to wait 5 minutes between grinds. The cup causes the grinds to adhere to the rubber top and the sides and is messy when you remove them from the grinder portion the grounds go all over the place.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great entry-level burr grinder with one small flaw
reviews.reviewText: I have had this grinder for over 5 years and still works like a champ. I will say for those who want a good coarse grind for their French Press, the grounds still appear to be fairly fine even at the top "coarse" setting. This might mess with the grind output you get and create denser coffee than expected, but my taste buds have adjusted and no one that has tried the coffee has complained. There has been some reviews about the plastic gears but I honestly have had no issues. I use the grinder once each morning and grind enough beans for 16 oz of coffee. It's hard to beat this for the price, and, unlike the Cuisinart low-entry burr grinder, this one is a conical grinder and not a blade burr grinder (like the Cuisinart).

Ok....I've had this about 8 months now. Does a good job! Simple and easy to disassemble and clean. Very easy to clean. Lost the rubber lid for the canister within a week and that was frustrating. Just broke the canister last week, but a coffee mug works well....overall an great grinder.

Downside....replacement parts are expensive and not easily found....

Works very well. It's easy to operate. A little on the noisy side, maybe a tiny bit quieter than the spice grinder I used to use to grind beans. But, it's turning beans into powder, there's going to be noise. Certain beans will cause more static in the receiving bowl than others, Ruta Maya is one of those beans. Overall, I would buy it again and recommend it to others.

reviews.reviewTitle: I wanted to love this but
reviews.reviewText:
Such a cute design! I wanted to love this but, as other users commented, the grinding size for the French press was too small so I found sediment at the bottom of my coffee cup. I have tried other burr grinders (cuisinart 8, baratza encore, and this one) and have noticed that all produce some coffee dust. The Encore was extremely heavy and produced a mess, the cuisinart had too much coffee dust, and the bodum grinder size for coarse grounds was not enough.

I will probably just opt for a cheaper grinder like the Melitta 3-setting grinder since these there seems to be coffee dust or some other issue associated with some costlier options.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works OK, breaks in a year
reviews.reviewText:
It works OK. Grind consistency is acceptable. Glass receptacle actually has quite a bit of static electricity, causing the grinds to stick, which is unfortunate, to say the least.

First one received broke in about a year — one day it stopped working altogether, pressing the button did nothing. Got a replacement after sending a video showing the unit not working. Bodum was pretty quick to respond and the process was hassle-free. However, the second unit broke in about a year also. Same exact issue.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grind quality, but grounds fall out after removing jar
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this coffee grinder for a couple months now using it for French press coarseness and I have been very pleased with the uniformity of the grind. There is only a very tiny amount of dust that is produced which will end up at the bottom of a pressed pot of coffee. As for aspects that are less than ideal I'm not wild about the lid and the seal for it; since the seal is recessed from the outer edge it can be somewhat difficult to secure on the cone without some concentration. The real annoyance however comes from the amount of grounds that remain within the chamber above the coffee grounds jar. These grounds will fall out after removing the jar, leaving a mess on the counter each time. I've now just gotten in the habit of picking up the whole grinder and smacking it about a little from every angle to ensure there's as little hanging up above as possible (this can result in knocking the clear plastic cone lose so be advised if you do this).

Overall it's a great product for the price when compared to other conical burr grinders, but it's not without issues.

I've used this product for several weeks. It does a good job and I've not experienced the problem others have described ie the motor shutting down for a 'mandatory' cooling off period. That said, the 'static-free' glass container is a bit of a laugh. I've ground several different types of Arabica beans and there is virtually always static cling and it's always a bit messy. On the other hand, a little mess often goes with preparing something from 'scratch', so it doesn't really bother me - just don't expect the manufacturer's 'no-static' claim to be much more than marketing hype. Bottom line: I like this grinder and I'd recommend it to a friend. UPDATE: I've now been using this grinder for slightly more than 5 years - I've had zero problems and it's still going strong!

We loved our old Krups 203, but now the Bistro tops it in every way. A lot pricier, of course (about $20 for the Krups, about $95 for the Bistro, on sale), but with the Bistro there there is absolutely no bitterness or acidity. Every cup is smooth, & strength is spot on (we added about 5% more beans after our test grind, but that of course is purely a matter of taste.) No "static" dust. Ground beans go into a french press (the Frieling USA Ultimo, also from Amazon), and since we got the Bistro grinder, the consistency of the grind has meant NO problems dropping the lid on the press. If I wanted to give somebody a perfect coffee setup, I would pair the Frieling press with the Bistro grinder, and I hope Amazon works up a deal on the combo soon.

reviews.reviewTitle: Why did I wait so long?!?
reviews.reviewText:
I got this grinder for Christmas after looking, wondering, reading reviews forever! I have used a blade grinder for years... a lot of years! Wasn't sure what to do after reading the reviews, but decided this would be the one to try! I was excited when I received it for Christmas and couldn't wait to use it! IT took a little experimenting to get the grind I wanted for the perfect pot... but I am very pleased! It amazes me what people will come up with to complain about when doing a review!! I seldom write reviews... and when I do it is usually for a product I want to say good things about... to balance out the bad reviews!

The grind is great... even... so much better than my blade grinder! The mess is minimal... practically nonexistent! The complaints about the mess are ridiculous... nothing is perfect... if ya don't like the mess... don't grind your own beans! Grinding = a mess! If you need more than 20 sec to grind your beans... buy a different grinder! This obviously isn't the one for you and you will have to spend the extra money to get what you want!

So... in my opinion... this is a great grinder for the person looking for a great grind to make a typical cup of coffee every morning.

I love it! It is quiet, quick, tidy and easy to use!

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder has served me well for 1-2 uses per ...
reviews.reviewText: This grinder has served me well for 1-2 uses per week (max) since 2013. However, it has now decided to shut itself off part way through the grind. Sometimes it will run for several seconds, sometimes only a few, and sometimes it won't start at all. There appears to be no way to service the unit so at this point despite being mechanically sound (I haven't had the broken gear issue mentioned elsewhere in reviews) it is effectively a doorstop due to some electrical issue. I would expect a $100 piece of simple equipment to last longer than 4 years.

I looked online at dozens of coffee grinder models and read hundreds of reviews before making a purchase, comparing blade vs. burr grinders, model size, extra features vs. no frill models, glass vs. plastic container, mess vs. no mess, noise level....etc.
this model is perfect for my 2 or 3 cup a day need. convenient, easy to use ( once you figure out the setting for that just-right grind), not very loud and minimally messy. I was a little surprised at the over $40 price difference depending on the color choice, but it wasn't a problem for me since I wanted the red anyway ( the black was $40 more than the red).

reviews.reviewTitle: don't purchase Bodium Bistro Burr Coffee Grinder - buyer be aware
reviews.reviewText: I have used the Bodium Bistro Burr Grinder twice. Both times, I had to empty the beans out only to clean out the grinder. The Capresso I had before was far more reliable then this. In fact my hand cranked burr grinder is better than this Bodium Burr Coffee Grinder

reviews.reviewTitle: so good. The Bodum is well made and quiet
reviews.reviewText: So far, so good. The Bodum is well made and quiet. It grinds nicely, produces good grounds, and it's features are very nice. The glass decanter is much nicer than the plastic types you see in many grinders. The cone grinder is much better than the typical burr grinders which easily burn beans. But, there are blade grinders that do as well even though they don't let you dial the type of grind. It's not cheap but it is a good machine. If you love good coffee, this grinder will work well for you. No problems or issues.

Very easy to use grinder. Grind settings are good enough. Okay for cleaning, could be better. Heats up fast and you have to wait far too long between grinds. Looks lovely on the countertop and has solid recommendations for time depending on amount of beans being ground build into the hopper lid.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is my second Bistro grinder; both worked for ...
reviews.reviewText: This is my second Bistro grinder; both worked for ~ 1.5 years and then stopped grinding at "espresso" level. A cheap plastic impeller is used in the grinding mechanism that wears down.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fresh coffee to your liking each and every day!
reviews.reviewText: Ordered initially from Amazon and due to a shipping problem, I canceled the order. Bought the same model at a department store and must report that this is "A Great Grinder!" I replaced an old Cuisinart grinder with this one and it works great. I especially like the timer and glass container. While static is mostly eliminated, there is always a small amount of coffee that sticks to the container, but much less than other plastic container models. Highly recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: How many cups do you need?
reviews.reviewText: The unit is meant for those who grind 1-4 cups at a time; NOT for those who want to grind a pound or two at at time. This replaced the Braun I've been using for 10 years (still works). The unit grinds for 20 seconds max and you have to press the button again. Other reviewers mentioned this issue as well. The manual says you need to let it cool between grinds. There are multiple settings for the size of grinds which is nice depending of what you need it for. The glass holder is small; again for those making small amounts at one time. When you pull the glass holder, coffee tends to fall out onto the counter. I always tap the unit before pulling it out which lessen the mess. Nice and compact and is stylish to leave out on the counter.

reviews.reviewTitle: The best coffee grinder I have ever used.
reviews.reviewText:
This coffee grinder is the best for making French Press Coffee. I have found that the setting just before the coarsest grind (conveniently identified by a small icon of a french press pot) is best. Also, I found that setting the timer for 20 seconds a bit too long for my 12 cup press. I set it for 15, and voila! perfect amount and coarseness of the coffee beans.

There are some who have had trouble with coffee grounds spilling out on the counter, and I had this problem too, until I learned that a few taps on the side of the grinder before removing the glass coffee grounds receptacle will fix it.

The cost for this grinder is exceptional for the best freshly ground coffee available. Don't waste money on the ultra expensive types. Bodum is definitely the best.

reviews.reviewTitle: Died 2years plus a few days after warranty coverage expired.
reviews.reviewText: We purchased this grinder on July 9th 2012. Today is July 18 2014 just a few days after the 2 year manufacturer's warranty expired and the grinder made a terrible sound and stopped working. Of course, because it is a few days past the 2 year cutoff date, we have no recourse for this very expensive grinder. There are a lot of very good grinders for under $30. We are definitely going that route in the future. Would NOT recommend this grinder to anyone unless they want to spend pretty penny every other year replacing it simply to grind their coffee. NOT a good value for the function of this product.

This grinder is amazing for the price! We purchased it based on the Starbucks connection assuming a big corporation would not put up with the hassle of a product with meager performance. The grinder is quiet, quick, uniform in grind and easy to clean. It is far superior on these counts to other burr grinders we have owned. The 20 second grind limit is sufficient for three cups of coffee in our experience. Bodum says more than 20 seconds will overheat the motor. Really? We can't say. What to do if a large party wants coffee? I suppose I will break out the old noisy grinder! Everything considered, we are very satisfied...the noise and long grind of the old grinders were a major hassle early in the morning. The Bodum Bistro solved our problem nicely.

This is the second one of these grinders that I've owned. The first one lasted me about 5 years before it started making a very loud noise when it was grinding, before it finally broke a week later. I would say that's a pretty good lifetime for a decently-priced burr grinder.

I use my grinder daily for espresso and it works perfectly. I wish there were more markings for grind settings, because I often end up somewhere in between the dots provided - however, it's very easy to adjust to my needs.

Pros:
This grinder meets my needs economically. I usually use a manual drip cone to make 1-2 cups, and set it to medium grind. The grind is even and consistent. The design is modern and stylish. The outer rubber material has a nice feel to it, and the burrs seem to be well made.

Cons:
It has jammed before on the finest setting. The maximum of 20 seconds use per 5 minutes may not be enough for some users.

I would recommend this to anyone looking for a quality grinder in this price range. There is a world of difference between this and a blade grinder. It could be worth looking at more expensive grinders if you want to brew espresso, grind large volumes of coffee, or don't like the look of plastic and rubber.

works exactly as described and does not take long to figure out the nuances of burr time vs output. It grinds perfectly even grounds every time and in exactly the quantity you want.
I have not experienced any of the issues that some people described here. I recently went on vacation for 2 weeks and ground several large batches at a time with no problem. I then cleaned the entire unit for the 1st time since I bought it 3 months ago. I don't think you need to clean the unit if you use it every day - I am just concerned that leaving it unused for a period of time might cause issues - so better to be safe.
Junk. Stopped working 31 days after purchase, no joke. Extra frustrating because it can't be returned now. Look elsewhere

This coffee grinder is absolutely fantastic! All you need to do is put the whole beans in the hopper...set the timer and push start. It grinds the beans to a perfect consistency. There is never a whole bean, or broken bean...in the grind. I find that I use less beans because the grind makes a better, stronger pot of coffee. It's also great for our espresso machine. I would highly recommend Bodum's burr grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Produces a consistent grind every time
reviews.reviewText: I use the grinder to prepare coffee for a single cup pour over. My daughter uses it to prepare coffee for her espresso maker. The grind and timer adjustments consistently give each of us the proper amount and grind of coffee as we adjust the settings back and forth on a daily basis. The machine has the feel and sound of a quality made product. We are very happy with the appliance.

reviews.reviewTitle: you can have a sad little coffee maker
reviews.reviewText: In my opinion, you can have a sad little coffee maker, and just purchase a great burr grinder, and you will have a great cup of coffee. I recently attended Coffee Con to learn about coffee making. I am very happy with this grinder. I also purchased the Bodum Pour Over coffee maker, which is equally great. I grind my coffee just once step finer then recommended for a standard coffee maker and am very pleased with the taste.

I agree with all the others about ease of use, no mess, no clogging and consistent grinds. My biggest complaint was that anything over 8 cups tooks longer than the 20 sec. maximum time limit. Even the beans for 8 cups needed to go over the 20 sec ever so slightly. I soon realized that several seconds were eaten up just getting the whole beans down to the burr to begin the grinding process. So I totally filled the clear top plastic container with whole beans and did several trail and error tests to figured out how long it took to grind enough beans for 4 cups of coffee. That time for us is 8 seconds. So we multiply that number by the number of cups we want and set the timer accordingly. The ease of having the beans already in the hopper and just pressing the button for the grind and not having to press it again for a full pot has been great. The first grind after you fill the hopper will take about 4 seconds longer as you will have to wait for the beans to get down in the hole where the burr mechanism is. After that it is a piece of cake. This is a definite keeper.

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't buy it, poor quality, terrible customer service
reviews.reviewText: I purchased the Bodum Burr grinder and in less than a month it is broken. I took off the bean hopper to brush the old grinds out and the plastic ring around the conical burr grinder fell off. I contacted Bodum customer service and was told that I had to PURCHASE a replacement part that they do not warranty "misuse". There was no misuse, I took the bean hopper off and the plastic ring fell off. So I am left with spending more money on this one or basically throwing away the money I spent on it. I am very disappointed. My first Bodum lasted for 18 years, I will never buy another Bodum product. Poor quality, terrible customer service.

Great features for the price. Soft grip coating makes it easy to move around. Noticeably better coffee compared to my old blade grinder. If you keep fresh beans, it is well worth having a good burr grinder like this one.

I'm 50+ years old and have owned or used about 5 grinders. This is the best grinder I've ever owned, for these reasons:

1. Doesn't make a mess when using
Most grinders fill the air, and countertop, with grounds. This one emits the grounds into the
glass receptacle.

2. The only work involved is pushing a button
Most grinders--surely for safety reasons--force you to hold down a button for the entire length of the grinding process. By adding a timer, this grinder lets me get around that tedious step. Just select the number of seconds for my grind, and push a button.

3. Allows me to create a perfect, measured dose
Because it has the timing feature, I can create exactly what I need, every morning.
I figured out that, to make coffee using my lovely Aeropress, I need to grind 7 seconds worth
of espresso beans. I grind for 7 seconds, then throw it into the Aeropress -- no measuring

4. Uses very little countertop space

5. Has a generous holding tank for beans
This means I only have to fill it once a week.

6. Precision grinding
I can really get the exact fineness of grind I want -- from uber-coarse to uber-fine, using the easy adjustment mechanism

* * * SUMMARY * * *
OTHER grinders make one go through the tedious steps of: a) fill grinder, b) hold down button for desired amount, c) pour grounds into coffeemaker, usually spilling some precious cargo along the way, d) clean up mess on counter, e) SNEEZE because, you have an allergy to airborne coffee dust

This grinder simplifies the morning process: a) push button, b) pour contents of glass jar into coffee maker

* * * WORKS BEST WITH: * * *
1. Nespresso Aeroccino Plus
Best frothing system I've *ever* used. I reviewed that, too -
http://www.amazon.com/gp/cdp/member-reviews/A2GH7L9R77OQRH/ref=ya_26?ie=UTF8&sort_by=MostRecentReview

2. Aerobie AeroPress Coffee and Espresso Maker
An unbelievable espresso maker for $25, which uses NO electricity and hardly ANY counter space

3. Aeropress Stainless Steel Coffee Filter
No need to re-order filters forever.

* * * NOTE ABOUT OTHER REVIEWS * * *
Most of the unfavorable reviews have to do with the 20 second limit on the timer. I wouldn't ding the product for this, in fact, I think it was simply a good engineering decision. That being said, I tested what would happen by running it for 40 seconds. Motor seemed fine. I think the manufacturers just want to make sure folks don't run it for an hour, which would of course blow out a motor of this size. Also, as I wrote above, grinding for 7 seconds gives me all the Joe I need for the day.

reviews.reviewTitle: A Reluctant 5 Stars Amended 9 Months Later
reviews.reviewText:
My experience with the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder (Black) makes quite a saga. First I ordered the machine in red, thinking the cheerful, vibrant color shown on my screen would enliven the kitchen. When the grinder arrived, I was disappointed to find how dull and dreary the color is "in the flesh." So I phoned Amazon Customer Service (which is dependably cooperative), and they agreed to accept the return of the machine without penalty. Thereupon I ordered the black, which, like the red before it, arrived fast and in perfect condition. I'm satisfied that the discrepancy between the red on line and the red in the actual machine is merely a matter of physics, with no intent to deceive; and my wife and I love the black -- so no "star deduction" so far.

Then we got into grinding. The Bodum emits the reassuring sound of precision. It is the sound that well-built, sturdy, meticulously-crafted machines nearly always make, and it gives you the expectation of consistency and longevity. The consistency is immediately apparent in the uniformity of the grounds, but we'll have to see about the longevity over time. We have an automatic drip machine, so the only grind setting we use is medium, as indicated by the middle icon on the machine. Our old grinder (also a burr machine, but not conical) always produced a by-product of fine powder in addition to the medium-sized particles. With the Bodum there is none of this undesirable powder. Consequently, I can say after a week or so of use, that the flavor of our brewed coffee is noticeably improved. To summarize, the particle size of the grounds is wonderfully consistent, and this is reflected in the taste of the brew.

Now to address a flaw that many other reviewers have mentioned. The grinder only runs for 20 seconds at a time. The instruction booklet tenders a caveat: allow 5 minutes before running the machine through another grinding cycle. I consider that a defect in a machine of this quality. It should be possible for the motor to run for, say, 45 seconds without overheating or sustaining damage. I drink two big mugs of coffee, and the beans necessary for that much java cannot be ground by the Bodum in 20 seconds. However, I don't stand and stare resentfully at the grinder for the next 5 minutes. I have lots of other things to do to fill in that time -- such as toasting and buttering a bagel; or frothing milk for the coffee; or mixing batter for pancakes or waffles; or beating and cooking eggs for a mini-omelet -- and so on. I'm in my 8th decade of life, I no longer go to an office or shop, and I cheerfully admit to being spoiled as hell. If I needed to bolt down my coffee and race out the door (as I once did), that 5 minutes between grindings would be a deal-breaker for me. But since that's not the case, I'm inclined not to deduct any stars for the 20-second limitation either. Call me sucker, but the integrity of the build, the consistency of the grind, and the improved flavor of the brewed coffee have me hooked. But everyone will have to decide for him/herself how important this is.

I consider the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder very good value for money.

NINE MONTHS LATER -- I think it's time to reconsider my original review in just one respect. I'm getting impatient waiting 5 minutes before running the grinder a second time. I now find this requirement an annoying restriction imposed by the manufacturer which should be corrected in subsequent models. Consequently, I have downgraded my rating to four stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'm actually really disappointed with this grinder
reviews.reviewText: I'm actually really disappointed with this grinder. I was very excited to have a grinder that matches our red bodum coffee maker. And this claimed to resolve all our frustrations with other grinders. But this is extremely frustrating. Claims the glass container eliminates the cling to grounds. Not true. Still grounds all over the place. It also is extremely inconsistent in the quantity of grounds. Some days the container is half full. Other days it almost overflows, when we never change the settings. Lastly, if you accidentally hit the button to grind without the container in there, it still runs, spilling grounds all over. Why wouldn't there be a mechanism that prevents it from turning on when the container isn't in place.

This is a great little burr grinder. I have owned it and used it every day, and sometimes more than once a day, for around four months, so I cannot yet talk about its durability. I am not a purist who will insist on a burr grinder over a blade grinder, and I have not owned or used another burr grinder, so I can't compare this one with others.
I like it for the following reasons.
1. It grinds well at the finest setting, when I use it with my cappuccino maker De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker. It also grinds well for our drip maker, which we use every morning, and it produces a nice coarse grind that I have used with my French press.
2. It produces grounds of a uniform coarseness--or fineness--which is the reason you want a burr grinder, if you want one. I confess I don't really notice a difference in taste.
3. The grind is easy to adjust, and you can adjust the length of time the machine will grind. Hypothetically, you could produce the volume of ground coffee you wanted for the amount you were brewing: X seconds at Y coarseness for Z cups of coffee. I do not do that. See below.
4. I think the one true advantage of a burr grinder over a blade grinder is that you can't do anything else while grinding with a blade grinder, but you can push the button on the burr grinder and go do something else, like put water in your coffee maker. That's a slim advantage, I suppose. Purists will disagree and say that the flavor of coffee ground with a burr grinder is superior. I will not contest that claim but I cannot confirm it either.

Cons
1. The grinder has a narrow profile and so is not as stable as I would like. This is the only reason I rated it four stars rather than five.

Notes
1. The machine is designed for you to fill the hopper with coffee and to measure out your grounds by the number of seconds you run the grinder. On the hypothesis that light will leach out flavor from beans sitting in the clear plastic hopper, I've developed my own system for measuring out how much coffee I want to grind every time I make coffee, as I did with all my old blade grinders. So my hopper sits empty. I don't really know if this produces better coffee or not.
2. Some reviewers have commented on the mess that this grinder makes: difficult cleanup because lots of grounds cling to the glass receptacle due to static electricity. I have found that this varies depending on the coffee I use. I use the same coffee beans for all of my coffee needs, but when I have experimented with coffees from other companies some have produced this messy result. I stick with my old brand, not because of that, but because I have not found a coffee I like better.

Addendum 11/06/2019: The grinder is still working but making an awful sound that has been increasing over the past year or so. I assume I am hearing a slipping gear, perhaps due to a broken cog. The noise is accompanied by a longer grinding time. It's still doing the job, but I will probably be purchasing another soon. It has lasted about 6 years, which I suppose isn't bad for a machine with plastic gears.

This steel burr grinder does a reliably consistent grind each time. It's relatively mess-free, and the borosilicate glass grounds catcher helps with that. One nice thing is that once you set the coarseness level and grind time, you only have to plug it in and push the start button.

reviews.reviewTitle: I would recommend this product to others depending on what you are ...
reviews.reviewText: I never owned a Burr coffee grinder before so it's hard to judge this against others, I have had many cheap coffee grinders in the past which had a spinning blade. After the Bodum Electric Burr Coffee Grinder arrived, I open the package and put it to use. You can adjust the level of the grind by turning the top, being new to the Burr grinding method, it took me a several attempts to find my idea grind depending on the brewing method (french press, Aeropress, or ChemEx). I would recommend this product to others depending on what you are looking to spend..

I've had this for about 5 months. Here's what I like about it: 1. Lid on top of unground bean area seals shut, so that you can keep unground beans in the grinder until you grind them and they still remain fresh (the seal is probably not perfect). 2. The grinds receptacle is sturdy glass. It is easy to clean and it inverts perfectly right into the filter basket of my coffee maker. 3. For a burr grinder, it is relatively easy to clean out. 4. It is small and compact, so it doesn't take up a lot of space on my counter. 5. As coffee grinders go, it is quiet. My routine is to pour a bunch of beans into the grinder at the beginning of the week, then grind what I need (about 5 seconds of grinding) each time I want a cup of coffee during the week.
I love this coffee grinder! I use a percolator and grounds have to be larger than normal so I can't purchase pre-ground coffee. This is a game changer. Coffee tastes fantastic!

reviews.reviewTitle: I loved it until the plastic button you push to activate ...
reviews.reviewText: I loved it until the plastic button you push to activate the grinding fell into the unit. Haven’t decided if I should request a replacement or choose another grinder. I love everything about it but couldn’t believe my luck. Received as a Christmas present from my husband and it is/wasvery attractive and useful

This is my second one - the first lasted many years. Tried another less expensive one from a major name kitchen appliance maker - It went back immediately. The Bodum burr grinder is at a great price point, great consistent grind and much less messy. Bodum Bistro, I'm apologize for abandoning you and very glad we are together again!

I'm not sure how to review this grinder because I've never had any experience with any other except for the cheap seed grinder type that turns things into powder. So, what I know about this one after a couple of months use, is that it gives a quick and even grind and you can adjust the grind for different types of coffee makers, but I only have used "course" for my french press. Also, it's not too loud and it's easy to clean. I don't see what you could get in the other much more expensive ones that this one doesn't have. Of course, I don't know how it will hold up over time, but it seems well constructed and appears simply built so that I might one day be able to replace the grinder burrs, the funnel and the cup.

reviews.reviewTitle: Inconsistent grind, unable to achieve fine grind
reviews.reviewText: I love Bodum products so have been very disappointed that this product has not been as great as past experiences. The coffee grind I get with this grinder is consistently inconsistent, with largish chunks surrounded by flakes and dust. I've followed the specifications for the product in terms of how to get a finer grind but to always have to give the coffee another few seconds in my electric grinder to get anywhere close to a grind appropriate for pourover. I've been using this and experimenting with it for some months to no avail. It's possible I have a defective product but not sure how to adjust.

Love this coffee grinder. I went from a small blade grinder to this and while it is slightly more noisy, the convenience and uniformity of the grind are excellent. It's attractive for my home and office. Best part about this product is no more guessing how many beans. Just set a time for the grind and push the button. For the price, I don't see how you beat this.
I use this grinder every day and it puts out a consistent grind each time. I change it for my french press, and does that well. It grinds much more evenly than my expensive blade grinder did.

reviews.reviewTitle: Two faulty products in a row! Don't buy!
reviews.reviewText: So we ordered the first one. It came. DId not work whatsoever. Plugged in, power on, pressed grind button, nothing. Totally broken out of the box. Replacement came. Grinds bean functionally, but defective base, or maybe thats how the product is? the cup where the grinds fall into doesn't seal al the way, thus making coffee ground spew all over the counter and kitchen. Unbelievable that this is a well reviewed product. It does not work

reviews.reviewTitle: Can't go wrong with this grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I had been wanting to find a replacement grind-and-brew coffee pot to replace my favorite Melitta that is not made anymore, but after reviewing all the hideous comments about the available systems (even the relatively "positive" ones seemed to have red flags, in my opinion), I decided just to buy a good grinder and a good coffee pot. This was the best decision I could have made.

I have the grinder set on the medium grind. I have a normal drip pot and like my coffee strong. This setting seems to "powderize" the coffee, and I was a little concerned at first, but it works perfectly in my coffee pot (which is the 14-c Cuisinart pot, also bought on Amazon, that I set to "bold").

The grinder is easy to use, relatively quiet for a grinder...I have no complaints. Plus, since it's a burr grinder, the grind is very uniform, unlike a blade grinder that I use for spices now while shaking (which seems to help the consistency).

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product. Support leaves much to be desired.
reviews.reviewText: This is the second excellent grinder I purchased from Bodum. I purchased direct from them a replacement for the glass catcher on the first one that I broke. They sent it out without the silicone cap. When I called to ask for the cap, a "manager" told me he 'just could not believe" that the cap was missing from the package. I guess he thinks I am a liar or simply hallucinatory. In any event, I've never heard a support person, much less a "manager" respond that way to a paying customer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy, reliable, good quality - but a little messy
reviews.reviewText: I like the hopper design which allows me to skip opening a bag every time I want to grind coffee. It's not too noisy, but it's noisy - no way to get around that with any grinder. The grind quality is good. I've read this thing is less messy than many others, but I've got to say ... it still produces a lot of particles that get all over. After you take the jar out, a little bit of the grounds will still be accumulated on the grinder mechanism and will sprinkle down. It will get on the jar lid, and it's a little messy. But it's just one of those things that happens with grinders.

Very nice grinder. It will grind the exact quantity I need every time. It's almost impossible to do without a mess as no matter how hard I try every time I use this I seem to get grounds all over the counter so be prepared to clean up every time you use it. I still get some static and coffee sticking to the sides of the glass container despite the manufactures claims to the contrary. In a fairness I have never used a grinder with a plastic container to I have nothing to comare it to.

reviews.reviewTitle: The first one's motor began a to have terrifically bad and loud sound and wouldn't grind even after dismantling ...
reviews.reviewText: This device starts its life as a hard and competent worker. The first one's motor began a to have terrifically bad and loud sound and wouldn't grind even after dismantling and cleaning. I supposed there was a pebble in the beans which caused the problem (although there's never been a pebble in these coffee beans before). I bought a duplicate January 2017. Again, a beginning tough worker but now, in November, the grinding has slowed to a trickle (2-20 second turns would complete the hopper-ful - now 6 for half a hopper-ful!) so that the motor now is beginning to have that "don't use me, I'll burn out" smell. For these experiences over time, I do not recommend this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best Coffee Grinder for you and me.
reviews.reviewText: So incredibly pleased with this conical burr grinder. I have a good friend that has a coffee business. He uses a more expensive model, but recommended this grinder for my home use. It is super easy to use and clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broken in less than 30 days; complete run-around by customer service at Bodum
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this grinder as a Christmas gift for my son. Less than 30 days after he received it, and not even under daily use, a piece of plastic on the grinder broke. After multiple contacts to Bodum customer service, someone finally agreed to send him a replacement part. That was more than 2.5 months ago. Bodum now says they mailed the part, do not understand why it has not arrived yet, and have only recently (2 weeks ago) promised to re-send the part. Nevertheless, the part still has not been received. Overall, we are both very disappointed in the lack of responsiveness. I expect more given the price point of the product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good to start, then it falls apart and you are not covered by the warranty!
reviews.reviewText: This product started off great! Then after about 6 months it started to have an inconsistent coffee grind. Big chunks and fine ground coffee came out. I took the top off and gave it a good clean, it did come back to life for a few weeks. Then after that it was back to inconsistent grind and after that it just stopped working. By this point it was just over 12 months old, given that Bodum provide a two year warranty we thought all would be fine. Then the shocking news, if you buy this product essentially anywhere other than direct from Bodum you are not covered by the warranty. I would suggest paying a little bit extra and getting a better made product from a company that offers a better warranty.

reviews.reviewTitle: worked fine for a year, then died
reviews.reviewText: This worked fine for a little under a year, then started making horrible grating noises and stopped grinding coffee completely, for no reason that I can see -- I had kept it clean and free of debris. It was very finicky while it was being used -- the manual tells you not to grind two batches one after the other so the engine won't overheat, which makes it difficult if you need to grind a lot of coffee for company.
