I went back to my trusty old Capresso Infinity Burr Grinder, which has been going strong for 3 years now (knock wood). This Bodum is prettier (I had the red one) but not worth the $$, in my opinion.

It grinds well but I've had it for just six weeks and the plastic gear mechanism already seems to be giving way. Almost daily now the mechanism will jam and start grinding plastic gears instead of beans. When that happens I have to invert the unit and tap it until the obstruction (i.e., the offending bean) shakes free from the burr. This will only continue to get worse in time. If I could return it right now I would.

Similar to other negative reviews from people who owned this for 1-2 years- it just breaks after around a year. It was fine while it lasted (roughly one year) and then it just craps out. I've had a $15 Hamilton Beach blade grinder for around 10 years now that still works and produces a finer grind. The bodum is too pricey for its poor durability.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love this burr grinder and it's affordable!
reviews.reviewText: Was using a Cuisinart blade grinder before and it works well enough. I use it at the office now, but this actually did make a difference in taste. It was a bit smoother. Not by great leaps and bounds mind you, but it does make a slight different taste. I highly recommend this grinder if you are in the market or on the fence for a burr coffee grinder.

I've had the Red Bistro version for just about a year now and for the majority of my brews have been using Starbucks French Roast. I grind every morning and usually after work so I put plenty of beans through the hopper to test this grinder out. I've ground for espresso, vac pot, for the keurig, and a small french press and haven't had a problem with achieving an even grind for all. The unit has never jammed or had any issue and I don't use any special cleaning practices except wiping the unit with a damp rag. The lid does a good job keeping the grinds in the container, but the process of grinding beans in general will end up leaving fines on the counter after a while. Overall I have to recommend since it works as described.

Have had this about a week now and the initial report is good.

Have had 3 inexpensive bean choppers. The first one broke a blade - the replacement blade was more expensive than the whole thing. The second was so loud I gave it away. The last one just did not handle my favorite Vietnamese bean well. It is very oily and you had to pry off the grindings every time. Further the grinding was very uneven. Some was powder; some of the rest was nearly whole unchopped beans.

I have looked at burr grinders before but they were very expensive and / or reviews were not so great - although part of that is due to "coffee prudes".

This one gives you a great range of control over grind size - from Turkish / espresso grind, to drip, to French press. As others have said the catch jar is glass - and the oily beans do not stick to it at all. It is much quieter than any of the choppers.

The instructions are sparse - but the device is simple really. The only adjustments are time and grind. These are interactive - it takes longer to grind fine coffee than the same amount ground course. So I started out with my usual quarter cup of beans(for 8 - 6 oz cups) and a fine grind and just let it run until the beans were gone - around 22 seconds. The grind was too fine and the resulting coffee was too strong. All the coffee was being ground - no more wasted beans. So I am now back to a medium drip grind and about 12 seconds - and somewhat less than a quarter cup of beans.
It holds somewhat more that 8oz of beans - certainly not a pound. My beans are usually sold by the ½ pound so that is fine.

So this guy is a winner so far.

Someone mentioned that theirs had stalled. Actually it has a clutch in it and it is supposed to stall if something ungrindable - like a stone -gets into the bean. Beans are a natural product so it can happen. Better to stall than to wreak the mechanism.

4/14/2012 - Sure enough after a year it had a jam-up. Took it apart according to the manual and pried out the offending rock. Works like a charm again.

9/17/2014 After 2 1/2 years of about one pot of coffee per day the motor burned out. I think the motor was under powered to start with.
Just purchased a highly recommended Baratza Virtuoso - Conical Burr Coffee Grinder to replace it.

I recently upgraded my coffee maker (more on that below) and decided to upgrade my coffee storage (more on that below, too) and grinder. I had been using a sturdy Braun blade grinder, which was fine. But despite a mention on Cooks Illustrated that the kind of grinder used in their testing of coffee makers made no difference, I opted to try a burr grinder. I hate to disagree with CI, but I find it does make a difference, and this little grinder performs really well and is a pleasure to see perched on the kitchen counter.

The Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder (I have the white--and it is white, not ivory) is very simple to use, produces a perfectly even grind, and minimizes static. I typically make 6-7 cups of drip coffee, and was quickly able to determine a good coarseness and amount of time (12 sec) to produce the perfect amount to dump into my coffee maker each morning. I have the top hopper loaded with beans (which stay fresh because the lid fits snugly) and all I have to do in the morning is press the starter button, and voila. Clean up is easy (and unnecessary day-to-day, but I brush it out when I switch beans).

For storage of waiting beans or pre-ground coffee (I received about 4 lbs. of 6 different kinds of beans this Christmas, which probably inspired my upgrades), I've been using these great Bodum glass jars: [...] . The 68 oz. will hold more than a pound of beans or ground coffee, has a nice snug-fitting glass lid with a rubber ring, and it is lovely. And matches the grinder :) .

As for the coffee maker, I cannot say enough about the Technivorm Moccamaster (and [...]) [...]. Can a coffee maker really be worth $300? Yes it can (especially with the extras that Roastmasters includes). I look at it this way: is it worth $1 a day for the next 300 days to have really great coffee at home? Yes. I had been using (for 20 years) a quite nice Krups coffee maker, but the liquid produced by the Technivorm is an entirely different, smoother and yet more robust, liquid than what comes out of any other coffee maker. The coffee maker is a minimalist's joy (on/off, that's it) and the thermal carafe is an essential.

Way more info than you're looking for, I'm sure. But I'll end by saying that the Bodum grinder is great, and worthy of my Technivorm. High praise indeed.

Bought in December of 2016 and it broke in April 2017. No way to return or get a warranty fulfillment from this vendor or Bodum since they told me that they don't fulfill from a third party-- so I am out 70 dollars and down a grinder. Would just go ahead and buy a grinder a step above (encore, etc for the price and quality). When it did work it would become jammed for no reason weekly and I would have to take apart.

reviews.reviewTitle: I dare say it's better then my old Braun
reviews.reviewText: My old Braun grinder of 15+ years died and I needed a replacement. I tried a few of the cheaper brands over the last year. Both failed and didn't grind well and died quickly. I got this Bodum on Black Friday sale and I'm very impressed. I dare say it's better then my old Braun, cleans easier than any grinder I've had before, glass jar, quiet (for a grinder), and looks good on the counter. I only occasionally make espresso and this unit works for my needs, but if you're looking for a real espresso grinder this isn't the unit for you.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is a really nice grinder! It does the job really well and ...
reviews.reviewText:
This is a really nice grinder! It does the job really well and you cannot beat the price given the quality!
Unfortunately, the grinder makes a mess. The soft rubber coating just seems to attract the lightest flakes from grinding whole beans and the cup that collects the grinds out of the hopper somehow doesn't catch them all.
Be prepared to wipe counters and the grinder after each use if you keep a tidy kitchen.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bodum BISTRO working well so far
reviews.reviewText: Like this grinder a lot. Definite upgrade from our Cuisinart grinder, which needed replacing as the hard plastic coffer threads cracked and chipped away. Not only that, but the teeth were worn. However, the Cuisinart was never even close to as good a grinder as the Bodum BISTRO. I grind fine for drip and course for french press and it does both well. Simple controls. The glass container fits snug and seals well. It does get some static cling, but I've not had one that didn't. Overall, very pleased for the price and quality.

Awesome introduction to making great coffee. I am a beginner and have done the research on making a cup of coffee. My first thought was I need an expensive coffee pot. NOT TRUE. This grinder has opened my taste buds to true bliss. No matter how you make your coffee this grinder will do the job. After my research I realized being stuck with an expensive coffee pot would be just that. Stuck. I have shown off my grinder to guests by making french press and a great pot of drip for comparison. Most cannot believe how good the drip coffee is, then I serve the French press. WOW!! You will see issues about noise and size but no issues on the quality of grind. I tried it for myself and could not be happier. Makes a 10 cup pot of grounds in 1 run. Or adjust for specialty brews.

Of the big three sub-$100 burr grinders, I dislike this one the least. My first, the Capresso, died rather quickly. The Breville, which I could never get dialed in for good coffee, spewed coffee ground dust everywhere. I couldn't send it back fast enough. I'll hand it to the Bodum--it does grind tasty coffee. But the grounds collector is made of glass and I broke it within a few weeks. I contacted Bodum to ask why the replacement wasn't available on their website, and they promised that it would be there within two weeks. That was about six months ago. I'll probably move up to the Kitchen Aid when this one dies or I get tired of having a non-standard grounds collector (a glass candle holder with the candle removed).

Caveat: I have no experience except second-hand with other burr grinders. That aside, I have found this grinder to be great for making coffee. Having not had it more than a couple months I cannot speak with authority to its durability, but so far it has shown no problems whatsoever and doesn't even leak grounds unless knocked around when the glass catcher is out. Before I bought it I noticed one reviewer who said the catcher was too thin (i.e. very delicate) which worried me slightly but in my opinion it's not any thinner than one would imagine on a device like this. Also, although Bodum recommends against running the grinder for longer than the max grind time (20 sec) within a given 5 minute window I haven't had any difficulties running two 15 second sessions pretty much back-to-back (although just watch me eat these words in two more months when it explodes or something). It is, however, pretty damned loud, but I'm not sure there exists a grinder that isn't, regardless of variety. I'm not sure what else you'd look for in a burr grinder, and wholeheartedly recommend it.

UPDATE: So, it's been almost 4 years since I bought this grinder, and have used it an average of every day for that entire time without any problems. It has required zero maintenance, and I've perfected a highly-nuanced technique whereby I tap the side of the grinder a few times before removing the catcher to reduce the propensity of loose grounds to fall out.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best value for money at this price point, hands down
reviews.reviewText:
Great little grinder. It is compact and well-designed. It is quieter than the blade grinders I had previously (duh) and makes a pleasing whirring sound rather than a high-pitch scream, which is another plus.

The grounds come out uniform and there is almost no spillage whatsoever. After a 20-second grind, I slide the receptacle out, tap the side of the grinder a few times, and can easily collect any spilled particles on a finger tip.

For my purposes (almost entirely aeropress double shots) this is the perfect grinder. A single 20 second grind gives me exactly the right quantity of grounds for 2 aeropress scoops, so the whole operation takes only 25 seconds to complete.

Since I have only owned this grinder for a week, I'll update this in the future if I experience any problems.
Can make a ridiculously fine grind to whatever level you prefer. Works great but it is loud, do not use if your trying to be stealthy in anyway. Hah

reviews.reviewTitle: Consistent grind, little static electricity. But failed after 19 months
reviews.reviewText:
I was quite satisfied with my first grinder for 19 months, at which time it stopped working. I liked the quality and consistency of the grind, the glass container that collected very little static electricity, the timer, and the large hopper. I made made two cups of coffee every day, grinding beans for 9 seconds each.

Would give it five stars if it had lasted longer than 19 months. But I liked it enough to buy another, with the hope of longer life.
I use it daily for three to four cups of coffee, works flawlessly, I do buy very high quality beans that are hand picked, maybe that's why I haven't had any issues?
After seven months, the product stopped working.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do not buy this grinder for making Espresso coffee
reviews.reviewText: This did not grind fine enough for espresso (using Breville BES840XL). If you want fine espresso grind buy the Baratza Encore, it works perfectly. If you are not interested in Espresso I am sure this grinder is fine for everything else. The 30 second limit is a bit low (you have to 5 min for the grinder to cool off in between), so be warned if you expect to grind large quantities of coffee at once.

reviews.reviewTitle: It grinds evenly but that's about it. The lid ...
reviews.reviewText:
It grinds evenly but that's about it. The lid doesn't fit well, certainly not airtight.
The anti-static feature of the container does not work at all. In fact, it seems more static-y.
It makes a mess no matter how much you tap the machine after grinding, stuff falls out all over your counter.

We had a Krups Burr Mill and two grinders. They are now at GOODWILL. The BODUM is great. You can make any grind - and it is uniform each time. We regularly use both a French Press and a drip coffeemaker. The BODUM rocks! It leaves you free to do the prep work while it is doing its grinding. Two 20 second presses gives us 8 cups of nice, strong coffee. The Krups was messy and gave a less perfect grind. Our grinders had to be shaken while operating in order to get a reasonable grind - and it varied each time. We have had NO problem with grinding two sessions in sequence. Highly recommended!

So our first Bodum coffee grinder worked fantastically until one day it just started grinding by itself early morning and when I came to investigate I saw smoke rising up from the grinding bit. So this was retired and a new one was purchased thinking this was just a one off. Now only 2 months after this purchase it thankfully does not grind without human aid. But just does not grind. Anybody know of a good burr grinder that is not possessed or apathetic by nature?

I've been using this product for 3 years now on a daily basis with zero issues. Yes, some of the grinds tend to static to the cup. No, I don't think other products fix this problem. The grind is always consistent. It is fast. It does make noise, but that comes with the territory and it isn't overly loud.

I also picked one of these up for my mother and she loves it as well. I would completely recommend this product to anyone that loves coffee.

Update: had this for 5 years now, still works like new.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good burr grinder for the money.
reviews.reviewText: Great grinder. The red color was cheapest so that is what I bought. Consistent grind. My only complaint is with the grind timer feature. If you need more than 20 seconds worth of grinding you have to hit the button two more times; once to start it again, and another to stop it.

I've been using this daily for the last few months and when it works properly, it does a good job. I have had issues with it being very inconsistent in the grind it produces as well as the amount of time it runs for a given amount setting. All without touching any of the setting. I am using it with a French Press so I use the most coarse setting, but sometimes it will only produce a grind more appropriate for a drip machine and it clogs the filter in my press.
I bought one of these grinders for myself 8 years ago, and it is still going strong. I bought another one for my mom about 1.5 years ago and she loves it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stylish and great function. No need to spend more.
reviews.reviewText: This is a great burr grinder so far. No need to spend more. The grind has been consistent, reliable, and not too messy. With these grinders you will ALWAYS get some rogue coffee particles due to static but this isn't bad at all. It looks great and functions great. Note that I don't use the timer function. It's much better to weigh the beans then dump into hopper for consistency. Combine with small batch fresh roasted beans, a digital scale, timer, a hario electric kettle and kalita wave brewer and you will experience nirvana.

I bought this grinder because my parents have had it for 2 years without issue and I needed something reliable.
I love the settings on the hopper, very spot on and I love how easy it is to clean.

The glass catcher is a plus, no static.

This is a must have for the coffee connoisseur, fresh grinds with a conical burr grinder is by far superior.

I do wish it came with a brush for cleaning, but at this price point, I can't complain.

LOUD ! But gets the job done. If you roast your own beans, be careful of under-roasting: The motor/burr tends to stall when it hits an under-roasted bean (Or the occasional pebble found sometimes in green coffee beans from the hulling process)

reviews.reviewTitle: Fine grinder for seven years running
reviews.reviewText: Wow. I truly don't understand all the negative reviews for the Bodum burr grinder. I bought mine in October 2011 and it's worked flawlessly since then, providing a daily grind for a French press coffeemaker. All the reported woes about having to clean gears/grinders and broken glass containers are mystifying.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poorly designed AND stopped working correctly
reviews.reviewText:
From the start, I wasn't crazy about this grinder because the container that catches the grinds is completely round, so getting the last of the grounds out can be tricky. Scooping against a round side wall won't do it, and pouring from a container that doesn't have a spout means some of the grounds may hit your scoop or some may go flying onto the counter. It was an annoyance but not enough for me to return it.

Unfortunately, I've now had the grinder for 6 months and it stopped grinding on the finer grind settings. The beans just won't descend unless it's set at a medium-coarse grind or coarser.

Follow up from April 2012 review below:

I purchased the Bodum grinder in February 2012 (wrote the first review in April 1012) and, if you read the review below, was mostly happy (I gave it 4 stars). In July 2013, one year and five months later, the timer failed. I am still within the two year warranty so the Bodum folks say that they will replace the unit. The problem is that the model is being reworked due to switch problems and will not be back in stock until September. You will note in the review below that I commented on the power switch when the unit was new. I decided early on to leave the main power switch permanently in the ON position.
There are several features we like. As stated in the original review the footprint is small, the fit and finish is good and the design of the timer allows for a consistent amount of coffee. I revised the rating to two stars because of the poor quality of the power and timer switches. The grinder failed the primary test that I outlined below.
Ed A
August 2013

I have used the Bodum grinder for about one month. I like the fact that the unit has a small footprint and is not imposing. I purchased the black unit and am impressed with the fit and finish of the grinder. I am particularly impressed with the timer for the grind time. I have it set so that I get the exact amount of coffee needed for my cup of coffee. I brew one cup (large) at a time using a V-filter and a filter holder. Also, there is absolutely no mess around the grinder. Not one time have I had to clean ground coffee from anywhere.
I am a little less impressed with the power switch. It feels like it is on its last leg (cheep). Also, the sealing system for the lid has what appears to be a adhesive type of seal. So far it seems to be OK: it just doesn't seem like a good system. I have no problem with the grind, however, I use only a medium setting.
The noise level is far from pleasing although not as bad as other grinders.
I am happy with my purchase of the Bodum and would recommend it to others. The primary test will be to see if I get several years of service from the unit.
Ed A

I had an inexpensive burr grinder that required you to hold a button during the entire grinding process. A drag. On a normal last-minute-to-the-office weekday morning I use pre-ground coffee, but I wanted something to conveniently enjoy fresh-ground coffee on weekends or entertaining, and although I've only used it for a couple of weeks, the Bodum seems like a great choice. I like the glass container for the grounds, and that its rubber top just fits snugly under the discharge chute so there are no clips or catches to fail or wear out. The unit is fairly quiet, and although I only grind a few scoops at a time, the hopper seems large enough for most non-commercial needs. There has been some discussion in other reviews about the 20-second limit on grinding time to prevent over-heating of the motor. In 20 seconds it doesn't quite finish grinding two rounded scoops. I just push the button again to let it do the additional 5 to 10 seconds of grinding and then stop it. My rationale is that 20 seconds is not a hard number and that it probably has some safety margin built in, and actual heating will vary with the ambient room temperature and how fine of a grind it's set for. (I use a medium grind for a drip coffee maker.) I would not use this approach to grind a significant quantity, but if you're going to the trouble of grinding fresh beans, you're probably not going to grind a whole lot in advance anyway.
The hopper comes off easily to expose the grinding mechanism, and I can see a difference in fineness between one grind setting the the next.

Nice grinder. Very adjustable (fine to coarse). It's much easier (and more expen$ive) than the cheaper propeller grinders. Love the timer - I get just the right amount of ground coffee for espresso every time. Love the bean storage. Really nice - I know it's more expensive than other types, but treat yourself to this grinder - it's great.

I have had this grinder for several months and still think it is great. The only down side is that the directions say to only run it once every 5 minutes. On the setting that grinds the most in one cycle I only get enough for a double espresso. I keep the grinder on the second from the smallest grind for espresso and I don't know if that produces less grinds because it has to grind each bean longer. Over all I think this is a good grinder, much, MUCH, better than the spinning blade grinder that it replaced. The grinder is an important piece to the coffee puzzle that people tend to over-look.

seems like a decent grinder but the catch basin is poorly designed it doesn't seal well and as you remove it grounds get everywhere. ive thrown out the plastic catch basin and just hold up a small mason jar which seems to mitigate things. just got it a weeks ago so i cant speak to its longtrem durability.
This is a sweet little coffee grinder. It works very well each and every day. I've given same to my son, and he too puts it through its paces every morning. Good purchase, happy camper.

reviews.reviewTitle: Cone Burr Grinder makes good grinds
reviews.reviewText:
Excellent burr grinder. Good variety for different settings and instructions are built into the lid. However the hopper is a little too small and wouldn't fully close with the different bags of coffee I've used. My old Cuisinart one held all the beans just fine.

I also am surprised by the static build up of the grinds because I thought the glass container was supposed to prevent that.

reviews.reviewTitle: the perfect grinder, and affordable too!
reviews.reviewText: Fancier burr grinders are so expensive, and not necessary. This works perfectly, and I love that the controls aren't digital. They're straightforward, and settings aren't lost when the power goes out. I also love the round grind cup. I've used burr grinders with square/rectangle cups to catch your ground coffee, and they're a regular pain to clean

We've had a few other coffee bean grinders in the past and this one tops them all. It's quiet, doesn't have much static and the variable grinds are perfect for us. We have a French press which we use on the weekends, and the grind for that had to be adjusted back a little (finer) as we like our coffee dark and rich. The setting indicator for the French press on the grinder was too coarse. But other than that, we love it. And beans don't get stuck in the hopper! Yeah!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for both the espresso maker and the drip coffee ...
reviews.reviewText: Great for both the espresso maker and the drip coffee maker. Only downside is not being able to remove the hopper or easily switch beans, but then if you'll be using different varieties you can add only the amount you need to grind.

Cuisinart broke second time in a year and a half. I took opportunity to look at options. Cuisinart was very loud, plastic parts created static electricity, which spread grounds all over, and most important did not make consistent grounds ...
Bodum looks great, has a glass, cylindrical ground container, is much less noisy, and most important, makes consistent grounds that make a noticeable difference in my press-pot brewed Peet's coffee. I could not be happier.

reviews.reviewTitle: The product works great. I only gave it 4 starts because I ...
reviews.reviewText: The product works great. I only gave it 4 starts because I expected it to be bigger, the grounds kinda get all over the place after taking the colander in and out, and it’s a different shade of white from the Bodum electric kettle I had. Partially my fault for assuming things. Overall, great product so far.

I ordered this on Sunday with the free shipping option. The expected delivery date was Thursday. It arrived on Thursday. I was impressed by how much quieter it is than my previous blade grinders. Its coarsest grind setting is finer than I would have liked. It does give a consistant grind. Other reviewers have complained that it leaves a mess when removing the ground coffee recepticle. It does drop some grounds. This can be eliminated by giving the grinder a gentle tap before removing the recepticle. You must be smarter than the grinder. Overall... pleased with purchase.

Great burr grinder. Easy to use. Don't understand the "flimsy" comments about the receptacle - it's glass folks. Only reason not getting a 5 is that it makes a little bit of mess, no problem unless you're a bit ocd.

reviews.reviewTitle: Would be 5-star but for misleading description.
reviews.reviewText:
Works well and produces very consistent grinds.

I would give it 5 stars except that they seem to outright lie about the glass container for the ground coffee. It is clearly some kind of plastic by feel and the sound of tapping it and it captures a lot of the ground coffee with static.

That being said, I still think it is a great product and was delighted with the price.

We have used this every day for five years and have never had an issue. I am careful to not exceed the 20 seconds without a rest. I use it for drip, chemex, and french press settings with great results.

I got this to make the occasional pot of coffee and store whole beans. I usually grind for about 15 seconds to make enough for my drip coffeemaker -- the timer runs to 20 seconds. The little glass jar that's supposed to be static free seems OK although some tiny amount of grounds usually stick to it anyway. It's fairly noisy when running, but not as bad as the VitaMix blender on high.
I've had occasion to clean it top to bottom, and no worries, it's easy to take apart and put together.
If you do a pot a day, this guy should be able to keep up.

I think is a very good home grinder for espresso machines. For me, the finest grind setting produces too fine grind for my espresso machine (i use Francis! Francis X5), so I use 1 or 2 dots coarser setting for my latte. 20 second timer setting produces a little bit less coffee than what I need to make 2 double shot. I usually grind for 20 seconds, make my first double shot, then grind again for 5 seconds, and make my seconds double shot. So far it worked fine for me.
The consistence of the grind appears to be good and comparable to what commercial "Magister" brand grinders produce. I think its an excellent grinder for home if you make just a couple of cups of espresso/cappuccino at a time.

I drink espresso, drip, and use a french press, depending on my mood. This grinder gives a perfect grind (consistency of size) for whatever I select. Moreover, I find that I use about 1/4 to 1/3 less coffee for my french press than was needed previously with my blade grinder to achieve the same intensity of flavor. (I can't say for drip and espresso since they are newly acquired home-brewing habits). Marvelous little machine! Seems really well-built. Regarding some of its quirks, the opaque instructions say to allow a 5 minute cool time in between 20 second grinds. On the rare occasions when I have needed more than 20 seconds of grind time, I have only allowed about 30 seconds of cool time, and based on smell and heat generated, I very seriously doubt I am putting the motor at any risk. (Surely 5 minutes is an "ideal" recommendation that puts the manufacturer at minimal risk of customer problems). Also, the directions insist that the grinder be running when adjustments to the fineness/coarseness are made. This is totally counter-intuitive and so I don't do it. I usually have it "on" with no beans in the hopper, but do not have it running. I have experienced no problems over about one month of use. In short, I have zero complaints about performance, although I might question the true necessity of some of the "rules" of operation mentioned in the instructions, although only time will tell in this regard. Now that I have used a quality burr grinder, I would never go back to a blade grinder. If you buy this machine you will enjoy sipping a quality brew and I believe you will have few if any regrets. Best wishes to you.
This item held up for about 3 months and then just would not work properly. Grinds became uneven and had to grind multiple times just to get enough to brew a pot of coffee.

Purchased this a few years back. Has been consistent with the grind and we grind 3-4 espresso cups a day. Every so often, you have to take it apart to clean it out otherwise it does get jammed up. Recently, the timer stopped being consistent. I had it set to 15 seconds and it would only run for 5-10. Took it apart to clean and it was still causing problems. E-mailed Bodum to ask what they thought and they quickly send me a new burr piece for free. Great customer service. Would definitely recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wow, what a fantastic upgrade in my morning routine!
reviews.reviewText: I finally decided to step up from my old slice-o-matic style coffee grinder, and I'm so happy I did! This Bodum Bistro crushes the beans consistently well, and it makes my stove top espresso coffee (Moka pot) finally taste like it should. The coffee now is much richer tasting even when I am using medium roasted beans. I should have switched over long ago.

This item is working well so far, but not as flawlessly as I expected. Here are a few minor gripes.

The size of the grinds are not as consistent as I was expecting. I've adjusted to a coarse grind, but still get some sludge in the bottom of my coffee cup! I can tell just by looking at the grinds that the size is not uniform. This is probably the biggest disappointment.

The special glass container does not eliminate static completely. It is a vast improvement over other materials, but some grinds do cling to the sides. This is not a big deal, just an observation.

Grinds continue to fall out of the grinder after the glass container is removed. I tried tapping the machine on the counter to get any loose grinds to fall into the container, but that didn't always work, and it is not something I want to have to keep doing. After dumping the grinds into my filter, there will be grinds on the platform and countertop by the time I return the container to its spot. So to fix this, I put another small cup in that spot to catch the random flakes whenever I remove the glass container.

The instructions are sparse. It's easy to use once you know how. I recommend watching a video review before using it for the first time.

Overall, I'm glad I bought it. For this price, it does a much better job than previous, more expensive, grinders. The noise level is not uncomfortable. The volume and timer restrictions are not a problem for me, since I only have a 2 cups a day habit.

------------------------------------

update: 12/06/2011

I still use this every day and it works great. The static problem seems to get worse over time but I've gotten used to it. The lid to the container that catches the grinds is now loose and comes right off. I don't know why or when that happened. As long as the coffee tastes good, I'm happy.

reviews.reviewTitle: BUYER BEWARE!!! Read thru the reviews carefully.
reviews.reviewText: What I thought was a good burr grinder turned out NOT SO GOOD! The base of the machine deteriorates over time and has become sticky and unsightly. Would recommend you BUY ANOTHER BRAND. This is awkward to clean and the machine does make quite a mess. Loved the way the coffee tasted when brewed however the machine is not durable. The company is aware of the inferior materials but would not replace the unit. Made me jump thru hoops with customer service to no avail. Waste of time, waste of hard earned money.

This is a must have for any serious coffee drinker.. Perfect grind every time. No need to buy more expensive grinders when this one performs perfectly and is built solid enough to handle all the coffee I put through it without blinking.. I've had it for roughly 2 years now and should have reviewed it a long time before but coming back now to review it I feel justified in saying that this is a quality piece of hardware that I suspect will last me many years to come.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked great for 2 years but now dead
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this product in July 2011 and it worked perfectly until this morning. As others have noted, there is some static and you have to shake the grinder or you'll end up with a build-up of dust. The dust doesn't hurt anything and comes out with the next grind but this adds stale coffee to what you just ground so gentle shaking was part of my daily ritual. The grind was consistent enough for my espresso maker and my french press; although, I did get a lot of sludge with the french press. I never found that to be a serious issue and you can always shake your grinds through a fine strainer if this bothers you.

Unfortunately, my unit is now useless. The burr still turns; however, there is a distinct sound of grating plastic when the unit runs. I've never liked that the grinding chamber has plastic components and it looks like one of those components finally failed. After unscrewing the base of the unit and gently pulling the unit apart about 3 inches (too many wires to completely disassemble just for a quick look), a few ground off plastic pieces fell out. After reassembly, same grating plastic sound so I guess that's it for this Bodum.

Overall, I'm pretty disappointed that this didn't last longer. I really liked this coffee grinder and took good care of it. Apart from the daily shake, this unit sat in the same place, was never dropped or damaged, wasn't used beyond the 20 second limit, and was cleaned fairly regularly. Had Bodum used metal components in the grind chamber, I think this unit would have continued working for many more years. As I said, I liked this unit and would rate it 4 stars for performance and value if only it lasted longer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect for every method outside of Espresso
reviews.reviewText:
Been using this grinder daily for just over a year and it still functions perfectly. My primary method is using the Aeropress and this grinder is perfect for this application. Works excellently for press pots and pour overs as well.

I don't make use of the timer function, simply weighing the coffee I use prior to each use. I never store beans in it either. Never encountered any issues with it over heating or jamming. I think 3 times in the year I've used it it stopped mid grind on the press pot setting. A simple twist of the grind setting unlocked it easily in each case.

While the price of this has come up over the last year it's still the best value on the market. Can't speak much to is espresso abilities but it's great for all other applications.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is a great grinder. The grind is easy to adjust
reviews.reviewText: This is a great grinder. The grind is easy to adjust, the reservoir holds ample beans, and it has a timer to set how long to grind for, and the price is right. Everything about this grinder is awesome. The grinder timer is really easy to tune in to how long you want the beans ground for. Set and forget, assuming you use the same grind/amount of coffee every time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grind button stopped working after 4 uses
reviews.reviewText: I ordered this coffee grinder few weeks ago and I only used it 3-4 times before it completely stopped working. When it arrived, the grind button was already hard to press but I thought it was meant to be like that. Now I tried to press it as hard as I can, but nothing happened. Very disappointing because the design and aesthetics were pleasant. Also considering the hefty price tag, I was genuinely hoping for a better quality.

This is an incredible grinder. It really improved the coffee I am making in my Keurig refillable K cups. Using the middle setting for drip coffee, the coffee is excellent and no mud left in the bottom of the cup like my prior cheap grinder. It might cost a bit more than some other grinders but worth every penny.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder until the burr goes dull!
reviews.reviewText:
After months of searching and pining over a burr grinder I decided to purchase the Bodum Bistro Grinder based upon it's reviews as well as the overall reviews of Bodum as a company. Right out of the box I loved the grinder. Having the ability to switch between coarse and fine grinding (although I usually stick with coarse as I mainly drink french press).

Then the problems started: After approximately 3 months of being used every other day or say, the grinder stopped grinding coarsely. After calling and speaking with a Bodum customer service representative they explained the part can go dull and needs to be replaced. I was then shipped a new part and was back in business! Unfortunately, less than 3 months after receiving the replacement part, the coarse grinding has faded back to fine and I'm due for a new part (number 3 for those of you counting).

I really enjoy this grinder, but having to call and ask for a new grinder part every 3 months is quite the annoyance. For those of you are looking to use it mainly for coarse grinding, beware, you'll be calling for replacements quite often.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinder worked great for 6 months and breaks
reviews.reviewText:
I bought the grinder along with the coffee maker as a set. The grinder worked well for about 6 months and started to get louder and louder and grind less and less. I suspect the plastic gears (as other low start reviewers have pointed out died) finally it no longer grinds anything. So I contact Bodum for a replacement under their warranty and that is of course a nightmare. I finally get a response from Bodum who tell me that they are "committed" to the quality of their products but will not honor the warranty because its not through their authorized dealer. But they "thank" me for me business. They then glibly offer me 25% off of a new purchase! What a joke, why would I want to buy a single thing from Bodum again.

Anyone looking to buy, be warned about this product's poor quality and their poor customer service. Never again Bodum.

Robert

reviews.reviewTitle: The low price for a burr grinder scared me initially ...
reviews.reviewText: The low price for a burr grinder scared me initially. Also because I grind a precise amount of beans for my method of making a single cup of coffee each morning, the hopper also concerned me. After dialing in the timer, I actually think I prefer this to my previous grinders. It's not ever going to land on some "best grinder" list but if you are grinding on a daily basis this is still more than adequate for the average person and it doesn't look too band on the countertop.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does the job but lacks stability
reviews.reviewText: This unit is not very stable. I have to push it down a bit while grinding. If it wobbles it shuts off early and won't let you grind more for a while. I do like the glass jar for the ground coffee-- no static to hold the grinds. And it does a good enough job grinding. Don't pay much attention to where "drip" and "espresso" and "french press" are marked... just experiment to find out what works for you and your coffee pot.

The first grinder I received was defective--sometimes it would grind when I pressed the button and sometimes I'd have to press 10-20 times before it would grind. I contacted Bodum customer service via email and they sent me a new one right away. The new grinder works perfectly and I'm pleasantly surprised to have such a hassle free return.

I love this grinder much more than my old blade based one--it is less messy and the quality is better. I use it with my Hario pour over drip coffee maker and it is great!

Love it love it, I use it daily!

Consistent grind size. Does not throw grinds all over the place due to static as is problem with most other grinders in market.
Grinding surface/teeth are steel.

The only way I can think of making it better is to have darker hopper (coffee don't like light and air/moisture) and steel grind jar ( remove the tiniest bit of static left).

French press grind is consistent. The glass container is great - easy to pour and leaves virtually nothing behind. Main concern is the overall feeling of being very light weight, but it does stand put on the counter.

I had my Starbucks Barista grinder for 10 years but it was clogging way to often. First I tried the Capresso 560.04. It was quiet but the static electricity made it unmanageable. Then I tried the Cuisinart CBM-18N. Very noisy and messy. The Bodum's noise level is probably between the Capresso and Cuisinart but there is no mess. It also appears to be a better made machine than the first two. I'm pleased (as I'm sure Amazon is) that I don't have to return another grinder.

Just as a point of information. I just grind for a filter drip maker so I can provide no feedback for espresso or Turkish coffee.

Nice Grinder, looks nice and works well. Four stars because it does make a bit of a mess, not much though. When I pull out the glass jar some coffee grinds fall out. I simply wipe them off the counter. I enjoy this grinder. Because I travel I recently purchased the Mr Coffee Burr Grinder. It does not look as sharp but does create less mess. I like the price better. If you want to leave it out the Bodum has a nicer counter top appeal. Both work very well.
Love this burr grinder. We use it 5 days each week for the past 2 years and it is running like new. It's simple to adjust the grind to make the perfect cup of coffee.

After just 6 months I found that this grinder consistently stops grinding and has to be emptied of beans and cleaned. It has a feature that is designed to stop grinding when it encounters a stone but in fact it stops grinding when there are just beans in the hopper. I would not recommend this machine. It has a one-year warranty but my complaints to customer service have gone unanswered. Amazon sold it to me - they were no help but I am shipping it back to them anyways.

reviews.reviewTitle: Jammed, can't get it operating well again
reviews.reviewText: Worked fine for a while, then it started jamming. Cleaned it all out as well as i possibly could but now it only grinds on the coarse setting. Nothing in the medium to fine range will work. No idea how to get it open or clean it so I'm kind of stuck. I would just spend the extra money on a nicer grinder...

This bad boy is great! Bought to replace my little krups grinder and could not be happier. My wife and I switch between drip and french press coffee and this grinder is perfect for it.

There are some more expensive grinders out there, but this one does exactly what I expected.

I've had this Bodum Bistro burr grinder for a couple of months now, and I've used it every day. I like it. I've always indulged myself with a good cup of coffee in the morning. I've wanted to upgrade to a burr grinder for awhile and after reading reviews on the variety found here, took the plunge and bought this one.

I've found that 1 'click' coarser than the medium setting grinds the dark roast coffee beans that I typically buy just about right for my needs. The resulting grind is relatively uniform and superior to the 'boulders and dust' produced by blade grinders. The few specks of grounds that do wind up on my counter top are minor compared to my retired but trusty 25yr old Krups blade grinder, or the Cuisinart Grind Central grinder, which I find is better used as a door stop... (sorry!).

Lots of the reviews here complain about the 20 second limit. I've found that this isn't a problem for me. In that amount of time, it grinds 4+ rounded 2 Tbs scoops of coffee, or enough for 8 'cups' of coffee. If I'm making a bigger pot of coffee, first I grind one 20 second batch of beans. I typically wash out my pot in the morning (some friends have commented that I am a little anal about that exercise), but that coincidentally takes about 5 minutes... just about enough time to grind a second smaller batch for the rest of the coffee that I need for a bigger pot of brew. So, the 20 seconds thing, not a problem for me.

The minor complaint... bottom of the glass beaker that catches the grounds which originally came with this unit was paper thin, and after a couple of weeks, a 1/2" almost perfectly round glass 'blank' popped out of the center of the bottom in the process of cleaning - an aparent manufacruring defect. Thanks to great Amazon customer service, a replacement grinder was out to me quickly and sits handsomly on my countertop. Excellent service provided and overall the Bodum Bistro burr grinder a good value to me.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder
reviews.reviewText: This is a very high quality coffee grinder. It grinds evenly, quickly, and quietly. Unlike my previous two grinders (over a 15+ year period), it does not generate static electricity and scatter finely ground coffee around the counter. It's also easy to clean; dis-assembly of the grinding burr is simple and fast. I'm totally satisfied with this product. -- As a matter of fact, I like this grinder so much that after a few months I bought another one -- for our summer camp where I can run it off our solar panel. The Bodum Burr Coffee Grinder is a very good product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Motor Failed after Less than 2 Years
reviews.reviewText: Like many other reviewers, the motor in my machine gave out as well. Used once a week. Very disappointing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Most annoying thing about the Cuisinart was that you had to ...
reviews.reviewText: My comparison is from the Cuisinart grinder this is replacing. Most annoying thing about the Cuisinart was that you had to bang it on a table, because of static, to get the coffee mostly out. The glass catcher does have a little static, but nothing like the plastic one in the Cuisinart. Makes a little bit of a mess too, but not bad. Daily use is a joy - set dial at 20, turn on, push start button, finishes grinding fairly quickly, pour into filter, start brewing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Picture on the box of how the burrs go in the grinder is upside down.
reviews.reviewText: Nice little grinder, just wish it came assembled. Didn’t work out of box and then found one of the birds loose in packaging. Seems it should have just popped in but I struggled with it for a while.
this thing is a dream!...its the other part that has made my mornings the best part of the day. Once in awhile, you have to clean, as it accumulates small deposits of coffee, but, love it!!..
Works when IT wants to...

Great burr grinder. Only downside is that the rumble can be a little loud early in the morning, but its still quieter than most grinders. It would be nice if there was an image of a aeropress on the grind settings as well. Also, the preset times of 5, 10, 15secs etc is hard to gauge when grinding. I always either choose too little or too long of a grind. Also, don't forget to replace the container before grinding again. I've messed up and had coffee grinds all over my counter.

This coffee grinder is easy to use and delivers a consistent grind. The only two things it gets a minor ding for are the limit on the grind, and the adjustment settings. The 20-second limit is perfect for me since I am almost always brewing for two, but when I need to grind more in one sitting, it can be annoying to wait so that I don't burn out the motor. I'm also not a big fan of adjusting the grind by twisting the top. I switch between french press (coarse grind) and espresso grind sometimes. The instructions state that you should not change the setting unless the grinder is actively working, but I do it anyway (no catastrophes so far). Otherwise, I'm not sure how you would get the grind exactly where you want it to be in time for it not to affect your grind (e.g. coarse grounds in your espresso grind).

I was disappointed.
Cons:
1. Leaks everywhere, on the collecting glass cup and some where in the middle of the grinder
2. I put 2 paper towels underneath it to catch the ground
3. It is only good for up to 10 cups, 20 sec grind per my preference
Pros:
1. It is still working
2. Looks OK

Please give me some advice to stop the leakage. It is pretty annoying!

We changed from our old coffee grinder that we had been using for years to get a white Bodum. Supposed to be good quality. It's not. Three months out, it stopped grinding. That's after grinding beans for two cups of coffee each day. NOTE the return policy. They know how long it will last - just over 90 days. It's a piece of junk.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best burr grinder for the price.
reviews.reviewText: Our old Bodum grinder died after 4 years of daily use. The new one is much quieter and grinds faster. We still can't grind a full pot's worth of coffee with one push off the button but that's a minor inconvenience. That's why I'm not giving it the full 5 stars.

This one works pretty well if you don't need espresso grind. On ( or near) the espresso setting, it "skips" more than it grinds. And the skipping noise is louder and worse than the grind noise
UPDATE: It doesn't work at all anymore after a few months. Motor and grinder not powerful enough and it just stopped grinding. Disappointing product. Save your $$
It lasted less than 3 months and is now in the trash

Gifted this for xmas and my sister finally got around to using it. It was DOA out of the box and the return window is closed. Looks
Like I’m out $50 for the original and $50 for a replacement. Very disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Burr Grinder in a small package!
reviews.reviewText: Absolutely love this burr coffee grinder. It has a small footprint, modern looking design and has a wonderful glass catch that helps eliminate the static coffee grinds that usually get all over when we use to grind our coffee in the plastic catch our old grinder had. Large capacity hopper for the coffee beans too! Don't hesitate to buy this if you're looking for a great little burr grinder!

I actually bought this grinder 6 years ago, and just came back to the listing because I broke the glass piece and needed a replacement (Bodum sells these for $9- thank goodness!). I love this grinder- I've been using it almost every day since we got it. It's a great reasonably priced option!

It was great while it worked. The plastic gears finally gave up today and ground themselves to dust a little over a year after I bought it. I thought Bodum would be better than this. Is there any company out there that doesn't rebrand cheap plastic Chinese crap? For the price, this should have lasted far longer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great design and value for the price
reviews.reviewText:
This is my fourth time buying this grinder. The reason i buy so many is that i take it on trips with me (out of the country) and i usually fry it. Then i have to buy i new one when i get back to the states. Now i have one for European plugs and one for the US.

Point is: I can't do without it. I am serious about coffee drinking and the grind makes all the difference.

Great design and value for the price. <3

This is a hard one to write. i love the coffee that this grinder produces - the flavor is perfect and the smell is divine. However, this is the second of these grinders I have bought in the last three months. The first one lasted about two months, then failed to grind any more coffee. Lots of noise and no action. The second of the same model, which I ordered a few weeks ago, broke within the week after I bought it. This is not a cheap grinder, but it surely is a piece of crap in working properly. I will not buy another one.

The instructions for this grinder are lacking as a potential shortcoming to any buyer who has never purchased a burr grinder. I still rated it 5 stars because the quality of the grinder, and grind makes up for the instructions. I have had previous experience with this type of grinder so the instructions did not throw a curve ball to me. The quality, and consistency of the grind is fantastic. Static is kept in check with the glass receptacle. I would definitely purchase this again if someone I know needs a grinder for a b-day gift. Enjoy!

One of the best purchases I have ever made for myself. The grinder does an excellent job. There is some static build up when you use the glass container to catch the grinds. I have found that I can avoid this problem if I just grind directly into my coffee filter. I have a gold foil filter basket that I use and there is no static build up. I have also used a paper cone filter without any static building up either.

This product worked really well for about 18 months. We used it probably 4 days a week. After that, the grinder slowed down. It now will only grid coarse, good for cold brew, but unable to make espresso. My husband took it apart, cleaned it, and put it back together, and no change Pretty disappointing considering it cost so much. I think I'll look for a lower priced item, for my next grinder.

love it. It's small and perfect for grinding enough for 1 cup pour through or 5 cup brewer. I use the former method because mr coffee type brewers make terrible, bitter coffee and therefore is not worthy of fresh ground beans

Pro: Quiet, fast (for a burr), cheap (for a burr), fights static nicely and it's attractive
Con: Not good for Espresso and Turkish grinds, 20-second on/5-minute off cycle

My wife are generally happy with the purchase. The only cons do not impact us though it would be nice to be able to grind for Turkish.

There is a 20-second limit on the motor before you should let the grinder cool down for 5-minutes. Fine by me (so far) but I can see where that may be a drag if you have to make several pots for company.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... coffee grinder I found this Bodum to be a delight. It is fairly quiet and will grind to ...
reviews.reviewText: Having a previous experience with a very noisy Burr coffee grinder I found this Bodum to be a delight. It is fairly quiet and will grind to perfection my 6 scoops of beans within 12 seconds. I love the design, the ease of cleaning it and especially the GLASS jar, which practically eliminates the grounds from sticking to the jar, unlike plastic containers. I think it's awesome!!

I love this grinder. It is so much easier than the way I used to grind my coffee, with a small Krups; the type with the spinning blade in a reservoir on top. This grinder yields very consistent sized grounds and stays very clean. The low static of the glass cup means the ground coffee stays where you want it, in the cup until you take it out. I can grind coffee every day for months before I clean up the counter around it (not that I'm a slob but that it doesn't make a mess).

I also like the size of the coffee reservoir on top. I only need to fill it about once a week. Each morning I flip the on switch and hit the button. 15 seconds later I have fresh ground coffee for my 32 oz bodum stainless french press. Easy and delicious.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best burr grinder we've ever owned!
reviews.reviewText: Works way better than the last burr grinder we had which had so much static in it after grinding you got coffee everywhere!! This has barely noticeable static and the coffee feeds perfectly!

A nicely designed, convenient, strong burr grinder. The main limitation of the grinder is the small output jar and warning to let the motor cool after using for 20 seconds. Unless you want to spend a lot more money, this is a very fair compromise. 20 seconds is enough to prepare a small carafe of drip coffee. We keep some beans stashed in the large hopper, and grind beans in the morning. It's the best thing you can do to improve the morning cup of joe; more important that your choice of coffeemaker. (we usually use drip Melitta cones.)
BEST, reasonable, burr coffee bean grinder. It's our second one, we wore the first one out with use and replaced it with the exact same one. It grinds a FINE grind beautifully and is dependable.

This has been a reliable kitchen servant for me. I received it as a gift over three years ago and it is still running well. There is some service you need to do occasionally: the grind area will build up a residue, so it needs to be cleaned now and then. Also, the hopper will get oily so it is good to give that a scrub now and then to keep it looking clean. I really like the little glass jar, one improvement would be adding a spout since i dump my coffee right into my Aeropress, i don't spoon it. One annoyance is the hopper lid having a bit of a rim: when i push the grinder back again the wall, the lid hits first and often pops off.
Overall, an excellent grinder with minimal mess.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is our first burr grinder and it's fantastic. We went out of town for Thanksgiving and ...
reviews.reviewText: This is our first burr grinder and it's fantastic. We went out of town for Thanksgiving and took it with us along with our french press so we could have delicious fresh coffee. For anyone wanting fresh ground coffee this is the grinder for you. We have it set for 12 seconds on the coarsest grind. Packed up our old coffee maker, got more counter space, and now have better coffee than those chain coffee drive thrus.

So far so good! This grinder replaced one I already had. The Bodum is much quieter, I'm happy to say. It grinds quickly. It's a bit messy when pulling the canister out after grinding but I'm not sure there's any grinder that doesn't have that problem. All-in-all, I like it and am glad I chose this particular brand.

Have had this grinder for approximately one year. Unfortunately, the outside got extremely sticky and would not come clean with water, soap, or vinegar. Additionally, it just completely stopped working.

Expected a better design and more durable product for the price point. Would not purchase again.

reviews.reviewTitle: For pour overs especially you'll get a wonderful, even grind
reviews.reviewText:
If you're a coffee snob you need this grinder. For pour overs especially you'll get a wonderful, even grind.

I've owned two of these, and notice they tend to jam a bit at first but eventually that stops happening.

I've owned the Bodum Bistro for several weeks and I'm very pleased with this purchase. I owned a Cuisinart electric burr grinder that lasted longer than I anticipated but provided very poor performance... inconsistent grinds, made a huge mess... I was glad when it died. I did quite a bit of research before this purchase and it definitely paid off. The motor is quiet, the process is clean and produces a very consistent grind. My coffee and espresso's are significantly better. I use a French press, stovetop moka and an electric espresso machine. Grind settings are easy to change and I've had excellent results using these brewing devices. I'd recommend this to anybody who wants an affordable, high quality electric burr grinder.

As a burr grinder alone I'd give it 4 stars, there are certainly better products out there, but the value is superb... this holds its own with $300 grinders and is elegant and highly functional to boot. A very well designed and executed product. Overall, 5 stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinding at a whole nother level!
reviews.reviewText: Wow is this thing a coffee eating machine! Giant tank for holding beans. Not super quiet but not insanely loud either. Dies a great job with grinding. Really nice aesthetics. Nice looking machine. Recommend

Like the machine but bought it used at a reasonable price ...I thought. However, the vendor did not disclose the timer button was broken. Not that I used that feature much but decided to use it one day several weeks after the purchase and discovered it was broken. Not sure what to do since I have had it for several weeks and been traveling for work, which has not helped to follow up

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked Great - then quit after 5 months.
reviews.reviewText:
Worked great...for about 5 months.
Grind was good, used daily and couldn't complain. Until the day it stopped mid-grind. I can't believe that it didn't even work for 6 months. Will buy a better model for more money.

Best price for a burr mill of this quality .. nice design.. if you keep it clean it won't let you down .. the finer settings can wear in and become too close but if you hear it bind or stale. Simple dial back the grind size and Resume.. not too loud..glass catch is best part and truly an upgrade from plastic

I love this grinder! Very consistent grind and easy to setup and use. I was very reluctant to buy a conical burr grinder because of the price so I was using a hand grinder. I found myself using the hand grinder everyday so I splurged and got this one. Most conical burr grinders are crazy expensive, this one was one of the few under $100.

reviews.reviewTitle: We purchased this grinder 6 months ago, it worked ...
reviews.reviewText:
We purchased this grinder 6 months ago, it worked perfectly for 5 months - then the grinder started getting stopped up. We have cleaned the coffee out of the grinding mechanisim several times yet the coffee continually gets caught in the grinder and will not release into the glass container below.
Do not purchase this product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Could not be happier with the Bodum Electric Burr Coffee Grinder
reviews.reviewText: Could not be happier with the Bodum Electric Burr Coffee Grinder. This is our second one. The first lasted over five years and was used daily with no problem. The coffee is always delicious with fresh ground coffee. Highly recommend this product.

I have researched several grinders and unless you are able to spend a great deal amount of money for one ($300 - $600), this grinder is the way to go. I use mine primarily for my automatic drip and it seems to work very well for this purpose. At first I was very skeptical; however, there is a HUGE difference in taste between a burr and a blade grinder. This grinder seems to grind the beans very consistently and appropriately for what I use it for. The burrs are some sort of metal (not ceramic), the collection container is glass (less static) and the overall quality of the machine appears to be in-line with its price. However, if you are in the market for a grinder that can handle espresso, I'm not sure this would be a sufficient product. My only 'complaint' is that it will only operate for 20 prior to turning off. Then, as others have mentioned, the manufacturer recommends that you wait 5 minutes prior to operating again. For me, this isn't a big deal because most of the time I am brewing just enough coffee for my wife and I (6-8 cups) and it seems to grind JUST enough.

We have been looking for an inexpensive burr grinder that wouldn't take over the countertop and this was the only one we saw that fit both requirements. It is compact and has an attractive non-slip outer skin. It is easy to clean, fully adjustable and delivers a consistent grind. The only drawback is that in order to give it a small foot-print, the motor is small so it can only grind for about 20-40 seconds before it has be allowed to cool. This is a minor quibble and we recommend this to anyone looking for a light-duty burr grinder.

Without a doubt the finest coffee grinder you can get. After years of chasing ground coffee all around my kitchen after grinding it...now with the Bodum grinding coffee is a pleasure. 98%+ ends up in the carafe and ground perfectly. I would buy this hands down...any other grinder would be money wasted.

The borosilicate container has far less static electricity, the hopper seals well, but the numbers on the grind size and the amount that is ground will require some testing for what is right for you. Very good for the money so far.

I wasn't sure at first that this was a good purchase but it was user error that caused my initial issues. I use the grinder for espresso, french press, and drip grinds and what I was doing wrong initially was putting the beans in and then trying to change the grind setting. You must change the grind setting before you put the beans in or it will jam. Since discovering this I have had no issues!

This is my second Bodum Burr grinder. Had the first one for about 7 years. It still works, I passed it along. There are videos available to help keep the grinder clean. It’s not hard once you see how it’s done. I do love my coffee.

While shopping for a new coffee maker, a very informative salesperson provided information on the advantages of a burr grinder. There didn't seem to be too many choices in my local stores so I went online and read the reviews. I was familiar with the Bodum brand in Europe and had some good experience with their french presses. I have been extremely pleased with the performance of this model. It grinds evenly and without much noise. The glass container is easy to clean and the coffee tastes better than before. I would purchase this again.

This grinder was awesome while it worked. However, after 2 weeks of use (and one week after my amazon return window closed), one of the parts broke. I e-mailed Bodum directly to ask for a replacement part and they said the part that broke was not under warranty. I have never seen a company not stand by their product like bodum in this situation. As much as I loved this product, I will no longer order form this company and encourage others to as well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do not buy for espresso. Waste of money.
reviews.reviewText: I'm extremely disappointed with this grinder. It's shoddy and rickety, and feels cheap. The fact that they market it as being able to grind to an espresso-level grind is a joke. If you buy this grinder for espresso, you have wasted your money as I did. Do not buy this and expect to get even a halfway a decent espresso grind. If you spend some more time and look at grinders meant for espresso (as I should have) you can see that this product doesn't stack up at all.

I loved this grinder for the first 10 months I had it. I recommended to everyone. But now suddenly it's begun making the same horrible grinding noise that other reviewers mention, and it stopped grinding. Naturally, it's too late to return. I'm now shopping for a new grinder, but it won't be a Bodum. :(

reviews.reviewTitle: a disappointment. I'm being very kind in giving it a ...
reviews.reviewText: very noisy and doesn't grind large enough for a French Press. When set on the largest grind, it shakes itself so much the bin on top shakes itself off so you have to stand there and hold it in place. Very noisy and a lot of static cling! It has a timer that turns it off which means you have to know how much it grinds in how much time - very awkward. I grind several days worth because of the mess so the timer doesn't work well, nor does the small hopper. Overall, a disappointment. I'm being very kind in giving it a three.

This grinder is a piece of junk. Worked ok for a couple of weeks then I had to hold the bin in place when it was grinding because it was moving all over the place. Just today it made a loud grinding noise and quit completely. About a week after my return deadline!! I have to throw it out. No more such purchases from Amazon by me ever!
Ok for price. Good even grind. Large hopper but small container fro ground coffee. Have to make two batches for 10 cup pot. Leaves lots of grounds on counter.

We've recently started grinding our own coffee. After a lot of research and review reading we decided on this one. We mainly use the coarse setting (french press) and it works great. Been using it every day for a few months now.
I love this I use it every day! It is a little hard to clean

Awesome. Small & powerful grinder. The top cover could use better material to resist dirt.

Update: Work exceptionally well after 1 year. The plastic material (cover, body) is terrible. It’ll be 5 star if they are stainless steel or dirt-resistant material.

We loved how the grinder makes the coffee taste. The grinder broke a little before owning it for the 2nd year. Bodum has a two year warranty on this grinder. My fiancé tried to call and email bodum, they did not return his emails or phone calls. What a bummer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grinder but still has static
reviews.reviewText: We haven't explored the various grinds much yet, but for everyday coffee in our regular maker the taste is very good compared to our old non-burr grinder. My only/biggest complain so far is that the "anti-static" coating really doesn't make it anti-static at all. The grounds still stick to the inside of the container and fly all over the place. Maybe it's better than other grinders in this respect (I have no basis for comparison), but I can definitely say that static exists.

I got this a bit under a year ago. Overall I am happy with it. It looks cool, is easy to use and consistently grinds my beans. Feedback on it would be that it is a bit noisy and I have found that it is hard to THOROUGHLY clean on the inside. I have also found some grinds no not always fall out until the grinder is picked up and shook around.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Encore is a far superior grinder.
reviews.reviewText: The timer is clunky and feels fairly cheap. The grind size isn't as consistent as I had hoped. After a year of owning the Bodum, I got rid of it and purchased a Barratza Encore. The Encore is a far superior grinder.

This is my everyday grinder and it works great. It is easy to adjust to different grind levels and produces very consistent grinds. The grinder runs on a timer so it takes some trial and error to get the right amount of coffee for your prefered brewing method. The collection jar seems to produce enough static that it makes the grounds stick to the glass. It would be five stars if it didn't have the static problem.

unfortunately, this burr grinder just doesn't work consistently. The first few months it was fine, and now there is zero consistency in the grinds. On the finest setting needed for espresso there are large pieces of bean mixed in with some fine grinds. On the coarser settings for French press, it's basically the same as the texture on the finer settings. If you make a lot of quality coffee in different methods, I would avoid this machine as it's becoming impossible to achieve the proper grind texture.

reviews.reviewTitle: The mess and noise level of 2 other disk burr ...
reviews.reviewText: The mess and noise level of 2 other disk burr grinders caused me to buy a hand conical grinder. This Bodum conical grinder is relatively quieter, cleaner, and more adjustible than previous electric grinders. I haven't used my hand grinder since I purchased this Bodum.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great unit! Quiet and low static
reviews.reviewText: I love this grinder! I've given it as a gift in addition to having one for myself. It is difficult to deal with the static issues with coffee grinders in general but this unit does it the best I've seen so far by using rubber and glass where appropriate. Also, it is much quieter than any coffee grinder I've ever used. You won't be disappointed!

Awesome grinder, grinds perfect for my espresso machine and french press. Just don't use a metal spoon and tap on the center of the glass. I was even using very gentle taps to loosen up the grounds in the corners. The other issue is if you do happen to break the glass, good luck buying a replacement on Bodums site they are always out of stock. I called Bodum to ask about the stock and was told they would be in stock in a week and its been over a week and they are still out of stock. So I just used some tape to cover the hole in the glass, so far the tap it keeping it all together. I am going to try and find a replacement at a local chemical supply store since the glass is just a beaker they over charge for.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... this for a bit and it has been working great. I would invest in some canned air if ...
reviews.reviewText: I have had this for a bit and it has been working great. I would invest in some canned air if you are using the fine setting. The shoot under the gears got clogged up. Once I had taken off the top part I could see the dust that had gathered. A few good shots of canned air once a week and it's been grinding like a champ. I am not sure if others would already know, but this was the first of this kind of grinder I've ever had.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awesome grinder. I like it being a conical burr ...
reviews.reviewText: Awesome grinder. I like it being a conical burr style as it is less noisy and the slower RPM is 'easier' on the bean. I like the grounds catch container being glass. I also like the sealing lid. Hopper holds 8-10oz and I use a sealed mason jar to store rest of beans. The grind is nicely adjustable and the grounds seem uniform. In 10 years from now, I'll buy another one.

reviews.reviewTitle: then it was like any other grinder with the grounds popping out onto ...
reviews.reviewText: Gave this to a friend and the button pushed through the housing in 6 months. It ground well while it worked but, the anti-static properties only worked for a week or so, then it was like any other grinder with the grounds popping out onto the counter.
My second one over the decades. Loved first one and happily ordered after years of use on first one.

Nice features, especially the timer and the two step turn on. It has a nice style and it doesn't look cheap. Occasionally the unit will not power up, but moving the burr setting allows the unit to start. Instructions could be more detailed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not too bad but have to hold top so it wont shut off or move from desired setting
reviews.reviewText: I have to hold the top (coffee containment) so it wont move out of the desired crush setting. Really annoying. So when i adjust for course grind itll turn off.

reviews.reviewTitle: three years isn't bad for $90 ( getting anything nowadays that last three ...
reviews.reviewText: NOT VERY DURABLE. The first of these lasted me three years before the burrs became ineffective. I use the grinder once, maybe twice a day. OK...three years isn't bad for $90 ( getting anything nowadays that last three years seems to be an accomplishment) so I replaced the the first unit with the same Bodum. The replacement lasted only 19 months before it died the same exact way the previous one did. The lifespan of the second unit was half of the first one I bought. Time to move on to another grinder that will hopefully last at least two years. Landfill....say hello to another Bodum

Seems good and fast. Easy to clean the cup.
***The reason for the ON/Off switch on the side is because it does Not have an interlocking switch for when you remove the cup. I hit the Start button and got grounds all over. I use that Switch now

I bought this grinder based on the great reviews on Amazon and other web sites. This cannot be the same machine the reviewers are talking about. I was replacing an old, inexpensive Cuisinart burr grinder. After many years of daily use and a motor that will run for as long as you need it, I felt like it was becoming a bit dull and thought the Bodum would be a good replacement. Although the Bodum is about the same size, the first thing I noticed was that it is half the weight of the old Cuisinart. I was eager to try it out, so I got out my beans, set the unit for french press and it immediately jammed. Had to remove the cone and the blade, make a big mess then resume. The second attempt produced an inconsistent grind, ranging from big chunks to fine powder. I moved the grind select a bit to the left of french press setting (finer) and it again jammed. Good bye Bodum and thank you Amazon for your effortless return policy.
Love it. But... it is not commercial grade so don't abuse it as such and it will last a long time. I like the fine turkish grind, and this grinder performs admirably.

Looks great, design wise, but sadly creates a mess every time it is used, and does not release all the ground coffee after the use.

To get the old grounds out you do not want to taint the flavor of your freshly ground coffee one has to slap this machine hard to clean it out.

Great look, poor functionality. Save your money for a machine that was designed better to be more effective.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect. Don't worry about the timer
reviews.reviewText: I'm a home roaster, I only make pour over coffee using a kalita wave dripper, I weigh my beans, I weigh my water, I'm a coffee snob. You should buy this grinder.
