The pros: Wide variety of grind sizes, from espresso to French press. Hopper holds a lot of beans.

The cons: It's noisy. No chance of letting the wife sleep in when this thing starts. The power light flickers. Not sure if that is a feature or if something is wrong. The plastic feels a bit cheap, but I have had no functional problems with it in 2 years.

Bottom line: I recommend this product. It works well, but one has to live with some quirks.
After three months of using this product, it works as advertised, no problems.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very time consuming to clear jams
reviews.reviewText: I've owned the Bodum for over a year. The coffee beans are ground very well, however the beans get caught in the grinder, and the jams are very time consuming to clear. You must disassemble the unit, and use a screwdriver to clear the pathway before it will resume operation. I wouldn't recommend this unit.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds fast and evenly, although noisily. Compact and ...
reviews.reviewText: Grinds fast and evenly, although noisily. Compact and light weight. Static leaves some grounds in the glass hopper, and more grounds spill on the countertop. You have to wipe off the outer surface frequently to get rid of coffee stains.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does the job, but super loud.
reviews.reviewText: So far so good. Grinds the beans evenly. Great grinder for the price, but beware that it's really loud.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice for the first year, problems with power switch...
reviews.reviewText: Very attractive appearance and worked great for the first year... But now the on/off switch is a bit finicky, have to jiggle it to get it to turn on.

I purchased this grinder to replace my electric blade unit. Overall I am very happy with the uniform grind the unit produces. I've had great success with both my drip coffee maker as well as my AeroPress. The style of unit is sleek, and passes the wife test. My only complaint with the unit is the recommended operating procedure. The instructions indicate to wait 5 MINUTES between each grind. Considering it takes 2.5 full cycles to grind enough coffee for my 12 cup pot, its quite unreasonable to wait 10 minutes to grind coffee. I've simply ignored that "recommendation" and run the cycles back to back. So far, so good, though I notice the unit is a little warm after use.

reviews.reviewTitle: she had been wanting a burr grinder for like 2 years and she quite enjoyed this one
reviews.reviewText: Purchased for my mom for Christmas, she had been wanting a burr grinder for like 2 years and she quite enjoyed this one, it produces a very consistent grind, is super adjustable, and is way quieter than my mom's previous blade grinder.

We've been using the grinder for a couple months now and really like it. Can't add anything beyond the reviews already posted here. Within a week of receiving the grinder, while using a metal measuring spoon to scoop ground coffee out of the glass "catcher", I punched a hole right through the bottom of it. Turns out the glass on the bottom is eggshell-thin (maybe thinner). This wasn't abuse IMHO, I was just scooping out coffee as anyone would do. Not sure if the catcher was defective or cracked but I suspect it was because the glass is needlessly thin. To make matters worse, it took a month to get a replacement catcher from Bodum due to the product being out of stock (we bought two just to have one in reserve). So, in summary, great grinder but be very gentle with the catcher.

reviews.reviewTitle: Outstanding grinder, and it has an on/off switch too!
reviews.reviewText:
Other reviews have accurately described this great grinder. No mess, works well with dark roasts that have caused problems with other grinders I have owned, the jar into which coffee grounds drop is easy to remove and fully empties every time. Not to mention its great design.

Another feature I really appreciate is that it has an on/off switch as well as a button to push when starting (or stopping) the grinding. This European feature means that in the 24 hours between grindings (if you flip the switch "off") there is no electricity being used to keep it on "standby". Yet it starts instantly, proving that there is absolutely no need for it to be on standby! I wish all small appliance manufacturers would include this feature, the waste really does add up.

I just upgraded from a Cuisinart DBM-8. I was hoping for better consistency and less static in the collector. What I got was a significantly better cup of coffee. That first sip was like being punched in the face with coffee goodness. The unit is small, simple and easy to clean. My wife even likes how it looks.

Highly recommended.

reviews.reviewTitle: My wife is amazed at how much she loves her coffee now
reviews.reviewText: After reading reviews about the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder, I bought one to grind coffee beans for my wife's coffee each morning. For upteen years I have fixed my wife coffee, using a $14 grinder to grind the coffee beans...until I bought the Bodum Burr Grinder. The first cup of coffee my wife tasted with beans ground using the Bodum burr coffee grinder shocked her. She was amazed at how much better the coffee tasted! Each successive cup has yielded the same emotion. I paid $80 for the grinder and I am delighted with the results. We didn't change anything else. She absolutely loves her morning coffee. Personally,I don't drink coffee but I love the smile on her face when she sips her coffee now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best purchase I've made this season
reviews.reviewText:
I was looking for a coffee grinder in my price range and was recommended this product. I've been trying to get into grinding my own coffee beans and brewing my own coffee instead of going out to a cafe.

It's a wise choice. This grinder gets the job done with no hassles. It's not loud, it adjusts how fine or coarse you want your grind, and it's rather easy to clean. Now, I get to enjoy better coffee for lower prices, and can choose what beans I'd like. For the price of the griner and beans? It's well worth it.

Worked well for awhile, but now having problems with the button you press to start it. Ordered replacement today. Hopefully it won't have the same problem. Other than that, good grinder and the glass definitely minimizes the static build up in the ground coffee. Oh, and 5 stars for Amazon's easy replacement
Rpm is a bit high, gas difficulty with espresso grind and limited to a 20sec grind. If you are grinding for American brew this is a very good machine.
Have it since May 20 2016 with no problems

I bought it when it was $75 and was a great deal. I bought a second at $130, but I don't know if I'd buy it for $189.99. I'd rather get the "Baratza Virtuoso Coffee Grinder 586" for $229.

I use it everyday with my Hario v60 and Hario Kettle or my Chemex 6 cup when I'm making coffee for a group.
Good

This unit replaced an older model Bodum grinder. (Apparently if you drop these things often enough on a stone kitchen floor, they stop working). The new unit has a slip resistant rubberized body (built just for me, I guess), and the blades and grinding mechanism are what you would expect from Bodum, providing precise grinds from course perc through espresso to Turkish coffee fairy dust. Very nice machine, especially for the money.

The first one i bought broke within a few uses. Bodum was excellent in sending me a new one right away. I had the second one for about one year before it too broke. I gave up & threw it out. I will not buy this gain. Seems that you have to have a very high end/expensive grinder if yo want to grind your own beans. I do not want to spend the $ for a high end one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good quality at a good price.
reviews.reviewText: This is a very good burr grinder for this price. I use the product every day to make a single serving. We have a higher end grinder that we also use daily for making a whole carafe and I don't actually see much difference in the grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: it doesn't grind my favorite coffee beans fine enough to get that perfect cup ...
reviews.reviewText: I received this grinder in January, and it's already broken. I"m going to get in touch with warranty to see what the company can do, but beyond that, it doesn't grind my favorite coffee beans fine enough to get that perfect cup out of my Breville machine. I was using a magic bullet to grind my beans before receiving this grinder, and i'm already back to that grind.
Unable to replace the broken Bodum glass "coffee catcher" for this unit. After considerable searching, my conclusion is that it just isn't around for sale.

reviews.reviewTitle: I love this easy to use grinder
reviews.reviewText: So, my spouse asked, why I need this grinder when I can brew my coffee at Costco. I didn't respond. It simple, I love this easy to use grinder. Enough said.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does not work for espresso grind
reviews.reviewText:
This machine is not capable of an espresso grind.
I bought this last December to use to grind beans for espresso. A few months later it stopped working. Called Bodum and I was advised to clean it out and grind a tablespoon of dry white rice. It worked for sometime then stopped. Bodum shipped me another unit. 2 weeks and this one too has stopped working.
Going back to a blade grinder.
It's beautiful ... it works nicely ... the glass container for the ground coffee cuts down on coffee flying everywhere ... a keeper ... let's see how it proves itself over time!
Great coffee grinder. We have other Bodum products and have confidence in the brand.
This grinder works so well! I use it multiple times each day and have been so pleased with it!

This is a perfect choice for those who drink one or two espressos at a time or their equivalent. I have not tried the grinder for other than espresso grinds, and have not owned it for over a week. However, the grind seems very consistent and my espresso machine performs better than it did when I used my Device Style grinder.
Very easy to use and effective. Love having the different grinding options. Fast and efficient little machine.

I was looking for a decent burr coffee grinder without spending several hundreds of dollars and this was the only one that received mostly positive reviews from other purchasers. I've now had my Bodum grinder a few weeks and find it ideal for home use. Because I don't make coffee in large volume, the timing/overheating issue that some have noted isn't at all a problem for me. 10-20 seconds is more than enough time to grind enough beans for my largest press pot. It's quiet, easy to clean, and doesn't take up much counter space. What's not to like!
Great compact burr coffee grinder. If like me you are moving up from a blade grinder to a burr, can recommend this one

reviews.reviewTitle: good for a year or two
reviews.reviewText: This thing has broke twice in 5 yrs the first time warranty covered it and now it is broken for good. It seems like a pretty poorly made item to me

The metal body makes for a quieter grinder than previous model with plastic body. Last one lasted long time before grinder wore out. Happy with new version, but still getting adjusted to the grind of new model.
VERY GOOD

reviews.reviewTitle: Best Coffee Grinder for less than $100
reviews.reviewText: I did a decent amount of research and decided to replace my burr grinder with a conical burr grinder. This is a great grinder and I am very pleased with the purchase. It is not as loud as my burr grinder that I replaced and it is very well made.Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder, Black

reviews.reviewTitle: It's a good product for the value
reviews.reviewText: This was a gift for my daughter and she seems to be quite pleased with it

Bodum is such a fine company, one of their other products has served me well for decades. This product is a mystery. It cannot grind any sufficient amount of beans in twenty seconds. It took me 25 minutes to grind enough beans for one espresso. The grind is no where near fine enough. VERY ANNOYING!

reviews.reviewTitle: bought in January and just stopped working
reviews.reviewText: Not sure why, but this grinder just stopped working today- less than a year old, and not used more than a few days a week- so not sure why it has already died. Would NOT recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder with a couple of faults.
reviews.reviewText: It's a good grinder and I love the red color. I had a Capresso Infinity for 4 years and this definitely grinds better than that one. What I do not like is that you have to wait 5 minutes after grinding for 20 seconds. What is that all about? I can't get a full pot for my red Technivorm coffee machine without having to grind twice. Also the static cling does exist.

If you're looking for a coffee grinder!! This one does an awesome job!!!
Thumbs up!! 👍👍👍👍

reviews.reviewTitle: We loved it while it worked
reviews.reviewText: Expect a short life span, and then to throw it away. We loved it while it worked, it has a nice consistent grind. Unfortunately after two years it goes in the trash because you can't get replacement parts, and apparently the gears are made of plastic.
I have used this for years. No problems.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grind is coarse even on espresso setting.
reviews.reviewText: I was looking for a decent affordable grinder for an espresso grind. As a burr grinder this worked ok for about a month then all grind settings stopped working as expected. The espresso grind is now coarse and uneven as shown in attached pic.

I didn't realize you could only grind for 20 seconds without potentially compromising the motor when I bought this one, but it has turned out not to be much of an issue. 20 seconds grinds enough for a pot of coffee so I just had to get used to grinding my beans right before I pour water over them. So far, so good. Grinds very, very fine, haven't tried anything else.

reviews.reviewTitle: It is to the date the best grinder I have owned.
reviews.reviewText: Of the 4 coffee grinder I have had, this is the best by far. Time measure is excellent and almost no static. The only fault I can find is that when the coffee is ground for French Press, it is not as coffee-dust free as I would like. But it is still one of the cleanest french-press-grinds I have found from a commercial grinder.

I liked The Bodum Bristro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder --- while it worked. 100 days after purchasing, the on/off switch has no effect. The last coffee grinder I had lasted almost 8 years, so it's not like I abuse them.

In June 2013 Bodum customer service promised to replace the grinder. Four months later, since no replacement grinder from Bodum. Each e-mail from customer service promises it "next week."

I researched and bought this to replace a smaller hand held type Bosch unit. I was underwhelmed. It needs to be run at least three times to make enough for a pot of coffee. It is unbelievably messy. I thought white would look cool, it does out of the box, not after use. Just really messy to use. I will just go back to buying ground coffee rather than destroy the coffee area every morning.

It took me a couple of pots to dial in the setting correctly, but everyone loves the result. It does leave a few specks of coffee grounds on the countertop, but nothing egregious. I have been using this in concert with a Bunn commercial coffeemaker on my countertop for the past year and it is a perfect match. If you are standing next to it, it can be a bit loud. If you are in the other room, you actually enjoy the sound because you know that someone is making you a fresh pot of coffee!

When the magic smoke trailed out of my ancient Krups blade grinder, I knew I was going to bite the bullet and buy a burr grinder to replace it. Reviews led me to the Bodum Bistro, so now I'll share my thoughts as well.

I make coffee one cup at a time using a Melitta cone filter basket that sits on top of my coffee mug. If you have thus far avoided the hype that is single-cup coffee brewing machines, take the money you've saved and get yourself a one-cup filter and this grinder instead. A few experimental runs led me to the coarseness (just finer than drip) and time (7 seconds) required to grind exactly as much coffee as I need for a single cup. Now I leave the settings as they are and only have to push a button in the morning. I find that a pound of coffee lasts me longer now than it did when I was using the old Krups.

In a nutshell:

Pros:
- Even grind with less dust and sediment around the work area
- Acts as coffee bean storage
- Makes more efficient use of the beans
- Identical results every time
- Glass catcher and plastic lid keep grounds under control
- Small footprint and attractive design

Cons:
- Stays on the counter all the time
- Hopper doesn't quite hold a full pound of coffee
- Settings are awkward to change if you need to change them often
- Relatively small capacity per grind
- Rubberized exterior requires frequent cleaning - collects dust from the kitchen (flour, etc.)

If you make a full pot in a 12-cup drip machine every morning, this probably isn't the burr grinder for you. However, if you're a French press or one-cup drinker, I haven't seen a better grinder on the market to meet your needs.
Works efficiently, medium noise, holds enough coffee, but the receptacle and the body don't match super well and there are staticky coffee grounds everywhere each time I use it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use and reliable grind
reviews.reviewText: The best burr grinder on market

I have happily used this grinder twice a day for the past 3.5 years. One of the most well-designed products I have ever used. It predictably delivers the amount, and fineness of grounds, I wish to use each morning. It has never clogged or failed. The perfect companion to my Aeropress.

reviews.reviewTitle: What a disappointment. The grinder seems solidly built -- too bad ...
reviews.reviewText: I used the grinder about a dozen times with no problems. But this morning when I pressed the stand-by-mode on/off button, the button dropped down the button hole, below the surface of the grinder body, where it's still visible, but untouchable. What a disappointment. The grinder seems solidly built -- too bad Bodum skimped on the quality of the switch.

The grinding mechanism only lasted about 1 month with normal wear before breaking -- it's hard to tell what exactly broke, but the burrs no longer fit together properly and do not grind effectively. Of course, this broke down just after the holiday return window closed, and it can no longer be replaced :(

Extremely disappointed with the quality of this item -- this seemed like a wonderful grinder at first, but it did not hold up to normal morning coffee usage!

The Bodum coffee grinder does a very good job WITH ONE MAJOR FLAW. To suit my tastes, it does not grind enough coffee at one time. My coffee maker makes 12 cups; the grinder does not grind enough to make a decent 10-cup pot, much less a 12-cup pot. Why not just immediately grind another batch? The instructions clearly state that one should wait at least five minutes between grindings. Well, that won't do. So, I end up grinding beans the night before so that I can add to the batch that I grind in the morning. Well, that defeats the purpose of having a coffee grinder so as to have freshly-ground beans. This is a real issue with me. I would not buy this product again.

I bought this about a year ago and started having problems with it this past summer. It started to struggle to grind at the finer settings and finally would not grind at those settings at all. Also, the on /off switch shorted, so the grinder turned on as soon as power was turned on. I contacted the company directly on their website and, after voicing my complaint and providing my receipt from Amazon, they sent me a brand new one with no questions asked, keeping true to their 2-year warranty policy! Customer service was prompt, efficient and helpful. Maybe not a fail-safe product, but definitely an excellent company! The working grinder is also quite excellent, I find.

reviews.reviewTitle: Has made all my past grinders seem like a bad choice
reviews.reviewText: Works superbly. Doesn't throw coffee dust and the glass receiving container minimizes static cling. Has made all my past grinders seem like a bad choice. Rating one point deduction for complete absence of instructions for assembling the cutter head to base and the bean reservoir. The scary separate sharp metal cutter is separate in the shelf box but not even listed as a component in the instructions booklet.

I bought this grinder based on the strong reviews on this site. The product worked well for about a year. Then, despite the fact that I cleaned the machine rigorously and followed all instructions for its use, it stopped grinding except in the coarse setting. Of course, this was just after the warranty period expired. I used the machine daily for my wife and I--not particularly heavy use--just one time per day. Pretty disappointing.
This is cheaply made machine with plastic components. Didn’t even last a year.
I returned this. It lasted 2 weeks.

Shalom, We bought our Bodum Bistro Burr grinder last week, arrived here on Friday! Awesome! Not messy or loud like our other burr grinder. With our old burr grinder we had to wear hearing gear and spend 15 minutes cleaning up the runaway grinded beans! We're very pleased with our purchase!
This grinder is slightly smaller than most, but it's still a powerful grinder. The glass receptacle seems to cut down on static and flying grinds, which is a plus for me.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bought this in May 2015 and love this grinder
reviews.reviewText: Bought this in May 2015 and love this grinder! This is the best grinder I've owned by far and I highly recommend buying it. Easy controls and a consistent grind. I have this paired with an Aeropress and I roast my own beans.
This thing works like a champ !

reviews.reviewTitle: Very good quality, as you can expect from bodum
reviews.reviewText: Was worried about durability after reading some reviews, but have had it for over almost 2 years and through 2 moves, still works great. Best value conical burr grinder. Consistant grind, easy to clean, and looks good.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great until the warranty period is over
reviews.reviewText: This product was great for about 14 months. Then it just stopped working. Nothing appears to be wrong. I suspect it is a simple switch or something but Bodem refuses to help since it is out of warranty. (Warranty is only for 12 months) I even asked about a paid for repair and got no response. Buy with caution, I have seen other reviews that had the product stop working for no apparent reason. I will probably not buy another Bodem product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder, have not had a problem with it ...
reviews.reviewText: Great grinder, have not had a problem with it not working, or with it not grinding them how I want the beans ground. My only concern is the lid of the hopper. It doesn't feel quite secure, but yet at the same time can be a pain to remove. Overall, I love this grinder. Does a great job, provides even grinds, and does it quickly.

reviews.reviewTitle: it stopped grinding at finer settings. It's a total waste of money
reviews.reviewText: After rare use (had bought it for a pied de terre) during a 60 day period, it stopped grinding at finer settings. It's a total waste of money, I wouldn't buy it.
Simply the best. Easy to set up, easy to operate. the guide on the lid is brilliant. Very useful.
Very nice--- grinds my beans quite nicely in a short amount of time. My coffee tastes great!

Died after approx 10 uses. I bought this for my son who is in the army and visits in frequently. So it is idle most of the time. Past the warranty ( of course). So I would not encourage anyone to buy this even though it is top of the line.
Much less messy than my previous one with a plastic grounds container. The glass has less static and so fewer fine grounds flying all over the place.
Just as I expected, very practical to adjust according to what you want to drink
Consistent grinds, good for consumer level. Has run solid since we purchased it.

I have been using the blade style grinders for years and finally switched to a burr grinder. I love the consistency of the grind and that I can push a button and the grinder runs for about 4 seconds and produces the perfect amount of ground coffee for a single cup. I use it in the morning but it is not very loud so it doesn't disturb anyone. The time is adjustable as well as the grind from fine to coarse. The beans are cheaper when purchased whole bean so this is saving me money in the long run!!!

Having used blade grinders for a long time I decided on this purchase based on the Bodum name and numerous reviews. This unit has lived up to it's reputation with a consistant grind at several different settings. I most generally grind for a Drip coffee maker for which I use a fine grind and on weekends, I grind at a course level for the French Press. Overall , I am pleased with this grinder and would recomend to others.
Grinds coffee fast and perfectly textured. There is no comparison between this grinder and most other non-burr grinders. The consistency is always perfect and the coffee tastes so much better.

This is my first stand alone burr grinder. It does a good job grinding beans, and has multiple settings to give you the grind you want for your coffee. There is some mess when you take out the glass container that catches the ground beans, but it is minimal. Overall I am very happy with this purchase.
Love it for french press. A lot cheaper than Rancilio I had for espresso. I have only used it for french press because that is what I drink. It works. Not too much sludge.
I had it for a month and it does not grind coffee near the espresso setting anymore. It's motor grinds gears like a manual transmission car and the beans get stuck in the burrs.

This works well enough for a cheap burr grinder... BUT, there is a tiny, plastic part that's incredibly easy to break. I'm still waiting to hear back from Bodum whether I can get a replacement for this little plastic ring.

Stores and Grinds as advertised BUT after removing the glass container, invariably, a cascading deposit of residual grounds appears on the grinder and counter, followed by subsequent cascades when the I move the grinder before its next use. As much as I desire the versatility of this machine, the mess, never a problem with the usual and customary grinders, is beginning to wear on myself and my significant others.

1. Dislike static issues, suggest a solution
2.Request inclusion of second receptacle for different brand of coffee
3.include small cleaning brush for inner grinder mechanism

reviews.reviewTitle: Use this at my Ford dealership, and we drink ...
reviews.reviewText: Use this at my Ford dealership, and we drink a lot of coffee. This is the 2nd one we have purchased, and have ground hundreds of #'s of coffee. You can grind it in different degrees of "fine-ness or coarseness" which is handy if you have different coffee makers.
I was very happy with this coffee grinder, grounds came out pretty uniform and was so quiet comp aired to my old grinder. I defiantly recommend the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder!

love this grinder!!! bought another as a gift to another coffee lover.

burr grinding does make the coffee taste better and this grinder looks great on the counter in a modern home.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bodum said they would not honor warranty for Amazon purchase.
reviews.reviewText: I received this as a gift and it was awesome while it worked as many have said but it stopped grinding after a few months of light use. I contacted Bodum and they sent a replacement which I thought was awesome. However the second one broke again and thus I contacted Bodum but they said that they would not honor the warranty since Amazon is a 3rd party seller. I even asked for help fixing it and I was simply ignored. Customer service was bad and the quality on this product is low unfortunately.
Quality and consistent grind. So glad I bought this vs other more expensive grinders.
Best coffee grinder I’ve ever had. Real neat, no mess. You can adjust amount and size of grind, plus it has storage for coffee easy to see if you’re going low. Real good buy!
This is the best burr grinder I have ever used. Absolutely love this unit.
Excellent coffee grinder but loud and the container is not the best.
Jammed and stopped grinding beans, I received a replacement, then the replacement jammed within a week.

reviews.reviewTitle: I really love this. So easy and makes the perfect grind ...
reviews.reviewText: I really love this. So easy and makes the perfect grind in the right amount every morning. It's so pretty too.
Love it!
Love love love this grinder! Very easy to use and a nice grind. A little static cling on the walls of the glass catcher, but that's not an issue for me.
GREAT PRICE, GREAT GRINDER, I HOPE IT LASTS LONGER THAN MY BREVILLE "SMART CHEAP GEAR TRANSMISSION GRINDER" DID. THE BREVILLE LASTED 13 MONTHS, A MONTH LONGER THAN THE WARRANTY .
Failing after less than a year.

Love the design, small footprint, effectiveness, and ease of use of this grinder. Easy to clean. Sadly, after 5 years of solid seasonal use at our summer house, the timer button seems to have broken. Wish I could repair it, but product repair for small appliance no longer exists in the modern world. So, I will have to buy a new one.
This grinder is a MESS. The grounds go everywhere. It is cheap plastic -- Bodum quality continues to decline. Buy another grinder.
Would like to be able to take all grinding parts out for thorough cleaning. Coffee taste is affected by residual grounds.

I have had this grinder for 2 years and have enjoyed it. I bought this grinder because my mom bought me an espresso machine and I needed a grinder for it. It has a wide range of settings which has been useful for my espresso machine, drip coffee maker and french press. It has worked great for all three! I have not had another grinder like this so I have no products really to compare it with. The only problem I have noticed is it is a little messy as I tend to always spill some of the coffee grounds when I am taking the glass bottom part out. I guess this would probably happen with any coffee grinder though.
my second one of these. we wore the first one out. quiet with consistent grind. love it. to do better will ocst twice to three times as much...

reviews.reviewTitle: I would STRONGLY recommend that EVERYONE buys a different product
reviews.reviewText:
This thing is an absolute piece of SH*T! I would STRONGLY recommend that EVERYONE buys a different product. I bought this for my Dad for Christmas and it's already broken (less than 3 months later). reviews.reviewTitle: Not powerful enough to grind coffee
reviews.reviewText:
I really wanted to like this product, which has the following "pros":
* Attractive design
* Low price
* Easy to use
* Not as monstrously tall as most of the high quality grinders

However, when I tried to grind coffee beans in it, it immediately stalled out, making the awful sound that is described in the manual as what happens when the machine jams. Note, this was at a medium grind setting (neither extra fine nor coarse), and I confirmed that this was not due to stones or other debris in the coffee beans. After emptying the machine, cleaning it, and trying to grind again, it again immediately stalled out. So I returned it.

I have since purchased the Baratza Encore. It has had no trouble grinding coffee, including the remaining beans from the very same bag that tripped up the Bodum.

My last two coffee grinders have been the Cuisinart units which usually last about two years before dying. The Bodium grinder is a far better unit. First the burr looks very substantial and is nicely made. The burr setup is set into a delrin type of plastic which is very tough stuff. The burr set disassembles easily for cleaning There are many nice features designed into this unit, most impressive is the glass collection jar (much less static cling) and rock clutch which slips the grind mechanism if a rock get in with the beans. The grind path is all downhill so I think this unit will clog less. I would say it is very well thought out from a design standpoint. The grind quality is the best I have seen in a relatively inexpensive grinder. We are using about 20% less coffee and the coffee taste is better which I can only attribute to the better grind. The Cuisinart sounded like and was almost as loud as a wood chipper, this unit is much more quiet. We used to run the Cuisinart for over 40 seconds to get enough coffee for our Newco (one of the best drip coffee units by far due to the superior, HOT, commercial grade heater), after experimentation we run the Bodium for 30 seconds. This brings us to the reason I rated this unit four stars, the timer only goes to 20 seconds max. and it is recommended to wait another 20 minutes before grinding more coffee due to motor heat issues. BULL to that, I will be the $75.00 beta tester on that BS rule. We run the machine first thing for 15 seconds, go through the usual coffee brewing preparations and then do the second 15 second grind. I do not think this will be a problem. reviews.reviewText:
I just received mine today. I promise I'll come back and change the stars if I change my opinion over time. Reading reviews of this grinder while shopping, I had a few unanswered questions.

How much coffee can one grind in 20 seconds? Just before my last grinder shuddered and died, I weighed the coffee it was grinding since I was satisfied with the portion. It was 50 grams. Today, I measured 50 grams of beans, and they finished grinding before the 20 seconds was up. This was enough coffee to brew a nice strong pot in my Bodum French Press which handles around 1.3 liters of water.

Is it really too fine a grind? Still don't really know how to judge what too fine a grind is, but I can tell you what the bottom of the cup looked like when the coffee was gone. My dead grinder was a Melitta, cheap, messy, but consistent. The coarsest part of the grind was coarser than what my new Bodum produced today. But at the end of the cup there was a pretty heavy dark sediment left. Today, I could look at the bottom of the cup, and tell that there had been coffee in it, but it was just a little dust. Much less muddy coffee. I was impressed.

How messy is it? Compared to my Melitta, not messy at all. There was a little dust which clung to the glass. I just moistened a tissue and wiped under where the glass container comes out, and got no dust. At this point I'm very satisfied. But I can't give five stars on the first day. (I was about to write that if you check the all my reviews link you will find this is the only one. I was surprised to find three, which I recognize must have been written by my son while he was between 12 and 14 years old. Who knew?)

reviews.reviewTitle: I Made Better Coffee With My Blade Grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I spent quite a bit of time before deciding on the bodum bistro grinder. There were so many positive reviews. I knew the limitations of the unit since it was sub $100. I was fine with these limitations since I only planned to make drip and press pot coffee with beans that I roast at home. The biggest selling point for me was the glass receptacle to prevent statically charged grinds.

I got my unit and couldn't be more disappointed. I almost think the unit simply has to be defective since it is so bad (based upon the glowing reviews other have given). Here are my complaints:

* The grind on the drip setting was much too fine. Unfortunately, using a coarser grind seemed to make no difference. The grind was a powder like consistency.

* The glass container had lots of statically charged fines stuck to it after each grind. This was disappointing since a large selling point was the anti-static technology and the glass container.

* A significant amount of coffee was left above the glass receptacle after grinding. I had to hit the unit with my hand to make it drop into the container.

* The coarse setting for press produced inconsistently sized grinds that had some chunks mixed in with very fine particles.

* The 20 second grind time before waiting 5 minutes (that other reviewers complain about). I knew this going in and could have tolerated it had the other problems not existed.

I sent it back for a refund today. I thought about exchanging it but many other reviewers complained that it grinds too fine for a french press. As such, I felt like even if the other problems were corrected with an exchange, I might still be disappointed.

Instead, I have purchased Cuisinart DBM-8 for $50. I fully understand that these are all budget, entry-level grinders that are meant to be a step up from a blade grinder (and have limitations when compared to superior, more expensive grinders). Hopefully, this new one will turn out better. As far now, I am enjoying far better coffee with my blade grinder while I wait for my new burr mill grinder to arrive.

I have owned this product for 2 days now and it looks like a solid piece of equipment. I have ground coffee for both French Press and Espresso (used in Aeropress), so both sides of the spectrum and the grind size seems to be accurate and consistent. The burr grinder is made of solid metal and not plastic and the grounds jar is glass.

My real problem is the manual says not to run the grinder more than the maximum time of 20 seconds, without letting the grinder rest 5 minutes.

Having read the reviews of this complaint and those dismissing it I decided to take a chance and purchase this. What I think the reviews lacked when talking about this shortcoming is actual examples of what it can grind in that 20 seconds.

On the finest setting with 2 scoops of beans and the timer set to its max of 20 seconds, the grinder only ground 3/4 of those 2 scoops. So you have to wait 5 minutes to finish off the rest of the 2 scoops. On the maximum grind size setting with 4 scoops of coffee beans, it will just barely finish the grind, but there will be a few unground beans left in the burrs. So what does this mean for those that use a drip coffee setup? On the medium grind setting, it will not finish 4 scoops of coffee used to make 8 cups. So me personally, I will ignore the manufacture warning and simple start the grind process again to finish. When it breaks I will throw it away and buy something else.

Lastly this thing is messy, there is always grounds left in the grinding chamber and you have to literally smack the grinder on the side quite a few times to clear it out before removing the jar. Even then grounds spill out all over the place. Having not owned an electric burr grinder before, I could not say if this is normal or not.

So while I really like the grinder design, build quality and consistent grind, it fails to do what it needs to do for me, which is grind a reasonable amount of coffee in a reasonable amount of time.

***EDIT*** Grinder Makes the Coffee Burnt Tasting
I purchased this grinder along with a French press as I had been using drip and an Aeropress along with a Cozyna Ceramic Burr Manual Coffee Grinder. Using the manual grinder, Aeropress and my own roasted beans, I made the most delicious cup of coffee. For the water I would use the drip coffee maker which put out water between 168 ~ 170 deg.
I found that the coffee has tasted bitter and burnt since using the new grinder. I had been using the same beans freshly ground and to the same grind size as the manual. I was using a new variable temp kettle and tried the coffee @ 170, 195 and 205 deg with still the same results. The beans that I use made a very distinctly buttery smell when ground. Testing side by side the grinds out of the Bodum smelled burnt. I then tested the same coffee from my manual grinder and the Bodum in the Aeropress using water temp of 170 deg. The coffee out of the manual grinder / Aeropress tasted as it always has, fantastic. The coffee out of the Bodum tasted bitter and burnt. I am not sure why it tasted different, the only thing I can see being different is that the burrs on the Bodum are sharp steel and still blade like, using speed to grind the bean as much as its burrs, whereas the manual grinder are ceramic and dull using pressure to grind at a much slower RPM.

Based upon the bulk of the reviews, I was expecting something a lot better. My major problems with the Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder are as follows in order of significance.

1) Its very messy. While grinds do go into the nice glass container when grinding, this doesn't prevent them from falling out of the grinder when you remove the container from grinder. It doesn't tell you anywhere in the site or manual, but the way grinds get into the little glass container is by their being pushed by the grinding wheel into an opening above the glass container. When you remove the container, there is a still a pile of grinds, at the opening ready to fall onto the base at the slightest jolt. You end up with grounds on the counter. You can try to tip the unit forward but that doesn't seem to work too well. Doing a periodic cleaning is even messier. There is no way to close off the hopper unit, so if it jams (as ours did once), you have to empty the hopper which is also messy.

2) While static is minimized, when you go to put the ground coffee into a plastic coffee maker (e.g. a Cuisinart DCC-1200), there is still a static attraction and the grounds scatter all over the top of the unit (which if you have it open as one normally would when putting coffee into the maker) results in coffee grinds getting into the water compartment. I now take the coffee basket out of the maker, set it in a canister to stay upright and put the grinds in there. Hardly convenient.

3) The hopper lid does not appear to be really air-tight and hence not a great place to store beans before grinding.

4) While quieter than a krups coffee grinder, it really isn't that quiet and it takes a lot longer (two pushes of 20 seconds each) to grind enough beans for 12 cups of coffee. So the resulting noise invasion is longer and ultimately more obtrusive.

Bottom line, it may be great if you only grind a few cups worth of beans for a french press or similar device. Strictly overrated for use with conventional drip maker.

Update as of 12/13/2011.

Have been using the grinder for about 8 months now, unfortunately, I still find the grinder to be messy. The tapping technique helps a bit, but don't expect to be able to grind coffee without having to wipe at least some coffee grounds off the counter. I am still surprised that static isn't a problem for more people. I live near the beach (1.5 miles) so its not like I live in a dry desert area. Standing by my two star review because of the mess.

Final Update 7/29/2013

My unloved Bodum grinder gave up the ghost today. The motor now spins but the grinder no longer grinds. Looked briefly for spare parts on the Internet, but didn't find much. Can't say that I will miss it. The unit got louder and louder over time, so much so that I was surprised how much quieter my old blade grinder was then the Boudum. All in all one of the worst appliance purchases I have made.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for Price! - Comparing to BODUM BISTRO with Continuously Adjusting Grind
reviews.reviewText:
I bought BODUM BISTRO with "CONTINUOUSLY ADJUSTING GRIND" eleven months ago and have been using that daily and am comparing this BODUM BISTRO 11750 which costs half as much, which I was offered to review. I will compare and contrast the two, I feel the price is a major decision point for me, as is mess and cleanup, so after using both side by side I would choose this BODUM BISTRO 11750 if given the choice between the two.

Top considerations for me: consistent grind size, mess or lack of making a mess, and price. Lowest price for best performance is my choice. Least amount of mess is preferred.

My most common coffee making style is french press with coarse ground but I did test with fine ground also.

Comparisons:
GRIND CONSISTENCY: The CONTINUOUSLY ADJUSTABLE GRIND does an action where the burrs move and adjust themselves in order to attempt to make a consistent grind size. I applaud this effort. In side by side comparisons of grind size consistency on coarse setting, I found the 11750 was just a little worse with occasional larger pieces and some fine grounds when I had set it to the coarse setting. This is because it appears that the 11750 does NOT have a constantly adjustable burr grinding action. I am questioning how necessary that action is and if it justifies spending double. Note when testing FINE GROUNDS the consistency was great, which honestly is more important when making espresso drinks.

THE MESS: One reason I purchased the "Continuously Adjusting Grind" was it supposedly had a lower static cling factor for the glass and it has a rim of silicone that is supposed to prevent spills. However this is not the case, it does make a mess, when removing the glass container the grounds are on the machine, under the glass, and already on the counter. When pouring it out it spills, I do this over the sink and pour into a large mouth jar and measure out from there. The max size of the machine does not fill my large capacity french press so the feature where you choose the amount of grinds to make and get exactly that with one press of the start button is not useful to me. I always must have more than one full container so I wind up with leftovers I use the next day. The 11750 has NO MESS at all and it has a plastic tightly fitting shaped container so you get a larger portion of grinds. The sharp edges of the 11750 allow a clean and static-free pour with no spilling.

Cost: The 11750 is half the price of the "continuously adjusting grind" model.

Other notes: The 11750 is a bit more basic. You must press start and you must press the same button for stop. It does not automatically stop when the container is full. The button itself is a bit mushy and you have to press hard and directly down the center of the button for it to work. For the value on price I can deal with this! The more expensive one has a nicer start button and that one shuts off automatically when it hits the capacity you set the dial to. Is this worth double the price? I don't think so.

To change the grind size on the 11750 you twist the clear coffee bean holder at the top rather than trying to force the red dial for size. You can select any size in between fine, medium and coarse by stopping along the large dial.

The 11750 has a clear lid and the other has a black lid.

Instruction manual: Oddly the 11750 has a diagram of parts which is missing the removable burr (!) so I figured out assembly with my own common sense, and it has an extra part for the bean holder listed that I don't have. Also the manual is frustrating as it has pages and pages of legal language but no instructions on how to use the controls. There is not enough descriptive information about using the grind setting. I was unable to shift the grind size when there were beans in it and it kind of fell apart and the beans went all over the place. That should have been mentioned in the directions, to empty all whole beans before changing the size of the grind! The manual is in 11 languages and is over 75 pages long because of that and the legal warnings.

I rate this 4 stars = Like It although if rating against value for the price compared to the other model that's double the price I may say 4.5 stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: Maybe I should read the directions better.
reviews.reviewText: I've had 2 of these. Won't get a third. Maybe I should read the directions better.

I was previous using a Cuisinart DBM-8 grinder. One of the main differences in functionality between it and this Bodum grinder is that the Cuisinart has a timer to control the grind, while the Bodum is push-on-push-off. I much prefer the later. The Cuisinart's timer had a minimum setting of 4-cups, and I use a pour-over filter and make one cup at a time so I always had left-over grounds. The Bodum gives me more control over the exact quantity of grounds. I also think the Bodum looks a bit nicer than the Cuisinart.

The Bodum has a major flaw however. The problem with the Bodum is the container used to hold the grounds. It wedges into the machine by friction with two rubber pieces on the bottom. This makes it extremely difficult (and annoying) to remove from the machine. This is aggravated by the fact that the sides of the grounds container are slanted in kind of a V shape, and the grounds container is smooth, slippery plastic. It's impossible to pull it out of the machine in a controlled fashion. The way I usually do it is to wedge the tips of my fingers between the container and the machine and pry it out. I can't believe they designed this without a better mechanism for holding the grounds container, or at least put some ridges on the sides of it so you could grip it in a normal fashion. The problem is made even worse by the fact the grounds container has no lid; if you lose your grip prying it out of the machine you'll spill grounds everywhere. The Cuisinart's grounds container is much better designed; it snaps in and out smoothly, and has a cover on it to keep the grounds from spilling.

I really like the design of the Bodum and the push-button operation, but this machine is a case of form over function and I won't buy another one if mine breaks and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone else either.

reviews.reviewTitle: First time it worked great, the second time it didn't work!!!
reviews.reviewText: It worked great the first time (Thanksgiving) so I threw all the packaging away! The second time we used it, it didn't work!!!
fell apart how do you get stuck beans? the instructions are poor if you have issues, will try a 2nd one.

I have a Krups grinder that's a little less expensive than this one so have been comparing the two.

The Bodum produces a nice, even grind. I can't tell any difference between the Bodum and the Krups in this regard. Both are adjustable and produce good coffee.

The container of coffee is very difficult to remove from the Bodum. I have to pry it out every single time using my fingernails. It's pretty annoying. The Krups has no such issue -- the container slides out and pops back in very easily.

With the Bodum, once you switch it on, it will run until you turn it off. Unless you can keep really good track of how much coffee is being ground, maybe time timing it, you'll have to measure the ground coffee for consistent brewing results. My Krups has a setting where I can choose how many cups of coffee I plan to brew and it will grind that amount. Super convenient.

While I had high hopes for better quality with the Bodum, it has mainly been sitting on the shelf as I continue to use the Krups machine.

It worked great for awhile but after 6 mos. of use it can only do a coarse grind. When I try to do something finer like a drip grind it takes forever (5 minutes for ~20grams). I cannot understand why grinders cost so much. At the end of the day it is just to pieces of metal spinning. My hand hand grinder (Hario Slim) never fails but grinding by hand is tedious with a busy lifestyle.

**** UPDATE: After no response from Bodum - I've decided to no longer purchase their products. Purchased my replacement grinder from Baratza (encore model). Baratza supplies parts completely for the grinders meaning if something wears out you can replace the part instead of buying a whole new grinder (parts are affordable by the way).

reviews.reviewTitle: don't buy if outside of USA
reviews.reviewText: Although it says this is suitable for use with European voltage, the unit blew and stopped working after around 5 times use at well below the recommended grinding times....once, i returned and got another as I though it was just a once off fault..then the same happened with the second one I got too!! A shame, as it is a nice unit but not if you don't live within the USA!!

I was very excited to get this grinder. I have had my current burr grinder for 5 years and it handles like a champ. Durable as all get out. But I wanted a second one because my husband uses it for his french press (coarse) and I use it for my pour overs (medium) or espresso (fine). So we determined a second grinder would be a good get.

This is larger than my current grinder and the materials do not feel as solid. Honestly the plastic in this feels a little cheap. But that isn't the issue...

No matter what setting I put it on, coarse or fine, the result looked like half chopped beans. I figured we hadn't assembled it properly, but nope, followed instructions meticulously. Still got "ground" coffee that looks like I coarsely chopped them with a knife. Sigh. I put it away and went by to my old faithful.

I bought this grinder about 8 years ago and its still going strong except for one major complaint: they rubber coating that covers the entire grinder has turned into a sticky tar-like substance. That started happening just a year or two after I bought it and has gotten so bad that I was about to throw it out because I couldn't touch it without sticking to it (see photo #1). But luckily, I was able to remove the entire coating wiping it with a rag soaked in 90% isopropyl alcohol. It came out looking nice and shiny, but the alcohol also removed all the markings, so I had to paint new dots and make new labels with a label maker which I then sealed with a clear coat of nail polish. Now it looks as good as new (see photo #2)

My only other complaint is that it can only grind enough coffee for a 4-5 cup drip coffee maker (which I have). if you need more grinds, you have to wait for the grinder to cool down before grinding more beans. But otherwise it perfectly fits my needs and makes consistent size grounds for both my French Press and Mocha pot.

If I had to by it again, I would definitely spend the extra money and buy one with the metal body. Or for the same money, I'd probably get the Baratza Encore Coffee Grinder which can grind more beans and also has great reviews (but lacks a timer).

reviews.reviewTitle: A more affordable Bodum bur grinder.
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using Bodum products for a long time now, and although expensive, I have always felt it was worth it because the materials and build quality were always topnotch. Not so much with these newer models however, but with that said, the price is also significantly reduced, so in the end I guess it's a fair tradeoff, but one that I'm wondering might tarnish their name a bit. Muddying the waters even further is the fact these cheaper versions share the same design and name as their more expensive brethren, possibly confusing customers on what they're actually buying.

Take this grinder for instance. I currently own A black Bodum Bistro Bur grinder that looks similar to this Bodum Bistro Coffee Grinder. My model feels and operates superior in every way, but is also twice the price at $100. But both models get the most important aspect right: the end grind results are practically the same; or at least good enough I can't tell the difference.

So in short, it's not the quality I've come to expect from Bodum over the years, but due to its very reasonable price point, I think it's still a great bur grinder for those who don't mind the cheaper parts and loss of some functionality, like auto-shutoff.

I by passed all the comments saying they loved it until it worked. I was in a pinch and thought, maybe we will be different! Low and behold, right around the year mark it starts to make these odd noises. My poor coffee snob of a husband would get so disappointed when it did that. I was hoping it was a fluke, one time thing.

Nope. That thing completely stopped working right at a year. Can you believe it? It was completely lovely before then. It looked sleek, grind beautifully. But whats the point if it stops working?! For the amount we paid I would expect it to last at least 3 years. Save your money. Find something better.

I loved the way this machine looked-I bought it for my husband-He roasts his own beans and a pricier grinder seemed in order-it was frustrating from the get go- Amazon was very good about crediting my account but i would not encourage anyone to purchase this-

reviews.reviewTitle: Good for about 50 uses, zero Customer Service.
reviews.reviewText: Anytime you sell a product and have no customer service, then you don't deserve to sell anything. My grinder quit working after about the 50th use, albeit over a year. It was used to make single cups with the aeropress. After I had not used it for a while, when I plugged it in, it did nothing. Upon leaving it plugged in overnight, it would run for 20 - 30 seconds and then die again. This was repeatable but not good enough if I wanted a second cup of coffee. I sent very detailed description of the problem to their customer service, and received a response the next day saying that I need to read the manual. I am confident that this is an automatic response and nobody had read my issue. I responded with a few more details and notice that I had performed the recommended maintenance. No response. I will be purchasing something different.

reviews.reviewTitle: and mine has lasted for something like seven years
reviews.reviewText:
It does a fair job, and mine has lasted for something like seven years. However:
- the rubberized coating on the grinder is a magnet for awfulness, and is virtually impossible to clean properly.
- fine grounds build up in areas around the burr that affect the grind and are very difficult to clean.
- grounds tend to stick in the slide from the burr to the container, then dribble out when the container is out.
- the stated duty cycle is 20 seconds on / 5 minutes off. 20 Seconds isn't bad for fine grinding a cup of aeropress, but it's not really great for making lots of coffee. The motor is nowhere near the outer case, so don't trust that it doesn't feel hot.
- There's almost always enough static electricity to ensure that theres coffee all over the counter.

reviews.reviewTitle: My Bodum is 6+ years and counting. . .
reviews.reviewText:
I started with the original, German made flat burr Braun back in the mid 80's--which still functions today without issue.
The Bodum was the first conical burr I purchased, which produced a noticeably more even grind than the Braun.
I like to have two grinders--one for caffeinated beans, the other for decaf--so tried a few different models (including the OXO seen in the photo) and in the process discovered the Bodum ultimately won for grind evenness/consistency and in its ability to produce a great tasting cup of coffee.
I grind only for drip coffee, so am unable to comment about finer espresso grinds.
The drip grind places less stress on the machine, so it may be some of the complaints about plastic gears and a short life could be related to the increased load and/or increased maintenance requirements (e.g., cleaning, burr replacement).
For whatever it's worth, the Baratza Encore uses plastic gears, too.
As for cleanliness, the Bodum scores high in this area, too.
It leaves less to clean up than the OXO, albeit both score equally high insofar each are virtually static-free.
Maybe I got lucky, and there are a high number of lemon Bodums in the world.
One thing for sure: when it eventually stops working I will replace it with the same (something I cannot say about the OXO).

reviews.reviewTitle: Still like-new after daily use for 12 years. SO GOOD!
reviews.reviewText: I love this grinder. I use so many different types of brewing methods: espresso, pour over, french press, drip, aeropress. It grinds the perfect grind every time. I'm a little crazy about having good coffee. I have found that the most important thing to brewing coffee the way I like it (rich and black!) is the perfect grind for the brew method. And this grinder delivers every time. I do not own expensive brewing devices, just this fancy little grinder. My husband has even used it to grind his own chili peppers. After which, it was very simple to take apart and clean thoroughly because it has very few parts. Because there is no blade, this never goes dull. I am just amazed at how well this grinder has performed over the last 12 years. I use it daily and it is the best thing I have in my arsenal of coffee-making heaven. I recommend it to everyone.

UPDATE 10/18: Sorry to those who may have followed my recommendation to buy this. I loved this grinder and used it for about a year, daily. I am a sucker for aesthetics and thought it looked cool and loved that you just press a button once and it times the grind. A few months ago the glass broke in an incident that I do not think should have broken it, and a month later it got jammed and the motor stopped working - I cleaned it out and got it going again but cannot get it to grind fine like it used to. Their customer service is non-existent. It now grinds 2x as many beans, half as fine, and I need a fine grind. So it is useless to me - I had to order a Breville unit to replace. If Bodum can make me whole and send me a new one or refund me, i'll remove my review, but I'm just very disappointed with their customer service - their phone # leads to nowhere and the only response I've gotten from them for how to fix is 'reassemble it,' with no details as to how to do this to make the grind fine again - I have already reassembled it 5 times reading online tutorials, etc and it still doesn't grind well. What a disappointment.

I love this grinder! Have had zero issues with it and haven't had to do any maintenance at all (brushing, etc). While it's best for 1-2 servings at a time (they want you to rest it for 5 minutes after 20 seconds of grinding), if that's all you need, snap one up when it goes below $70. I get a consistent fine grind with no issues whatsoever. It looks cool and has a great borosilicate glass receptacle.

I've owned this grinder for about 4 or 5 years and it hasn't slowed down one bit. It grinds the coffee very evenly and has never failed me and we use it every single day. It is such a significant improvement to those pulse grinders that don't grind evenly and you have to hold down the button. The hopper holds a generous amount considering the size of the grinder and the machine is low enough that it fits easily under the cabinets in our kitchen. We use it with our Technivorm coffee maker (we are fairly serious coffee drinkers) and the 20 second grind is perfect for 10 cups on that machine. The only knock I have is that it is a bit loud so i just walk away for that period of time. I love the rubber grommet cover over the glass jar eliminates any dust that is so common with coffee grinding.

reviews.reviewTitle: Going strong for more than six years
reviews.reviewText:
I've used this grinder daily to make one or two cups of pour-over coffee for more than six years. I have one of the orange ones, it's here in Amazon on a separate 'unavailable' page.

Rarely have I bought something that is so reliable and easy to use. It's worked day in and day out without a problem. After each grind I whack the machine a couple times with the heel of my hand to get all the grounds to drop into the glass jar, so it takes a beating but keeps on working. The most I've ever ground is two full 20 second grinds back-to-back, no problem, didn't overheat. But usually I do about 30-40 g at a time (measured on separate scale) which is about 14 seconds at the grind I have it set at (near the middle).

The machine is compact, fits under the counter easily and doesn't take up much space. I think it looks good too. I bought a Capresso 560.01 Infinity Burr Grinder for a friend and it's a lot bulkier. Then it got stuck on fine grind, but I suspect user error broke something. (I didn't want to get the same machine because it seemed a bit forward, but I should have.)

I don't know how I'd break the Bodum. I've washed the hopper and top burr piece many times, no issues. After removing these pieces I've shaken the base over the sink to remove stray grounds, it's solid.

The Bodum isn't perfect. The first thing I'd change is the material that the base is made of. After a few years the rubbery plastic gets a bit tacky and picks up dirt and is hard to clean. So there's usually a dark smudge where I pick it up with left hand thumb.

The second modification would be to make the grind time setting harder to change, like with small detents. The time + grind fineness setting have the biggest effect on taste so they are important not to change once you've got it right.

Finally, it's not quiet. But I've come to like the sound because it means great coffee very soon. And the on/off button (which I just keep on) is upside down because French.

The machine consistently grinds the same amount at the same setting for years, I've measured with a scale. If it ever dies I will buy another one. It gives you hope when you come across something that just works.

I bought this grinder one year and one week ago from my local Target. It was on sale, and I love other Bodum products that I have. Last night I went to grind the coffee, and it began making a horrible noise. I dumped out the remaining beans, took off the hopper and top grinding assembly to check for a stone or blockage. I didn't find anything, so I did a quick clean, reassembled it, and returned the unground beans. It all ground fine. This morning I went to grind beans for a second pot, and it sounded fine, but the grounds were not exiting through the shoot into the collection container. I took it apart to make sure nothing was stuck and it was fine, no blockage, no reason for the assembly under the second grinder to not be turning but it was not. So I checked how long ago I had purchased it and saw that it was a year and one week but decided to contact the company. They could not or would not do anything for me. The burrs are great, but the plastic assembly under the burrs is not turning to shove the grounds out. After they would not help I took the grinder apart and couldn't find any reason that it should have stopped working. I am disappointed in Bodum for not standing by their product. It costs about $.13 a day s​o it still may be worth the price for a year's use, but I expected to have it longer especially since the burrs are still sharp enough to slice my finger during the examination of the problem!

As this grinder ages, several completely unacceptable issues develop with it. In a nutshell, it is an annoying mess maker! The entire machine develops a static charge such that every part magnetically attracts huge amounts of ground coffee during use. Cleaning up after use is a chore and big time waster. The receiving jar seal wears out and grounds literally spew everywhere during use-all over the counter and the floor. The plastic coating on the machine body and the plastic band around the receiving jar deteriorate over time and develops a most disgusting, sticky residue that cannot be cleaned off. This contributes to the massive amount of grinds that attach to the machine during use. I will say that the grind is consistent and, after 6 years, the motor and blades continue to function well. But unfortunately the unacceptable mess created when grinding will soon land this machine in the trash.

Update 4/17/18
After 2 years of once a day usage, the plastic retaining ring surrounding the conical burr broke, rendering the entire unit unusable. Replacement parts are not available.

After checking reviews for comparable units I decided to purchase the same model again because I like the way it works and other models seem to have structural design deficiencies also. Additionally, I'm not willing to spend several hundred dollars for more reliable models.

Original review:
Yes, this grinder does result in far better coffee than what I was getting with blade grinders that I've been using for many, many years. The blade grinders resulted in a mixture of partially ground beans to a fine powder.

In general, burr grinders do produce a static charge to the grindings. I guess its just a fact of life. Prior to purchasing the Bodum, I had bought a Capresso which made such a mess everywhere, including the countertop and all over the machine that I returned it. The Bodum does do a better job at confining the grindings than did the Capresso and I don't have coffee grounds all over the countertop. However, I do have to wait about 5 minutes after grinding to give the static charge time to dissipate. Without the wait, about a tablespoon of grounds clinging to the collection container and when dumping the grounds into the coffee maker, stray grounds tend to fly about landing everywhere.

Two principal negatives for me are that the motor requires a 5 minute cooldown if an adequate number of grounds cannot be done in 20 seconds. The other is that the timer setting dial is too easy to move. There should be a click to hold it in place for every second. For me, a retired design engineer, these would be major design flaws. I also think that the collection container should have been made of stainless steel instead of glass. If it breaks, I note that a check on the Bodum web site that a replacement is not available.

For background information, I use French roast and make a 12 cup carafe each morning in a Melkitta drip machine. I originally started with the Bodum by measuring the same amount of beans that I had used in the blade grinder, being a quarter cup for the 12 cup drip maker. What happened is that the Bodum would not grind a quarter cup of beans in 20 seconds, so I had to wait 5 minutes to complete the process, then another 5 minutes to let the static charge dissipate. I've since found that with the quarter cup of beans I was getting coffee a bit stronger than I would like and that the amount of beans ground in 20 seconds is just right. So, I'm using a few less beans because the Bodum produces a more consistent grind and getting a better cup of coffee.

Now, its a wait and see to determine if the grinder will fail early in its life as many have reported.

I Use My Bodum Everyday.... and have for the last 4+ years. I use it with different types of coffees and grinds for different brewing methods. Drip, press and with my espresso machine. No problems with the grinder at all. Mine hasn't clogged. This is probably because I switch up the coffee blends as well as the grind. Manual grind adjustment Fine > Coarse works perfectly. Just move the pointer to the desired grind. I uses the timer dial to get the right amount of coffee. Nice big hopper too, so you can go several days without re-filling. Oily coffee beans can leave a residue. If you use the same coffee over and over and never clean the grinder, I guess you could have issues. Again, I haven't. One of this grinders BEST features is its glass catcher. Anyone who knows grinders can tell you that a plastic catcher will have static and can be messy. Not the Bodum. Static free, no mess. I probably take mine apart twice a year to inspect and clean. Comes apart and re-assembles easily. There is only one thing I don't like about this grinder. The finish on the outside is tacky. I've tried damp cloth, mild soapy solution but the thing remains sticky to the touch. My only complaint. Its durable for sure and does exactly what you expect.

reviews.reviewTitle: has stopped working after a few years
reviews.reviewText:
I think there's a design flaw in this product. The way that the conical burr slides under a plastic lip to stay in place in a counter clockwise motion, is UNDONE by the clockwise assembly of the top reservoir that contains the grinds and adjusts the setting. I used to be able to just take it apart and put it back together to get it to start working again (which has also been very annoying, but is something I've put up with for the last few years).

By grinder is now making a very loud, aggressive, clogging type of noise, and I know EXACTLY what it is but can't do anything about it because it's simply how the product was designed. When turning to a more fine setting, the conical burr handles slide out from under the plastic that is holding it down and then the burr is beginning to jump up and down when you try to grind any beans.

Again, as much as I try to take it apart and put it back together, it has finally, once and for all, stopped working. When it did work I was very happy with it! (even though it always required quite a bit of maintenance to keep working) but I think I will not buy another Bodum grinder because i am afraid of having this exact same problem!

reviews.reviewTitle: As for the functionality it is as good as it gets
reviews.reviewText:
I owned the black coffe grinder for 4 years. As for the functionality it is as good as it gets. The coffe comes out uniform in the size that you desire. I used it daily for all this time but decided to change to another one as the "matte" finish of the outside started to melt away and looks gooey and unpleasant. No matter what I did they wont completely go away. Aesthetically after time it did not look good.
Another issue I had was that it produces a lot of noise, if you live alone then this isnt a problem. Now that I am married, sometimes I had to grind my coffee the night before so that it wont wakes my partner up.
In conclusion, I am giving it 3 stars because it is a good machine works completely fine and still going strong! I loved the machine for all these years and have been satisfied for the final result that it produces. But it was time to replace it for another more modern and less noisy.

reviews.reviewTitle: After a year the grind simply wasn't fine enough for a proper espresso shot
reviews.reviewText:
Ok, so firs thing, this is the cheapest machine you can get (barring a sale) that well give you a consistent espresso grind.

It worked great for about a year. I even had to use the second finest setting, because my crappy espresso machine couldn't provide enough pressure to get through how fine the grounds were. I've since fixed the espresso machine, but now this grinder, on the finest setting, doesn't give the sorta clumpy powder consistency needed for espresso.

Even after two years the grind is finest enough for a decent cortado, especially if you sorta create a lungo version like im doing, but if you want a real rich espresso shot, this machine well eventually fail you.

Once I have a job again, I plan to buy another step up.

If you have the money and truly love coffee, just buy a well rated $300+ grinder. If you don't have a lot of money, or are on the fence, or simply want a cute grinder to make espresso drink for your friends who don't know any better, then feel free to buy this.

One last thing, the machine could not be easier to use, or clean, and if the grinder becomes dull, it's easy and relatively cheap to replace.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broken plastic drive gear is only a matter of time.
reviews.reviewText:
Well , I've officially encountered the broken plastic drive gear problem that everyone else has. It started to make a horrible plastic banging noise when grinding coffee and grinds about 1/2 the amount that it did prior to it breaking. I'm assuming I've stripped some teeth off the gear like everyone else. I'm guessing it's only a matter of time before it stops working completely. Mine lasted 4 years. A little longer than most people but I only use it a couple days a week though so it probably averages out to 1-2 years of daily use. I just called Bodum and it's outside of the warranty and they don't sell a replacement. If they sold a replacement set for like $15, I'd probably buy it. If someone made a metal upgrade for like $30 I'd probably buy that.

That being said, it was a good grinder while it worked but it's officially garbage now.

If you're buying this, just know that you're only going to get 1-2 years of daily use out of it and it looks like it's made to last till just outside of the warranty when used daily. If you're fine with that, then it's a pretty good grinder. Seeing as how I can't justify paying $50 a year to use a coffee grinder, I just got a manual ceramic burr grinder to replace it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent quality and a major improvement over a cheaper Capresso unit
reviews.reviewText:
I got this as a gift intended to replace my Capresso burr grinder, which had a plastic grounds bin. Since pros of the unit have been covered in a lot of reviews I'm going to do this as more of a comparison and list of the improvements in this unit over the cheaper one. I grind coffee every day for a french press (coarse grind).
1. Fairly airtight hopper should keep beans fresher. Hard to be objective about this but the lid seems to be well sealed. The hopper holds slightly more than a half pound of beans.
2. Better quality grinders that appear to be made out of stainless steel. Overall the grind appears more consistent; the Capresso machine produced some finer dust and the Bodum one is producing some larger shards but these shards are very thin.
3. Glass grounds bin. This bin plus the design of the lid vs. the plastic bin in the old machine reduces static greatly. If you have ever used a plastic grinder you probably are familiar with the problem of coffee grounds shooting vertically out of the bin at every opportunity. It's actually kind of impressive but creates quite a mess. This bin's lid has a hole in the center which helps prevent this, and with glass, there is much less static overall.
The bin is thin glass and I could see it breaking easily, but mine is intact so far.
4. Quieter, and in addition to being quiet the sound is more pleasant. It doesn't scare my cats.
5. Precise timer. As others have said, it goes up to 20 seconds only. That is not a problem AT ALL for my french press use of the machine, but if you make large pots of drip coffee it might not be enough.
On the Capresso machine, the timer did go much longer, but it was very inaccurate. You could have the timer in a particular spot, move it, and put it back and get a different length of grinding.
6. Design. This unit has a modern, nice look (I got the off-white one, really just because it was cheapest.)

reviews.reviewTitle: Well worth the price. Reliable, convenient burr grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I've owned 4 burr grinders over the years. A manual, pioneer-style grinder, an inexpensive Braun burr grinder, a very expensive Rancilio Rocky doserless grinder, and this - The Bodum Bistro (mine is orange).

My Rancilio was my favorite, but it's strictly for grinding straight into a portafilter for espresso. My manual grinder provides the best results, but it takes 3 minutes to grind your coffee each morning. The Braun was very inexpensive (about $35) and was OK, much better than the pulse grinders that give you grounds of all different sizes (not what you want).

So, how do I like the Bodum Bistro. Well, I love it but I just can't give it five stars, because it's not the ultimate coffee grinder.

What it is though is a very well designed, legitimate coffee grinder that makes my mornings very efficient. You set the grind, and you set how long you want to grind and these settings remain, so when you want to grind your beans, you simply depress one button and it takes care of it. It's fairly loud, but it takes only about 10 seconds so it's not too bad. One major advantage of this device is that it employs a glass hopper, instead of Plastic.
