It's easy to clean, and it doesn't have the static problem you get with plastic hoppers.

I also like the size of this device. It's quite small, but the hopper is relatively large.

All in all I think they really put some thought into this product. I've been using mine for over a year and I have no intention of replacing it any time soon.

Note - I use this to grind for a one-cup Mellita pourover that uses #2 paper filters. I get a good balance between speed (takes 3 minutes between grinding and taking my first sip (my water is already at 208° thanks to my Japanese hot water pot that keeps hot water ready at all times.)

Pros-

Relatively inexpensive
Small footprint
Glass hopper for the ground coffee
Large hopper for the whole beans
Timed grind for convenience, simplicity and consistency
No need to hold a button while grinding. Just push once and you're good
Much better results than with a blade grinder

Cons-

Result not quite as good as manual grinder (but better than many other grinders under $300)

Recommendation - If you currently use a blade grinder, do yourself a favor and move up to a burr grinder. It makes an enormous difference. This is a very good one.

reviews.reviewTitle: I would buy it again but looks like I won’t have to any time soon
reviews.reviewText: The grind is consistent. It grinds fine when I want a fine grind and when I want course it grinds course. I’ve had this grinder for 3 years and use it almost daily and sometimes multiple times per day. The only complaint I could have is the top of the lid has somehow become sticky. I don’t know how this happened. Soap water won’t clean it off. I think this is a quality burr grinder and worth the purchase.

There are tow models of the Bodum Bistro Burr grinder. This one (11750-01US) which Amazon calls the Standard Burr Grinder, has a plastic grind catcher and throws grinds all over regardless of how the grind catcher is installed. It's so bad that there are posts debating how to prevent the mess. It also does not have a timer, so will run continuously until you shut it off. The other model (10903-01US) Amazon's Premium Burr grinder, comes with the glass grind catcher, has a built in timer, and a clutch to protect the burr and gears.

I have both and the Standard grinder builds up grinds in the top hopper that requires removal of the hopper to clean quite often. The premium model also has a clutch to prevent damage to the unit in case something not grindable, such as a small stone, gets into the grinder. That and the plastic gears, all but ensures that the standard model will fail sooner than later.

I have had this grinder for about 5 years. The carafe finally got broken. Apparently no replacement is available from Bodum. After measurements and Amazon search found: "Stainless Steel Double Wall Camping Mugs (2-Pack); 10-Ounce Capacity Brushed Metal Coffee Cups w/Double Wall Insulation". Manufacture is listed as Darware, cost is $10 for two. These fit perfectly (tight) without the carafe lid. So far have not seen problems due to lack of lid. They are metal, so tapping to get the ground remains from the cup is OK.

I used it every day, usually only once in the morning. If I used it twice I was careful to wait between grindings because the instructions say it has to cool. It worked well until yesterday morning. I turned on the power and the light came on, and then I pressed the button to begin the grind and ... nothing. No click, no rattle, no movement, not a sound. Just silence. I cleaned it out thoroughly, got out the manual and took it apart and used a soft brush to sweep out all the coffee. Reassembled and ... still nothing. It's a mystery. I used the burr grinder in my Krups coffee maker daily for years and it still works fine. I'm very disappointed that this grinder failed and so soon. I called Bodum support and she said they would mail a replacement to me after I send them a .pdf of the receipt, which I did. But I got an email reply saying they were completely out of stock of those, in any color. I am not sure what will happen now. Is this item being discontinued? I would not choose this grinder again, given this experience.
EDIT: Dec 2013 - I re-contacted Bodum in September, just before the one year warranty would end in November, and attached all the emails from the spring. They never replied but in a week a new grinder showed up at my front door. Editing my review to add a star since they did come through.
The last thing I want to do in the morning is clean up spilled coffee. This grinder is horrible. Coffee everywhere except where it should go. Garbage.

reviews.reviewTitle: At Last, a Grinder with No Static Electricity Issues
reviews.reviewText:
Having used both Capresso and Cuisinart grinders previously, both of which had issues with static discharge causing grounds to fly out of the container, it was a relief to discover this Bodum grinder. Unlike the other brands, this one dispenses grounds into a glass (rather than plastic) container, thereby avoiding the static issues that had plagued the others. Amazon reviewers of various brands of coffee grinders have reported widely different experiences with the static electricity problem, so what works for one person may not work for another. But if you have had static issues with other brands of grinders, this Bodum may be worth your consideration.

The instructions indicate that this grinder should not be run for more than 20 seconds without a five minute (!!) break between grinds. That's hardly optimal for anyone who wants to brew a moderately large pot of coffee. To produce the quantity of grounds that we require to brew eight cups of moderately strong with our drip coffee maker, we need to run the Bodum grinder for 20 seconds, and then another 15 seconds. We have found that taking a short break between the two grindings (measured by the time it takes to fill the coffee maker with water and install the paper filter) seems to be sufficient; at least our Bodum grinder hasn't yet overheated or shut down using this procedure. Fortunately, it comes with a two-year warranty, which should be sufficient to let us know whether our operating procedure is ultimately harmful to the device.

reviews.reviewTitle: Like having a Ferrari in your kitchen
reviews.reviewText: Seriously, not based on anything scientific, but having done a pretty fair amount of Googling, this is a really good value in a burr grinder. We've been using it daily for 2 1/2 years and it's pretty tough. When my son needs to give an expensive gift, this is one of his go to picks. Two minor nits. We're a two coffee lover household; his espresso and my French press. Making that adjustment by rotating the hopper is a bit of a pain and heaven help the other party if I'm first to the kitchen in the morning and forget to check if he's swung it back to my grind after his use! However, the thinking behind implementing this mechanism probably led significantly to keeping the price down so that's a decent tradeoff. If he hadn't been doing months of experimentation on pre-ground roasts I would think the solution is a second grinder. Not as outlandish as it sounds as it doubles the life of the one machine, we always would have a backup and someday he will fly the coop. The other nit is no fault of the Bodum, but of the love of the bean. Grinding is messy. Some people buy vacuumns just for this; I can't bring myself to that. Several years ago I purchased the Plastic Stackable Jewelry Tray 1" Deep Black ([...] on Amazon and that solves the problem by coraling 99% of the effluence and is just large enough to hold the grinder and a small canister of beans. Still messy, but a contained mess. Cheers, Al

reviews.reviewTitle: terrible product, terrible, price, terrible service
reviews.reviewText: This grinder worked for one grind. The second time I tried to grind beans, it gave half chopped beans at best. Looked like flakes from Folgers just larger. After the first grind, which went fine, I cleaned it completely as directed, and stored it. Pulled it out 1 month later, and garbage. Really, I was shocked at the quality of the product and do not recommend it. I tried cleaning it several times, and tried to find assistance online to help - which was fruitless. It was a waste of 80 bucks. I would rather have the hassle of going to the store to get ground coffee now, as the bitterness of this product, and the price, pretty much convince me not to grind my own beans.

After 1 damaged motor on original product after 6 months, a replacement was sent to me and now the beans are only being broken up, not ground after 6 months (again).

Other than that, when it functioned, it did a very good job.

Amazon's return/refund policy is pretty awesome. I am getting a refund for this purchase and I will seek out a different option.

Bodum's claim process was inconvenient and not organized. Hopefully they improve.

I originally gave this one star after it clogged and I had to clean it out. After cleaning it would not grind beans. The motor would spin and the beans would bounce around in the hopper with only a few getting through not much smaller than when I put them in. I could not figure it out. I took it all apart and examined how it should grind and it made no sense at all. Just as I was about to break it all apart in frustration I discovered I had left the top part of the grinding burr out after cleaning. I put it back in and it was like a miracle. The lesson I learned from this is never grind more beans at a time than the reservoir can hold and always keep track of what you take apart. If you grind more beans than what the reservoir will hold, they will back up and clog, especially the oily beans. By the way, I contacted Bodum customer service not asking for a new one but just ideas how to fix it and they offered a free replacement as long as I had the receipt up to two years after purchase. I did not even buy it from them but from Macy's online and they still offered to replace it. Still think the coffee doesn't taste as good as out of my cheap Krupps blade grinder but its a lot easier to use.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinder is good, Bodum customer service is terrible
reviews.reviewText:
The grinder works well and does the job, but you're out of luck when it comes to replacement parts - Bodum's customer service is terrible. I lost my glass container while moving so I ordered a new replacement online ($8). The replacement piece came and on first use a piece of glass broke from the center of the bottom and went into the coffee machine. It was not an impact break; it was a defective component. Bodum's response was that they do not have a warranty on glass so they asked me to buy it again.

Additionally, the rubber top does not come with replacement. The grinder is a mess without it. So, Bodum's response is to buy a new grinder if that needs to be replaced.

All-in-all, works well, but would definitely not buy Bodum products again. Not worth it...

reviews.reviewTitle: Great burr ginder for home use
reviews.reviewText: Ever since my husband saw my brother's fancy burr grinder (the brand escapes me, but it cost a pretty penny), he has wanted one. I was able to find one of these Bodum burr grinders at a local store at a very good price and gave it to my husband as an early Christmas gift. We got the red color, which is a fun accent (we leave it on our counter). We have had ours for over a month now and use it daily. The results are great. We make coffee using the french press, using a cone drip (when we only need one serving) and also with a traditional coffee maker. The beans ground by this grinder work well with the three methods of making coffee that we use. Anyway, I would definitely recommend this burr grinder to others. One thing that I did notice is that it is not as big as the burr grinder my brother has (his is quite tall), which I see as a positive feature. The little glass jar with the silicone lid on this grinder is also a great touch. I thought at first that it would leave a big mess, but it actually does quite a nice job of keeping all the grounds in, and not all over the counter top.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lasted One and a half years.
reviews.reviewText: I really love this coffee grinder, but it has let me down after 1.5 years. I could take it apart and try to fix it, but I don't have a abundance of time for that. The problem is the switch, it just clicks, and does nothing. I can't stand blade grinders, but I have a hand powered burr grinder until I figure out what to replace this with.

When my coffee grinder that I have had for years and years died, I thought how will anything compare? Started to research all Bodum products and found this little jem. I went with Bodum which is what my deceased grinder was and can only hope it lasts half as long. I like the color choices, I get so tired of black and chrome and the ease of use and cleaning, I also appreciate the glass, yes that's right - real glass - container with this machine. It makes very little noise, grinds quickly and there is no static because of the glass. It takes a few seconds to grind coffee beans for my first cup of the day. I've seen reviews where people complain that you can't grind a whole can at once, doesn't that really go against why you grind coffee beans in the first place - so that the ground coffee is fresh? Anyway to each his/her own opinion. I do not think anyone could go wrong with this Burr Grinder unless you want to grind enough coffee for a party - then, of course, you need something else. But if you want a few cups or one this is the grinder you will be happy with. Go crazy and get a red or green one, go against black and chrone.

I bought this grinder after extensively researching many different makes and models. I had been using a blade grinder for use with a Bodum Chambord French press and have never been able to get a consistent grind. I always ended up with chunks of beans mixed with very fine powder. There's just no way with that style grinder to get a uniform grind, something that's imperative to get the most out of your French press.

The Bistro grinder has an attractive, well thought out design. The top canister holds about 3/4 lb or so of whole beans and is sealed by a rubber gasket with a silicone rim to ensure they stay fresh. The grind setting is easy to set and goes from coarse (French Press) to Espresso. The timer is nice in that it doesn't tick down like an egg timer but stays where you set it. It's great once you figure out the time needed to get the right amount of grounds for your morning brew as you don't have to reset the timer every day. Grinding is quiet and produced a very consistent coarse grind without many "fines". I haven't used the other settings yet so can't speak to those. The taste of coffee from the press is markedly improved with less sediment. There is a 20 second limit to each grind time with a recommended 5 minute wait between grinds; worth considering if you need a lot of grounds at once but not an issue for me. I use about 4 tablespoons of grounds in my press and it takes about 10 seconds to produce that much.

The glass canister has a nifty rubber top that sits flush with the grinder housing and prevents dust from spilling out. The glass is also less static-prone than the plastic in my blade grinder. The whole unit is easy to disassemble and clean as well. Also, there is a cord wrap space under the base to help minimize cord clutter.

Overall, the build quality is just excellent with every component serving a function and working as it should. For the price, quality, aesthetic, etc. this was the right choice for me. Highly recommended.

I did quite a bit of research before purchasing a new coffee grinder. The reviews on the Bodum site were stellar, not a grain of coffee appeared on the counter as this nicely designed burr grinder prepared the specified quantity of perfectly even grounds, static-free. The coffee is delicious and fresh.
However, unless we let the jar sit for an hour or more after grinding, static causes grounds to fly all over the counter when emptying the ground coffee into the pot.

Also, after about a week we noticed grounds building up under the base... So, I emptied all the beans, inverted the grinder, and peered into the motor with a good flashlight. The motor housing is filled with coffee grounds! Most drop into the jar, but not all. A lot winds up on the counter.

reviews.reviewTitle: Terrible product returned... stopped grinding after just a day of use
reviews.reviewText:
I've only ground a few shots worth of espresso and already it has stopped working. The motor struggles, speeding up, then slowing down. The burrs become clogged, and grinds stop coming out. I tried cleaning it, and it worked for half a dose, then clogged again. It went from producing 17 grams of espresso grind at 15 seconds, then dropped to 11, then less than 2. Then it starts burning what little amount comes out.

Also, the grinds aren't fine enough. With 30lbs of tamping pressure (unpressurized portafilter) and 17 grams of espresso (2 shots) the extraction time is just over 12 seconds, which is barely enough. No more crema is produced than regular store-bought pre-ground espresso, with a pressurized portafilter, which was also very disappointing.

I'm returning this awful product. If you make espresso, this isn't the machine for you.

I’ve had this for about 4 years. The soft texture it’s made of is sticky so it’s hard to clean and it makes your hands sticky. Other issue is you need to tap or shake it forward to get all the coffee out or it spills out and makes a mess. Last issue is it started to get stuck. I had to break the beans apart because they got stuck in the burr grinders.

I too have had issues with ground coffee getting into the grinder housing. I sent this email to Bodum Support:

“I have a question/concern regarding your coffee bean burr grinder. Awhile back, my first Bodum burr grinder failed. Thinking that I might be able to fix it, I took it apart. I found the grinder body filled with packed ground coffee from the bottom of the chamber to the top. I pitched it and immediately ordered the newest model, the Bodum 10903 Bistro (not sure how long ago, can't find the receipt, but likely less than 2 years ago). At any rate, this model is showing signs of the same issue. Gently tapping on the sides produces coffee grounds beneath it. How does this happen? What steps can I take to prevent a second failure?”

Here is the response I received from Bodum Support:

Hello Albert,
“We do apologize about the issue you are having with grinder.
Try to run a few tbsp of dry white rice through the unit and see if this will solve the issue.
Thank you,
Samantha”

Really, run white rice through it???. My response to that was to go by a Capresso Burr Grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: So That's How Coffee Should Taste
reviews.reviewText:
Okay. To be honest, I'm not much of a coffee drinker but thought it would be nice to have this when company comes. To familiarize myself with the grinder, I carefully followed the instructions and ground my first batch. Freshly ground coffee has the most amazing aroma. Much to my surprise, now the coffee tastes so much better that I've started drinking it again.

I use the medium setting since I have a drip coffee maker and it works perfectly. It is noisy but it has to be - it's grinding hard coffee beans, after all. The only problem I have is that it's a bit messy. No matter how hard I try to shake out the last bit of grounds, some still manage to escape and get on the countertop. Easy cleanup but, still, something better avoided.

A nice-to-have would be a lid for the ground coffee container. It comes with a plastic lid that has a hole it in through which the grounds fall. However, if there are leftover grounds, it would be nice to seal them in the container.

It's well built and sturdy, plus the grinder's outer surface has a non-slip rubbery feel to it. The power cord can be stored under the unit, but it's more trouble than it's worth. Cleaning the grinder gear is easy, too.

Good overall product for the price, but nothing I would rave about. Have only been using it for 3 months, so can't speak to the longer-term reliability.

Pros:
- Holds large quantity of beans and keeps fairly fresh
- Instructions on underside of lid are easy quick reference
- Not too loud
- Grind is consistent

Cons:
- Glass grind container advertised as eliminating static issue of plastic containers does not hold true; the resulting static is incredibly annoying and makes the area around the grinder/coffeemaker a mess all the time
- Max 20-sec grind time before needing to let unit sit for 5 min (should be able to design product better than this)(
- Instructions on underside of lid could be more well thought out (try to be short and to the point, which I appreciate, but feels like designer took shortcuts on making it really useful)

reviews.reviewTitle: Plastic gears between motor and burr fail
reviews.reviewText: Had this grinder for a little over a year under light use. Unfortunately, the gears between the motor and the burr are cheap plastic, and one of the gears failed. This lead to a horrible noise whenever the grinder was operated and eventually the gear box will fail entirely. If you are looking for a quality long term investment avoid this product.

reviews.reviewTitle: It is OK but not great
reviews.reviewText: I have owned this grinder for about 3 years, and grinder about 60gm of coffee a day. I am now looking for a replacement as the motor is starting to wear out I think. What used to take 10 seconds to grind, now takes 30-40. It is a good grinder for the price, and have recommended it to a few people. However, it just doesn't seem to last.

reviews.reviewTitle: The grinder actually grinds fine, but I hate how messy it is
reviews.reviewText: The grinder actually grinds fine, but I hate how messy it is. There are coffee grounds left in the shoot, and when you replace the glass jar, grounds dump onto the base and inevitably over surfaces around. You have to vacuum up every time you use it. Another less annoying design flaw is the lid of the bean silo. The flange is very shallow. There is no feedback letting you know that the lid is actually in place, and it pops up very easily. Bodum's small appliances look cool but have many fundamental design flaws. I have the grinder and the Bistro coffeemaker; I purchased them for their aesthetic appeal. However, if you are after performance, choose another brand.

reviews.reviewTitle: For a Coffee Grinder, it is very clean
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder is squeaky clean and tidy, and that's been my biggest problem with grinders. The glass container with a great rubber/plastic lid keeps stray grounds under control. I notice a couple of other reviewers who have complained about stray coffee grounds but I don't find that to be a problem. It looks great, and it does a precise job of grinding at the various settings. The 20 second limit for "avoiding overheating the motor" is a pain if you are wanting to grind very much coffee at once. In other words, you are supposed to let the motor cool for 5 minutes for every 20 seconds of operation. This could be a deal breaker for some potential buyers.

The 20 second limitation was not a problem for the first ten months or so, because the grinder would generate about six tablespoons of coffee which was fine. That efficiency diminished during the last couple of months until it only produced about 2 1/2 tablespoons. However, upon reporting this to Bodum they replaced it with a new one, which is fine.

I'm very surprised this item has a 4 star rating. Perhaps it has something to do with the dark roast beans I tend to favor or maybe I just the one bad unit in the batch.... I don't know... what I do know is I'm rarely this disappointed with a purchase.

The unit worked okay for the first couple weeks but it always took a long time to grind all the beans. It didn't seem to matter if I had it on a fine setting for my coffee machine or on a coarse setting for my french press. The unit requires that you preselect how many seconds it will run for before you turn it on. The knob only goes up to 20 seconds. I always found this to be very frustrating because to grind enough coffee for an entire pot, I had to run it for at least 40 to 60 seconds. The beans progressed through the grinder very slowly. THEN I read that after 20 seconds of operation, it is recommended to give it a 5 minute break or one risks damaging the motor...seriously? 20 seconds? I would be lucky to get enough beans for a single cup of coffee in that time. I don't know about you but I don't want to spend 20 minutes grinding my coffee every morning just so my poor little coffee grinder doesn't overwork itself.

Then things went from bad to worse: beans just stopped grinding...period. I thought maybe it was just clogged up so I took it apart and cleaned the grinder itself and the dispenser chute and everything else I could find that had coffee grounds on it... which were everywhere. By the way, did I mention this was because the unit stopped grinding beans part way through? So when I took it apart, whole beans and grounds spilled everywhere, despite my best precautions. Cleaning seemed to restore the device's original lackluster but still functional performance....for a short time.

Things kept going downhill from there.... I went from having to clean it every couple of days to every single day and eventually to the point where I would have to clean it out 2 or three times just to get enough beans for one measly pot of coffee. What would happen is about 20% of the beans would actually be ground then it would just clog up and while it was still running and sounding like it was working fine....no further beans would be moving through it. So I would keep having to take it apart with beans still in it (as I mentioned before, making a big mess and wasting coffee beans) to get a little bit more ground each time before progress would come to a halt. Please don't forget that according to the instructions, I should be waiting 5 minutes in between each clog before turning the machine on again. I suspect they designed it to clog up so one would have something to do while they were waiting for the motor to rest.

To sum up: I have no explanation for why some people have had better results with this than myself and can only speculate that maybe dark roasted beans are harder to grind than medium or light roast. My firm opinion though is that this coffee grinder is a complete an utter piece of worthless garbage. It would be a considerable waste of your time and money to purchase it-- you'd be better of grinding your coffee with your teeth. Buy something else!

We purchased this burr grinder a year and a half ago. I want to say that its still going strong and we love it! At first I was a little worried as some reviews mentioned motor burn out. Because of that I was careful (especially at first) not to grind too much coffee at a time. But, hey! having fresh ground coffee is the point, right? Typically we fill the hopper 3/4 full and have used our Bodum every day or every other day since we purchased it. Our previous Capresso, though long lived, would only grind (barely) for a gold cone filter at the last setting. We would never have been able to do espresso. The Bodum's grind choices are across the board. We're grinding for the gold cone just shy of middle. Too true that the design, with a glass container, considerably reduces the grounds flying all over (as our previous Capresso experience.) There's still clean up after grinding but not nearly as much. Also, its easy to take apart for cleaning and put back together! And, finally, we love the look of it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinding plates touched on fine setting
reviews.reviewText:
Upon receiving the unit, I tested it by turning the motor on and rotating the hopper toward fine. At about 1/4 of the way towards max. fine, it started to sound like metal on metal. l think what was happening is this unit was out of spec on the clearance between the grinding plates. I dared to turn in all the way fine for only a second and metal sound got so much worse the motor started to bog down. This is with no coffee beans.
I decided to keep it, thinking maybe it needed to break in. After using for a few weeks on the middle to coarser end of the scale, I occasionally went a little finer, and always got the same metal grinding sound. Definitely was never able to go all the way to fine. I was afraid I'd have metal bits in my coffee.
I have been around several other brands of burr grinder and never experienced this, including a Baratza Encore that a friend has. The Baratza could be turned fully to fine and still sounded smooth.
I finally decided to return it and ended up getting the Capresso Infinity. It works great all the way down to fine.
The only reason I give this two stars is that it really is a slick looking, nicely (at least aesthetically) designed device. I wish it worked because it is really compact and looked nice on the counter. I loved the rubberized textured enclosure and the red highlights. Too bad the manufacturing controls around the mechanical parts is sub par. Such a shame that companies put all their $ into marketing and throw the quality control out the window.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's too expensive for the quality
reviews.reviewText: We actually have three of these is various parts of the family, and they look quite nice. I also like the glass jar for ground coffee. However, there are two problems you will eventually experience. First, the burrs get dull, and Bodum does not sell replacement parts. It will take longer and longer to grind the same amount of coffee. The second problem is in the switch mechanism. When I press the start button, the amount of time it grinds has become random. Sometimes it grinds as long as expected for a given setting, and sometimes only for a second or two. This morning I hade to press the button 25-30 times to make coffee. I have taken it apart to thoroughly vacuum it out, but that did not help. My guess is the electronics. If you are handy, your could replace that board too, but it isn't available either. I am actually looking at the Amazon today to find a replacement grinder.

Having used other grinders (and still use old ones for the unleaded beans) I love this one for the price. It is quiet, and cleaner than many others. I've seen others complain about the mess with scooping it out, but that is going to happen with most any unit that doesn't directly dump into the portafilter. You could hold the portafilter under this unit, but I don't think the time can be set quite that exact to get just the right amount of grounds. (it is only a 100 dollar unit after all, the second cheepest out of five I have).

It even took on a rock today. BTW, those who describe the unit making noise and jumping around and/or not working need to check to see if there is a rock in the grinders. It is not all that uncommon to get them in bags of beans and if your lucky the machine grinds it up and there is no problem. Mine was jammed so bad I had to crush the rock with a pair of needle nose pliers before I could get it apart. I cleaned it up and waited for the thermal breaker to cool down (another thing people need to check on). I was happy to find it fired up once cooled down and is grinding beans just fine.

While it is true the grind needs to be adjusted daily, this usually has more to do with the weather, humidity, temp, and such. This is actually normal. Ask any Barista. That is why grinders have so many settings, or the newer ones now are stepless so as to be able to adjust infinitly. I will admit here though that this thing can go to extreems, that is from an 18 second shot one day to a 32 second shot the next. Readjust, and enjoy.

After about 6 or 7 months of use, I noticed that there were little piles of coffee grounds on the counter after each use. I finally figured out that the grounds were coming from the apertures in the bottom of the casing. I took the grinder apart and, sure enough, the casing was full of coffee grounds. The conduit between the grinder and the outflow is not properly protected. So I gave up on it; too messy.

I was using french roast in a fine grind. Other roasts and/or coarser grinds might not be a problem. But at this price I would expect a better implementation. I had some other gripes but they were minor in comparison. Not recommended.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bought it 3 years ago for making 2 or 3 ...
reviews.reviewText:
Bought it 3 years ago for making 2 or 3 cups a day. Looks 5 star. When it was new i put the grinding time on the max 20 sec and it was enough for my strong tastes. Now i put it on 15 sec and after it is done push it again cause the blades are not as sharp, this gets me 30 sec total cause the blades are less sharp but this is a minor issue.
If you don't know an arabica from a robusto bean just get a hand held unless you are rich with no debts. If you always grind your own and you are not in debt buy it. It does not result in using less coffee but i am fussy and find it a little easier than dealing with a hand held cause i dump the caraffe into a paper filter over the sink and this is slightly easier than doing it with a hand held.

I bought this grinder in May. Everything went ok until December, the plastic ring on the top part of the burr snapped off after adjusting the grind size. I thought to myself, this should be no problem. Searched online and it seems to be a common problem. And it's still under warrantee and things happened. So, I first contact Bodum via their contact form. A few days later I got the e-mail asking for my receipt. I scanned it and replied back the next day. And that's the last I heard of them.

I sent the follow up e-mail in late December and again in January. Never get any reply back at all. I just sent them the e-mail again (April 15) & post on their facebook before my warrantee expire just for kicks. Will update if I hear anything back, but I'm not holding my breath though.

So, anyone who want to purchase this grinder, beware that you are on your own. Bodum don't really care once you bought their merchandise.

*EDIT*
Surprisingly, I got the reply back the next day. They did apologize for the horrible customer service and will send me the replacement unit + 25% off coupon. It should arrived within 6-8 days according to Bodum. I'll update again when I get it.

*EDIT2*
The grinder arrived as promised.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bodum does not honor their warranty
reviews.reviewText:
Purchased for retail price of $99.95. I really loved it however ours now has an electronically
Issue, and Bodum will not stand behind the product. Nine months is not the lifespan I expected for a $100 coffee grinder. And I refuse to support companies who don’t stand behind their products. My replacement will not bear the Bodum name. Suggestions welcome.

I bought this grinder to replace my old Starbuck's Barista burr grinder that I'd owned for years. The Bistro has a few enhancements over the Barista, notably the glass coffee catcher, a timer that actually works, and an on/off switch. Personally, I think a burr grinder and fresh beans are the best investments you can make to improve home brewed coffee. This grinder makes an extremely consistent grind, which means less sludge in my french press coffee. For my 10 cup drip coffee machine, I've always used 1/3 cup of beans, which the Bistro grinds in about 18 seconds, so the 20 second time limit is perfect. Like others, I've found that the finest grind is a little too fine for my espresso pot, so I set it a notch or two coarser. For the money, ($79, but prices seem to vary) this is a best buy.

I have used this grinder daily until this morning for the last 2.5 years. This morning was the first time that I got a rock in my coffee beans and that rock broke the plastic ring around the burr grinders. I agree with all the users who say there is coffee everywhere, but I think that is the nature of the beast. I put a tray underneath it to create my morning coffee station since I use the french press. The only disappoint I have is the fact that Bodum does not sell replacement parts for this machine. For a company that sells replacement parts for almost everything else, I am shocked and hope they become more conscious in its sustainability practices. I will be ordering another one and hope that Bodum starts providing replacement parts. I gave 4 stars because there are no replacement parts.

This coffee grinder is well designed and made. It has a "solid" feel to it. I've not used a burr coffee grinder before. In the past I bought pre-ground coffee or occasionally bought beans and ground them in a little coffee mill. With that experience, it does take a little while to adjust the coffee/water mix to get the coffee just the way I like it - its just a learning curve.

I like that the grinder is easy to clean. I want appliances that make my life easier - not more difficult.

I know that the 20-second limitation has bothered some. I rarely need to make a large pot of coffee so that limitation has not affected me. In most cases I only need enough coffee for two people and we don't drink copious amounts at a time. I am easily able to grind enough coffee in the first 20 seconds to make that amount of coffee, so for home use this is fine.

The Bistro is a nice entry level Burr Grinder.
It is not intended to grind large quantities but should be good for homes with 1 or 2 coffee drinkers.
For those using Drip brewers this would be great, some indicate it can be used for espresso, others say not very good for that. Grinding for espresso is much more a challenge and I would think this entry level grinder would be hard pressed to do that well but once again it is an entry level machine so you can not expect it to be great at everything.
I only use it for drip brewing in my Bunn Phase Brew (HG) and it is great for that.
 BUNN HG Phase Brew 8-Cup Home Brewer

It appears to produce a nice consistent grind, I notice some large pieces at the large end of its grinding range. Medium and finer grinds look very consistent in grind size.
No noticeable dust produced..
The overall design appears to be good, Simple to operate, once you get it dialed in it is basically push one button every morning and it will do the rest.
The timer remains set where you want it until you change it which is a feature I like.
The glass grounds holder makes static buildup practically a non issue. Appears to be built well and is an attractive unit.
Being so new we have no idea how long it will last.

Price wise I will say it can be bought for much less if you check around. I got mine for $[...] shipped from BedBath&Beyond. Use one of their mail out %20 off coupons and if you ask they will even wave the shipping, not stocked in store, Most times it is hard to beat Amazon's prices but this is one time I was able to.

For the price I paid this is a value for someone wanting to get into a burr grinder. It is a entry level machine as grinders do sell for many hundreds and even thousands of dollars..

You pair this up with some good Freshly roasted Beans and a good brewer and you can produce a very good cup of coffee.

8 MONTH UPDATE:

I have been using this grinder for 8 months now. I use it every day and it has performed flawlessly. I grind on the coarse setting for use in a Clever Coffee Dripper Clever Coffee Dripper and the grinder performs like a champ..

I want to pass on an experience I had this morning... Somehow I managed to crack the glass grounds container. SO, I went to Bodum's web site to order a replacement.. No luck on the U.S. site but found it on the U.K. site. But it was out of stock and upon further digging found the U.K. site won't ship to the U.S. hummm SO... I placed a call to the U.S. contact number and the extremely nice helpful person with Bodum fixed my problem in 2 minutes. She said it is not an item they have for sale but she would look around the office and see if there was one they could send me... I offered to pay but she politely declined my offer and took my info and let me know she had one she is sending out to me today....

That is what I would call great customer service...

My opinion of the grinder has not changed from my initial review. I think for a low volume situation it is a very good basic burr grinder. After all $85 for a Burr grinder is definitely an entry level unit.. I do not do expresso so I can not comment on its ability for that but for a 1 or 2 person coffee situation it is a nice option. I have read that some users would like it to grind a bit coarser and that could be one thing to consider (French Press types maybe) and I want to repeat it is not suited for a high volume situation..

But what it does do it does very well..

I have never experienced any "Static" problems, I never have loose grounds on the counter ever, and it is basically a dump the beans in the hopper, press one button, and it's a done deal.. Love the timer that stays set where you put it.. easy daily ritual.. Takes me probably 10 seconds for the whole grind process (dumping beans in pressing button retrieving grounds). 15 seconds tops.

After 8 months I find that it always gives me a consistent grind day in and day out..

Oh and its a nice looking unit as well..

05/2013 UpDate:
2 Years + later and grinder is still going strong. No issues what so ever. This product is an A+ for a entry level Burr Grinder.. All my previous info still stands ..

However it Can be bought cheaper elsewhere...

reviews.reviewTitle: After 12 months, gears are worn out
reviews.reviewText:
I have enjoyed owning it for 12 months, but for the money, I wish that replacement parts were available or else that it was not built to wear out so quickly.

There are plastic drive gears that move the conical burr to grind the coffee. These WILL wear out in time, how quickly depends on the amount of use. It is impossible for their design engineers not to have considered this. For the original purchase price I'm sure there were alternatives to the parts they designed: using larger gears or using a tougher plastic are two options that come to mind quickly -- and I'm not even a product engineer.

These gears are designed to wear out pretty quickly intentionally and you should consider your 'investment' as disposable. Spare gears, replacements, are not available through the Bodom spare parts website. This means that Bodom has shot itself in the foot by designing and selling a product that works fairly well, for a while, but then fails and can not be brought back into service by ordinary users. It says in the manual that the only user service is to clean the burrs and to clean the outside of the unit, but if you do even a little bit of internet research on the Bodum 10903 you will find the gears don't last very long -- they are the most frequent failure-poijnt, but I have not found any source or mention of available replacement gears.

The grinder is good in a number of ways: color, outward design (neat plastic funnel bean holder, good quality grounds cup, soft plastic covering over most of the machine), function (pretty good grind), but its short intended span of service (lifespan) means that it is a poor buy.

Now to find something better!

reviews.reviewTitle: Products coating makes this a major hassle to clean
reviews.reviewText:
This product along with a lot their small appliances have this weir coating on them. Not sure if they tested this coating over a long period of time but after a year or two it starts braking down and becomes this gummy mess. All most of their products have this coating ( in have their toaster with the same problem).
The bean bin is hard to change beans to grind a different type of bean without making a major mess.
It grinds well enough but with so many other brands out their I don’t need the hassle this Grindr gives.

Had the grinder for a little over two years. One morning the little red button to start the grind wouldn't work. Not much use tearing it down as replacement parts are unavailable. Back to the cusineart that lasted 5 years for 1/2 the cost.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... few years now and I put it through some pretty tough use
reviews.reviewText: I've had this little unit for a few years now and I put it through some pretty tough use, that is to say all the way as fine as I can get it and for the maximum time every single morning without fail and I've more than happy with it but this morning the motor started going slower and slower and then it sounded like the gears were starting to strip out. I took it apart and cleaned all the beans and grounds out of it, put it back together and it started out ok but again, the motor started going slower and slower like it was under a heavy load, then it started sounding like the gears were stripping again. So, I think it has ground its last cup of coffee for me. What did I do? Well, I was so pleased with it I'm back here on Amazon ordering up another one just like it!

reviews.reviewTitle: O.K., but Wow is This Thing Flimsy
reviews.reviewText:
This is my first burr grinder and I had high hopes. I used it a couple of times this morning for the first time. Like others said, I don't think the coarse grind (when set to the unit's little French press symbol) makes large enough particles for a French press. But that's fairly minor. The lid to the top bean loader compartment is really dorky and awkward to use. A fixed, hinged lid would have been better.

Bodum says you can store a week's worth of beans into this, but the unit's not airtight so I'm not doing that and then taste my coffee get more stale each day. Before this, I'd only ever used a blade grinder. To me, the coffee from the Bodum tasted more bitter, but I'm just starting out with it and maybe need to ride the learning curve.

Overall, the whole unit feels cheap. The plastic bean loader/grind adjuster moves around a lot as you adjust it and the unit itself is very light in weight.

The 20 second timer engine burnout factor shows extremely poor design. If the engine is that sensitive, why install it in the first place? Still, I'd have to think it would be impossible for Bodum to confidently pin the blame for engine failure on the user if, theoretically, someone were to turn the grinder on two or three consecutive times without waiting five minutes.

I'm considering returning this for something else. Maybe a refurbished Starbucks burr grinder, which is made by Baratza and available for $80 from their Website. The Bodum Bistro may just be too inexpensive and cheaply constructed to hope for a good quality burr grinder.

UPDATE: Oct. 26, 2011

After almost a week I like this grinder a lot more. The bitterness I tasted vanished when I began steeping the grounds in my French press for 3 1/2 to four minutes instead of just two. Very smooth coffee now.

I also think that you can probably live on the edge and run the grinder for two consecutive grinding sessions without waiting five minutes. I have not done this, but I know someone who has and her Bistro is still purring along great. I can see how running it for five minutes straight could damage the motor. But 30 to 40 seconds?

Still feels flimsy and cheap, which I suppose it is. But this is a very good grinder in its price range and I think you'd need to spend a lot more for something better.

UPDATE: May 17th, 2013

I must have been luckier than those who gave this grinder one star because it broke soon after they bought it. Still going strong regardess of whether I grind lightly roasted beans or very dark beans. I still believe the whole unit feels flimsy and cheap, but it still works fine, and I'm getting consistently sized grinds for French press. There are always some "fines" as they're called, but very few compared to the the coarse granules I get. If you search a bit you can buy this for under $100, which makes it an amazing buy. I got it on Amazon for $67. Well worth it even if you pay more. Think of all the expensive coffee you now buy that can't possibly taste its best when ground with a blade grinder.

I've read a few comments from folks in the coffee business that whatever device you use to brew coffee is merely an accessory to the grinder. I tend to agree. If your grinder makes uneven, inconsistently sized coffee, what you end up drinking is going to suffer regardless of your coffee maker. I now steep the grounds in my French press for a minimum of five minutes, usually six, and the taste is much improved. I'm also roasting my own beans so my coffee is about as fresh as you can get it unless you grow your own.

reviews.reviewTitle: Relatively quiet, cool looking and clean! But how does the timer work?
reviews.reviewText:
Update: Worked well while it lasted. Now it won't grind for more than 2 seconds at a time. I can also no longer control the coarseness of the grind.

I just used mine this morning for the first time. I had tried using a Cuisinart burr grinder in the past and it broke on me twice. The Bodum is much higher quality. It feels sturdier and the glass really does reduce the static which makes the grinds fly everywhere.

I can't, however, figure out how the timer works. How many seconds = how many cups? One of the benefits of a burr grinder is eliminating the measuring scoop. But I find myself having to use the measuring scoop from the glass container. I'm sure there is a way to set the timer to get the number of cups you need in one go, but there's nothing about it in the instruction manual.

reviews.reviewTitle: Rubber degrades and becomes sticky over time
reviews.reviewText: As other reviews mentioned, the rubber exterior degrades and becomes disgustingly sticky over time. Early on, the start button stopped working reliably. I have to press the button repeatedly until the grinder turns on. The grind was sufficient for my needs, but I would not get this unit again.

Like others have said, I paid more for this expecting quality but it has died after just a few years. It worked well when it did but I won’t be buying another one or any other bodum products. Really disappointing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very disappointed in both product and company.
reviews.reviewText:
Unfortunately this was the worst customer experience I ever had with a company.
The unit worked for less than a week and could not handle the espresso beans I used, and would dunk up after every use. I did not get a receipt from the retail store I purchased it from since it's not a shelf item for them and the print out from their register did not reflect what item has been purchased . They wrote up a statement to confirm my purchase date and Bodum after telling me twice it will suffice as proof of purchase changed their mind and will not replace it under warranty. So the small local coffee shop has to stand up for the manufacturer's fault. Way to support your retailers and way to stand behind your product!
There is other grinders out there for the same price that will hopefully handle the beans they are made to grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: I LOVE the glass container for the ground coffee
reviews.reviewText: Have been using this Bodum Burr Grinder for about four years with no problems. I LOVE the glass container for the ground coffee. Really minimizes the static cling, and the mess. I took note of the instructions to wait five minutes between twenty second grinds, and promptly ignored them. We use it once daily to grind sixty seconds worth of beans, which pretty much fills up the container. We run three twenty-second bursts back to back, and have never had the unit overheat or fail. Your mileage may vary. When the machine does balk, a quick cleaning fixes the problem.

I have been using a Black and Decker blade grinder to grind my beans for about three years and have been told that a conical bean grinder would make a difference in the taste of the coffee. I was skeptical, but I had to find out for sure. After spending a fair amount of time looking at the different CBG's that are out there, I settled on the Bodum due to so many good reviews on not only Amazon's site, but several others on the internet.

After brewing my first batch of coffee, I was very surprised in the taste of the coffee. Using my Technivorm KTBS coffee maker and Starbucks House Blend, which I always buy in one pound bags from Sams, I brewed up a batch. It appeared to be less bitter, more aromatic, and EXTREMELY similar to any great cup of coffee that I have ever had in a coffee shop. I'm going to be experimenting in the future with the different settings on the Bodum, but right now I'm using the drip setting, and setting the dial to 15 seconds.

I'm using a delonghi bar32 with this grinder and the results are out Of this world. I can confirm that it does grind very small particles for espresso. A YouTube review by Seattle coffee gear on this grinder will show just how shocked they were when tasting an espresso made from this grinder and cheap machine. They do state it would work for pressurized filter machines only. So basically all lower end machines and a few higher end. So to all the reviews saying "not suitable for espresso" I say it in fact is. I didn't think going from a blade grinder to burr would impact the taste that much but it has. So for under 200 I am making drinks that Starbucks can drool over. You don't need expensive equip anymore to make espressos in your home. I'm talking tasty, mouth watering, don't want to swallow cause it tastes so good on my tongue stuff. Yeah.

7 sec grind finest setting will get yeah one shot worth for fyi.

Pros:
Quieter then blade grinder
Very even fine particles (haven't tried course settings)
No static (finally the struggle is over!)
Grinding blades are sharp, appear to be solid, quality metal
Look great

Cons:
20 sec wait time. Not an issue for espresso makers but I can see that for drip and some French press users.

reviews.reviewTitle: The container for the ground coffee beans is nice and large; Bodum makes great products
reviews.reviewText: Bodum makes great coffee grinders. You can select how coarse or fine you want it to grind very easily. It takes up a bit of space on your counter, but it's worth it for freshly-ground coffee. It doesn't have the timer on it, but that's not a problem for me.

I echo the words of many of the other reviewer here that a 5 minute-between-grinds wait time is a bit ridiculous. My theory is that this allows them to decline most if not all of the warranty repair requests. The grind quality is much better than my other electric grinder, but interestingly enough, my hand grinder actually gives more consistent grinds than this unit (not that this is bad, it's just not AS good as the hand operated unit). The glass catcher is nice because you don't have the static problems that you get with plastic catchers. The motor is fairly quiet. All in all, a good product, though I would like to see a motor that can grind more in a 5 minute period of time and a more consistent grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: Product failed and no replacement parts or customer service
reviews.reviewText:
Loved the design, worked well. But as other reviewers reported. plastic drive gears shredded.
No replacement parts available, and customer service was nonexistent.
Was hoping that for $100 I was not buying a landfill item, but that was the case.
Worked well for about a year with occasional episodes of completely locking up but after year and a half it has completely stopped working. Warranty department is non existent.

reviews.reviewTitle: When i took the box out of the shipping box it was obvious that the box to the grinder had been opened before and looked like so
reviews.reviewText: When i bought this item know where in the description did it say that i was buying a used product. I bought the grinder as a gift for a family member and wanted to see it before i gave it to them. When i took the box out of the shipping box it was obvious that the box to the grinder had been opened before and looked like some sort of label and been torn off on the outside. When i took the grinder out the whole thing was dirty covered in coffee grinds.All over the outside and the inside were covered in grinds. I am totally okay with buying used products, but not when they are not posted as used and show up not clean at all. Happy i looked at it before wrapping it up and giving it away.

I bought this grinder two years ago when it first came out and loved it. The grind is even and easily adjustable, and coffee tastes surprisingly better compared with my old blade grinder. Unfortunately it seems I loved my Bodum a little too much, as it inexplicably died after two years and one month of almost daily use. Even though it was a month out of warranty, Bodum replaced it for free, without me even asking (I e-mailed them to get a repair estimate.) It's always a pleasure dealing with companies that place a high priority on customer service. I recommended this grinder to all my friends even before I learned what a great company Bodum is. Doubly so now.

This grinder is fantastic. The grind is even and quick. We have had no problems with this item after our first month of use.

This being said, there are a small few recommendations for Bodum:
1. The glass container is a great complement to the grinder. However, it would be great if there were extra containers available for purchase with air-tight lids. This way there would be no need to mention the next recommendation.

2. Grinding different kinds of beans is a daily occurrence in my household. I drink espresso, my family drinks regular eight o' clock Columbian coffee. So, what happens when you empty the bag into the grinder for ease of use? The next person has to come along, unscrew the hopper, and empty it into a secondary container. Sure, you can try to only put in the amount you want, but it is a little difficult to hit that margin every time. Easy solution? See #1.

3. This brings me to the final suggestion. When grinding with this machine, the glass container really helps with static electricity. Yes, there is a very small amount of grounds that escapes every time, but it is in no way a major issue. The issue comes with the way the grounds are delivered to the container. They come vertically through the hopper into the conical burr grinding wheels. From there, they change direction to horizontally flow into the container. The problem that arises is the excess grounds that have just been ground, but were not able to be pushed through to the container. This is fixed by lightly tapping the side of the unit a few times while tipping it slightly forward, but this could have been offset by a small adjustment in the delivery system.

All in all, this is a product that I would recommend to just about anyone. Maybe not someone who is grinding lbs of coffee a day, but certainly the average homeowner who is looking to up his or her coffee savvy. The unit is well made and looks great on our counter sitting next to a Bunn coffee maker.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wouldn't Stand Behind It When It Suddenly Quit
reviews.reviewText: I purchased one about a year and a half ago and it suddenly quit. When I contact Bodum at first no one responded. I contacted them again and finally someone did, and told me that the unit had a two-year warranty. The catch—I had to send them a receipt. Who keeps a receipt for a small appliance like this for two years? Bottom line: they refused to stand behind it. There are plenty of other grinders out there from reputable companies. Don't buy this one.

Like many others, the stylish Bodum only lasted a short 3 months of week day usage (only 10 seconds of grinding a day). It's a hard choice picking a sleek modern grinder that is both affordable and doesn't take up so much counter space - so it is triply disappointing in many ways. If you find yourself swayed by the cool appearance, I would recommend reconsidering.

reviews.reviewTitle: A grinder should last 3 years with regular use and always be able to grind fine enough for espresso
reviews.reviewText:
I have been reading a lot of praising reviews of this grinder. If I wrote this 6 months ago, I would have been one of them.

If you need this to grind for espresso....stay away.
If you want this grinder to last you more than 6 months....stay away.
If you expect the company to replace anything, should something go wrong....stay away.

The burrs on this grinder will wear down very quickly. A grinder should last 3 years with regular use and always be able to grind fine enough for espresso. Shame on Bodum for putting out such a cheap product.

This grinder was a gift for my birthday in November, 2011. I immediately noticed that the grind settings were inaccurate. When I set them on drip, I had been getting a super fine grind and to get a coarser grind for drip I had to change the setting to French Press. Then, later on, when I used the French Press setting, the whole thing jammed up and coffee beans went everywhere. After that, I tried to grind fine for espresso but now I'm getting coarse grinds! So, now it's useless to me. I have emailed Bodum to get a full refund because I am thinking these problems are due to design flaws. Bodum has been completely non-responsive. I plan to call them next.
My previous grinder was the Capresso Infinity Burr Grinder, which never jammed and was able to accurately grind the coffee beans. The biggest problem with the Capresso was static electricity. Now I regret replacing the Capresso with the Bodum.

I've had mine for quite awhile and it works great. I love the fact the bean hopper has an airtight lid that lets you store quite a bit of coffee beans right in the grinder. This is super convenient as each day you simply turn on the power and push the grind button and it's done. I like my coffee a little stronger than my wife. I just set the grinding time a little longer when I make my cup for the ride to work. She she moves it to her preferred time setting for her cup. On the weekend the full 20 second grind is perfect when we make 2 cups. Everything has a high quality feel to it and the the motor and grinder really do the job.

Some people find it annoying that you have to wait 5 minutes between grinding sessions. So yes, if you make a large quantity of coffee at a time you should consider that. In my opinion, the glass cup is not 100% static fee. A very small amount may stick but I found that just tapping the bottom of the jar makes virtually all of the coffee fall out into my coffee maker basket. Plus, this machine is way better than the $60 Cuisinart grinder we used to have. That one had a plastic jar and there was a ton of heavy static. On that one, about 20% of the ground coffee would stick to the jar which was pretty annoying. It basically wouldn't come out no matter what.

Overall the Bodum blows away the Cuisinart. The Cuisinart was much louder and the build quality was much lower. We burned through 2 Cuisinart's, that's why we switched to the Bodum. All in all, a really nice machine for the money.

Bodum has a good reputation and I've had this coffee grinder for several months now so I'm ready to do a review.

I vary my grinds. Sometimes I use a Japanese mesh coffee filter which requires a very fine grind. Other times I use a standard coffee maker or French Press. Each grind has worked beautifully for me. However, I do have a problem with flecks of ground coffee adhering to the glass receptacle. One review said the glass would prevent this. At first I didn't have flecks but after about a month I did. Still, it's simple to use a soft towel to wipe out the glass receptacle when I change grinds. I wouldn't trade this coffee grinder for another.

Been in the coffee industry for over 10 years. I own at least 10 grinders, most of them commercial brands for our shops. This grinder is a pleasure to use both at home and in the shop. The burrs are made of quality material that will take a lot of abuse. I recommend this among quite a few other brands to customers as a good tool to use at home while making coffee. Cheers!

The grinder works well enough, but the glass catcher... It will break. It just will, you will drop it. The type of glass is a nice feature, but the company has no replacements. None. You can't order extras when you buy the machine. So you're out of luck when it happens. You have to use something else to catch the grinds, and that's harder than you think. Consider well before you purchase.

It was great... until the engine/motor stopped working within 2 years of purchase. We contacted Bodum - they told us to contact Amazon (the seller). Amazon was unhelpful, as was Bodum.

So, although it works well while you have it... be prepared for it to just stop working.

$100 for less than 2 years of use. Does that work for you? If so, could be worth it.

As others have mentioned in their four and five star reviews, this thing has a flaw. The max time in can run is 20 seconds and then you have to wait 5 minutes to run it again or risk motor burn out. Well I use a manual drip coffee cone most of the time. We also have a french press and espresso maker. I grind six scoops of beans for our carafe. It takes ~30 - 35 seconds to grind the six scoops so I have it set to 20 seconds. I grind for 20 sec, wait 4-5 minutes and then grind the rest. Waiting to grind is no fun. Why did they design this thing to run only 20 seconds every 5 minutes? This is annoying. Otherwise I have no complaints. I have used it twice so far. The mess is minimal and the grind is very even. It grinds so much better than the blade grinder we have been using for years.

10/10/2013 - I have had it ~3 years now. It is still running well. I upped the rating to 4 stars. The manual that came with the grinder stated to not run it more than once every five minutes to avoid overheating the motor. I still don't use twice in a row. I run it once, let it sit at least a minute or two while the water is heating and then run it again, usually 10-15 more seconds will finish the amount of coffee I use.

I have a confession to make.

I don't have either an axe OR coffee beans that need grinding. What I love is authentic steel cut oatmeal. The problem with most varieties is that the grains are hard, coarsely cut and require overnight soaking and a long time stirring and cooking on the stove top. Most mornings I'd just give up and pour cold cereal out of the box. Or use microwave packets...not the same texture or flavor...sigh.

But this lovely coffee grinder makes a perfect grist mill. On the fine setting, I can make oat flour to mix in for multi-grain homemade bread.

Ten seconds on the coarse setting grinds enough steel cut oats for one breakfast serving. Twenty seconds makes 2 servings. When grinding oats, the amount you put in the top will be the same volume coming out at the bottom so don't put more oats than what the receptacle below can contain.

Once the oats are ground, they can still be soaked overnight if you like that flavor, or you can stir in water and microwave for 2 minutes. Be sure to stir the oats before microwaving them as if you let them settle out they won't soak up the milk or water properly. Season to taste. Authentic rustic flavor and really sticks to your ribs!

Love my coffee grinder. Wondering if I could use it to make my own cornmeal?

Has been trouble free for us for more than five years of daily use. I wish it had a little bit longer timer setting, as I like my coffee strong, but it's not big deal, I just hit the button a second time and then stop it short after a few seconds.

I purchased this grinder to supplement a manual grinder for days when we didn't feel like turning a hand crank, and to replace a burr grinder that had serious static issues. I really liked the idea of a glass receptacle to prevent static issues and I saw this grinder had good reviews and wasn't as expensive as the KitchenAid. Now that we've had it for a few weeks, we're generally pretty happy with it. However, the glass receptacle doesn't completely eliminate the static issues. It's not as bad as ones with a plastic receptacle, but it's still there. Perhaps this is an inevitable side effect of burr grinders? Has anyone solved this problem?

I would recommend this grinder to anyone looking for a good burr grinder, but just don't expect it to be static free.
Way better than any blade grinder. Better than the crappy burr grinders. Cheap and comparable in quality to the baratza encore

reviews.reviewTitle: Best Grinder for the money and maybe more!!!
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this Grinder for my husband in January for his birthday. I was worried about some of the reviews of the machine getting clogged up, the 20 second timer, and whether or not it would grind nicely for espresso which the only thing my husband would use it for.

It is loud, but it is grinding coffee...it is going to be loud. My sister has a $400 grinder and her's is much louder than this one. My bedroom is across from the kitchen and when I am sleeping and he is grinding coffee, the noise is not enough to wake me and I am not a heavy sleeper.

It took a couple of cups for him to figure out the setting to get the grind just right for the espresso, but he has it all set now and it grinds wonderfully. We use the beans from the local coffee shop that he LOVES and now with this grinder and his espresso machine he says the coffee tastes EXACTLY like he bought it from the coffee shop only we are not spending $4 for it. The machine has never clogged up and it cleans up nicely. The glass grind catcher is nice because there is no static in the cup. The rubber seal on top of the catcher is wonderful. There is VERY LITTLE loss of coffee with this machine. Barely even enough to even clean. It is literally about 7-10 tiny pieces of grind that the machine losses. SERIOUSLY! My sister's losses about 1/8tsp and she spent 5X more.

We have not used it for large quantities of coffee so we have not had to worry about the 20 second timer, but we have used it to make multiple cups of espresso back to back. We just grind and brew the first cup and when that one is done we grind the second one. He has used it every day sometimes twice a day for the last 6 months and it is wonderful. He loves it and every time he makes his coffee he says that it is the best gift he has ever gotten. $90 well spent if you ask me considering the best gift he had ever gotten before this was his 50" flat panel TV that was $1400!

It grinds very well... when it grinds at all. Something in this machine is very finicky, and even on the first day out of the box, it sometimes won’t start. Maybe it thinks the hopper isn’t on securely? It feels like every morning I spend five minutes jiggling parts trying to convince this grinder to grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not good for French press users--grinds fine at all settings
reviews.reviewText:
Despite some concerns based on negative reviews, I decided to give this grinder a try because most of the reviews are positive.

Right out of the box, the machine ground coffee very finely--even at the coarsest setting. This is unacceptable, as I prepare coffee with a French press. So it's back to my 20-year-old, $10 Braun blade grinder. Ironically, the coffee from the blade grinder tastes better than the coffee from this $120 mistake.

Because I'm not the only one encountering this issue, it seems this product needs to be redesigned to offer more predictable grind consistency.

Grinder worked great for about a year. Then just stopped. I've had similar issues with other Bodum products. Sucker for design and now I'm paying for it. I will not purchase any more of their products.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Service Matches a Good Grind
reviews.reviewText:
I've used this grinder for over 5 years. It has always served me well. The best part is the glass canister. My father-in-law's grinder has a plastic one and when I use it I'm always thankful for my Bodum grinder.

Recently part of the grinder broke because I adjusted the grind roughly. I contacted Bodum about replacing the part and they simply sent me a free replacement part.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works well, but plastic casing gets sticky
reviews.reviewText: It's been reliable for about five years, but the plasticizer in the body and lid of the grinder caused it to get tacky after a couple of years. As a result, finely ground coffee sticks to the thing and it's nearly impossible to keep clean.

I was tired of getting a decent cup of espresso occasionally at home. It seemed that I could always pay for decent cup at a coffee shop. After my last blade grinder died I was going to replace it with another. Doing some research I turned my attention to a burr grinder but thought it was too much money for just a cup of coffee. The Bodum Bistro changed my opinion quickly. I found out on my first cup that the grind is everything. That is the only thing I have changed and I consistently get the coffee shop quality I was looking for 1/4th the cost.

What I specifically like about the Bodum are all the little things. The rubberized casing makes for a nice tactile feel along with sure grip taking it in and out of the cupboard. The glass coffee catcher eliminates all static and makes for a clean machine. The variable grind setting is easily marked. The simple push button and timed operation helps make every cup the same great taste as the previous one. The rubber cover for the coffee catcher keeps it in place snugly along with eliminating coffee getting everywhere. Even the cord holder has been thought through to allow you to have just the right amount of cord out at a time.

I've been using the Bodum for a month and have not had any problems with the grinder or the motor. I clean the machine each time I refill the bean container. So far so good. I am looking forward to a lot more use out of this excellent machine.

This grinder failed after about 7 months of relatively light use. It initially performed well when used for French press and drip coffee makers, but struggled in consistency when used later for espresso applications. The grinder was also often inconsistent in the time required to grind the same type and amount of coffee, even though it was only used to make enough coffee for one or two servings at a time.

Bought this for my husband, I gave this as a gift when he came from work, it didnt work at first. The start button got lost inside the grinder by only pressing it, he found the button and set it to work again, even when it finally started working the consistency of the grind was horrible. Do yourself a favor and skip this grinder.
I have used this grinder daily since 2014. A rock jammed it once, but I took it apart and works fine. Like the rubber ring around the glass. Great grinder. I’d buy it again if this one broke.

reviews.reviewTitle: So the expensive grinder is useless unless you want coffee grinds spraying out all over ...
reviews.reviewText: Grinder was OK - service in USA is non-existent! No phone number available in USA and they do not respond to your website requests for help. Glass coffee catcher is fragile and when it breaks there is NO REPLACEMENT PART available to purchase. So the expensive grinder is useless unless you want coffee grinds spraying out all over the place. Tried to rig something but can't fit the rubber top on anything I tested.I have been a loyal Bodum customer for over 30 years. I feel ripped off!

I really liked the simplicity and the look of the coffee grinder, so when my first one broke after 1 year of use, I bought another one in case I was just unlucky. Unfortunately, the second one just broke after 1.5 years. Same thing, the plastic ring around the burr. Not buying again unless they make some modifications :/

This is a Wonderful product and the best coffee grinder I've had. You can grind your beans to the finest powder possible if you wish or into a thicker consistency and it grinds very quickly. The beans may be stored in the top, sealed container where they remain fresh. I usually grind mine the night before so they are ready in the morning, and I wont wake anyone with the grinding noise. A fantastic gift for coffee lovers you know as well as a handy item for your own home.
Update: I still have this device in 2016. Used it every day all these years and still works great!!!
Update: Still using this everyday 2018 and still working great!

I've used mine every morning for 2 years and it still works great. The more expensive grinder I had previously didn't even last a year. I use mine for French press (we grind about a pound of coffee every week). I love that the carafe to catch the grinds is glass, even more expensive machines often come with plastic carafes and the static makes the grinds jump all over the counter. This one is relatively clean. Doesn't require much maintenance, I've only taken mine apart to clean out the burrs a handful of times over the course of two years, and it still works great. Definitely recommend this grinder and would buy it again.
After 1 year of use, it began smoking and smelling like it was going to catch on fire. Great product until this point. Poor longevity.
The 15 second grind only lasts about 4 seconds for me - doesn't seem to grind correctly. If there is a way to make this work correctly, I would be much happier!
If you're looking for a grinder that can grind espresso quality grounds on a budget, look no more. This grinder is everything I had hoped it would be.

While I haven't had this grinder for more than a week, I can say it was worth the purchase. I had a Breville conical burr grinder for about two years. The motor on that guy burned out just before Christmas. I figured that it couldn't hurt to go out and purchase a regular burr grinder from Sears given I was there already for Christmas shopping. Well a regular burr grinder could be heard for about 15 feet outside of my house when it was running. I couldn't take it anymore and decided to purchase a new conical burr grinder because they are quieter and do a much better job of grinding the coffee beans. I looked on amazon and found the Bodum conical burr grinder. I liked the look of the Bodum, the black one, grinder and decided to buy it. I am extremely impressed with the performance of this grinder. It generates a uniform grind and the glass hopper really does a good job at not stinking to the grounds. The one thing I can say bad is a 20 second maximum grind time is a bit off putting. Other than that I do not regret this purchase at all and like it even better than the Breville I had for two years.

reviews.reviewTitle: Figured out hot to make a prope espress grind!
reviews.reviewText:
I love this grinder for my Chemex drip brewing.

But if you're planning to use this for an espresso grind, don't buy this machine. The espresso grind output isn't fine enough.

[EDIT] I was somehow able to get a perfect espresso grind out of this machine! I pulled off the bean hopper and 1/2 of the burr grinder that's easily removeable. I re-assembled it, tried a grind, took it apart, put it back together, tried a grind, etc...for some reason, after a few times of doing this, the espresso setting actually produced a fine grind. Maybe the burr grinders don't perfectly align all the time?

My favorite feature is actually the automatic timer. I only grind one serving per time and I can set the timer so the machine grinds the perfect amount of coffee every time. No waste.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fine for a cup here and there
