reviews.reviewText: Fine for a cup here and there. Larger issue, cannot clean the burr grinder parts. The pathway gets clogged as they all will accumulate the finer particles with the oil from the beans. For this product, cannot clean or service. Not a good design.

Our grinder grinds the coffee just fine but it leaves little grounds EVERYWHERE. I literally have to wipe down my entire counter and the machine after each use. And it’s still has little grounds stuck on it that I can get to. Not a bad machine but i would recommend getting another one that won’t be so messy.

reviews.reviewTitle: my second one in two years just broke again
reviews.reviewText: this is the first review I have eve written, and I am doing it because I am so unhappy with this product. The first one I bought, the switch completely stopped working after about two months--the motor would not go on. So I had to send it back and get a new one. Now, about two years later the motor is burning out--running slowly or not at all. This is with normal use, two coffee drinkers in my household. it is junk!!

Don't buy. When it worked it didn't have a uniform grind. At that point I was only disappointed with how much I paid for it. After a year the plastic gears sheared leaving me with a disappointing grinder that I paid too much for that no longer works. Buy anything else.
It was great when it worked, but it stopped working after 1.5 years. There really should be a longer warranty, other people seem to have similar issues.

I bought this to properly grind whole beans for espresso. When I put the setting on the 'espresso' setting I get a beautiful oily powder that is so fine the water can hardly be pressured through it. I end up using a few clicks to the right to get a fine grind that water can permeate. This is an excellent grinder and it looks nice sitting on the counter. Now if only Bodum would make a matching espresso machine...

reviews.reviewTitle: Need better customer service at Bodum
reviews.reviewText:
I wanted so badly to like this grinder. I was looking for something that could better my grinding experience for every day coffee. But this grinder is messy, messy, messy! It gets coffee dust everywhere- it sticks to the grinder blades and drops when the glass container is not there, and it gets all over the top
Of the glass container when it is in place.

I've tried getting in touch with Bodum through email, phone and Twitter. Each time I have received zero response. Amazon hasn't been helpful at all because they can't find the receipt of the person who gave it to us. Just know that if you get this grinder you will be cleaning up after it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Only okay for drip or french press
reviews.reviewText: I bought this grinder for my dad for more consistent espresso bean grinding. I'm surprised at all the positive reviews on this unit. It just cannot grind fine enough for espresso. The grind uniformity is also very poor. I can take a small spoonful of ground coffee, spread it on the counter and see a wide range of size from dust to larger sized chips. Perhaps this is just a defective unit, but it's useless for espresso. Grinding more coarsely for drip or french press works fine, but then so does a 20 dollar blade grinder. I've had much better luck with the Capresso Infinity and Baratza burr grinders.
Broke after less than a year. Don't waste your money.

We got it on clearance at another retailer. Personally, I don't care for the look of it. The red dial and buttons look cheap and cheesey. The whole thing looks like a 70s-ish appliance to me. But the thing works which is more than I can say for the Cuisinart CBM-18. That POS stopped working after a few days. The Bodum has lots of settings, grinds well and can do a fine grind for espresso. Also, the cup catching the grinds is glass so you don't have to deal with static charge like with cheap plastic cups(like with the POS Cuisinart).

reviews.reviewTitle: Beware! They do NOT sell replacement parts for this ...
reviews.reviewText:
Beware! They do NOT sell replacement parts for this.

If you break the glass coffee catcher, there is NO way to replace it unless you buy a whole new coffee grinder.

OK,

I am the only coffee drinker in the house. I make myself a one "extra strong" coffee latte every morning. I take the beans out of the freezer and messure exactly how much I want, I set the grinder to the second highest settings. AND it takes THIRTY SECONDS to grind. That's right it takes about 30 seconds to grind coffee so you can fill your expresso machine to the max. You know the rest... the instructions say wait 5 minutes after 20 seconds of usage.... And I have a CHEAP espresso machine ($20.00 at building 19, in the day) and it can not handle coffee that is more fine, figure if your machine takes the finest, the burr may take 45+ seconds.

This is what I like about this machine... it is a BURR, it works well, it's pretty fast (even though I can't do all my beens in 20 seconds), overall it's pretty good. This is my second burr, but my first was a the cheapest piece of... you know what....

I OBVIOUSLY don't wait the five minutes between grinds (don't have the time). The machine is brand new and I have used it for less then a dozen times, so far no problems.

What I have found is that this affordable grinder produces an even grind without too much heat, which can affect the flavor of the coffee. The problem, however, is that I have to put a cup or more of grinds in the hopper, and then I have to run it for a few seconds, shut it off, then run it again or the machine gets really hot. That is not a big deal for me as I am the only coffee drinker in the family, but if you have a bunch of beans to grind at one time, this may get on your nerves.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grinder that is messy when cleaning
reviews.reviewText:
I have never owned a coffee grinder, so I didn't know what to expect when I tried this one. I have always ground my coffee beans in the supermarket before I bought them. I found that the instructions for this grinder were not that good. They have numbers for each part of the machine, but do not explain what each part is for. I really had to figure it out for myself. What I liked about the grinder is that you can grind as fine or a course as you like. I think that is helpful for all different kinds of coffee machines. It ground very well.

Once I experimented with this machine, I found that it was easy to use. What I didn't like is the mess when you clean it. I got coffee grounds all over the counter top when I took it apart. When you are done grinding you must clean the two plastic bowls, the one you put the beans in and the one they go into when they are ground. The plastic casing causes some of the grounds to fall out when you remove the bowl. This is where the grounds spill on your counter. You must also clean the grinding mechanism.

The Bodum bistro-electric burr coffee grinder does a great job, but is messy and a pain to clean. I would recommend this if you really want to grind your own coffee. If you don't mind it preground I would recommend grinding it in the store before you buy it. If you coffee only comes in beans I would recommend this grinder for you.

reviews.reviewTitle: not durable enough for espresso, fine for french press
reviews.reviewText:
I've owned two Bodum Bistro burr grinders. I primarily use them for espresso, but I occasionally make pour-through and french press coffee. I haven't been happy with the espresso from this machine, and eventually decided to look at more expensive but better made machines.

For espresso: not durable enough. The first machine I got used. It was unable to grind finely enough for espresso, the coffee was consistently weak. I later received a new machine as a gift. It made fine espresso for a few months, but then began to act the same way the first one had. The coffee was too weak. To verify the problem was the grounds, I purchased some coffee from my local coffee shop and asked them to grind it for me. Their grind worked just fine. Cleaning the burrs didn't fix the Bodum Bistro, so I started shopping for a new machine.

For pour-through: the Bistro works, but is kind of expensive. A whirly-blade grinder is more durable, less expensive, and is fine for pour-through coffee.

For french press: perfect. Gives a consistent coarse grind. The coffee is good, and has no stray coffee grounds.

We got three good years out of this. Then it stopped working. Cleaned out everything I could get to, but now despite sounding like it's grinding nothing comes out. At this price, it should be more user-serviceable. Now we're faced with throwing it out. I'll sure never buy this brand again.

This grinder was performing well up until a couple weeks ago, when the retaining ring broke. This would be fine, except there appears to be no way to purchase replacement parts. They are not listed on Bodum's site, nor on Amazon, and I can get no response from their sales contacts. So, its hard to recommend a product for which breaking one little piece of plastic renders it useless. If you are going to spend good money on a grinder, ensure that it can be repaired or replaced easily.

reviews.reviewTitle: I emailed Bodum and the send me a "one time" replacement burr (the old one is easily removed) and the machine is back to it's sh
reviews.reviewText: Purchased my Bodum Bistro over five years ago and have used it every day. It's a well designed burr grinder. Recently, the time it takes to grind my beans had just about doubled. The burr had dulled. I emailed Bodum and the send me a "one time" replacement burr (the old one is easily removed) and the machine is back to it's sharpest origins. Completely satisfied with this product and recommend it to anyone preferring burr-ground coffee.
I love this coffee grinder. It does a great job. My only complaint is the amount of static and how much of a mess that makes with rogue coffee grounds.
The motor on ours died after two and a half years, which given the price is too soon and, of course, beyond the warranty period.

I've had it for about 3 weeks now,and I love it. I like that I don't have to get the beans out every morning to put in the grinder, because it has the storage hopper. I like that I can grind more than one coffee pot amount at a time, with the ground coffee holder having room to store more than one pot worth,and the storage jar makes it easy to just shake the coffee out of it through the opening in the lid, without having to get a scoop out.

While grinding it's a little quieter than my old one, but the noise is not a problem, it's only for a few seconds anyway. I played with the various settings and from coarse to fine it seems to be consistent.

I'm very happy with it. I would surely recommend this to friends based on my use with it so far.

reviews.reviewTitle: Gears made of plastic break after 4 months of use
reviews.reviewText: Purchased this with a gift card from Christmas 2016 and it was broken by mid April. The metal burrs are driven by plastic gearing inside and are not sized to withstand normal use. I used this maybe once or twice a day to grind 40g of beans for my Chemex. Don't buy this product as Bodum will not replace your grinder or offer replacement parts.

This grinder was recommend from a boutique coffee distributer and I'm pleased with it so far (a week). I had trouble getting it in black, ended up getting it in white, which I don't recommend. There were red smudges on it that looked like possible bleeding from buttons (not sure), and the static of the grinds do show.

I see that others mention the static issue is much less than other grinders, although I still experience enough static to make a bit of a mess each time I pull the cup out from underneath.

Overall I'm very happy with the grinder and would recommend it! (But in black)

reviews.reviewTitle: If you desire poor quality and high price
reviews.reviewText: If you desire poor quality and high price, this is the grinder for you. As with my Bodum coffee maker, this grinder broke early in it's life. I will never purchase another Bodum product as long as I live.

I found this grinder to easily clog and not easily unclog. The glass cup for ground coffee is fragile -- mine broke without much provocation. When the grinder works it does fine. When it doesn't it is a pain to fix. Very disappointed in this expensive product.

My wife gave me a Bodum Bistro grinder for Christmas 2012. If I had written this review two weeks ago, it would have been glowing. The grinder works well for French Press, and grinds finely enough to choke our Gaggia espresso machine.

Unfortunately, last Sunday, I used the grinder as per normal, and the motor overheated and let the "magic smoke" out of the windings. There doesn't seem to be any way to repair the grinder, so now it's a $140 paperweight. I'll buy another grinder to replace it, but it won't be from Bodum.

reviews.reviewTitle: Got it on Clearance at Penneys for $15.
reviews.reviewText: I have no idea why it was so cheap. Maybe I will learn in time. I've ground beans for my first pot of coffee, and it was quiet, fast, and clean. I bought 2, so if it lasts until next Christmas, some coffee lovin' friend of mine's getting one of these :)

reviews.reviewTitle: It does what it's supposed to do
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this to replace an aging Krups that I've had for a long time. Read reviews on several sites and decided on this one as it fit my budget needs.

Very easy to use, open the hopper and pour your beans in. Turn it in, select the setting for the grind, then push the button. Within 10 or 15 seconds you'll have a nice cup of ground beans. I use a Bodum french press and I use the 2nd setting from the right (course). I pour the grind into my press, add a little hot water, swirl, then top it off.

The container holding the grounds is glass, I wouldn't tap it with a metal spoon to get the stuck grounds to move. Tap with your hand.

reviews.reviewTitle: Consistent Grind, Even After 35 lbs. of Coffee
reviews.reviewText: I've ground approximately 35 lbs. of coffee since I purchased this grinder last year. I wanted to give this grinder some time before writing a review. The grind consistency is spot on, every single time. Very high quality grinder. No gripes whatsoever.

This is my second bodum, and it is far superior to the first. I cannot attest to it's longevity and I have never given a 5 star rating, but after two weeks use I am more than thrilled with the improvements bodum has made. It is quiet, stylish, smaller more efficient in operation and space and finally it has a glass receptacle to catch the coffee in. You will not be disappointed with this purchase.

I just got this grinder for Christmas. I've had multiple other grinders, but this is definately the highest end one I've had. The consistency of the grind as well as the size of the grounds are fantastic. The taste was perfect, although I do have to admit that the beans I used were very good to begin with.

So far the ONLY gripe I have is that you can only grind for a maximum of 20 seconds at a time.

Bodum makes awesome coffee accessories and this is another prrime example of that.

For a while, I couldn't decided between this burr grinder and the capresso infinity that has a million good reviews. I actually went to the stores and looked at each individually. Despite the great reviews, the all plastic capresso felt flimsy compared to the bodum that had a sturdy and compact feel. I really love the glass receiving jar, too. One thing I noticed is that some of the caps for the jars on the display grinders fit more loosely than others. So, when I finally bought the bodum, I asked to open the box and make sure the cap had a snug fit to the jar. This is my first burr grinder, and I just don't know how I had gone so long without it. It's incredibly simple to use and produces fantastic espresso grind. Additionally, I'm very impressed by the cleanliness of the machine. While there are a few grounds on the rim of the glass jar's cap, I have not found even a speck of coffee on the counter. Excellent machine. I only gave it 4 out of 5 stars since it has not yet withstood the test of time.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is a great grinder for $$$; HOWEVER, the Bodum glass is thin and breaks easily
reviews.reviewText: I knew that Bodum had thin glass on their products and hoped it would be fine. It turned out that tapping the glass on the underside to get coffee out breaks the glass. When I went to the Bodum warranty site to see about a replacement piece, it says explicitly that glass is not under any warranty. I've improvised and it will last fine; however, I'm not a fan of Bodum and will not buy any other item from them going forward. I would recommend the grinder if not for the cheap glass and poor warranty by a large company. Take it for what you want but plan on replacing the glass container unless you can always be very careful with it.

reviews.reviewTitle: this grinder was great while it lasted
reviews.reviewText:
grinder produced great consistency for me until it started smoking...yes, smoke was coming out of the unit after only 11 months of once-a-day use.
unfortunately i did not keep packaging or receipt so cannot look into warranty service.
Grinder broke less than one year after purchase. Now, nothing happens when I hit the red grind button. The grinder is poorly made. Grounds were inconsistent, even when grinder was working.

Be very cautious when buying this product! If the flask lid is destroyed, ours accidentally melted in the bottom of the dishwasher!) it can NOT be replaced....so odd, but it can't just the flask! We now have to hold a cup up tight against the top and still get grounds all over. Aside from that grinder works great, just boarder line useless if you need a new lid.
It is a very nice grinder BUT there are no instructions at all!
After about three months it is now starting to grind longer than the 10 seconds, it is grinding until the grinder fills up. Anyone know why?

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't expect it to last more than a year or ...
reviews.reviewText: Don't expect it to last more than a year or two. Stops working, only spins for a second. Never run hard.
The Bodum Electric Burr Coffee Grinder has consistantly produced great grinds for use in our AeroPress. We would highly recommend this grinder to home coffee fanatics

I got this primarily for use with my single-cup maker, but also for occasional use with my French Press. So far, so good. I only need to figure out whether I want to get a second one for decaf, or keep switching back and forth.

reviews.reviewTitle: Performs as advertised and then some
reviews.reviewText: We did a lot of online research when we wanted to buy a burr coffee grinder, and this one seemed to fit our requirements. You never know, though, until you try it. I must report that we are pleased in all respects. We don't have experience with other models to compare the noise, but to my ear it is not at all noisy. We have not needed to grind beans for more than 20 seconds to get the amount we want, so we don't know if you really have to wait before you can grind again. It is easy to adjust the fineness of the grind. The glass carafe for the ground coffee has not had any static build up and is not at all messy. So it does pretty much what the description and reviews said it would, and it makes really fresh, delicious coffee with our Mr. Coffee Espresso machine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Died in six months and Amazon fulfilled order through non-authorized reseller
reviews.reviewText:
Worked great and died in six months. Bodum refused to honor the warranty because the order was fulfilled through "Amazing Deals Online"
which is not an "authorized reseller." Caveat emptor. After a long hassle on the phone, Amazon decided to make good on it.

Wow, had this for a month now.. super satisfied. Best, most easy to use, easy to clean grinder I've ever had. I've had burr grinders and blade grinders, even a good saeco one..for $75 bucks you can't go wrong. Grind is very consistent every time. Great Product!
Plastic piece broke. Works kinda, but SO LOUD.

Bought one about two years ago. It worked well and I really liked the consistent grind and ease of use. But it started stopping short of the set time for grinding (8 to 9 seconds for my needs), and now only grinds in a small burst, and I have to constantly push the start button until I think I have enough coffee grounds. I would have thought it would provide more reliable use for more than a couple of years.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not for Daily Drinkers, only Design Enthusiasts
reviews.reviewText:
I guess I bought this grinder because it looks cool sitting on my counter. I bought this grinder about a year ago and put 5 scoops of beans in every morning for my Bodum French Press. On weekends, maybe I make a second pot. for about 3 months now, It takes a more than the maximum 20 second grind to complete the 5 scoop grind. That's 10 Minutes.... This works because it takes time to boil water, but is really a load of Crap. I have a 6 cup moka espresso maker, and it takes the same 10 minutes to fill the filter with grinds. Total crap.

I wish this grinder was built for real coffee drinkers and not just for design. I haven't even thought about sending it back as the reviews tell such a sad story about customer service.

Now I have to wait untill this thing completely dies before I can justify $120 for a new coffee grinder.

My basic Proctor Siles blade grinder lasted 12 years. Only the electrical cord is crummy on that.

reviews.reviewTitle: Received this grinder as a birthday gift and I love it! I used to use a hand grinder ...
reviews.reviewText: Received this grinder as a birthday gift and I love it! I used to use a hand grinder and what used to take ~2 minutes for perfectly ground coffee now takes less than 15 seconds.

I received this coffee grinder for my birthday in December. Overall I am very happy with it, but there is a problem that I would like
input from other users on. In taking the grinder apart for a good cleaning, it is very difficult to put back together.
As a matter of fact, I took it apart over this past weekend and now cannot get it to go back together. The book that came with it is pretty
much useless for any sort of problem. I have been on their website and it has no information. I have sent an e-mail to their customer service and never
received a response.
Does anyone have any ideas or suggestions? Has anyone had this same problem?
For well over a year it works as advertised. This purchase was a step up from a blade grinder to pair with a Technivorm Moccamaster (purchased at another site). I'm completely happy with the pairing.
Stopped working after less than two years. Grinding has slowed down to a halt, and will only grind a small fraction of what it used to in the same time frame. Very disappointed.

Worked great for a while, but broke after less than a year. Makes noise like the gears are moving but no longer grinds the coffee. No rock or anything else stuck in the gears. Looks like the warranty won't cover a replacement, and no one has much luck with their customer service.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked beautifully until it stopped working
reviews.reviewText: Worked beautifully until it stopped working. Just refused to start. Called Bodum and they shipped a replacement right away. Great customer service, and I barely missed my morning coffee.
Worked great for 8 months and then it died. Bodum has poor customer service.

reviews.reviewTitle: Loved it but the timer has never worked properly and ...
reviews.reviewText: Loved it but the timer has never worked properly and now 3 days after the return policy expired the timer doesn't work at all.

reviews.reviewTitle: We searched for a good grinder that would last a while
reviews.reviewText: We searched for a good grinder that would last a while. This seems to do the job! It grinds so fine for espresso. We love it. We also reached out to the seller after seeing the item available at a lesser price. The seller credited our account the difference and was extremely understanding. We would definitely buy from them again.

I had one of these for almost two years and it worked great, and then it stopped grinding. Motor was spinning but burrs weren't. Took it apart to see one of the plastic gears was stripped. A friend's went bad in the same way on the same gear and his was almost new. I would say that the material used for the plastic needs to change. Good luck with those who have them.

Works better than expected. I've had this over a year. No problems. Great price compared to other options. Glad I didn't buy a more expensive grinder. Looks great. Cons: fairly loud, grounds stick to glass due to static electricity, you have to slap the side to get all the grounds out of the bin.
Hmmmmm, for the price I would expect it to last longer than the warranty. It made it just past a year. The recipients of the gift laid it to rest in their trash can. Lovely remembrance.

this is a good grinder but it is really a lot of work to keep it clean! it makes a mess of itself and everything around it. i'd prefer something a little more hands off. also a lot of the parts are flimsy plastic where you wouldn't expect it for this price

reviews.reviewTitle: Best price for the quality you get
reviews.reviewText: I have been using Bodum Burr Grinder almost every day for a year now. It still works perfectly fine. I used to use those small blade grinder but it was so cumbersome and messy. This Bodum Grinder is so easy to use, not messy, easy to clean, and looks very elegant in the kitchen.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fine powder makes bitter drip/press coffee
reviews.reviewText: I had this grinder for a few years, but ended up replacing it with a more expensive model that didn't produce fine powder. The powder results in overextraction of the bean, causing in an overly bitter flavor, especially for darker roasts. It's possible to sift the powder before brewing, but it's a pain. The fine particles may be less of an issue for espresso brewers; however, for larger-grind coffee brewers I would highly recommend getting a better grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: It works great! The grind for the French press has Been ...
reviews.reviewText:
It works great! The grind for the French press has
Been the best outside a coffee shop and the drip
Grind is consistent.

reviews.reviewTitle: HUGE upgrade from a blade grinder.
reviews.reviewText:
I received this as a Christmas gift and it's made a big difference in my morning cup of coffee. The grinder produces a consistent texture at all settings and will grind finely enough for my espresso maker, and coarsely enough for my French Press.

The glass container makes it so much easier to clean, too.
Excellent grinder while it lasted, but the motor burnt out after 16 months of daily use. Would not buy again!
Best coffee grinder yet

I was very satisfied with mine for 18 months, until I got hold of some beans with a small rock mixed in. The rock jammed the grinder, which resulted in the destruction of the plastic gears that drive the burr. I didn't try to find out if replacement gears are available. My fault, of course, but stuff happens, and you'd expect that a jam could be anticipated by the designer and handled without tearing up the gear train.

DO NOT BUY THIS GRINDER!!

THIS IS THE WORST PIECE OF GARBAGE I HAVE EVER BOUGHT.

Not worth 10 cents, much less $100.

It produces almost zero ground coffee. ABSOLUTELY WORTHLESS.

The instructions for use are in 10 languages, and none of them says the slightest thing about assembly and use.

Bodum site is down indefinitely--so no help there.

COMPLETELY INOPERABLE AND UNUSABLE.

I have bought and used a variety of complex devices, never had a problem with assembly or operation - until Bodum.

Will never buy anything Bodum again. I have been a frequent Amazon buyer. No more, given the fact Amazon carries this absolute piece of rubbish.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does not grind fine enough for stove-top espresso makers
reviews.reviewText:
I retuned this grinder yesterday. After talking to both the Bodum sales staff in the store and the Bodum hq and testing with various coffee beans and settings, I have come to the conclusion that even on the finest setting the grinder does not (and never will) grind fine enough for my espresso maker (the coffee comes out watery). After checking out some of my friends pressurised espresso machines I have noticed that the coffee grind for these machines does not have to be ground as fine as for my traditional stove-top espresso maker.

My conclusion is that this grinder does not grind fine enough for stove top espresso makers, but is probably fine for everything else.

reviews.reviewTitle: Messy and grinds for 20 secs only
reviews.reviewText: I should have paid more attention before buying but a 20 second grind is just not enough coffee for me to make the kind of strength I want in 6-8 cups so I have to grind 2-3 times. The glass container seems flimsey and would break easily. It is messy with the grinds sticking to the glass container due to static. I like how it looks and it is too noisey for its price but I am returning it.

Bought this after reading the reviews. Boy were they wrong. Noisey! Very Noisey. Very inconsistant grind as well. Grinds fine very well but when trying to grind a more coarse grind for drip or french press there are also many fines mixed in. Reviews also said that there was no static in the hopper. Wrong again. Avoid this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: So happy with it, buying it for my parents
reviews.reviewText: I bought this a couple of years ago and use it everyday for my french press. It's so easy! I don't usually review items but I'm back to buy another as a gift, so thought I'd say so. I like it that much!
Love it works very well would like to give it a few more tries though and then give an update of the continued performance but grinds well love the color.
Works great and is easy to clean the burrs.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked nicely, and then went up in smoke
reviews.reviewText: Worked great for a little over two years, then all of a sudden after grinding some coffee it smelled like a campfire. Turns out, there was a fire inside of the grinder and I'm afraid to turn it back on. Contacted customer service and there is only a 2 year warranty on this. Not going to repurchase again.
Outstanding as as always you guys are the best! No issues on the return. First time i returned an item and it was quick and easy. Thank you again!

reviews.reviewTitle: Works like a european labor union worker
reviews.reviewText:
Being forewarned will give you only so much cover. I read several of the reviews for this coffee grinder and decided to take a chance. *the motor is not the best, *many were returned because the grind time timer doesn't always give you the time set on the dial, and *the ground coffee doesn't stick to the glass.

The motor is good (for 20 seconds every five minutes) and the grinder will grind the beans so fine that when set for he finest selection, the grinds are very close to qualifying for ground Turkish coffee. I backed off two settings and the grounds are still the finest ground espresso coffee I used, including products from Italy. I still produce a great creama from a counter-top machine. No problems there.

Now for the title I wrote. I actually read the instructions and they are very clear and concise. 'Do not run the grinder motor more than 20 seconds every five minutes for it could damage the motor.' On my grinder, I set the timer for 20 seconds and sometimes I'll get ten seconds, other times 12 or 15 but only about a third of the time will I get a full 20 second grind. Just like the 36 hour a week union worker, when it works, there's no question the product will be of quality fit for a shipping magnate sipping espresso in their villa in the Aegean Sea. However, I have had to break the contract with my grinder and make it toil so I have sufficient coffee for my daily double cappuccino, dry. It has not stopped in a wildcat strike,...yet. Oh yeah, the coffee grinds not sticking to the walls of the catch container; there are more important problems in our lives than to worry over this one. The grinds do not adhere to the sides, this is a true statement. Could be.. the material used for the catch container is a superior grade of silicon used in the manufacturing of the container is mined only from the secret location of Atlantis.

Bodum should invest in higher quality motors or should stick to glasses.

We received this as a wedding gift. I drink dark, greasy french roast beans. The grinder gets stuck constantly and you have to push the grind button 20+ times to get the thing moving again. I tossed it this morning - a $20 grinder much better option.

Horrible in every aspect! NO auto off feature to begin with! Messy messy always when grounds are left under the glass container etc. This is a great looking product but that is where it ends. Bodum's Bistro line isn't very good including their Bistro Auto Coffee Maker which i returned after many failed attempts to make coffee that didnt' overflow.

Skip this brand and go for another, sorry to say!
love it !

This arrived 2 days earlier than it said it would. However, when I opened the box I noticed that packaging that housed the actual product looked like absolute CRAP. This is supposed to be a gift, the box looks like it fell off the back of a truck and was shamelessly taped back together. Thankfully Amazon is replacing the shipment.

reviews.reviewTitle: Did not have good luck with this
reviews.reviewText:
A plastic on/off button broke the first time we used it. Also, the instructions say not to use the grinder for more than, I think, 30 seconds at a time, but that's not nearly enough time to grind beans.

A positive note: we had no problem returning it and getting a refund.

Bodum generally makes good products so the grinder probably works fine, however....
Amazon has copy- pasted the product details from the more expensive model into this one so it is wildly inaccurate. The Collection container is plastic. It's triton which is high grade plastic, scratch resistant, but it will probably still have the static electricity issues associated with burr grinders. There is NO timer function. It is totally manual on-off. So if you keep your beans in the hopper you will have to learn how to count to 15 or so to know when to stop grinding. Its probably a very good product, it's just not what they are telling you it is at the moment. Please disregard this review if it comes to pass that they fix the product description.

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't Consider Buying until You Read This
reviews.reviewText:
This coffee grinder was delivered to me on October 16, 2016. It worked quite well until it broke on June 10, 2017. And then the fun began.

I called Bodum to get this product replaced under their fabulous "1 Year warranty." Bodum stated that they don't stand behind the warranty because it was sold by a 3rd party company; "Amazing Deals Online," and that I would have to contact the seller to get the warranty.

I contacted "Amazing Deals Online," and was told that they can't help me because the product order was over 30 days old. They stated that I would have to contact Bodum. So, I am now stuck between 2 companies that one, won't stand behind the products they sell, and two, apparently don't give a rip about customer service. My advice is to stay very far away from Bodum and Amazing Deals Online. As far as I'm concerned, the people who wrote the bad product reviews on this machine are 100% correct. I have nothing good to say about either company at this point.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quality beans ground in this and brewed in Chemex or in French press made a wonderful brew - when it worked
reviews.reviewText: Pain in the neck. Quality beans ground in this and brewed in Chemex or in French press made a wonderful brew - when it worked. Even though I cleaned the burrs weekly, with daily use, with a brush, beans kept stopping it - even drier light roast beans! To clear the stuck beans requires taking the grinder apart which makes a mess of partly ground, partly whole beans all over the place. I appreciate and require quite a few cups of properly brewed quality coffee daily - but this is not worth the time or the mess, especially not for the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: started well but lasted only 16 months
reviews.reviewText: I really liked this when I got it 8-2015, but it went on life support 1-2017. The grinder locks up and sounds like grinding nylon gears if more than a very few beans enter it. This maybe the advertised clutch engaging to save the grinder in case you have a rock, but I had none. Whatever the reason the only way I can grind coffee with this is to slowly drop a few beans at a time into the hopper while it is running. If it times out it while doing this, the beans jam it up again and I have to clean the beans out and start again. I am fairly OCD about my 1 mug of pour-over coffee a day, so I'll do this until I find a replacement. I thought this was a very nice grinder at relatively reasonable price. I really liked the glass receptacle with silicone lid to keep grounds from flying everywhere, but 16 months seems like a really short life span since this wasn't used a lot. I never had a stone in my beans, so I don't know how useful this clutch is nor if that is what causes it to stop.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Price is Right, Bob! Excellent product!!!
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this grinder for:

•The amount of positive reviews vs negative reviews.

•The timer can be set according to the amount I want to grind and the "fine to course" setting is simple and consistent.

•The price wasn't too high for the amount of coffee I grind per day.

•The color and design looks nice in my kitchen.

•It has a handy dandy guide on the inside part of the lid that helps determine the grind time. (Example: 15 seconds for 4 cups fl oz, medium grind consistency) but it's a little hard to read **Picture is included**

Pros:
•Consistency of the grounds
•Versatile features
•Price, wasn't too high (I bought it on sale for $70 at the time of purchase)
•Easy to clean
•Looks nice on the kitchen counter
•Cord storage for less clutter on my counter
•Not incredibly noisy like other grinders I've used
•100% Great customer service (quick replies and my issue was resolved within one week)

Cons:
•The only negative is that the power button started being "glichy" after 9 months of grinding 4 cups, once per day, and stopped working altogether after 10 months.
**This is the part where the excellent customer service keeps this grinder at 5 stars.

To sum it up:
It's an electric grinder with moving parts at a reasonable price so I do not expect perfection, but it's perfect for what I want.

It meets my needs with very little maintenance and I'm able to enjoy a freshly ground cup of coffee every morning.

****I would definitely recommend this grinder, and I hope my review was helpful and easy to read****

reviews.reviewTitle: Great little burr grinder for my espresso!
reviews.reviewText: I have had several coffee grinders. Most, more expensive than the Bodum. Only the conical burr grinders, like this Bodum, do a good job of grinding. I have worn out two other burr grinders and decided to try a less expensive grinder. I am very happy with the Bodum grinder. I use the finest grind setting for making espressos, using dark roast beans. The grind is uniform and not dusty or clumped. It packs well in the portafilter and after extraction, the puck is easily tapped out of the portafilter on the lip of my trash can. The container which catches the ground coffee is glass with a rubber grip and a flexible plastic top. The top is slightly convex (pointing up to the grind delivery opening), so it contacts the opening through which the ground coffee is delivered. This keeps the ground coffee from getting away. I have not seen any significant static generated. The hopper is fairly small compared to previous grinders I have had (Breville Smart grinder and Baratza Encore) but is adequate for a few days of making two 20 ounce quad lattes each morning and sometimes an extra 12 ounce double midday. The grinder is fairly quiet; probably quieter than my previous grinders. It is small enough to keep out of the way on the back of the counter. To grind an amount of coffee, you just set the timer (up to 20 seconds) and press the start button. A 20 second grind produces enough for about one 20 oz. quad latte. There are suggestions inside the hopper cover for the amount of grind and time needed for different grind sizes. If you need to interrupt the grinding, just press the start button again. The grinder also has a power switch on the side, so you can shut it off completely with that. Coarseness of the grind is controlled by rotating the hopper to the size grind you want. Rotate only while the grinder is running. This is not a commercial grinder, so Bodum recommends grinding for not more than 20 seconds every 5 minutes to allow the motor to cool between grinds. This grinder is certainly adequate for home use (at least my home). The grinder is easy to disassemble for cleaning (although I haven't had to clean it yet).

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy way to solve this issue to to make two ...
reviews.reviewText:
Dear Bodum,
Please inform your engineers to upgrade and distribute a new grinder parts made of metal. The whole reason everyone has been returning these grinders is due to the two pieces of the grinding mechanism. This results in the two pieces stopping from working and either burns the motor out. Easy way to solve this issue to to make two inter-connecting parts made of metal with a metal sheath to protect the plastic.

Review-
Honestly I cannot recommend this this grinder at its current state. The average user cannot use this product without returning it. And at $95 your better off saving up for a professional grinder or a hand grinder. There is absolutely no reason, the parts of the machine cannot be interchanged even if there is a problem. Work harder Bodum you can do better.

This grinder....

It's fantastic. I use it at least everyday, sometimes 2-3 times a day. All in all I probably grind an average of 45 grams of coffee a day in it, usually light roast (harder beans) and it works like a champ. It's OUTRAGEOUSLY easy to clean. The quality of the copper (and aluminum presumably) is fantastic. The grind settings are consistent, the burrs are sharp, the speed is great. It's honestly not even that loud (it might wake up a baby in the next room, but not on the other side of the house... ask me how I know :/ ). Also, the grind settings are not fixed, it is basically infinitely variable and I can confirm it is great for as fine as for an aero press (just short of espresso) up to a french press (very coarse). I don't have an espresso machine so I can't speak to that.

I know a lot of folks get worked up about the main gears being hard plastic (and I mean like... ABS hard) but after months of use (and cleaning it between every few pounds of coffee) this thing is clean, smooth, and running like a champ. Also, it has a 2 year warranty, so people who complained about it breaking after 13 months... use the warranty--that's what it is there for.

I would strongly recommend this grinder. You need to figure out what you do, but this is awesome.

reviews.reviewTitle: I absolutely love this coffee grinder
reviews.reviewText:
Original review posted 11-15-2013: I absolutely love this coffee grinder. It grinds uniformly every time regardless of the fineness/coarseness selected. It disassembles easily for cleaning and is relatively quiet, as far as electric grinders go. Every couple of weeks I run a tablespoon of dry, uncooked rice through it on the coarse setting to clean out any leftover grounds or oils. The glass receptacle creates little static, a little more during the winter when the air is dry but the coffee grounds don't fly out everywhere when removing the cup from the machine. I just tap the glass cup a couple of times on the counter before removing the lid to settle the grounds that may have stuck to the sides. It stores easily and leaves a small footprint. it has a handy cord wrap on the bottom of the base too. The start/stop feature is very useful, especially if you need to stop the machine mid-grind for any reason. I'm the only coffee drinker in my house so this is the perfect size for my needs which is 1 or 2 cups per day, though it will grind enough for an entire pot.

1-7-2015 UPDATE:
Recently I broke my glass grinds receptacle for this grinder. The glass was very thin and it didn't take much but a light tap on the counter to cause it to break. I went to the Bodum website to buy a replacement but they were out of stock. After giving this conundrum further thought, I decided to replace the cup with something more durable. This is what I came up with and it's working fabulously! Tablecraft H159 Stainless Steel Dredge with Handle, 10-Ounce It is slightly narrower than the original glass container so the silicone lid fits loosely. However, when you put it into the machine, it fits very snug, (height-wise), so there is no slipping or moving at all from vibrations during a grind cycle. Also and most importantly, there is VERY LITTLE TO NO STATIC! When I pull it out of the machine there are no messy grounds flying around or on top of the lid. This stainless steel shaker cup (dredge) is also available without the handle but since it's such a snug fit in the machine, I think the handle serves a purpose in being able to remove it easily. There are many other brands/prices of stainless steel dredges on amazon that would also work, provided they are the right size. I found mine at target ($5.79). FYI: If you break your glass container, hang on to your silicone lid. The Bodum website does not sell replacements for it. (I misspoke in the video.) In fact, the ONLY replacement part you can buy for the entire grinder is the glass container, (w/o the lid). Hope this info helps if you've broken your glass grinds cup.

reviews.reviewTitle: A great value on an espresso-quality grinder - - maybe not.....
reviews.reviewText:
I needed a second grinder for decaf beans for my espresso maker. My main grinder is a commercial-grade La Pavoni. I make espresso every day and appreciate the importance of properly ground coffee. However, changing beans from caf to decaf and then the reverse in my La Pavoni is a hassle and wastes coffee in the process. I shopped for a grinder that could do a good job without spending big bucks. I didn't think that would be possible until I tried this grinder. I can produce a beautiful shot of espresso, rich with crema. I'm very happy with this machine.

ONE MONTH LATER
After about 20 espresso grinds, the grinder was almost completely plugged. I was using Starbucks Decaf Espresso. I emailed the maker and they advised me to clean the machine after every use. Really?? I clean my La Pavoni about once a year and that's just because I think I should. It never plugs and works flawlessly even though it's probably 15 years old.

MY ADVICE:
If you want to grind for your espresso maker, spend a few more dollars for a better machine.

Excellent grind very very uniform on whichever level u select, hopper fits alot of beans an the lid provides a nice seal to act as a storage unit for the beans also if u wana leave some inside so u dont have to keep pouring beans in everytime just leave them in the hopper if u prefer (i do not) and just set ur timer once uve figured out how many cups ea time provides ( aprox 13sec for 3 cups) and ur allset. The glass receiver is a nice touch and much prefered over plastic that comes with allmost every other grinder, it dosnt totaly eliminate static but its very minimal just a lil bit of powder along the sides of the glass which is easily tapped down but deff no powder flying around or flying out of the jar making a mess so u dont have to worry about that like with some other grinders u have powder flying out of the receiver theres so much static not with this one the jar is desighned pretty good i must say and has a rubber top that helps just handle the jar with care and dont drop because it will break its not super thick glass. Nice length cord and underneath the machine has a system to keep it wrapped nicely so ur able to just let out the exact amount of cord you need. Now my biggest complaint is the base of the grinder could of been designed better it is not very sturdy or solid and tends to wiggle if you move the unit with your hands which isnt a huge deal because it just sits on the counter and its not like it moves while its grinding or anything just when ur physically handling it which makes it feel kind of umm cheap maby is the word or just not very solid especially if the cord isnt placed in the slot thats carved out for it to run threw and the machind ends up sitting on the cord then its very wobbly so with that said the base could of been designed better maby with wider pegs for it to stand on. All in all im very happy for the price with this unit an would highly recommend i give it 4.5 stars!

reviews.reviewTitle: Aluminum version looks great and grinding is excellent.
reviews.reviewText:
I know you shouldn't buy a grinder on looks alone, but it's hard to resist the unique look and feel of this Bodum unit. I got the Aluminum model and it feels way more solid than the rubberized ones, and looks great sitting next to my original Bonavita coffee maker. I was torn between this Bodum and the comparable Capresso, but in the end I just thought the Capresso looked ugly ;) I realize this Bodum has plastic gears that a lot of reviewers complain about, but just by the Asurion 4-year protection plan. For $4 you can get a brand new Bodum at no cost if those gears break out of warranty (or buy something else if you want). I didn't let that one issue dissuade me from choosing what I think is the best looking mid-priced grinder on the market.

Functionally I find the grinder to work every bit as good as my hand-cranked Hario Skerton. I bought it to use primarily with a french press, and the coarser grind settings were perfect. It's also incredibly fast. I keep it on the 10 second setting and it gives me the perfect amount of grind to use for a full french press. I like the glass carafe - while there is some amount of static cling it's nothing that a few seconds of cleaning can't handle. The carafe feels solid and compliments what is already a beautiful appliance.

If you're on the fence between this and the comparably priced Capresso or Baratza units, don't over think it. All are great grinders, and it really comes down to the visual aesthetic you prefer. For me it was easily this Bodum and I'm happy with the choice.

Well, what can I say . . .

I initially gave this product a 5 star review because it worked great out of the box and ground coffee beans much better than using my "old school" Bodum blade grinder. However, after only 2 months, this burr grinder gave up the ghost. Very few things that I ever break and, even when that happens, not is so short a time.

The grinder started to grind very slowly and could not even finish grinding a 1/4 cup of beans (the standard amount I use each day) before overheating and binding. When it worked it only too about 30 secs to grind the beans and, although I used it every day, 7 days/wk, I wouldn't say that 30 secs of grinding time is that much to expect from the product.

No point trying to get my $ back from Amazon or fixed by Bodum. Although burr ground coffee is "better," I think I'll just stick w/my blade style grinder from now on.

Oh well . . . lesson learned. Sometimes simpler and cheaper is just better.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poorly designed grind mechanism fails after 11 months.
reviews.reviewText: I was initially sold on this grinder by the glass bin. However, I found that the plastic top still trapped coffee grinds. Occasionally, the cap came off, and made a huge mess. Purchased in Jan 2017. Unit failed on 12/31/2017. I typically ground about 12 oz every three weeks. 20 sec/grind, finest setting. During grinding I heard a pop, and the grinding rate slowed down significantly. I emptied the bin, shook the unit then proceeded to grind. However, grinding rate was still very low. After the hopper was empty, I could still hear a rattling noise inside. Upon disassembly of the unit, I found a tiny bearing had come out. I conclude that this tiny single bearing is held in place by a spring. The spring failed, and let the bearing come out. That is what affected the grinding rate. For $100 I expected this unit to last 5-7 years, not 11 months. Additionally, the unit is very hard to clean. I had to purchased compressed air cans to clean it out. After disassembly coffee grounds were scattered all over the electronics and trapped under the grinding blade. Trapped coffee gets stale and affects the flavor of fresh coffee beans. So over time, I would expect coffee to taste worse.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works well but impossible to keep clean!
reviews.reviewText:
I am, admittedly, a form over function gal and I couldn't resist this beautiful design when I was shopping for a burr grinder. I've had various Bodum products over the years and they've all been high quality, so I gave in to temptation. It's an excellent grinder. We use it daily (sometimes more) for the last 5 years to make pour over coffee with a Chemex. I also bought the matching white electric kettle and they look cute as heck sitting on the counter together.

There is one glaring problem, though: Unlike the kettle, which has a smooth, albeit cheaper-feeling, plastic finish, the grinder has a rubber-like surface. It feels sticky to the touch, and basically acts as a coffee grounds magnet. Since ours is white, it looks eternally dirty. I've tried damp clothes, light soap, even bleach sprays - and it never looks clean.

I still have to give it 4 stars because it's really an excellent grinder and it's pretty to boot. If, however, you are borderline OCD when it comes to kitchen cleanliness, then consider looking for another grinder. Or perhaps getting the stainless or copper option.

Okay, I just received and used it twice -- LOVE IT! Way less noisy than expected, Zero mess or static (but I only made enough for one cup), very easy to figure out and use (the 80 page manual in 400 languages is pretty basic, but good enough). I purposely sought out a grinder with a GLASS jar because of so many reviews for different grinders with plastic catch jars being horribly messy. I originally tried a manual grinder, which worked fine, but figured out quickly that I don't want to do that every day. This Bodum takes FIVE SECONDS to grind my two Tb of coffee perfectly (I did a coarse grind; haven't tried anything finer). And, I like that I can store beans in the top for a few cups and not have to do THAT every day (how lazy can one get?!). But -- we like what we like. I bought the warranty just because of a few reviews, and if anything goes wrong in less than two years I'll let ya know!

I wanted consistent, measured ground coffee at the touch of a button. Fresh ground coffee is the number 1 most important consideration for a quality cup. But I don’t like mornings and need to keep my routine as simple as possible. I wanted the fancy machines that were twice the price and ended up waiting a long time to finally decide that I didn’t want a giant machine on the counter and didn’t want to spend over $200.

It has a ‘quality sound’ to it. I love the small (low) ROUND glass carafe - the leading brands have rectangular or odd shaped plastic carafes that are difficult to pour from. BUT, I actually ended up grinding my coffee right into my strainer as I steep my coffee French-press style, but then remove it instead of pressing it. It works great!

reviews.reviewTitle: Bodum made an astetic, functional and compact grinder
reviews.reviewText:
Bodum's Bistro grinder is not only astetically appealing but extremely functional for the size of the unit. Let me start off by saying I've been hand grinding my beans for the better part of 2 years now. Call me crazy but I enjoyed the satisfaction of producing the grounds for my own coffee. Recently the coffee consumption in my house has increased it was no longer efficient to grind the beans by hand. Before purchasing I had a few questions that I was not able to find find an answer for here on Amazon so I thought I'd provide a few of those for those who find themselves asking the same thing.
The first, how consistent is the grind? Like many machines, the finer the grind the more consistent. See pictures for an example. My second question, what's the range of the granular grinds themselves? Again see pictures. Based on my brewing methods of choice (drip, Chemex, V60, Aeropress) the grinds provided are excellent!

reviews.reviewTitle: Good small grinder, but not durable
reviews.reviewText:
This puppy grinds well, per your setting, and grinds cleanly with no mess. There is I feel a defect that keeps it from being perfect. The maximum time setting is 20 seconds. This is only enough for 3 scoops of coffee beans, enough for one big mug of 12-16 ounces or 2 smaller cups of 6 - 8 ounces each. Grinding a lot of coffee beans would take a long time given the warning to let it cool. The guide embedded in the cover for quantities would only hold true for a very weak brew. It is not realistic. Also, the resevoir for holding the beans is small.
This is less a problem for me as I rarely grind for more than 2 cups anyway. If you bear these limitations in mind this is a good grinder.
UPDATE: Worked fine for 10 months until it didn't. Worked one day and the next day it wouldn't grind or even illuminate the on-off switch. Tried 3 different outlets - same result - nothing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bodum sells a flawed product and does not sell replacement parts, pass on this grinder.
reviews.reviewText: Alright, so on the surface this is a nice little grinder with the features you've all been told to look for but the plastic internals and lack of replacement parts make this thing a dud. The death of mine ended up being the *plastic* retaining ring for the metal burrs, Bodum *does not* offer a replacment for this part, making my $75 grinder a paperweight. I hate having to throw things like this out and luckily someone on thingiverse has listed a file to print a replacement part, hopefully I can squeeze a few more months out of this thing before the plastic internals give up.

reviews.reviewTitle: Budget friendly grinder that produces great espresso grind
reviews.reviewText:
January 2018: I bought this burr grinder alongside my first espresso machine (Breville Cafe Roma). I had done enough research to realize a burr grinder was key in making decent espresso. However, as a student, budget constraints prevented me from spending much more than $100. I bought this burr grinder based on reviews and my brand familiarity with Bodum.
I have used this grinder for 2 weeks. I am very satisfied with the grind I get on the espresso setting on this burr grinder; the freshly ground beans feel like sand which is exactly what I've read is the desired grind for espresso. The grind produced seems to be composed of consistently sized particles with very little variation in particle size (no noticeably large hunks of beans and not a lot of powdery grind). I haven't had any issues with the timed grind (20 second maximum) that other reviewers have mentioned in a negative light. I grind my beans immediately before I make my morning latte. The small quantity of beans required for my double shot only takes the grinder about 10 seconds to grind. On weekends, I can grind enough beans in 20 seconds to make myself and my boyfriend a latte each.
I absolutely love that the ground coffee container (where the ground beans land) is glass. As I was wandering throughout the burr grinder selection online, it was disappointing to see the number of burr grinders that used plastics for this particular container. This Bodum stood out to me because of the use of glass in its design.
This grinder is noisy, but as I am usually the last one out of bed, it hasn't been an issue in my household. I have not had any complaints from apartment neighbors either. I'm not sure how many burr grinders are quiet. It seems to me, the grinding of any material = noise.
I will try to update this review over the years to share longevity of this burr grinder.

Wow, what can I say?

History:
Having used C*******t coffee grinders for many years, it was time to replace the C*******t. That was the second C*******t we have worn out, the bearings in the motors gave up with screaming sound effects. The C*******t also had all the "features" we did NOT like: a VERY static electricity prone hopper, which "helped" distribute the ground coffee all over the kitchen. A sound volume that almost required hearing protection. It was impossible to clean properly... also, the grinding mechanism is disk/burr, and it tended to overheat the beans - being oily French roast, things got stuck and tasted awful on occasion.

Back to our new grinder:
Looking high and low for a new one, most grinders that "seemed OK" and had good ratings were in the multi-hundred-dollar price range. Clearly not for me.
Found this at the last minute, before I ordered a C******o. Why did I not know about Bodum's coffee grinder before? I know their coffee presses and glass-ware... but did not know they made grinders.
This grinder exceeds all our expectations of a coffee grinder, and it is stylish as well!

It just does everything right, I think:
It really is a conical burr grinder!
The grinder runs slow, so not to heat the ground coffee.
It has a glass hopper that is not prone to static electricity - at least not in any significant way. The hopper can be emptied straight into the filter without beans flying all over. That alone makes me happy.
The hopper seals well to the body of the grinder so no ground coffee escapes.
It comes apart easily for access to the grinding mechanism - it can be cleaned! Without resorting to tooth-picks, Q-tips and compressed air.
It is quiet - for a grinder.
Stylish - we got the red grinder. Color splash on the counter! Why is everything else black/white/stainless?

Getting to the coffee - how did the coffee taste? We set it for the recommended size for a drip/paper filter brew. The beans we use are very oily, being a French roast, but they came out beautifully, no "gooping" up of the grinder.
First brew: we think the coffee tastes superior to what we have been used to: more coffee flavor and less bitter. Guessing that the large conical burr mechanism treats the beans much better than the disk/burr grinder did.

Would I recommend this? Absolutely! Price point? Excellent value.
I have attached some pictures to show the conical burr grinder mechanism.
Have to stop writing now and get a refill of coffee!

reviews.reviewTitle: Quality grinder, has lasted over 5 years now
reviews.reviewText:
Wanting to replace the tedious hand burr grinder that I use pretty regularly at my girlfriend's house, I searched Amazon for an electric one. I came across some cheaper alternatives to the Bodum grinder...but not sure if I want to save $30-40 for a grinder that might fail in a year or two. I have had this Bodum model for over 5 years now (purchased in December 2011), and it is still going strong. For that reason I will purchase it again. I do not use it regularly - in fact, over the past couple of years it has really only been used once or twice a week since I have been doing large batches of cold brewed coffee - but when I do use it, the motor is running for the full 20 seconds so that I can get a good full cup of coarse ground coffee. I have probably cleaned the unit just two or three times over the years...so I don't really baby it either.

After considering some alternatives, the thing I like most about this unit is that it has a large coffee hopper (12 oz. versus the typical 8 oz.), easily allows you to set a wide range of grind consistency and has a separate dial for the grind time (0-20 seconds) so you can just push a button and let it grind out a consistent and predictable amount of coffee each time, and it has the nice glass container that holds the grounds versus the typical plastic ones. I also liked that I paid $80 for this in 2011 and now it is only $72...not sure if that is timing or if the price has decreased a bit over the years.

I will be going back to what has worked for me in the past - the Bodum Bistro grinder.

I looked high and low for a good espresso grinder under $100. I settled on a $10 manual grinder because 1) I only drink espressos on the weekend and manually grinding didn't sound that time consuming. 2) I wasn't convinced any other grinders were worth the price because so many have a heap of bad reviews.

Needless to say, I got tired of manually grinding my beans after about 5 occasions. Specifically, the last time when I made a double-shot espresso for myself and someone else. Then, yes, quite time consuming.

I went back to the drawing board and, after coming across the Bodum Bistro several times pre- and post-manual grinder, I decided on this grinder simply because I feel I know what to expect from it. It's clearly an amazing and well-loved appliance until the plastic gears inside break. For that reason, I also purchased the 4-year warranty for $5.54 which has a $0 deductible. Bodum provides a limited one year warranty on manufacturer defects so the SquareTrade 4-year warranty covers the 3 years (yes, 3) after that. The most important factor with warranties (to me) is whether or not it will cover shipping costs. The SquareTrade warranty does provide prepaid shipping labels although you are responsible for packaging it (safely) yourself. Hence why I'm opting to hold onto the original box until the warranty's up.

Another big reason I chose the Bodum Bistro is because of the glass container that catches the coffee. I read many reviews about plastic containers causing a ton of static electricity and therefore causing coffee grounds to jump all over and make a mess. I really didn't want to deal with this so glass was a requirement.

I used the grinder for the first time this morning and, boy, it works fast. It's not too loud. I'm not sure how quiet you expect a grinder of any sort to be but, in the wee hours of the morning, it certainly wasn't startling. Although, I imagine it's loud enough to wake someone up. I wasn't sure how long to grind for 2 shots of espresso so I opted to start with a 5 second grind.. Not enough. 10 second grind.. Getting closer. 10 second grind.. too much! 20 seconds seems to be the winner for 2 shots.

I'm very happy with my purchase and hope I never have to utilize those warranties!

reviews.reviewTitle: Coffee snobs don't have to drop a fortune on a good grinder.
reviews.reviewText:
I'm a coffee snob. I work from coffee shops. I drink coffee every day. It's always locally roasted and fair train and usually organic. I am a jerk when it comes to coffee. I talk about the notes and the acidity. I care about where it's grown and I remember regions I like. I use a multitude of methods of brewing: pour-over, press pot, cold brew, and an auto-drip (Bonavita).

So, that being said, I know I should have invested in a nice grinder, like $400+. I get a lot of feedback at grinders from coffee shops and this one shouldn't cut it. But it does! It's consistent and that's what counts. I have a hand-crank coffee grinder too which might be better, but I don't want to crank out coffee every morning. This is quick and easy. The timer makes it nice for ease, but you can always weigh your beans and run them through then turn it off.

Sometimes the start/stop button doesn't work and I have to press it again. There's always the switch on the side though. I had a friend who burned out the motor on one of these by letting it spin for too long. So I am aware of that and I don't let it go for too long. I usually only make 1-2 cups at a time anyways.

So, pros: small/compact design. Different colors to choose from. Big hopper if that's your jam. Glass container w/lid. Master on/off switch. Timer. Wide range of grind settings.

Cons: My start/stop button sometimes sticks. That's it. This grinder is awesome.

reviews.reviewTitle: Really good burr grinder, not so great customer service.
reviews.reviewText: Other than the abysmal customer support this has been a great little coffee grinder. It has been going strong now for three years. My son also has this grinder and has had his for about the same length of time and really likes his too, (he is a real coffee snob). It is a bit noisy but not as bad as previous grinders, (I’m not sure there is actually any such thing as a quite coffee grinder). One of my favorite features is the borosilicate glass coffee catcher. Bodum has no mention on their website of replacement parts for any thing they make. Others posting here have mentioned that Bodum does have replacement glass containers but not the rubber lids. I don’t know how they found this out but I have not been able to reach anyone with the company to find out if they actually do have the replacement cup or how much it costs. Well I broke ours this morning and not wanting to buy a whole new grinder for that simple part I started looking around and found that the yellow Rubbermaid cups that were provided in the 50# bags of Purina Dog Chow 30 years ago fit perfectly. (See pictures) I love these old cups and recently bought several more on eBay for what I would guess to be a lot les than Bodum charges for their glass cups. The advantage to the glass though, is that a gentle tap on the bottom of the glass while emptying into the coffee filter loosens nearly all of the fresh coffee grounds. We’ll see now, if the static cling of the dry coffee grounds keeps the plastic cup from being a capable replacement. If the company would simply make replacement parts available I would give it 5 stars plus, but the lack of parts and a decent website makes it a 4 star item. ...... Sorry Bodum.

reviews.reviewTitle: After all the great reviews for this grinder
reviews.reviewText: After all the great reviews for this grinder, I was excited to finally replace my Hario Skerton hand grinder with a quicker, easier source of fresh ground coffee. However, after a couple of months with this grinder I am back to hand grinding my beans. The Bodum Bistro jams on almost every grind. Clearing the jam involves removing that catch bin, flipping the grinder over (which is full of beans), twisting off the bean hopper, picking the stuck beans out of the burr with something pointy, then reassembling the whole mess. Then I pray I can grind the rest of my cup without another jam. It's infuriating. I'm very disappointed with this product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Melting monster with a heart of gold
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using this grinder for five years and it is still running and grinding great. I keep thinking it is going to die as the machine has run a bit slower after getting jammed on a pebble hiding in a batch of locally roasted beans fours years ago but it just keeps on trucking. Very consistent grind and not too awful hard to clean the inside of.

So why the three stars? Cleaning the outside is a completely different story. The finish on my White model quickly became utterly disgusting looking and has remained that way no matter what I do to clean it. Every soap I've tried does nothing but smear it around. The only thing that takes it off is to physically scrape off the goo but there is no way to get it all and the remaining bits smears all over the device in short order. I thought I would eventually get rid of it all but it keeps coming back so I think that something in the white plastic itself doesn't take to well to the oils found in coffee and the kitchen. I wish the grinder part would just break already so I can stop having to hide it away after each use but don't feel like I'm throwing away a perfectly good machine.

I've had better luck than a lot of the one star reviewers did here - mine lasted 4.5 years. A few weeks ago, I heard a weird noise while grinding my daily beans and now it takes a lot longer to grind 30g of beans (and it's getting worse). I think perhaps the gears are shot.

Otherwise, this grinder worked well enough for just me. I used it for about one grind almost every day. I've used it for everything between espresso grind and course grind. It's a bit of a pain to clean but that's about my only (very minor) complaint.

One other weird thing - the manual says that you're only supposed to run the grinder for one 20-second grind every five minutes. I thought this was very strange. A course grind for one person could easily take almost 20 seconds. I can't imagine this being very useful if you've got guests. I think this has to deal with the motor overheating.

I can only recommend this grinder if it'll be only very lightly used (maybe just enough grind for one person). Otherwise I'd recommend something a bit more expensive and durable (probably the Baratza Encore), which is what I am going to purchase today.

It is a great price for a quality burr grinder.
It is easy to clean, has a start/stop function and timed grind with a conversion for grind time to the number of cups it will make (under the lid). I have an eye for it now. The hopper lid seals and the glass that catches the grinds has a silicone lid. It is not a solid seal as if it were put in a closed container, but the silicone lid is raised in the middle butting it up against the grinder opening. So, the closure occurs between the hopper lid and the grinder lid. Not bad if you grind daily.
I always put the coffee back in the bag and put it in a sealed container. I only grind the beans when its ready. And MMMMMMMM it's delicious.
The glass container has much less static than the plastic containers I've used.
- TIP: Hold the container with your dominant hand, and with the palm of your other hand, cover the lid opening and shake in a stirring motion. It doesn't need to be done hard, the swirling of the grinds take any possible static-charged coffee off the walls. The glass will not retain a charge so any cling is minimal and short-lived.
Also, Clean it after so many uses, the powdery grinds cake up and will be super hard to remove later. This is for any grinder.

Update: In June, 2018, after about 2 years of service, this grinder just totally failed to work one morning. After some serious comparison shopping, I ordered another of the same model. While waiting the 2 days for my Prime delivery, I took it apart and found that the main power switch had failed. I never did like that switch, the way the light flickered. I happened to have an extra toggle switch, and it now works perfectly again and figured it would serve as a backup.

However, when the replacement arrived, I ran some rice through it and found out about the plastic gears I've read complaints about in other reviews. The discordant sound of grinding gears signaled an immediate return. I'm so glad I was able to fix that power switch!

The good news is that Amazon Customer Service is second to none and the replacement that arrived 2 days later seems solid. For the price and the years of service I've gotten, I still give this grinder 5 stars.

Original Review:

I just bought this grinder to replace the same model that has served me well for 5 years and a couple of months.

They look almost identical, but there are obviously some underlying differences. After running a cup of uncooked rice through the grinder and cleaning everything well, I roasted about 200 grams of beans to a full city roast and eagerly tried it out.

The first thing I noticed is that it seems quieter. It has a lower pitched growl as opposed to a high pitch whine like the old one, and sounds more solid.

With the old grinder, I could reliably grind for 17 seconds and get 45 grams of ground coffee, plus or minus a gram or two depending on the coffee. Running this grinder for 17 seconds gave 64 grams of coffee. Setting the grind level between the first and second dot after the French press symbol gave a consistent, good-size grind for a pot of pour over coffee.

If this grinder lasts as long as the last one I had, I will consider it a fantastic buy!

Right off the bat, probably within a month, a bean got stuck in the burr (or something) and the motor got stuck and it sounded like a lawnmower. It soon cleared itself and that problem only happened a few times over the course of a year (but still 100% more times than it happens with any ~quality~ burr grinder)
Now, less than two years later, it's started happening daily. I almost didn't get my coffee this morning. Good thing I bought a protection plan, since I was already suspicious of its quality.
Update! Turns out even though I bought the $8 Asurion protection plan, their website seems to not want to honor it! I can't get anywhere in the claim filing process. Best to take your money and run FAR away from this whole mess.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good product, but short life span of use (at least for the price)
reviews.reviewText: I really like this grinder, I was going to buy another one but holy cows they sure jacked up the price. Because of the price jump I will shop around. It seems like I paid $40-50 dollars for it, but now its $100 or more, that's a bit much. I used this for about 3 1/2 years. It did a good job, but the covering got dirty easy-I got the red one and the plastic seemed to absorb a lot of the coffee so a cleaning was needed and not a wipe down like other small kitchen appliances. When it broke, my son and his girlfriend got me a Mr.Coffee and that was a piece of junk compared to this. In fact I got that coffee grinder for Christmas of 2016 and now that one's broken. They don't make products as good as they once did. but charge high prices like its a high quality item. The amount of money you have to fork out-and the life time of this being less than 4 years, doesn't make it a good buy. Maybe if they reduce the price by 40-50 bucks than it would be worth it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Messy, but provides good, consistent grinds
reviews.reviewText:
To start with, I don't know what magic the folks have that don't experience any static electricity issues. I have grounds stick to the inside of the glass jar, to the outside of the jar, and to the plastic area where the jar sits, as grounds still in the grinding chamber are jostled loose when removing or inserting the jar. Granted, these are consistently-sized, flavorful grounds the the machine did a fine job of creating, but they still stick and create a bit of a mess. The only other issue I have is that the grinder has a 20-second limit for grinding time with a 5-minute wait between grind attempts. I use a heaping 1/2 cup of beans to make a pot of coffee and grind to a relatively fine texture (the second dot from the finest grind choice), It takes two cycles - 20 seconds, plus 5 minutes, plus 20 seconds - to grind the 1/2 cup of coffee beans. That's a little slower than I would care for, not to mention having escaped grounds in the area that need to be cleaned up.

Overall it's not bad, but I can't say I have noticed any flavor benefit in a pot of coffee after upgrading from the blade grinder I used previously. It does do a very nice, fine grind for when I use my Aeropress, though.
