I have to start by saying this was one of the worst purchases I've ever made. I strongly suspect most of the positive reviews are fake. Why ? First of all with all those reviews no one mentioned you can only grind enough beans to make a half a pot of coffee. If you want a full pot you have to wait 5 minutes and do another 20 second grind. I can only characterize this thing as a joke ! One of the main reasons you spend money on a conical burr grinder is supposed to be to limit the powder. Powder results in bitter coffee when used in a drip coffeemaker .This thing produce so much powder on the medium setting it ruined the entire pot. My $18 Braun blade grinder does not produce anywhere near the powder that this thing produces! Furthermore, the glass cup that is supposed to reduce static was about the worst possible. After one grind the entire inside was coated with fine powder. I was also attracted to the comments about " easy to clean " . This thing is a nightmare to clean. Only the top of the grinder comes off. The bottom half is attached to the motor. After one grind it took me 20 minutes to clean. The powder just kept coming and coming out ! I even took it down to my shop and blew compressed air through the top. My whole shop is now covered in coffee powder ! . I sent it back after the first use !

reviews.reviewTitle: but easily came out when I gave the grinder a little ...
reviews.reviewText:
I just completed packing my Bodum coffee grinder up to return. Three main reasons:
1. The grind was inconsistent; I ground some for a french press and got everything from the proper course grind to what would have been appropriate for espresso.
2. It's messy; when I pulled the container out, grounds went everywhere. Quite a bit of grounds were still in the area just above the catch container, but easily came out when I gave the grinder a little nudge or two.
3. Non-static container??? Not this one, that's for sure! For as much hype that is made about it, I definitely expected at lot better. It wasn't even close.
New one is already on order...going back to a Breville.

I've been using this coffee grinder daily for nearly a year & love it.
I was hesitant about getting a burr grinder because I didn't like the idea of statically-charged grounds all over the kitchen. This little darling is surprisingly tidy.
I did experiment with different types of roasts which I learned makes all the difference. Dry beans (light roast) make a big mess as soon as you pull out the glass container. Oilier beans (medium to dark roast) - barely anything! Who knew? On the other hand, too dark a roast (which is what brings out the oils) can make a bitter tasting coffee which I don't like, so there was a bit of trial & error until I found beans I liked. (New favorites are Allegro's Vienna Roast & Espresso Sierra.)
It's also worth mentioning that this little grinder is adorable to look at as well as being easy to use & to clean.
l'm really happy with it.

I bought this grinder after seeing a couple in use, and the feedback was good. Understanding that sometimes you get a lemon, mine is not working properly if at all. I have contacted Amazon, they were great, but told me to contact Bodum, which I have. To date, nothing, only a reply saying sorry your having a problem. No effort to to address that fact that mine doesn't work. They have asked me for proof of purchase, which they got on the first email, (twice now), and then replied to ask me to send a "video" of the grinder NOT WORKING", Haven't heard from them since, nothing, no RME, no acknowledgement of warranty, or making and effort to fix the problem, It has been over two weeks, and I guess the warranty means nothing. So buyer beware, if yours works out of the box great, but for the money spent, if it doesn't , don't count on them, as they have yet to acknowledge anything, or try to make amends?

Been using this grinder for a few weeks and overall I like it. The grind is good and has plenty of adjustment depending on if you are doing a drip, pour over or espresso type of brew. However, this machine also has some drawbacks, mainly, this machine makes a mess! I have grounds all over the place from this machine and I cant do anything about it. There are grounds falling out of the machine when I take the cup out, grounds falling off of the lid, cup, etc. Its just everywhere. Despite what the manufacturer says, the cup does very little, if anything about the static cling. Lastly, this machine makes a ton of noise. It will wake up the whole house in the morning whenever I turn it on, so it doubles as an alarm clock. I would rate this machine much better if the mess wasn't so bad.

reviews.reviewTitle: Is it is worth the work???
reviews.reviewText: I wrote the following review titling it that "it is worth the work" and gave it five stars. Now I change the title to "Is It Worth the Work?" Now I am downgrading it to 4 stars because after several months of using it, I am getting tired of cleaning it. It has gotten to the point where I have to clean it every day. About a teaspoon of grounds stay in the upper part, and I have to shake the grinder as they fall out and make a mess. So, Yes, I love this coffee grinder, but for those of you thinking about buying it, be aware you really do need to clean it once a week at first. One of the people in the answers section has really good advice for cleaning it with rice. Read it. I follow his directions once a week. Also, after I grind coffee, and I put the contents of the little jar into my filter, grounds continue to leak out, making a bit of a mess. I have learned to tap the machine to get more of the grounds out, but there are always more. I do think the cleaning procedure is worth the delicious coffee you will get with grinding it yourself. But be sure to store the grounds in one of those air-sealed type canisters. I got the friis one on Amazon and it works really well, but once more, it takes some work. You have to change the filter once every two months. At any rate, you have to decide if it is worth the work.

Wish I'd paid attention to the reviews! Nowhere in the description does it say wait five minutes between grinds. But it does in the manual! 20 seconds of grinding for 10 cups of coffee is ridiculous. We need 60 seconds for our preference. First thing in the morning, we aren’t going to wait over t n minutes for the grinder. We're just going to keep continuously grinding u til it doesn’t work. Then replace it with something better engineered.

My husband makes the coffee, but I moved it to clean behind it and the top of the motor casing was very warm, hours after grinding. I did not notice the on/off switch. I called the 800 number on the manual. A recording said if anyone in our household was over 50 they had a special offer. I pressed one and got a hard sell woman trying to get me to accept a medical alert device. I said I was not interested, she kept selling, I asked to be transferred back to Bodum, she said she could not do that. Hung up and called again. Now a different product was being pitched, but no way to talk to Bodum customer service. A ridiculous joke. I found an online chat for Bodum, sent my question. They responded by telling me that any problem I had needed to go back to the retailer. I gave up. And THEN they sent me an email asking me how I would rate their customer service!!

I have never had a coffee grinder I had to turn off after using. Can’t it turn itself off when the grind is complete? I do like the styling and the glass carafe. When this baby grinds itself to death, we won’t be buying another one.

reviews.reviewTitle: I really like this coffee grinder
reviews.reviewText: I really like this coffee grinder. My family likes fresh ground coffee. Who doesn't? Our old Cuisinart grinder died some time back so we resorted to buying pre-ground coffee. I accidentally ordered whole bean and we were suddenly in need of a grinder. I didn't want to pay too much but I did want something decent. The reviews seemed good and the white one was priced at a good discount on Amazon so I bought it. It is much better than the Cuisinart ever thought of being. I was always a bit ticked at the inconsistent grind with the Cuisinart. This one grinds a consistent grind every time. It has a glass container for collecting the ground coffee which really reduces the electrostatically charged grounds flying all over the kitchen counter as they do with a plastic container. It is also relatively quiet. I can only hope it will be durable. We'll see on that. So far, though, I really like this Bodum grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's burr grinder that doesn't suck
reviews.reviewText:
MY SNOB LEVEL: I'd describe myself as a "coffee enthusiast." I am willing to go through a daily ritual of Aeropressing my coffee. I bought a temperature-controlled electric kettle. I chastised my roommate for using a Keurig.

THE GRIND: Good consistency--nothing to complain about (as a "coffee enthusiast"). About as loud as you'd expect of an electric burr grinder. I'm not a huge fan of the timer-based grind, as I had gotten used to weighing out my beans before the grind. However, if you're less concerned about precision and more concerned about not having to hold down a grind button, it works out all right.

THE BUILD: The build of the grinder feels a little cheap-plasticky. It also has a fairly narrow base, so attempting to handle it will make it teeter a bit. The large hopper if you don't want to go through the effort of pouring out beans for every coffee. Personally, I would have preferred a smaller hopper to grind out individual servings, but that's a mea culpa on my part.

ADD'L THOUGHTS: I'm not the biggest fan of the grind-bin's design. There's a rubber thingy that goes on top to prevent grinds from getting all over the place. However it's really just an annoying extra step of the grind process to try to get grinds stuck to the rubber thingy to drop down into the glass bin. I'd also recommend washing the glass bin before you use it, as there seems to be some coating out of the box that makes grounds more likely to stick to the walls of the bin. As with most electric grinders, you will want to give the grinder a few solid taps after a grind to get stubborn grounds to drop into the bin.

OVERALL: It grinds coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love it! The glass canister is now available for replacement!
reviews.reviewText: Love everything about this! Our coffee was starting to taste chalky and we noticed that our old cheap grinder was leaking grounds from the bottom onto the counter and had a lot of static buildup that we had to wash away frequently. The look is fun (we got the chrome), but I can't say enough about the round glass canister! It feels cleaner, has no static buildup, the grounds dump or scoop right out and because it is so perfectly shaped, it's as easy to clean as a drinking glass. So I often wash it right after use even though there is no buildup, just a few crumbs. By the way, you can order replacement glass canisters directly from the manufacturer, so no worries if you break one, just save your lid. In fact, I plan to order an extra anyway, would be nice if you were grinding two types of coffee. It is very quiet compared to our old one. The second timer vs. a grinder that grinds by cups, takes a little trial and error, but suggested amounts are on the lid of the grinder. Worst case you grind a little too much and you just save what you don't use in the glass canister until later. Instead of dumping it into my coffee maker, I now use a scoop to measure it after grinding to get the precise amount. Now for the best part, the coffee tastes amazing! No chalky taste, just depth from the bean and a smooth finish. I wouldn't normally spend this much on a grinder, but it sure made a difference and knowing how many coffee's I dumped out and then went to get out, I think it will save in the long run...a lot!

I purchased this item to replace the same model that had come to the end of its useful life. I thought I would get the same performance from the new one. Unhappily, no. This model makes twice the amount of noise as the last one: high pitched and annoying. It also takes longer to grind the same amount of beans. Add to this, that when I unboxed it, the burr grinder was missing. I had to go through a lengthy process to have a replacement shipped. (Amazon's customer service was very helpful. The manufacturer was totally unresponsive.) I suggest looking for a different grinder from a different manufacturer.

I grind 60-200 grams of coffee a day. I can't say I've done this consistently for 7 years but that's how long I've owned this grinder. Just recently it's started showing signs of giving up on me, the switch has been little dicy on the side, and the motor had a funny bogging down noise a few times recently. My guess is a wire has been vibrated loose, something I could probably solder myself if investigated. Either way, I'd have to say the plastic gears have probably been designed to take the load of grinding beans for as long as 20 seconds, but I do hold myself to the rule of letting the grinder cool down between 20 second grinds for a least a minute. But my sister in law did decide to grind 2 full bags of coffee one day and pushed thru back to Back full grinds for at least 10 minutes. So I can't really complain about the durability of any of my gears. I would say an engineer knew what he was doing when he designed the gears and maybe some of these customers were just unlucky enough to have a batch with some quality control issues.

I am here to order my second Bodum coffee bean grinder. The first one was purchased in February of 2012. The unit I had before owes me nothing! It ground out coffee at least four times a day for years and would still be in use today if it hadn't been for a small piece of metal that fell out of the coffee roasters machine and into the beans that I ran through the grinder. Even after that it ran for a few months more.
Two things:
You want more coffee, hit it twice or more! Never bothered to let it rest. It got hot once when the metal jammed it up and I had to unplug it in a hurry. Just stay nearby and monitor the process.
The plastic gears are to keep things quiet! They are sturdy and well made of quality plastic and never were a problem until they were damaged by foreign material.
Cannot think of a purchase that gave me so much satisfaction for less than a hundred bucks.

Well, some engineer finally designed a well thought-out burr-type coffee grinder, and this company (Bodum) figured out how to manufacture and sell it at a very reasonable price. This machine is a JEM! It's compact, easy to operate, and colorful on our counter.

PROs:
Well made, with hardened steel burrs
Quiet operation compared with some other machines
Large bean hopper
Logical controls that give you lots of options in operation
In-machine cord storage
Has a glass ground coffee container (instead of plastic -- very important)
Minimal ground coffee dust (more on this later)

CONs:
Ground coffee container could be slightly larger, but that would increase the overall size of the machine
Ground coffee container lid rubs against the grinder housing when being removed, brushing a little coffee dust onto counter

Now, let's consider ground coffee dust. I tried another noted brand of burr-type coffee grinder and had to send it back within days because of the mess it made with coffee dust. It made so much static electricity in its operation that the product was unusable. The ground coffee container was plastic and when you tried to remove it from the machine and remove the lid, coffee dust first would jump out all over the place, while lots remained sticking to the underside of the lid and was hard to remove without falling all over the place. Then when you tried to remove the ground coffee from the container, static would cause the ground coffee to spray around instead of falling into a coffee filter. Because ground coffee would adhere to the side and bottom of the container, it was next to impossible to empty completely without getting the ground coffee all over everything. When I checked online to see if others experienced this same problem, I found many such reports, with a like number of proposed "solutions." When I tried a few, I found that none of them solved the problem. So, I returned the unit to the supplier for a full refund, did a lot more research on the Internet, found the Bodum got high marks, ordered it, and have been enjoying it and the ground coffee it produces. A small amount of ground coffee still adheres to the inside walls of the ground coffee container, but a few taps of your hand or on the counter causes that to fall to the bottom of the container.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good value for the money, IMO
reviews.reviewText: Happy so far with performance given the price of the grinder. I know I spent less than $70 for the unit, so I don't expect it to live up to the standards of a $200-$300 grinder. Grind is more uniform that I had anticipated. Given the plastic gears, I can't expect it to last more than a year of daily use. At it's price point, I'm completely okay with getting ~365 uses from it before it wears out. Others may not have the same perspective on a grinder and longevity. The container glass isn't completely static-free, but holds static of grounds far less than other containers I've used. Overall, very happy with my purchase (after three weeks' use with this grinder).

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazing design and functionality, but horrible choice of materials.
reviews.reviewText: Amazing design and functionality, but horrible and bizarre choice of materials. I absolutely love the way this grinder works; it gives you the ability to adjust coarseness as well as the quantity that it grinds. And all the while, it even looks cool on your countertop. BUT!!! After about two years, the black casing and round lid turned soft and sticky; So much so that I can almost dig into it with my fingernail. While that's just sort of weird and slightly annoying, the bigger net result is that coffee grounds and general grime stick to it and it's virtually impossible to clean (which is definitely not a good arrangement for a device that tends constantly be around something as insidious as finely ground espresso!). As I say, it's really just sort of bizarre. I love industrial design and pay attention to details, yet I've never seen this kind of plastic used in any application. If I had known this before my purchase, I would have chosen another brand and model.

reviews.reviewTitle: not durable electronics but Good otherwise
reviews.reviewText: Everything is good about it except durability, electronics failed and it is not serviceable. It lasted 8 years however, so I just decided to purchase the same unit WITHOUT the timer function which eliminates alot of the problematic electronics. The timer mechanism is electronic and worth eliminating, I took it apart twice and tried to fix that - not possible. If you want this to be bombproof., look for the same model without the timer - or cups of coffee selector function. Simple on/off switching. Simple is best says the engineer in me.

The is the second Bodum burr grinder I have owned. I expected it to work as well as the first one I received as a gift. When it stopped grinding within 6 months I tried to make a warranty claim, well within the 2 year period. Had to contact Bodum, not Amazon. No returns authorized without Bodum's official "RA", Return Authorization. But they will not issue one without you first making and sending them a video. Many consumers would not have the capability to do that. They are obviously banking on consumers losing interest and dropping their warranty claim.

It has been more than two years since I bought this product. A few months after I bought it, the casing became sticky. And the sticky situation becomes more severe as time passes by. Now it is very very sticky. I really don't to want to touch it. But every time I need some coffee, I just hate to touch it.
I emailed my situation to the customer support and I got back the answer indicating the casing is silicon and it will become sticky when the temperature is hot.
Let's face it, how hot it can be inside the house on the kitchen counter all year round. This is a premium product when I bought it. I really expect a different treatment than the one I received. Shouldn't I?

I gave away my last two plate burr grinders because of the mess the static buildup on the plastic grounds container made and went back to Bodum's very nice blade grinder. After wearing out two of those motors and getting tired of hand grinding with an indestructible grinder I found in a cooking store in Germany, I revisited burr grinders on Amazon. The conical grinder and glass grounds container were enough of an incentive for me to give this grinder a try.

I've been using this grinder 3x a day for nearly a month now and love it. It does a uniform job of grinding for a press pot, with a continuous scale to very fine. They warn not to change the grind unless the grinder is in operation or the beans have been emptied. That seems a small price to pay for its being priced for the home market. The amount of beans ground is controlled by a timer. It is comparatively loud, but is over with faster than anything I've had before.

This grinder is not very powerful, but it worked well enough for home use for a few months. Then, unfortunately, the motor burned out. The motor was under a manufacturer's warranty for either one or two years (depending on what part, precisely, broke). When I contacted Bodum they refused to accept the item, saying that because I bought it from Amazon, I had to return it to Amazon. I made it clear that I wanted to have the item repaired, not returned, and that it was still under warranty. They refused to deal with me at all and said I had no option but to contact Amazon. Fortunately Amazon offered me a refund on the item despite it being several months since the purchase date. It goes without saying that I won't be buying a replacement coffee grinder from Bodum!

reviews.reviewTitle: A great burr grinder for the home coffee enthusiast but maybe not the home coffee aficionado snob.
reviews.reviewText:
Update: damn thing broke. About 100 uses and it's done. It was grinding and suddenly made a very loud clicking sound and wouldn't grind. I pulled it apart and cleaned everything out and now it grinds but no matter the setting (despite carefully putting it back together exactly how it was assembled) now the grind size setting has zero impact on the grind size. It come out a mix of espresso grind and larger than French press. I am terribly disappointed with this grinder breaking so fast.

The grinds are 100% consistent but they're consistent enough to make this grinder worth it at the price. You're looking at about double or even triple the price before you get into the price tier of perfect electric grinders. This is the perfect home "casual enthusiast" solution for burr grinders. Well worth the extra price over the Cuisinart burr grinder. I had it and returned it because every grind was a totally different size which defeats the entire purpose of a burr grinder! I feel like this grinder gets it about 90% right with a 10% discrepancy in grind size. Compared to the cheaper ones that are way off, it's worth it.

I have owned this machine since November 2011. I have used it almost daily to grind beans and it has never disappointed. I use it for both my drip coffee and my espresso machine (depends on what I am in the mood for). It is a light-duty machine - it states so in the owners manual. The grind is easy to adjust and is consistent. It is not a quiet machine as it is grinding beans but it is not out of what you would typically expect. I have had the grinding gear clog once with very oily beans and it was easy to open and clear it out. The only issue for me is that sometimes when removing the glass coffee container some of the ground beans will fall onto the counter. To eliminate this from happening I will "tap" the grinder before removing the glass container. Overall I am very satisfied with my purchase and would buy again.

reviews.reviewTitle: OK for Small Use, Terrible for Large Quantity Grinds.
reviews.reviewText: This is a very nice burr grinder that have a very big design flaw. You can only run the grinder for 20 seconds, then you have to wait 5 minutes before grinding again. If you deviate from that the grinder is apt to overheat and fail. If you're a person who's just needing a cup of coffee or perhaps a 32 oz french press, then this could work for you. If you're making a large amount of coffee (i.e 12-16 oz of grounds), this is a big fail.

Grinds well, BUT as other users have noted, something about the plastic causes it to form this really sticky substance (almost like tree sap) all over the outside of the machine. Basically the entire outside of my unit is now covered in this disgusting glue-like goop that absolutely will NOT come off (I've tried household cleaners, rubbing alcohol, you name it.) (This has happened to other users, and has not happened with anything else in my kitchen, so is not due to my cooking methods, etc.) This started as only a minor annoyance, but has now become so disgusting that it's a deal-breaker. I'm shopping for a new grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: $95 Gets You A Fancy Grind, But Is It Worth It?
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this grinder over 5 years now, and while it was definitely a huge improvement over my old Krups blade grinder, the allure of a Bodum Burr Grinder has gone dull.

Pros:
- Does a decent job grinding coffee to a consistent size.
- Its easy to clean out.
- Still going strong after 5 years of almost regular use (4-5x/week).
- Perfect size for grinding beans for espresso, 8-cup French Press or a 12-cup drip.

Cons:
- The plastic top of the bean storage is really just a dust cover. No seal. Don't plan to store your beans there long.
- The rubber top of the grind receptacle is decent, but coffee dust & chaff still manage to get everywhere.
- Grind consistency has faded over time.
- I have the plastic red/black unit, which is starting look and feel cheap sitting on out my kitchen counter.

Other notes:
- This grinder really hit a wall when I started to make cold brew at home. It takes 4-5 repetitions of grind, empty, grind, empty to get the 240g of coarse grinds I need for my cold brew set up.
- Occasionally, and for no apparent reason, I am only able to grind for a very short time - like 1/2 a second. So I have to keep pressing the button to get the amount of grinds I need. Could be an isolated event, but this and the need for a bigger grinder are what spurred me on to write a review and seek out a new grinder.

In summary, 5 years of pretty regular use and this $95 burr grinder has lost some of its edge. Its still a great burr grinder and it outperforms many other units. Then again, you do pay for the quality which (for me) has faded over time.

I was pleased with the look of this grinder when I unboxed it and wanted to give it a try immediately.

When I did my first grind on coarse setting it started humming away and then promptly halted. It seems a bean (or maybe a pebble) got bound up in the burr. I had to take the hopper off and clear the burrs manually (easy to take apart). Not sure what it was but after that one incident, it's been working without a hiccup. I got a little worried when that happened on the first grind but hopefully it was a one time occurrence.

I've read about concerns over the durability so I'll be keeping a close eye on this unit and the warranty.

Aside from that, the grind is great and it makes less mess than my previous grinder. The beans feed nicely from the hopper. The receiver and lid are designed well to reduce mess. I do give it a little tap with my finger to dislodge any grinds in the chute before I remove it from the machine.

Overall, a great grinder for the price point. Hopefully it lasts a long time.

Sound level is much quieter than my last grinder too (but keep in mind, these machines are an unavoidably loud appliance). You would hear it in a near bedroom but could probably get away without waking a housemate sleeping further from the kitchen.

I have been using a french press for a good while. I have been using a blade grinder to grind fresh beans every morning. Even though my blade grinder is a good quality brand (Krups), I noticed a lot of variability in the grain size after grinding. I recently switched to this burr grinder and I have noticed a big improvement in the coffee taste. It is a noticeable improvement! I choose a Bodum grinder because they pioneered the french press; they should know a lot about the best grinds for the french press method.

I like the timer feature, after you figure the ideal grind time you no longer have to measure beans. I also like the soft rubber wrap on the outside of the removable glass coffee container. It prevents the glass slipping out of your hand, early in the morning, before you have had your first cup!!

This product is fairly unremarkable - not exciting (maybe it would have been more exciting if I'd ordered one of the colorful options), but then, I didn't need excitement. I just needed coffee ground properly. The conical burr grinder works very effectively without sounding like there's a Learjet trying to take off from the kitchen. When researching the product online, I was initially concerned that there could be a lot of spillage of coffee grounds such that it would make a mess, but that has not come to pass. Grounds are deposited neatly into the glass jar and the rubber lid/seal make it so that there's no spillage or mess. The settings and adjustments on this grinder are simple and straightforward to use and the grind settings allow you to have the flexibility to prepare a variety of types of coffee from espresso to french press. Ultimately, it just works and I don't have to worry about it.

reviews.reviewTitle: yup, joined the burning smell club
reviews.reviewText: I must admit that it lasted almost 6 years (maybe 600 pots worth), however, at this price point, I don't think its demise should involve something burning inside. My only negligence was pressing the button periodically for long enough to actually make a small pot, instead of letting it cool so ridiculously long and often that I would go insane. It was also just as noisy as a blender, so scares the kids/dog/etc unlike a more commercial grade model.

reviews.reviewTitle: but requires a lot of shaking to get what I had once thought was a pretty even grind
reviews.reviewText:
I had been using the usual $20 spice grinder, which can do the job, but requires a lot of shaking to get what I had once thought was a pretty even grind. Boy have my standards changed since I got this grinder! Now I get just the right grind, and perfectly even every time. My cups of coffee are richer without having to also be stronger. Combined with an Aeropress, I don't even need to add milk any more, each cup is just that good.

I love that I can leave it off until I need it, not wasting power. It's easy to add just the amount needed for 2 cups, grind only that (timer set to 20 secs but I turn it off manually) and walk away, which has me free to switch flavours daily.

Bottom line? There may be bigger fancier brands, but this works beautifully and I don't need more. And for a $5.00/pound "boost" in the quality of the coffee from the right sized even grind, it's already paid for itself in three months.

reviews.reviewTitle: Still enjoying this after a year PLUS a static tip
reviews.reviewText: I've owned this grinder for over a year now and am very happy with it. I just visited this review section to see if anyone had any tips on cleaning the interior of the machine. (I'm happy to see that the advice about running some rice through on the coarse setting is just what I was looking for!) I did notice people complaining about the static and I wanted to mention a simple solution that seems to work for me. By the way, I own two of these machines: one at a house near the ocean which never has a static problem as the air is so moist. But here in my dry, dry, dry apartment, the static issue was making a mess of my counter. The simple solution I read about that works for me is this: after grinding the beans remove the plastic cover from the glass container and take a stainless steel (don't know if composition of the spoon makes any difference so you silver spoon people carry on) and stir the grounds for a minute or so. This seems to diminish the static tremendously. Works for me anyhow! Good luck with your grinders. I think it's a fine little machine at a good price.

reviews.reviewTitle: best bang for buck on grinder
reviews.reviewText: I have had two of these. Don't let that red flag you, because the first one lasted over 5 years and I used it EVERY DAY. The first one I had to clean it once or twice (put dry uncooked rice in the grinder and let it run through to grab out all the coffee mud). That bough it two more years of life! Now I've had the new one for two years and it is still getting the job done with heavy use.

We have gone through 3 coffee grinders in 2 years and this is the only one that doesn't make a mess!! And it's relatively quiet. Come on! A grinder is never going to be silent. And I actually find the sound of this one somewhat pleasant. I think it's muffled a bit so it's a softer sound. The coffee is ground perfectly with very minimal dust. On the bottom of the lid there are handy instructions for how long to grind to make the amount of coffee you want. For the price, it's the best burr grinder on Amazon!

I've had mine for 7 years now, according to my order history. While it's held up to twice weekly use there are a few things to be desired, most importantly the lack of control over the grind. To switch between coarse and fine you twist the hopper where the beans are stored, only this doesn't work. I like to alternate between French press and pour over which call for 2 separate grinds and this machine can't keep up. After switching settings the next 10-15 seconds of grinding will be in the previous setting before it actually switches, and it sometimes takes even longer than that. Who wants to waste that many beans?

I got this in the black finish which isn't particularly nice, it's a matte rubbery kind of material that grabs dirt, grease and dust like nothing else in my kitchen. Even after cleaning the machine it still looks dirty and feels sticky and greasy. I'll keep this until it breaks, but I'm kind of hoping it breaks soon so I can get something better.

Broke after 3 years. Makes horrible noise and vibrate at it was going to explode. Should that be expected for a $80 item?
Update: discovered that ground coffee powder was continuously coming out of 2 bottom holes. Finally unscrewed the bottom to discover that the electric motor and inside of the machine was full of rounded coffee!... A major flaw in the design, as I have no clue on how the coffee powder got there (could only come from the grinder), with major fire and electrical hazard... I am literally in shock to discover that. How can this be possible without having a major design flaw. Totally unambiguously stay away from that machine!

Update at two months: I wish I had returned this grinder while I could. Despite my efforts, it, my counter, and the inside of my coffeemaker constantly look like they're growing a five o'clock shadow. Gritty, messy to clean up. Again, I do live in desert de-humidity, so this might not be a problem everywhere. But it is for me!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
. . . When I grind for 15 + 15 = 30 seconds (for a strong 12-cup pot), static electricity IS a problem.* Stray grounds not only coat the outside of the glass cup, the grinder itself, and sometimes the counter, they scatter within the coffeemaker, getting into the water and filter openings. Messy! Also, the flimsy lid does not fit tightly on the needlessly broad top, which wouldn't be a problem if I didn't store beans in the grinder. Yes, I know Bodum says not to do that. But let's get real: lots of us can't be bothered emptying unground beans out each time, plus, if Bodum didn't want us to store beans there, why did they make the hopper so big? Especially considering the timer maxes out below one pot's worth. And why, by the way, is this grinder such a wimp that it can't go to 30 seconds in one pass? The ground coffee is okay, but I don't think I'd buy this design again.

* I live in the Arizona desert, so static might not be such a problem in more-humid areas. To mitigate (but not completely avoid) this problem, I empty the first 15-seconds' worth into the pot before the repeat grind. Less of a mess, still annoying, though.

For the price it gets the job done. I own two of these--one for use at work and the other for home. Both have performed flawlessly for over 3 years. One of the good things about the machine is that it is so loud that you won't need to share your coffee to help wake up the other people in your house: They'll be awake before you're done grinding your first load of the morning. It's the perfect grinder for aircraft lovers as it's about as loud and high-pitched as an F-16 fighter jet engine spooling for short field take-off.

The output container is glass, which is nice, but its distance from the output chute results in fragments all over the plastic/rubber top, and it can be a bit messy. I've looked at many other designs and I think that without spending a lot more money, it's difficult to have a "mess-free" grinder. But you will be cleaning up the countertop after each use of this Bodum.

One of the units is showing signs of failure in that the on/off button more frequently does not start the machine. But 3 years seems a fair lifespan for the moderate use I've put it through. You get what you pay for here. And not a bit more.

I use the machines for "oily" coffee beans and have had no problems with clogging. I am not a sophisticated user or coffee connoisseur, but have family members who are more so than I. One grinds for French Press, the other for aeropress through a stainless filter, and I grind for aeropress through a paper filter. All of us use different size grind settings and have no problems. It grinds quickly.

I give this 4 stars because of the noise pitch and volume and the messiness.

reviews.reviewTitle: Falls short in too many areas
reviews.reviewText: I've owned this for two years and it just died. But even if it was still functioning I'd give it two stars. It says in the description the glass container minimizes static, but I always dealt with TONS of static with this device. But the primary reason I've always been dissatisfied with this machine is its lack of a way to clean properly. You can remove the hopper for cleaning, as well as one of the burrs (or whatever they are called), but plenty of coffee dust accumulates inside the machine and there is no way to access the insides the clean it out. There got to be so much coffee dust inside the machine that every time is remove the glass container after grinding, coffee dust would continue to intermittently rain down on my counter, like snow falling from tree branches. I'd wipe it up only to then have more fall, yet I had no way to get in there and clean anything out. It seems to me that someone who cares enough for an even grind is also someone who cares about old stale coffee grounds intermixing with the fresh grind. Based in my two years' use I do no recommend and will be replacing this with a different brand--probably the baratza.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best Coffee Grinder I've Found for the Money
reviews.reviewText:
After using this coffee grinder for almost a year, I give it a solid 5-star rating. Although it's nowhere near professional quality, I don't believe you will find a better grinder for the price. I tried two or three other brands (sorry, don't remember them) but sent them right back because of either inability to grind accurately, or just plain poor workmanship.

I've found that the Bodum Bistro is quite good at achieving the desired grind size (I use mostly coarse, for a French press pot). It's easy to clean, too.

Two caveats:
1. Be careful storing the unit, as the carafe can easily slide out of its receptacle if you tilt the unit. I rubber band the carafe in place to keep it from falling out when storing on the shelf.
2. This grinder, like all the rest, creates a lot of static electricity, so even with the glass carafe, the grinds tend to fly all over the place when you're emptying the carafe. I do my transfers inside the sink after grinding, so the mess is contained and easily rinse-able.

reviews.reviewTitle: Accurate and consistent grind, glass anti static round canister
reviews.reviewText: I only have used this grinder for a few weeks. We shall see about durability, but the five star rating is for how silently it operates and how consistently it grinds at all settings. I used to own the cuisinart grinder which lasted me 10 years and was still going. The bodum is much quieter and more consistent in comparison. It’s glass canister is also much more useful since it doesn’t have coffee cling to it by static, and since it is round and its diameter is less than my 1 liter French press, it is a simple as dumping the ground coffee in the press effortlessly. I love this for the moment. I hope it will hold up as well as the cuisinart has.

reviews.reviewTitle: Over five years old and still runs like new
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this grinder from Amazon in July 2011 and I have used it daily for over five years. It runs flawlessly and I have not experienced any quality issues whatsoever. Some have commented that the unit only delivers a maximum of ten cups worth of ground coffee when the timer is at the maximum setting of 20 seconds, but the timer is quickly and easily reset by turning the unit on and off. If this unit ever stops working, I would replace it with the same model Bodum coffee grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great little inexpensive grinder, if you are on the fence, go ahead and get it
reviews.reviewText:
I love this grinder. I have had it a couple of months now. I primarily make either Aeropress or pour-over coffee. I also have an inexpensive Expresso machine (the Cuisinart). I have had no problems getting the grind size I want. I felt like the Expresso grind was good enough too. Though I am no expresso expert.

I typically measure 23g of beans and grind for a little over 10-12 seconds. One feature I really like is that the "time" knob does not move. Ie. unlike some, it is not a spring loaded timer, it is a set and it stays design. I like it (though it could be a little tighter).

This is a "geared down" grinder, which I like. It means the grinding burrs are not spinning too fast, and therefore not heating up my coffee. It is a true conical burr, not a flat burr like most grinders in this price range. Its noisy, and I imagine there is not good way around it. But its not too bad and I can grind 23g of coffee in about 10 seconds.

I like the glass grinds container. It is still a little staticy, but better that all plastic would be.

reviews.reviewTitle: Earns a place on my counter
reviews.reviewText: This replaced a Krups model that made a horrible racket, walked all over the counter when running, and collected gooey coffee dust in the corners of the plastic output bin. This model is quieter (though far from silent), stays put when running, and has a glass output jar that dispenses the ground coffee cleanly without residue. The input bin is air sealed (not very tightly, but adequately for small amounts) and holds enough beans for maybe a week or so. I have it set on fine for espresso grind for my Aeropress, and this gives entirely satisfactory results. The grind is cool and consistent, and the timer (I have it set on 10 seconds) is accurate and repeats reliably. I have ground three batches in a row a couple of times without the motor getting warm or showing other signs of straining. The only negatives are very minor. (1) The on-off switch on the side is unnecessary. Actual start/stop operation is with the red push button on the top of the body. (2) There is no safety switch to ensure that the output jar is in place when grinding. Made this mistake once. (3) A tiny bit of grind will fall after the output jar is removed, and will have to be blown or brushed off once a week or so. Giving the machine a brisk tap before removing the output jar will minimize this. All in all, a very good household coffee grinder for the price. This has earned a permanent place in my kitchen.

As the title says, this item is VERY noisy. I am not sure how it compares to other burr grinders but it is very very loud. That being said, everything else about this item is VERY nice. The glass container sits nice and flush, the precision of the grind is very good, the size is very convenient for a small apartment, etc. Overall, happy with this purchase, other than I can't sneakily grind stuff to make breakfast for the wife.

reviews.reviewTitle: but it is wonderful so far
reviews.reviewText: I've only had this for a couple months, but it is wonderful so far! It looks nice on the counter, but more importantly it performs well. It is very easy to use and so far the resulting grinds are consistent in size, but I have only been using this for coffee that is brewed in a Chemex so far so I will update with results for finer and courser grinds as I use the grinder. It's certainly not quiet, but it is much less obnoxious than other home burr grinders I've used! Overall this is excellent (especially compared to other burr grinders at this price range!) and I would definitely recommend it.

reviews.reviewTitle: If you like coffee grounds everywhere, you'll love the Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder!
reviews.reviewText:
Spent nearly a hundred bucks on this, and it's a total nightmare. Coffee grounds get everywhere. Five weeks in (after the window of return expired), I had to disassemble it because coffee grounds were coming out of the bottom of the unit. Inside, it was a mess. Coffee grounds all over the electronics.

Bottom line is that t's absolutely a faulty design; the grounds go down a multi-part plastic chute to a flat area above the glass receptacle. The chute can come apart, causing grounds to fall into the unit. Grounds that make it past this problem are deposited into a flat area that has a hole in the center. What ends up happening is, the coffee grounds build up over time and -- every time you move the unit -- spill everywhere. It's a mess.

We bought this product based on all the 5-star reviews. Now I'm pretty convinced they were Vine reviewers or 5-star reviews paid for by Bodum. There's just no way a design this faulty could result in satisfied buyers of this machine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Inconsistent quality. YOURS might not have consistently sized grinds.
reviews.reviewText:
I bought two at the same time; one for use by me and one by my wife. One of the units had visibly uneven grinds, especially as compared to the perfectly consistent grinds in the other machine. I closely inspected the uneven unit, but I couldn't see any difference in it that was causing the unevenness. So, I returned the bad machine.

Be careful, if you have nothing to compare to, you might think the uneven grind sizes is normal. It's not!

reviews.reviewTitle: All mechanical products need servicing from time-to-time.
reviews.reviewText:
Love this grinder. We've used it nearly every day for the past 8 months. The glass cup is far superior to plastic for pouring the grinds.

This morning, I got the horrible noise that others have referenced, and the coffee wasn't grinding. The fix was easy, thanks to another reviewer: I emptied the beans; tapped the grinder until I thought all of the coffee was out; and ran 1/3 cup of rice through the machine. Almost instantly the noise went away and the grinder went right through the rice. Problem solved in less than the time it would have taken me to contact Amazon/Bodum.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bodum worked great, but Not Durable
reviews.reviewText:
Purchased this nice unit in November 2011, and am returning it today for a refund. It stopped grinding suddenly and I noticed as burning plastic smell from the unit.

It is unfortunate, as I was touting the benefits of this grinder which produced a very fine espresso grind, which was contrary to some reviews that almost prevented me from purchasing the machine initially. While it worked, it served as seemingly cost efficient way to produce an excellent grind for a higher-end Italian Espresso machine.

All a long I knew that I probably needed a durable grinder that was at least in the $200 range, or more. And this was proven to be the case. So the day this one stopped working, I decided to buy another grinder. I bit the bullet (willingly) purchased a Breville Smart Grinder. I did not order it from Amazon, but purchased it from Sur La Table and paid the sales tax. Seems stupid, but actually the store provides a lifetime warranty; so for about $220 for the grinder I have a lifetime warranty to return the grinder for any reason. I found this to be important as this is the 3rd lower cost burr grinder that stopped working shortly after purchase (including Capresso and Cuisinart brands).

The Bodum Bistro was a great unit while it worked, but was just not durable enough.

reviews.reviewTitle: the quality of the grind is good. PROs
reviews.reviewText:
After doing some research on burr grinders I went with middle of the road. I know that having fresh ground coffee makes a huge difference is the taste of your coffee. I wouldn't buy this one again for a few of the simple cons stated below. Yet, the quality of the grind is good.
PROs: Grinds great. Took a little time to figure out the right grind but does a good job.
CONs: Timer stopped working correctly after a couple months. Glass jar is NOT static free. Messy around the grinder because of static. A bit loud.

***UPDATE 4/8/2017***
I use this everyday. It is slowly going downhill. It is not grinding as long as the timer says. I have to keep pressing the grind button 4-5 times to get 7 tablespoons of grounds. I have cleaned it twice and each time it has seemed to get worse.

I have sent 2 emails to Bodum and have not heard back yet.

We purchased this coffee grinder to replace our Cuisinart DBM-8. The Cuisinart was great, but the timing mechanism began to fail to the point where a press on the button wouldn't activate the motor for any length of time. So far, the Bodum has been very good. Pros include the glass container for the coffee grounds (the Cuisinart's was plastic), and it is quieter. The Bodum has a "timer" function rather than being based on how many cups are being ground for, but the concept is pretty much the same. The Cuisinart seemed to be more ruggedly built. In comparison the Bodum seems a bit lightweight and has a less quality feel - but time will tell how long the Bodum will hold up. We liked our Cuisinart but just wanted to try something different. So far (about a month later), we're pleased!

I grind exclusively at the espresso level - almost at the finest level. I grind french roast beans which seem to contain significant oils. The burr grinder jams up and refuses to pass grind to the container after 2 or 3 uses. Grind amount is around 8 ounces at a time. The unit plugs up to the point of grinding the gears. After a year and a half of weekly use and frequent cleanings I threw to device away in frustration. FREQUENT CLEANINGS.
Yes, I am a high volume, fine grind user, but the blasted thing in not designed to be cleaned !!!!! It was impossible to clear the plugs.

reviews.reviewTitle: Started simple, working. Two years later, useless.
reviews.reviewText: We've used this product for years and it's mostly been good. However, we started noticing coffee tasting stale, french-press grinds being too fine for a french press, etc. It turns out that for some time the grinder has been letting really copious amounts of particles build up in its hollow space (that you can't get to). Now, after a grind, if I tap it on its side a few times, several large spoonfuls of old coffee drop out onto the counter. I'm on Amazon now looking for a replacement that is less messy and more durable.

This grinder had good reviews but it was noted that even at the finest settings it was still not suitable for good espresso. However several people had investigated modifications that would increase the fineness of the grind and based on their reports I decided to buy one and take the chance that a modification would work out.
When the grinder arrived I took it out of the box and found that the conical burr was only finger-tight to the spindle and easy to remove. So I proceeded with the modification without even turning on the grinder. The change consisted of making a washer 0.032 inches thick that mounts over the spindle and up inside the burr. With the washer in place, the burr is elevated by 0.032" above its normal position resulting in reduced clearance to the upper burr and finer grinds, especially at the finest setting.
The results we are getting with this grinder are spectacular. It produces fine, even grinds that function beautifully in our Gaggia Classic resulting in thick crema and great taste. We have been using the grinder daily for 5 months and it has not plugged up once. The overall construction of the grinder is of very high quality. We couldn't be happier with this product and have no complaints.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just to add to the pile of similar complaints. ...
reviews.reviewText: Just to add to the pile of similar complaints.....Purchased March 2014, died November 2015. Will not grind coffee without the beans becoming stuck in the burr. We grind 40g of coffee (not oily dark roast either) every day on a medium/course setting for use with a pour over. It worked well for at least a year and then, beans would become stuck once a month. Now, it will not grind enough for one cup of coffee. My husband had to take it apart to remove stuck beans 6 times today before we gave up. Even when it was functioning well, it leaked coffee grinds from the bottom of the machine. Took it apart this morning to look for issues and noticed that the inner electrical housing was FULL of ground coffee....stuck to all the wires, etc. I am giving up and opting for an inexpensive hand grinder.

We bought this grinder in 2011 and have used it nearly every day for six years and multiple times on weekend days. It's well engineering and and beautifully designed. It ground coffee admirably for the first five and a half years but has been struggling to grind coffee consistently of late. As a result, we bought a new grinder and promoted our older grinder to spice mill which is the highest office an appliance in our kitchen can hold.

The coffee grinds are consistent and of high quality for light and medium roasts and non-oily beans. It doesn't work as well with oily coffee beans and really dark roasts. This wasn't a problem in our house but its worth keeping in mind if you like really dark roasts.

I bought this grinder because I wanted a burr grinder (for grind consistency), the price was right, and I needed it to fit under my cabinets.

I returned it because it would only grind for about 2sec-5sec at a time (I did get one 13sec run) then would shut down and not restart till it cooled (taking many minutes or more). Basically it was unusable (and hopefully defective)! At the time (10/2012), Others were complaining about the short grind times so I think Bodum may have had an product issue. Since I see a lot more positive reviews here now maybe they fixed it (Although people still talk about the short grind time). My take is that Bodum built an underpowered unit which they knew would over heat easily. To keep users from burning it up they put in some kind of thermal protection. I think the 20sec time limit may not be enough to grind for a 10 cup drip. You may find that depending on your unit you may be grinding more then once. Having to walk away for 2-5minutes between grinds. (Note that finer grinds take longer and auto drip grid is already on the coarse side)

Since I didn't have it long I still have a bunch of unknowns: coarse to fine settings (can it do french press to expresso?), grind consistency at each setting, cleaning (a stone, yes coffee sometimes has little stones in it, can jam the machine ... how do you get it out), if the motor is constantly stressed ... how long will it last

My take is that this grinder may be more of a frustration then it's worth. If your price constrained and only grind for a few cups at a time the Bodum may work for you.
Pro's: small, burr grinder, good looking
Cons: underpowered, may have to grind several times (taking 10+ minutes or more), unknowns listed above.

My rating if they fixed it to actually run for 20sec ... two stars ... (my defective unit gets 0 stars)

P.S. I ended up with a Breville BCG800XL Smart Grinder. Costs two to three times as much (depending on sales and such), has a much bigger motor (I wouldn't call it oversized ... i.e. I think a even bigger one would not be bad). It does not fit under my cabinet but it does do a nice job of grinding (I'll try and review it soon).

I've been wanting a conical burr grinder for sometime. I was never really ready to justify shelving out over $30 for a coffee grinder. I made coffee using a French press, espresso machine, and my aeropress. Finally, I decided to treat myself. Boy was this a great decision. The design is very mod and sexy. The noise level isn't too loud and the grinds come out perfect. It was super simple to assemble and get going immediately. There isn't much of a static that I have noticed. I did notice some grinds on the bottom, it could be due to some grinds falling when I pull the little cup out. All in all a great piece for coffee lovers.

reviews.reviewTitle: BODUM made a great grinder for the money!!!
reviews.reviewText:
This coffee grinder is incredibly versatile, and fits a small footprint. Both the grind settings and the time are infinitely adjustable. It'll grind a perfect double shot of a espresso, in less than 10 seconds.
Also there's very little static charge on the glass container. I've got other similarly priced grinders before, And in the long run I was terribly let down. Bobum really knocked it out of the park with this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not at all what I was hoping for
reviews.reviewText:
Let's start with the cons:
- The most coarse setting isn't coarse at all
- The most fine setting is possibly too fine
- Messy as all hell! I was hoping a glass bin would reduce static and fine grounds and dust flying everywhere. Not so! After grinding static *always* has grounds clinging to the underside of the lid (even if grinding only a few grams of beans for a single cup). Slide the bin out slowly and you can watch them hop out from the hole in the lid and up the front side of the grinder, and then on to the counter. Removing the bin also has grounds fall out from the grinding area above, no matter how much you try to tap on the unit before removal. Also have found that after just a single grind there are grounds and bean dust on the counter directly under the motor. What? How does *that* happen?!
- The longest run time is 20 seconds. If you were maybe making a 10-cup pot of coffee, 20 seconds doesn't cover that volume. Directions indicate you need to wait 5 minutes between runs if you do a full 20 second grind. I've never seen a consumer motor in anything with such a pathetic duty cycle (blenders and mixers have no problem running longer periods with no cool-down in between). If you like to grind fresh immediately before brewing, this puts a huge crimp in morning routines.

Pros?
- It's Bodum. That's about it.

The fact that it's Bodum should make all the cons non-existent but such just isn't the case. I'm incredibly disappointed with this, especially for the cost. I'm on the edge of just tossing it in the trash and grabbed a $35 Cuisinart like every other home-grinding coffee drinker in the US has. It's really *that* bad.

Think it over a few times before clicking 'add to cart'; this is one of the few regrettable purchases I've made in quite some time.

I've been drinking espresso daily for the past 20 years. I've had a succession of gadgets along the way too. And I have found that I don't have spend a fortune to make a good espresso. But, I do have to have a burr grinder in order to get that good shot.
Enter the Bodum Bistro. I bought it to replace my last grinder which finally burnt out after years of use. So, far this has been a fine little grinder (I've had it for a year and a half, paid $66.48).
It certainly grinds fine enough for espresso on range of beans. My wife is a regular drip coffee drinker and has no complaints either. I can not speak to the coarser grinds, like french press, because I never use them.
The only trick one needs to know with this machine is how to avoid the sneak attack grinds which jump out after you remove the collection container (container is glass, no static, very nice!). So, these grinds stay up in the housing and don't fall into the collection glass. But, once you remove the container, they pour out. It is less than a quarter teaspoon but still makes a little mess. So to avoid it, after the grinding stops, but before you grab the container, just tap on the side of the machine and the sneak attack grinds will fall into the container and everything is fine. No mess. No reason to complain. Just about every gadget has it's particular idiosyncrasy. The sneak attack is this one's, and it is easily remedied.
Overall, this is a great little grinder. It gets used twice daily, once for espresso and once for drip. I'd buy it again.

UPDATE:
I bought this grinder in 2012. Now 5 years later, 2017, we still use it twice daily. I use it for espresso grind, my wife for percolator coffee. It still works great!
I now need a second grinder for the office. So, I'm buying another Bodum.

reviews.reviewTitle: would be a good move. Assuming it's identical then yes it would ...
reviews.reviewText:
I have used it every day since I bought it in 2012. It's 2017 now, so that's five years of three 20 second grinds a day. It was quiet when I first bought it (which is the reason I bought this model) but recently it seems to be less quiet. I hesitate to grind the coffee when the rest of the family is asleep on the weekends because I don't want to wake them up. But that has only been true for about the last 6 months. For that reason, I'm wondering if a new one, which is half the price I paid in 2012, would be a good move. Assuming it's identical then yes it would be.
Otherwise the quality of the coffee grinds is still excellent. It's still good, whether made in the Bonavita, or pour over in the Chemex. Love the glass receptacle - no static, never broken. So really, an excellent machine.

No way to clean the exterior. It is a strange rubbery finish that stays sticky. I've tried soap and water and Windex but still sticky. Too bad as this is a fantastic coffee grinder. I've had it for 2 years and every morning it delivers beautifull fine ground coffee. I just wish it was made of some ordinary plastic or stainless steel.

We've been looking a long time for a good, affordable burr grinder for espresso. We saw this in a coffee shop in Banff and immediately looked it up. The reviews seemed solid, so we got it. We turned it to the finest setting, grind for 15 seconds, and it produces just enough grounds for two cups of espresso. It makes the finest grounds we've had from home! We previously used the HEB and other grocery store machines, but this produces the best, by far. I would say it's almost borderline Turkish fine. Some reviews suggested that the metal variants work better for them, so we got the copper. Absolutely no problems with static, fingerprints, or any other complaints so far. For some reason, it makes the coffee beans go longer; we have bought noticeably less coffee since we got this grinder. Also, we use it occasionally for French press, and it has no problem making coarse grounds.

I bought this grinder as a move up from the blade grinders which can deliver an inconsistent result and one not very precise for different brewing methods. I carefully considered the options, read the reviews, considered my price point, and decided on the Bodum. The white was available at about $10 less than the black and matched my other appliances, so I went with that one.

Pretty much everyone praises the uniform grind, etc. The cone is designed so that beans feed easily into the grinder. Unlike a Krups burr grinder I have used, I've had no occasion so far to have to shake the Bodum to move the beans from the storage cone into the grinder. The unit is relatively small. It could be even smaller if the cone weren't designed to hold beans for 30 cups of coffee. Folks serious about their coffee aren't apt to be storing beans for 30 cups at room temperature on the kitchen counter--well, maybe folks soooooo serious about their coffee that they're drinking huge quantities--but the rest of us could get by with a much smaller cone.

The 30-cup capacity cone is especially silly in a grinder that is supposed to be run for only 20 seconds at a time, max, with 5-minute intervals between grindings. Many of the reviews take note of this limitation: some dismiss it as largely irrelevant to their habits; at least one reviewer ignores this prescription entirely; others do find it to be an issue.

After reading the reviews, I bought this grinder thinking that, for the relatively small quantities of coffee I brew--the equivalent of about 4-5 cups each morning--the 20-second rule probably wouldn't be an issue. There were few specifics in the reviews I read as to how much coffee you could grind in 20 seconds.

As it turns out, the 20-second rule is a minor inconvenience, even for my 4-5 cups each morning. If I'm brewing French press, 20 seconds will give me enough beans at the relatively coarse grind. If, however, I'm brewing drip, my five scoops of beans requires about 35 seconds.

My work-around--and it is a work-around--is to grind for 20 seconds at the drip setting, let the grinder rest for five minutes while I get the water ready and bring it to a boil. About the time the water is at a boil, I grind for another 15 seconds or so, and that gives me the amount of ground bean I need.

As for the much touted advantage of the glass (v plastic) receptacle for the grind, I'm not seeing it. I get pretty much the same amount of cling with the glass as I've experienced with the plastic receptacle on the Krups that I've used. My theory here is that it's not static cling that causes the grind to stick to the receptacle; it's the oils in the ground beans that sticks. If it were static cling, it stands to reason that the plastic might hold more of the grind, but the glass holds just as much of the sticky oil. OK, there may be a slight advantage to the glass, but it's not much in my estimation.

Would I buy this product again? I'd certainly consider it at this price point, but I'd also have to look hard at other models, including the Krups at about the same price and the Cuisinart at a markedly lower price point.

I’ve had this grinder for four months, and would like to share some observations that may matter to some. I replaced a standard Cuisinart coffee grinder with a burr grinder to enjoy a better tasting coffee, and this grinder accomplishes this. I chose this medium-prized grinder over the more expensive Baratza Virtuoso grinder to save a few bucks, and I’m starting to wonder whether “being cheap” was a mistake in this case.

I use a French press, and although the Bodum offers a range of grind option, the coarsest setting is still finer than it should be for a French press. To make matters worse, when I have it on the coarse setting, I actually have to hold the top part in place or else the grinding vibration causes the top to shift counterclockwise and turn the grinder off because the top becomes loose.

Bodum markets the glass catcher as “reducing” static that causes jumping coffee grounds . . . well, it still leaves a mess: you get static coffee flakes all over the plastic lid and bottom part of the grinder which can (and will) get messy as you remove the catcher and take off the lid to pour the coffee into your French press, for example.

Also, granted, just a nit: after four months, the on/off button still trips me up: you need to push it down, not up to get the on position . . . (as another reviewer pointed out: it’s something that really could be easily fixed "for export").

Finally, the timed grinding feature is nice, but it would be even nicer if they included some kind of instructions as to what setting amounts to how many cups (roughly). It was a trial and error for me to get it right.

Bottom line: it’s OK; it’s a value burr grinder; you get what you pay for. But I wouldn’t recommend it to a friend, not without the above caveats, which have me knock off three stars. Personally, I now wish I had invested $100 more to get a “real” burr grinder — one where I don’t have to hold the funnel in place on the coarse setting and where “coarse” means “coarse.”

Coffee experts agree that for the very best tasting coffee we need good beans, good water, and a good grinder (beans should be ground right before preperation for the best freshness). The best grinders use conical burrs to do the grinding.

The pick of conical burr grinders under $100 is slim indeed. Since the product description on this one did not specify that its burrs were conical, I went with the Brevell first. It did the job, but was quite messy, so I tried the Bodum, which does turn out to have conical burrs. Here's the comparison:

Pros: The Bodum is much neater. It's description rings true--using a glass catcher for the grinds reduces static electricity and results is much cleaner usage. No grinder will be perfect, but this one is a huge improvement. The 8-oz bean holder is also an improvement. The seal is tight, so the beans remain fresh. It is convenient to add new beans far less often. So, for convenience, the Bodum is far superior to the Brevell. Also, it's about $30 cheaper.

Cons: Other reviews have mentioned the fineness of the grind. I prefer a corse grind, but mainly use an automatic drip maker. So, the coarsest setting is acceptable. If grinding for a French press, or similar preparation method that calls for coarser beans, some may be disappointed. The other issue is that I often have to hold the bean container, to keep the machine grinding. If I simply push the button it will often stop grinding within a couple of seconds. This is a minor inconvenience, at thie price, but one worth noting.

Bottom line: This is a great conical burr grinder for the price. Most people will be more than satisfied. Those who prefer French press or perculated coffee may find the grind too fine. If so, prepare to pay more, because I'd recommend skipping the next step up (the Brevell) since it is so messy and inconvient.

I had this blade coffee grinder for many years. I was waiting for it to die so I could justify getting a burr grinder. The darn thing wouldn't die. I use a french press most of the time. I also have a stove top expresso maker and a turkish coffee maker. Impossible to get decent even grounds. I broke down and got a burr grinder. I did a lot of research before I bought this one.
I love it. The grinds are just right and very easy to use. It's not too loud, and doesn't scare Dennis (the cat) the way the blade grinder did. Why didn't I buy this sooner. Well worth the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... product for about 6 weeks now and I'm quite happy. I use it about twice a week and ...
reviews.reviewText: I've had this product for about 6 weeks now and I'm quite happy. I use it about twice a week and it works well. I had a problem trying to grind some locally bought coffee - the grinder got stuck on some beans for whatever reason and gave off a loud buzz until the timer finished. My guess is that the dark roasted beans were too oily, as I've read this can cause this type of issue. Other than that, medium roasts seem to grind without issue. Coffee is fresher and more flavorful when ground with the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr grinder right before brewing, though I have never owned another grinder to which to compare. It's the equivalent of using dried parsley flakes from your spice cabinet vs. chiffonading fresh parsley to top a homemade meal.

reviews.reviewTitle: A ceramic burr grinder that is reliable, durable and does not cost a fortune
reviews.reviewText:
I have two of these (one in each home) and my brother has one. They are now several years old and get daily use. They are still doing a good job.n They are pretty straightforwards to use, you turn the clear plastic cone to set the fineness, the time to set the amount and push the little red button. Set it to 2 and 10 seconds for a double shot.

What's to complain about - that it didn't cost $200+ Oh, and when I broke the glass jar on one, the replacement from Bodum was reasonably priced.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lasted three months before it wouldn't grind coffee. It ...
reviews.reviewText: Lasted three months before it wouldn't grind coffee. It runs, just doesn't grind the coffee. Stopped grinding one day for no reason.

reviews.reviewTitle: UPDATE: Lasted 7 months!!!....Best grinder out there for under $250, great for Aeropress!
reviews.reviewText:
UPDATE:
After 6-7 months of daily use (2 coffees a day), our beloved Bodum bit the dust. I am somewhat handy so I disassembled the machine as fully as possible and cleaned everything out with a wire brush. I re-assembled but it was still broken. The grinds were not coming out properly, usually 15 seconds would give us the amount of grinds needed for the aeropress but now 15 seconds was only producing 1/10th of what normally came out. Even after continuous grinding to fill the cup, it made horrible coffee. So I phoned customer service and despite me asking them if there was anything I could fix by myself, they would only send me a replacement machine. Thank god for the 2 year warranty! I gave them my information after that via an email and received a response back 3 days later. They asked a question about my address so I replied and didn't hear back for another 3-4 days, in which they needed something else. I replied again right away and didn't hear one word back after repeat emails to them for about 14 days. I was giving up but then it showed up in the mail right after.
Not sure who sits on the other end of the inbox for them but a quick, "We shipped it" email would have made me a whole lot happier.

So although I was able to get a replacement unit (without sending the old one back) with relative ease, I am still giving this product a 3 star review. A $100 grinder should last longer than half of a year and I am worried the replacement unit will break like the first one. And since it only has a 2 year warranty, I might be out a hundred bucks, sooner than later.

Initial Review:
We bought this grinder after returning from Hawaii with $140 of some of the world's best coffee. We have an espresso machine and also an Aeropress but no grinder! We had been just buying vacuum sealed espresso grind and while it usually made pretty good cafe americanos, it never really made a good Aeropress coffee.
When we got the product in the mail in came in the world's biggest box and we thought it was going to look bigger than our Saeco in the kitchen. It wasn't that bad when we got it out but this guy is still pretty tall on our counter. A little bit taller than the toaster but I like the design and the rubber feel to it. The hopper cap seems like to barely clicks on when you cap it but it has never fell off during use. Also I always seem to find grinds under the glass grind bottle and I don't know how it gets under there!
The grinder does have a 20 second timer and then you're supposed to wait 5 minutes until it cools down before next use...we do our best to wait the full 5 minutes. For the Aeropress we need more than 20 seconds worth so we grind for 20sec and then for another 10sec. Still works perfectly fine. It is also very easy to adjust the grind. We have made consistently good coffee with the finest espresso grind and Aeropress coffee with a course/fine grind. And for all of you Aeropress lovers out there: We consistently grind on the 3rd last dot from the FINEST end.
My friend recommended we buy this after he bought his for a $1200 espresso machine and I would recommend this product to anybody who likes fresh coffee. This thing works perfect or an espresso machine, a french press or an Aeropress. Just don't get the green color!

Do not buy the copper version!!
My friend bought the black version of this grinder, and loved it, so I decided to get the copper one, and after the third use, the button busted and the grinder stopped working completely. I sent it in and got a replacement, and the replacement also didn’t work! The grinder looks really pretty, and it worked alright the theee times I used it, but after that it’s useless.

I have had this grinder for 6 years and a 2 weeks now. It has held up over the years. The only issue is that about 4 years into its life I have to do this thing where I flip the power switch on and off before hitting the start button to get it to start grinding. Make clean it out every once it a while. I just gently shake it out and blow some air with a compressed air can after a bag or two of beans. I use it with my aeropress mostly and sometimes with my french press. I'm not really a fan of french press. Also with this grinder there might be too many fine bits that make it through for a good french press course grind. For the price though it has a pretty consistent grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good, but could and should be better
reviews.reviewText: Okay, I realize this isn't a high-dollar burr grinder, but then it's not cheap either. My likes: Quiet operation, nice rubberized exterior finish, glass receptacle and stainless steel burr set. My dislikes: Short motor run time. It can overheat if not given a five minute rest period between 20 second grind sessions. Really? Cheap power switch. The power switch on mine failed the second day I had it. The switch is cheap and flimsy. I started to return it, but for what? If I exchanged it, the replacement would just fail too and none of the others I looked at were made to suit me. So, I took the bloody thing apart and replaced the switch with a beefier toggle switch. My suggestion if you are considering one is to leave the main power switch ON and just use the start button on the top of the unit to power it on and off. One other gripe...unless you pick up and shake the unit post-grinding, it will dump a bunch of grounds all over your counter.

It's the afternoon and I never drink coffee in the afternoon because I'll be awake until 2am. . .but . .my Bodum Bistro grinder just arrived and I couldn't wait to try it. I've been using a Capresso for 7 years or so and it's been fine, but the spray of coffee grindings got to be too much (I know, the plastic grounds holder causes this). So basically I was replacing something that really didn't NEED replacing. Extravagant. Who cares? So, I opened the box, read the [non]instructions*, ground my beans, and poured my usual 16 ounces.
