If I hadn't actually put the beans into the hopper myself I would have been pressed to believe this coffee was made from same beans I've been using for 2-3 years. I mean like, OMG. Is this what French Roast really tastes like? When used in a French Press? Apparently so. And all this time I've been settling for a fairly dilute version and didn't know it. Actually, I just kept buying deeper roasted beans, trying to glean some quality flavor. I am gobsmacked.

Some details:
- I use the coarsest grind.
- Measure 4 tablespoons of beans. (which take about 4 seconds or so to grind . . I didn't time it, but it was SO much less than my Capresso I was hardly prepared. Some reviews have criticized the 20 second limit before the little motor has to rest, but I'd imagine the hopper would have to be filled to the brim to take 20 seconds. That's a whole lot of coffee!)
- *The "instructions" are so crazily non-instructional you have to go to Youtube for little information you might want. I looked at Mikemuonline. Pretty good except the cheesy advert for a fax company thrown in the middle.
- The perfect instructions for making coffee in a French Press come from Harold McGee's "On Food and Cooking":
- water between 190 and 195 degrees (I use a digital thermometer)
- stir grounds after adding water
- allow 6 minutes for full flavor extraction

I never realized I was in desperate need of a new grinder and now I do. Purchase totally justified!

reviews.reviewTitle: that's a lot of use from this VERY GOOD grinder. We very rarely adjust the grind once ...
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this for my wife and I in October of 2011. We make 2 eight-cup pots of coffee a day into a Mr. Coffee stainless steel vacuum pot (thermos). We do a "fresh grind" for each pot, then into the paper filter. If you do the math, that's a lot of use from this VERY GOOD grinder. We very rarely adjust the grind once we found our "setting" but, we do vary the time by a couple of seconds to adjust for roasting and bean differences in our purchased coffee. This has been a perfect machine and a perfect combination with the Stainless steel carafe.

5 years and going strong. Still very consistent in it's grind. This was a GREAT BUY. thanks rch

I've been using this grinder everyday for 5 months now and couldn't be more happy. After a few tweaks to the timer and grind settings - I get a consistent grind every time. I love that I can store my beans in the container and in the morning just press a button. The glass receiver works well and doesn't leave a lot of grinds in it. Just rinse it out on occasion to clean out the oils from the beans and the grind won't stick. I love the compact size as it doesn't eat up a lot of counter space.

Wow. I've read that a good grinder would improve the quality of espresso, but I was not prepared for this. This makes for a good dark, STRONG double shot, unlike any that I had pulled before from my Saeco Aroma.
My previous grinder was a B&D burr grinder. To be honest, I saw no difference between that one and any of the other (non-burr)grinders I have owned. Sure, it's nice to use freshly ground coffee, but even on it's finest setting, the grain of the grind was on a par with what you would get from a can of Maxwell House. The Bodium will grind as fine as dust. And speaking of dust, it is completely dust free, as in sealed. Unlike the B&D, there is no leakage to clean up.

The feed cup is large, and holds a good amount of beans. It seals as well with it's rubber top as any can top. Certainly better than a paper or foil coffee bag. You can fill the thing and your beans will stay as fresh as any other storage solution I can think of.

Another thoughtful feature is the rubber ring around the collecting jar which lets you easily pull the glass jar from it's seal, even with wet fingers. In my short experience with this grinder, the seal on the collecting jar is the work around for the admittedly limited duty cycle of the machine. It is enough of a seal to be dust free and enough of a seal to leave some coffee for your next use, without detectable degradation.

My only minor quibble is with the collecting jar's circular shape. The diameter is just a little too large to load a portafilter with a pour. You pretty much have to use a scoop. But, as I said, a minor quibble, and it would not be an issue with a larger target such as a Malita or drip machine.

The good:
Brain dead, one touch ease of use, once you've dialed in your setting.
Consistent ultra fine grind.
Reasonably quiet.
Sealed storage solution for beans.
Sealed glass collector with a convenient rubber grip.

The almost good:
Requires use of a scoop for loading small targets such as a portafilter.

The not so good:
The machine does have a very short duty cycle. There's a workaround that's acceptable to me, but this is the only legitimate strike I've found against this machine

The bad:
None.

I would heartily recommend this machine to any one who appreciates their coffee freshly ground.

reviews.reviewTitle: Five Years Plus Of Heavy Use For French Press
reviews.reviewText: This is our 2nd one. The first one finally started to fail after over 5 years of flawless coarse grinding twice a day for our Bodum 8 cup French Press. Bodum thought all I needed to get it working again was a new burr insert which they sent as a no charge courtesy. Unfortunately it didn't help (timer/power switch had failed), but we certainly got way more than our money's worth (approximately 4,000 carafes of coffee). The silica glass container is a definite static free plus and unlike Bodum's carafes, it has a rubberized grip band so we've never broke it due to careless handling. Once we determined the right grind and timer setting for our taste we never had to adjust it again. As with any grinder, you should brush it clean regularly. Because we use very oily espresso roast beans, we also run a lid full of cleaner "tablets" made for costly commercial grinders through it every 90 days. We use a high end Rancillio grinder for our espresso machine so I can't comment on its suitability for really serious espresso machines.

I finally broke down and decided to get a decent grinder for using with my Aeropress Aerobie AeroPress Coffee and Espresso Maker. I always hated those small hand grinders that make such a mess, and I finally got sick of the grinders I'd use at Trader Joe's which are never calibrated correctly. I'm so glad I finally got this one. The design is so perfect. First, it has a small footprint. It's definitely smaller than it looks in the picture, at least to me. Second, there are many different sizes of grind you can choose. I picked halfway between drip and espresso for my Aeropress, and it's perfect. Third, the one-touch pre-set timing mechanism is brilliant. You choose anywhere from about 5 seconds to 20 seconds, then just push a button. The grinder will automatically grind for that length of time. I don't have to hold it down, and I don't have to guess from day-to-day whether I'm getting it right. It just works. I used to weigh the same amount of coffee every day, but now I don't have to bother with that. And because the grind I can get is finer than I was able to get at TJ's, I actually use about 10 grams less coffee every day to make the same great, intense cup. Ten grams adds up, right? In no time this thing will pay for itself!

It's no joke about how mess-free this grinder is. I guess it's partially due to the glass, but it's also the design. There is one small hole at the top of the container and I just shake the coffee out of that right into my Aeropress. Absolutely no grinds anywhere on the counter. Love it.

If you've been on the fence, just go for it. You will not be sorry.

reviews.reviewTitle: The grinder I was searching for (Updated)
reviews.reviewText:
Update (07/08/2014)
I have been using this grinder everyday for two years and it hasn't missed a beat. I am careful not to over-run it by waiting between grinding after 20 second-runs. It takes time to pull espresso, so this isn't much of a problem. I highly recommend this grinder if you can buy it for less than $100.

*************ORIGINAL REVIEW****************

BACKGROUND:(you can skip to pros and cons if you'd like)
I've only been drinking coffee for the last 7 years or so, but being in Seattle, I've come to appreciate truly great coffees. Starbucks isn't too bad, it's not one of the better ones around here.

Wanting to enjoy good cup of coffee anytime at home, I began the search for the tools. I didn't want to go all they way and spend couple of grand to make espresso, nor even couple of hundreds of dollars. I couldn't afford them and my wife would never approve of it anyhow. So, I've tried drip coffee, french-press, Aero-press, but settled on Bialetti 6800 Moka Express 6-Cup Stovetop Espresso Maker for making a good cup of coffee. Meanwhile, I've also tried out some of the best rated coffee and settled upon Jammin' Java Coffee Kingston City Roast, Espresso, Organic Gourmet Whole Bean Coffee. Medium Dark, Choco-nut & Creamy, 2.2-Pound.

I've been grinding my beans with Capresso Coffee Burr Grinder which I had bought from local costco, but wasn't satisfied with the ground consistency nor the mess it created with the static it seemed to bring. With the great reviews and the container being glass, I decided to try this. Now, this was more expensive than the coffee maker and it was a "big" investment for me, but after using it for a month, it's worth every penny and then some.

PROS:
1. Grind - Consistency: The grounds are quite consistent, much more so than the Capresso burr grinder. This consistency seem to improve the taste. [A]
2. Grind - Range: Range of how coarse or fine is quite broad. Though I'm just using one setting, it's there when I need it. [A-]
3. Container - Mess: Because it's make of glass, there seems to be minute amount of static, if any. This makes it so much more pleasurable to use. [A+}
4. Container: The container has rubber band around it to help with grips and has rubber cover with 3/4 inch hole in the middle. Nice thing about this cover is that just tapping on the cover pretty much releases all the coffee grinds from it and when you open it up none of the coffee grinds go anywhere since there's no static. [A]
5. Aesthetic: It's nice looking and has smaller footprint than I had imagined. [A-]

CONS:
1. Time Limit: the max time you can run at once is about 20 seconds. However, if you press it again right away, it will run. I suppose Bodum wants you to give couple of minutes before you run it again to prolong the life of the machine. Some also has mentioned burr may become too hot and thereby destroying the coffee flavors, but I'm not sure about that. As for me, I run it once and start preparing my Moka and when I'm ready to add the coffee, I just run it again to finish it. So it's no big deal for me. [B]

CONCLUSION: I've only been using it for a month, but I could not be happier with the purchase. This has to be the best sub-$100 grinder out there. As for durability, I will update in few months. Another thing I'm happy about is the color. Although my unit is white, it does not seem to get dirty much while looking good on the counter. I would highly recommend buying this grinder if you're serious about drinking a good cup of coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder works very well and is quiet
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is a replacement for a fairly expensive ($90+) Capresso burr grinder that I had for about three years that just up and quit working. This grinder works very well and is quieter. I usually measure my beans into the hopper as the timer doesn't really seem to have a good correlation with the amount of ground coffee you want. The unit has 3 controls a timer, a power switch, and a button to start the grinding. It seems the two on/off switches are a bit redundant.

I have nothing bad to say about this fabulous little coffee grinder, only good things. I've had cheapo grinders in the past and they pale in comparison to the Bodum Bistro. While technically this grinder is not advertised as having the ability to do a Turkish grind, I have found that putting it on the finest setting produces that almost powder-like consistency that delivers a walloping strong cup of coffee.

I have had no problems grinding with the darker/more oily beans either.

I love that I can grind only as much as I need by setting the timer, so every morning I have freshly ground beans.

Very clean and tidy, no mess -- no coffee grinds spilling everywhere. I literally have not had to wipe up the counter around this Bodum in the two weeks or so that I've been using it.

Super easy and efficient to use -- so long to the banged up community grinder at Costco! This Bodum is worth every penny, I highly recommend it!

To Everyone concerned about the 5 minute wait between grindings. It is absolute nonsense. You don't have to wait. I've had this grinder for over 4 years, using it at least twice daily, and nearly every time I grind 20 seconds then immediately grind several more seconds. It doesn't even get warm. Also, you can leave the switch on the side on at all times, it doesn't cause a problem, nor does it drain power, however if you don't have it plugged into a surge protector, it would be best to switch it off.

Amazon is amazing. It not only told when I bought this but allows a duplicate invoice to be printed. Brilliant!

When my grinder was 22 months old it quit. Bodum replaced it free of charge as they have a 2 yr. guarantee. Great!
Then, the 2nd one gave out the other day--again approximately two yrs. from receipt. I called to see if they could repair it, as I knew they wouldn't send me a new one again. They said they don't repair them! I was really angry but. in reading reviews of other grinders
I found quite a few complaints about quality. In mine a screw got loose and the motor was bouncing around. It was, of course, made in China, but they need to improve quality control. They were also not gracious about it. So I won't order a Bodum again. Companies don't realize how important Customer Service is!
Once I learned about burr grinders I had to have one. I researched them and decided the Bodum was worth the extra money over the Cuisinart. ($80 vs. $50). I knew I wasn't about to spend over $100 on one as that seemed just too persnickety! I got some money for Christmas and ordered the Bodum.

Others have reviewed this thoroughly, showing buthow much coffee lovers care about their coffee, so I'll just say a few things. First, it really does make a difference in the quality of my coffee and, as that was the most important thing to me, I am thrilled. I've had delicious coffee every morning. Of course I start with good beans.

There are a couple of drawbacks to the grinder, however. The fact you have to wait 5 minutes after the first 20 seconds has been well noted. For me that hasn't been a major problem. I use 4 heaping coffee measures to make 8 cups/4 mugs of coffee for myself and, on coarse grind, that takes about 16 seconds. If I put in a little more than 4 I have waited a few seconds and finished it up. If I were to do 8 or so I would plan ahead. It's not a great feature but you can live with it.

What has surprised me is that COURSE isn't very coarse. I guess that's OK as it still makes delicious coffee.

What has annoyed me is that I can't seem to use it without making a mess on my counter. There are several reasons: Coarse is really Medium and therefore the grounds cling to the glass receptacle, its cover, the opening where the ground coffee comes out, and the cover of the cone. I have been working every day to overcome this, with some success, but I still end up with grounds on my counter top. The grounds do cling to the glass receptacle, though I thought glass was preferred over plastic because it didn't do that, and I have to scrape them out or lose them. Also, be sure the glass is absolutely dry.

I notice one reviewer wrote that it didn't make a mess, which puzzles me, as when I looked up more expensive grinders one reviewer had the exact same experience I have.

I see that there is a soft brush made for the grinder. I am going to get one as I see fine grounds collecting on the burrs. I think that is a worthwhile investment--$5 or so.

So, in conclusion, I give it 4 rather than 5 stars simply because of the messiness. If really great coffee is important to you I suggest this grinder is well worth the bother.

I've used a number of blade grinders in the past, and they all had two thing in common--tons of mess, and uneven grinding. I'm currently using a french press for a couple months (drip machine packed for moving), and have used a french press for years, especially when the office coffee was standard issue terrible. Bar none, every blade grinder has defeated the press, with varying degrees of literally sludge at the bottom of the cup. Well, no more. The Bodum beauty burrs out a nearly perfect consistency grind. I set it for expresso, I get baby powder. I set it for press, I get press grade grinds. At the bottom of my cup I still do get a minor, and I mean MINOR, amount of "silt" but this is literally the last few sips. More importantly, those last few sips are NOT gritty like every other grinder I've used will do. So, you may see a swirl of powdered grind at your last 4 sips, but you won't taste or worse feel it. For french press users, your perfect cup is now only limited by the quality of your beans.

Operation: I have found it works best with a hopper full of beans. The timer and grind setting are most consistent then, as it feeds evenly. I know some people are worried about the 20 second every 5 minutes limits on the motor. Well, this isn't a commercial unit, it's under $100. Expectation management, people. For my morning 20 oz coffee, 7 seconds is plenty of time to produce 3 scoops of grind. 20 seconds should be fine for your average 10 cup pot, and if you are grinding expresso for 20 seconds, you are making a cup that will cause your heart to explode. Again, this is great for home use, not a restaurant.

Mess: The glass receiver and the soft rubber top keep it contained. I've gone through a lot of coffee getting my perfect cup down, and the counter top does not look like a disaster area. After the grind finishes and before I remove the glass receptacle, I usually tap the machine a couple time out of habit, but honestly haven't seen any noticeable grind settling. The other benefit of the glass receiver is when you dump it out, pretty much all the grind goes into your press or filter. No static electricity, no old coffee waiting for your next grind. Just on cleanup alone, this thing is awesome.

Noise: This guy is reasonably quiet. It is grinding beans, so it will be noisy, but unlike all blade grinders I've used, this is a lower frequency noise and you can carry on a conversation with it running. Overall it is the quietest grinder I've used.

Versatility: I've used this on several settings, and not just for coffee. I took the old trick of running some white rice through the burrs (after a thorough brush cleaning) to get all the coffee out, then used it to convert coarsely ground flax seed to finely ground flax seed. This took a while, as the course ground seed was already pretty fine, and flax tends to clump, so it fed slowly. But, once done, the fine flax seed was very well and evenly ground. I plan to use it on whole flax seed in the future, and expect it will feed much better.

Overall, loving this machine and looking for excuses to use it!

I bought this about a year and half ago, and use it every day. It works very well with only minimal scattering dust and produces an evenly fine grind for drip coffee.
To be more precise, I generally grind 48 grams of light roast (for 750 ml of water) at the fine setting, which takes a bit longer than the preset 20 second timer. So I just hit the timing button again. The warning about waiting 5 minutes between grinding sessions seems to me to be an exaggeration intended to keep some idiot from running the device continuously for several minutes to grind a big bag of beans (and that would likely fry any small motor).
I don’t do espresso, but the finest settings seem to be powdery enough. For an occasional French press pot, I use a coarse setting, which produces a mostly uniform grind with very little powder and has worked well even with dark, oily beans. At the very coarsest setting I once had a bean jam the device, though that was easily shaken loose.
To minimize dust left in the chute, I give the side of the device a hard slap before I take the receptacle out. That leaves about 0.1 grams of dust behind if you then brush out the chute. For information, a single coffee bean is about 0.1 to 0.2 grams.
The device is attractive and small enough to be left out on the counter, and most of the noise comes from grinding the beans. I like the presence of a separate power switch, so I do not feel the need to unplug the device between uses (and the chassis is not warm when off - it is not a secret power vampire.) The only downside to this device is the glass receptacle jar, which is likely not to survive a drop onto a hard, tiled kitchen floor.
Combined with my Technivorm Moccamaster KBTS, I get great coffee with this.

I use my coffee grinder(s) to grind spices for use in herbal teas and other products. The coarse grind has been perfect so far. The grinders are stainless steel, so will be very durable, however the casing is plastic, and thus probably won't hold up to repeated use. The directions are printed in 7 or 8 languages, but the English version is terrible. We basically figured out how to assemble and use on our own, by trial and error.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds evenly and by time rather than trying to guess # of Cups
reviews.reviewText:
I have been looking at a number of different Burr Grinders. I had been using a low priced one which I though was "doing the job", but in comparison this Bodum Bistro is much better.

This has metal grinding mechanism, a glass container to hold the ground coffee and has the ability to grind for an adjustable number of seconds. Grinding for a adjustable number of seconds is best since I load my coffee in an expresso machine and only grind enough for a single cup serving. This gives me a lot of flexibility to grind only the amount of coffee I need.

Interesting side effect of the grinding is that my Yorkie dog starts to bark when she hears the grinding. Must be some high pitch sound that I don't hear, but cute to see her reaction. She never did that before with my other grinders.

I have also compared this to my brother's Cuisinart CCM-16PC1 and this Bodum is much better. Its been well documented that the grinder makes a difference, and I definitely see the difference in consistency and fine granularity of the grinds with the Bodum Bistro Burr Coffee Grinder.

The product was delivered on time and as expected through Amazon Prime.

Bought unit in October 2013 to finally replace an awful grinder/brewer from Cuisinart. This grinder has consistently performed for three years no matter what setting it is adjusted to. The outlet from the burrs to the receptacle will begin to clog after a while because of coffee oils, so its worth cleaning out ever 6 months or so. The non-static glass receptacle has never really been free of clinging coffee, but I can live with that.

With the price drop since I first bought it on Amazon ($120, now $75) I might get a second as a backup-in-waiting.

I had this same grinder previously. Love that you can set it to grind for various times of grind (15 seconds, 20 seconds, etc.) and for various types of grind (coarse to extra fine). My previous grinder lasted about 5 years. We used it twice a day, every day and it performed beautifully. So when it no longer worked, of course I wanted an exact replacement. Yes, it is a bit on the pricey side, but it's awesome and doesn't take up much counter space.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for solo user, though I'd worry for high volume
reviews.reviewText:
I love this grinder for my purposes. I'm the only coffee drinker in the house. I use this grinder 3x a day, usually, some days 2, some 4, but generally 3x (breakfast, snack time, dinner). It grinds really nicely. It's EASY to switch to coarse (for press pot) and back to drip or to espresso. However you like.

I bought this to replace my pricey Baratza grinder, which broke after 2 years. That was really disappointing. I decided if these things are prone to kaput after a year or two, I'd buy CHEAPER. I found this one to be decently reviewed and cheaper than the Baratza Virtuoso. (I paid $82 in 2011.)

Well, 1.5 years later, this one is still working. Let's see if it makes it to a longer work-life than the Baratza. I mostly use the drip grind for my Technivorm, and the press pot one for my Frieling, rarely the espresso. I make about 6 cups (Technivorm measure, which is closer to 3 cups) of coffee 3x a day. Each time, I ground 3 scoops. I use those pellets to clean the burr grinder. No problems so far.

I have read here that if you grind a lot, the machine can be problematic. If you're like me, i.e. you make smaller pots a few times a day, I don't see any issues. If you have to grind a lot of beans at once, well, yeah, I understand it might overheat. Be aware of this.

I have had no issues. Am pleased. I took a star off for that grinding/heat issue, since that seems to be ridiculous for a 100+ buck grinder.

For solo drinkers or light drinking couples/households, this should work beautifully.

reviews.reviewTitle: We loved the consistent grinds and the less static grounds
reviews.reviewText:
We purchased ours in 2011 and it finally wore out about 8 months ago. We purchased a different brand grinder because we could pick it up the same day locally.
I am placing another order for the Bodum Bistro today.
We loved the consistent grinds and the less static grounds, especially if you let it sit awhile before you dumped into the filter.

I am concerned about the negative reviews. I'm hoping something didn't change in the manufacturing since we bought our last one.
I love this grinder but my first one only lasted me 18 months . I thought it may be a fluke so I ordered another. Today it broke again after about the same amount of time.

I thought I'd write this review after using the grinder for several months and also because we use it mostly for espresso grind. Bottom line up front (BLUF): this machine provides a great espresso grind for the various roasts we've used so far which include dark oily beans. After several trial and error attempts to find the right grind setting for our Gaggia Classic, I found that the setting fifth from the finest was just right, providing a good extraction (around 20 seconds), abundant crema, and leaving a dry puck. I was surprised initially that this grind setting wasn't closer to the finest setting, but I think that may be more a function of the type of espresso machine being used. I've found that a 15 second grind cycle at that setting produces enough ground beans for two double espresso shots that become the basis for cappuccinos for my wife and I. We both feel the coffee tastes better than what our previous blade grinder produced. There is no mess nor static problem with this grinder. The only time I had a mess was when I started a grind and realized I forgot to put the glass container in place (my bad). Also, the 20 second rule and 5 minute wait in between which others understandably find to be a problem are not a big inconvenience for us. By the time we're ready for a second cappuccino, more than five minutes have passed since grinding the first batch and I can grind another. When I want to grind beans for regular coffee, I grind the beans in two batches. I can easily kill the five minutes between batches by doing some chores like setting the breakfast table, feeding the kitty, getting the newspaper, or washing some dishes from the night before ;). Ideally, it would be better if the grinder had a more robust motor - maybe future models will have it. Some have noted that the plastic used in the power switch and grind button have a cheap appearance. True - but they still work, so far. All in all I consider it a good product.

reviews.reviewTitle: I have been using my happy RED Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder every day years now
reviews.reviewText: I have been using my happy RED Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder every day for years now, and it just keeps going, knock on wood! You can easily adjust the grind to whatever you prefer. It's a little noisy, but that's to be expected and you only run it for a few seconds when making your morning coffee. It's red plastic parts are tough and have remained bright and true to their color -- no fading or yellowing. Amazingly, I have managed not to break the carafe, knock on wood! I attribute that to careful use and washing combined with the fact that it's got a rubber grip on the outside. All in all, this a great product that you will use for years with no issues!

reviews.reviewTitle: First burr grinder and I'm very happy...
reviews.reviewText:
My first venture into a burr grinder and I'm very pleased. Sometimes you venture into something new and buy the lowest cost item just to dip your toe in the water and then you figure out what you really want, in this instance, a burr grinder. This is a sturdy, robust product that produces a uniform grind.

Oh, if you don't have a digital scale you should buy one. Get used to how many seconds it takes to grind the desired number of grams for your beans.

After the grind coffee remains in the chute so tilt it forward and give it a few taps on the side. You might want to turn off the unit before doing this because I have a bad habit of hitting the grind button again.

Whether or not you have to deal with static electricity making a mess of things when you dump the grind into your brew basket is highly dependant on the humidity level in your home. The glass container does not eliminate static. I hold the container in my hand for a moment before dumping. And I keep a little basting brush nearby to sweep out anything left behind.

I have been using the burr grinder for the past two weeks and it's great. I went from using a manual burr grinder to this electric one and I'm glad that I can grind my coffee in less that 20 seconds compared to 3 minutes by hand. I don't have a problem with how loud it is and I use it early in the morning while everyone sleeps and no one wakes up. It doesn't grind by cups but I usually weigh my coffee and then pour it and start grinding so I automatically put 20 seconds and stop it when there isn't any more beans. Overall great Grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: it's exactly what we needed to make good strong coffee in our new OXO coffee maker
reviews.reviewText: After researching coffee makers and coffee grinders until we were ready to switch to plain water at breakfast… we found the Bodum Burr Coffee Grinder. We've only had this a few weeks, but, it's exactly what we needed to make good strong coffee in our new OXO coffee maker. There's a definite difference in burr and blade; thanks to many other reviewers, I don't have to detail these. The Bodum is simple in design, easy to calibrate, and the glass container is infinitely easier to clean than the reservoir on the coffee makers w/self grinding capacity. Our preference is for dark roast, "bolder" flavor. We tinkered with the settings, and, came up with a setting of "15" - and the pointer is just past mid-way towards the French Press coarsest setting. The device is small, it's a bit noisy, but then grinders are noisy. We really hope that this stays functional; it's an excellent product thus far. I'll update in a few months.

reviews.reviewTitle: Could be too early to tell, but so far it's decent
reviews.reviewText:
Have had this for a couple months, so my experience may not be as deep as others, but up to this point, I can't complain too much about it.
Hopper holds enough beans for say a week. Which is good because it's not exactly air tight (though still a good seal), so the beans don't dry out too quick.
Jar is a decent size, but does feel like it may be a tinge fragile. Time will tell.
You can dial in the grind size pretty well and it's a consistent grind.
Downside - Dialing in the grind time for the right amount without wasting. This is pretty much an art, based on grind size and time. You could just fill the hopper with the amount of beans you want each time, but you still have to work the timer so it doesn't spin the gears forever on an empty hopper if you happen to turn away from it. And if you say do drip most days and then french press on others, the timing will be off because a coarser grind will come out quicker.
I like it overall, but if your patience is thin, you may want to chose another.

I really like this grinder. It's very consistent, quiet (for the job that it does). However, I think it has four downfalls.

1. The power stays on. If you finish grinding your beans and leave the device on, it remains on all day and gets rather warm. That means it's a huge energy suck. With the switch being on the side and hidden away (at least where I have located the grinder), unless you are actively thinking about turning it off, it will remain on.

2. The grounds do not always perfectly enter the glass jar. This makes for a small mess after each use. Again, it's small, but annoying.

3. The bowl (where the whole beans are stored) will spin loose if it's on the coarsest grind. Any other setting, it's just fine.

4. I keep my grinder under the cabinet. It would be easier if I could refill the bowl by taking it off. However, there is no bottom to the bowl. I made the mistake one time and the beans flew all over the kitchen.

I bought this grinder for my husband based on the great reviews. Wow...it is the greatest. He usually takes forever grinding up a couple of large containers of coffee and makes a big mess. He only uses Starbucks French Roast whole beans that we get in bulk at Costcos. It is very time consuming and messy to do. But, unbeknownst to us you just put the beans in the top of this clean machine and quiet machine and figure out the grind and the time needed for your perfect pot of coffee and what a breeze. He sets it on medium and first pushes 20 seconds and then ten seconds and the container holds the exact amount he needs for his pot of coffee. We have a 12 cup coffee maker. Makes it a lot easier for me too since I am always second guessing what is the right amount of coffee and I do not miss grinding all that coffee and filling up those containers either. The hardest part of this job is just filling the top carafe with the whole beans. So now, every pot is a freshly ground pot and is so much easier. We just thought we were buying a coffee grinder and would still be filling up containers, what a great surprise! We love it. We've been using Bodum glass coffee cups for years and thought this would be a great product since their glassware is and were definitely not disappointed.

I purchased this because I received a Gaggia Espresso Pure machine for Christmas. I didn't want to pay $90, let alone $250 for a grinder, but after reading reviews on my espresso machine saying it was rather picky on its grind I decided I had to step up a little. I read a few reviews here saying the espresso grind works for them, and I am here to say the same.

I have used this grinder everyday since I received it (12/28/11), and I have had no issues. The espresso grind is very fine, and always uniform. I found that it takes about 10 seconds on espresso grind to produce enough for a double shot with just enough excess to distribute the grounds evenly. Brewing espresso with this grind gives me a nice crema, and getting better as I get used to my espresso machine.

I used the french press grind once, just to see the difference in texture. It too was uniform, but I didn't brew as I don't have a French Press (yet). 10 seconds on the French Press grind ground about twice as much coffee as the espresso setting would for the same time.

A note on the motor, it does only run for 20 seconds at a time. This doesn't mean it's not possible to run for longer.

I will update soon.

2/27/2013: My grinder is still grinding strong, no problems. It's done many grinds of different coarseness.

I never owned a grinder before, but having spent countless hours of on-line time researching different grinders and reading about all the problems people have, I decided to purchase this one. After owning and using it for 3 months, I'm happy to say i made an excellent purchase decision.

This grinder is quiet compared to others i've heard, the grinds are perfectly consistent, the beans flow through smoothly, and there are no static problems at all with the glass cup.

I mainly use flavoured coffee beans which i've heard tend to clog grinders quickly but in 3 months i've never had a problem, never had it clog up with grounds, and i've never had to take it apart and clean it (although i do tap the side a few times before removing the grounds)

My only concern before purchasing this grinder was the fact that they state to let it cool down after 20 seconds of use so as not to overheat it. This made me concerned about its power and durability, but thankfully this turned out to not be an issue. When it's grinding, the motor runs easily and smoothly and has more than enough power. Personally I would not hesitate to run it longer than 20 seconds when necessary.

I generally make 4 cups of coffee in a french press and i find a 13-15 second grind is the perfect amount.
I would happily recommend this product to friends and family.

I bought one a few years, and still use it at home. I reently bought another for making fresh ground coffee where I attend church, and it is much faster. With my older Bodum, it take about 45 seconds to grind enough for a full pot (drip coffee setting), while the new one does the same in less than 30 seconds. Seems like a small difference, but the maximum time setting is 30 seconds, which means the old grinder requires two grind cycles where the new one can do it in one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Products focused on aesthetics instead of quality, terrible customer service
reviews.reviewText:
I own two of these coffee grinders. The one I purchased more recently has completely stopped working. I believe the motor went bad. I would not recommend anyone to buy one of these grinders. While it does look nice, it's not made well, and the customer support is horrible. I will not buy any Bodum products in the future.

Pros:
- It looks nice
- It grinds coffee evenly when it works

Cons:
- The grind time knob is loose and doesn't always stay put
- The grind is adjusted by unscrewing the hopper, coarser grinds leave the hopper loose and it rattles
- It's extremely noisy
- One of the two I own stopped working in less than a year
- Bodum customer service didn't respond to my email request after I sent them my receipt
- Bodum customer service stated they do not warranty any products not sold by Amazon directly (I bought mine from an Amazon seller)

I scouted heavily for grinders before deciding on the Bodum Bistro. After 2+ months of using it, I have the following reactions:

Pros:

1. It's compact. I leave it on my kitchen counter all the time.

2. Consistent grind.

3. Easy to operate, though you'll want to experiment to get the grind that's right for you. It took me a week before I nailed it.

4. Cool color, wrapped in non-slip rubberized finish.

5. Not excessively loud. It's a grinder, so some noise is necessary.

Cons:

1. The timer. 20 seconds, max., is a disappointment. I grind 1.3 ounces of coffee beans daily, and the timer barely gives me enough grind time to get the job done. I nearly returned the unit because of this. Why make a product with such a sensitive motor?

2. Kind of messy. There's no way around it--extra grounds end up around the base of the grinder and on the counter. It's a simple wipe-down, but it needs to be done daily.

3. No click for incremental adjustments. This could be just my grinder, but the adjustment selector just slides from one mark to the next. No click.

4. No lighted power switch. It's easy to leave the unit in the On position.

5. No grind-release lever. This means the unit always has extra grounds in it. Move the grinder, or just clonk it by mistake, and spare grounds sprinkle out. A release lever would get most of the extra coffee out of the unit.

6. I know this is subjective, but I'd expected to get a fresh-ground-coffee aroma. With the Bodum, I get fresh-ground coffee, but no smell to go with it.

In all, three stars (though 2.5 is closer to my best rating). The grinder does perform, but Bodum seems to have cut some corners. If I had it to do over again, I'd have spent more $ for a more solid unit overall.

The Bodum is a terrific grinder. Very consistent grind, easy to adjust. The thing I like best is that because of the borosilicate glass grounds collector, coffee grounds don't spew all over the counter when I remove the container. I let it sit for a minute while the water heats to the right temperature, and by that time, the static electricity created by the grinding action has dissipated. Just tap the container on a hot pad or cork trivet and the grounds fall to the bottom of the container, then dump into the filter. The coffee grinder is also compact, and just plain attractive.

We purchased this coffee grinder after doing a lot of research. This coffee grinder was highly recommended so we purchased it. We never used and returned it within a couple days of receiving it. When we took it out of the box it was pretty small and had a very small hopper, much small than our current coffee grinder. We were looking for a durable coffee grinder with a bigger hopper.

I've owned this grinder over a year and still like it. Prior to this purchase, the grinder I used got grounds everywhere when I turned it on. The Bodum Bistro container for the ground coffee fits tightly against the hopper so that there is no cleanup after grinding. And the container is glass which was critical to me since I avoid plastic as much as I can especially for food items. When grinding, one can select from many levels. Since I use a french press, I've selected coarse grind. I make one 20 oz cup coffee each morning. The grind selector runs by seconds and 5 seconds makes one morning's worth of coffee for me. The grinder will run for 20 seconds. I don't know how much coffee 20 seconds worth of ground coffee will make but if one needs more than 20 seconds ground coffee, then one can wait 5 minutes and grind more coffee. The only regret I have is that the hopper is plastic and I really, really wish it were glass. However, the grinder is attractive and has a small foot print so since the coffee isn't ground yet, I gave in on that one point. This grinder is also easy to keep clean, important since mine is on the kitchen counter. Overall, I highly recommend this grinder.

The BODUM burr grinder makes perfect size grind without dust or static. How nice it is to be able to pour ground coffee directly into the coffee pot without with it all going into the pot and not all over the counter. Each grind is the same with the same quality and quantity without having to measure each time.
Unit is also the quietest that I have ever used or seen. Cleans like a dream. I have ground beans with heavy oil without any buildup or mess. People who have trouble with this unit must be trying to use wet beans or coffee beans with frost on them directly from the freezer. Cleaning the unit is a breeze and the plastic rubber surface is easy to hold without slipping.
The only thing you must watch for and is is stated in the manual is that cannot adjust grind size (from coarse to finer) with the unit off. If you do, you may cause the beans to jamb so that the grinder won't turn and possibly burn out the motor. If you follow that rule, your unit will last for years.
I am using less coffee because of the grinder and the quality of the coffee taste is better than I had with the common chopper and flat disc grinders.
Very very happy with this unit.

Works well, coffee tastes great!

We've had this machine for 3 months and there's one tiny annoying thing: I'm not sure why there's an On/Off switch- I leave it on and the little light bugs my husband, and he turns it off so it never goes when I press the button. It makes us both grumble a little, but that's it. Also getting used to putting the little cap on after each use took a bit of getting used to. It makes a bigger mess if you don't use it.

We had a Baratza Encore before, and don't notice any difference in the taste of the grind, and this one is much quieter and faster. It died after 2 years, so we're hoping this one will last longer- we drink a lot of coffee, so have high demands!

Provides consistent grinds. Works great with my Espresso machine. Warning: mechanism will get clogged to the point where the safety clutch in the motor engages. This happened to me with a bag of Starbucks Italian Roast. The roast was super oily and moist. On the espresso setting, the whole path became plugged. This is easily solved buy taking the hopper off and firmly banging on the body of the grinder to shake things loose. Not a big issue but I thought the grinder had failed at first until I investigated and figured out how to clear the path.

Update: Grinder gets clogged daily. I have to whack the unit really hard to get it clear. It is good for 2-3 cups of espresso and then I have to clear it all again the next day. At this point, I have dropped the rating to two stars and would not recommend it to customers that grind espresso regularly. VERY frustrating product. Looking for a replacement now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love the grinder, but NOT white in color.
reviews.reviewText: I love this grinder. I don't have any experience with other burr grinders, but this one certainly seems top notch. Very little static and the grind is perfect for my espresso machine. I do not need to set this on the finest grinding to get the perfect espresso grind either. My only complaint is the color. I ordered white and this is clearly not white. It's more of an almond color or off white. I already broke the glass container that catches grinds and when I went to Bodum's website to order a replacement, the color is listed as "off-white" for this model. Amazon should clarify this in their description.

My first burr grinder. The 20-second limitation of the motor to prevent overheating doesn't bother me as I only grind one or two cups at a time.

Pluses
1) Small foot print - takes up little space in kitchen
2) The grind seems fairly consistent with the setting.
3) Nice looking and available in black - the rubbery covering in any other color might be hard to keep clean.
4) Not that costly for a burr grinder - when in stock for the Prime price and 2-day delivery.

Minuses
1) Retains a fair amount of grinds from previous use. To remedy this, I slap both sides after grinding to get the trapped grinds to fall. Hopefully this won't cause an issue over time.
2) Says to use a brush to clean but Bodum should have included one.

Update: April 5, 2014.
Still working fine but downgraded review from 4 stars to 3 based on the amount of grinds that are retained and the time it takes to clean it.

As my first foray into automatic burr grinders and after reading a ton of Amazon reviews, I decided to get this due to the fact that most of my other kitchen appliances are red.

The glass cup is advertised to reduce static, but this is not the case. Something about the burr grind process generates tons of static charge and the finer your grind, the more it sticks to everything. Pulling the cup out generates a cloud of statically charged coffee that goes everywhere. I have to place the machine on top of a cookie sheet with a lip to contain the mess.

The ~20 second timer is a pain. Due to the mess it generates, I only use it once a month or so and tend to grind a large amount of coffee at a time, which takes forever.

I think this is a problem with most burr grinders, but cleaning is a pain due to the shape of the chute that leads the grounds to the cup. You have to take it all apart, shake it and tap it all around, stick toothpicks down to scrape out the compressed grounds... It's quite a process.

Also very noisy; sounds like a loud electric motor inside of a plastic box, which is exactly what it is. Don't expect to operate this while others in the house are sleeping...

I also have a hand-operated Hario ceramic grinder, but it takes forever to grind and I don't always have that kind of time daily. Cleanup is much easier and static-generation is almost non-existent.

I bought another machine for my office and intentionally looked for one that could be run for a longer period without overheating. Even though it has the same static issues as this one, it feels much better built and indeed runs for 4-5 grind sessions without heating up noticeably: Capresso 565 Infinity Conical Burr Grinder, Stainless Steel

reviews.reviewerName: The smiley face on Amazon means A to Z -- CRAZY!
reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent in everything; up to certain espresso machines
reviews.reviewText:
First off, if you're still using a slicer-style grinder do yourself a favor and get a burr grinder. If you enjoy your cup not just for the benefits of caffeine, but also for taste, then it's time to step it up. This particular Bodum is d*mn good for the money if you're grinding up to 4 people max. If you have something beyond an entry-level espresso machine, then you should probably look at the solid $200 smart model.

It gets it down to a size that's good for pressurized filters all the way to french press thickness. The 20 second limit, well if you're into guidelines then yes, take it as a factor. You'll get enough grind for 2-3 people. However, that doesn't mean you can't run it back to back. Let alone letting it cool for just a minute in between if you want to stick close to said guidelines. For the money, can't be beat. If you're making espresso from a machine beyond entry level, look at the $200+ models.

As far as the oily-bean issue in the finest setting, well I couldn't tell you because I don't use oily beans in the espresso machine. But for filter/drip/presses which doesn't require fine grinding, this shouldn't be an issue.

I am on my 5th electric coffee grinder. This product is easy to use. The grind settings allow the user to easily change the grind on the beans. The unit is quieter than several others. The unit has two power switches that I assume are required down under. Cleaning has been easy. i learned a hard lesson never to wash the burr. Don't repeat my mistake.

The quality burr and a perfect ground is all I need in this machine! Bought the black version on 2011-07-19 for $82 new and have been using it everyday. The burr and gears of my copy are still going strong as of 2018-01-31, however the timed trigger died completely last summer so I DIY'd to bypass the PCB and use the main big switch on the side to control it. Besides, the black paint became sticky about 3 years ago, so I also sanded it off and recoated it myself. I thought of replacing it and had tried other blade type grinders but they only produced inconsistent ground, so returned all them and I kept coming back to this workhorse! I accidentally broke the ground holder glasses years ago, however it's easy to find a replacement metal tin (I use the TableCraft 10oz stainless steel dredge) that can still fit the original plastic lid tightly. The grinder is easy to clean (in fact nothing to clean if you can live with some residue but it never accumulates), easy to dump out the ground, minimal static, and it never shoots out coffee ground during its work. Avoid water humidity in the surroundings or in your beans otherwise the finest grind setting could clog it only sometimes. It could be loud (consistent sound and not sputtering or clunking like other grinders) and it's a good way to wake everyone up in the morning! Highly recommended.

Didn't realize that I've now had this grinder for a year. It has officially lasted twice as long as its two predecessors. It gets used multiple times a day... I drink a lot of coffee... and is still performing as if it just came out of the box. I thought the plastic cone (the hopper) felt a bit flimsy at first but after several drops from wet hands to floor, I can say that it is not flimsy at all.

Two problems: it's loud as hell. Plus, the manual insists that you empty the hopper to change the grind setting - really? I do it because I want this thing to last but, come on Bodum.

This grinds coffee really well - BUT! The ground coffee doesn't all end up in the hopper. Coffee grounds leak out of the housing of the unit or build up in the passage and fall out when you remove the glass container. This machine sheds coffee constantly! Every couple months I shake the unit and end up with a good dose of grounds all over the counter. I'd give a full 5 Stars for the grind quality of the coffee that makes it to the press, but the rest is pure waste and a PITA to clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: looks cool, and may grind just fine (I'm a coffee ...
reviews.reviewText:
Fairly quiet (for a grinder), looks cool, and may grind just fine (I'm a coffee n00b, what do I know?). However, two big issues that I've discovered after using it on and off for a year:

There's no good way to get unground beans out from the hopper. If you try to take the hopper off, any remaining beans will spill out over the counter. I'm currently picking up the entire unit and pouring the beans back into the original container. This is tricky because the hopper doesn't securely attach and thus you need to hold both the hopper and unit.

There's a lot of grounds left inside the unit, which do not fall into the container. If you move or knock the unit, a lot of grounds fall out. This creates a mess, but also probably means the next time you grind, you'll get old grounds.

It's my first grinder, and seems to do a good job actually grinding beans, but I wouldn't recommend it.

I already have one of these & bought this one for my brother. The box arrived already opened which is not what I paid for, and it had some grinding residue in it . I expected NEW! It did not originally work but after my brother worked with it a bit, we got it going. It’s louder than the one I have at home, but does a good job grinding the coffee.
I think it’s very poor form on the sellers part to resell their returns as new.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best coffee grinder I almost never hear
reviews.reviewText: This grinder way past exceeds my expectations!! It's far and away the quietest coffee grinder I've ever heard let alone owned. No mess to clean up after grinding. Virtually no static cling. Really like that part! I plan to make sure that everyone that I know knows to BUY THIS COFFEE GRINDER! It's a conical burr grinder, which gives a cooler grind, resulting in a better tasting cup of coffee! And the price couldn't be better! Don't wait lIke I did. Buy yours now so you can enjoy a great tasting cup of coffee, now! I am a very satisfied customer.

This is expensive if the product only lasts 4 months. Customer service is nonexistent. I don't recommend this to anyone since the grinder literally won't turn on after 4 months, and there is no customer service to help. Spend your money on a better brand with better quality elsewhere that'll last longer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Improved my French Press Coffee Experience!
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using a cheap "blender" style coffee grinder for over 10 years to make my morning french pressed coffee brew. There was a brief period I did get a burr grinder, but one day about three months in, it died. It did so grinding up bits of little internal plastic gears along with my coffee and spitting them out. So back to the cheap but reliable "blender" coffee grinders it was for the next five years.

Finally I decided the coffee I was getting just wasn't consistent enough, and what I drank every morning had some element of a surprise. I don't like surprises in the morning when I'm in a rush to get to work.

This burr grinder is bigger and weighs about 5 times as much as my last burr grinder did, and feels very solidly constructed. Using it, you can set the coarseness and length of time of grind (which determines how much coffee is ground) and just push a button. Next time you want to grind, all the dials are still in the same physical location without having moved and you just push that same button again for the exact same consistent experience as the last time!

One thing that I was originally worried about was storing large amounts of roasted coffee stored in the top dispenser. Air exposure can affect the taste off coffee. But the lid creates an air-tight seal with the container. Air exposure would come from whatever air is already in the container when it's sealed, possibly with minor seepage, or possibly a bit might come up through the grinding path. But I so far have haven't been filling the container to the top and been going through the coffee before any possible air exposure/oxidation becomes a problem.

Also, my French Pressed coffee is much, much smoother now with 1/10th the sediment produced from the "blender" style grinder. This burr grinder just simply makes more evenly shaped grinds, and less "coffee dust" that ends up as the sediment at the bottom of your cup! I am now drinking much smoother and tastier french pressed coffee!

reviews.reviewTitle: This is Our third Bodum Grinder of this type. ...
reviews.reviewText: This is Our third Bodum Grinder of this type. However, We noticed it wasn't working immediately after starting to use it last month. No matter what the setting it ground the beans very coarse. It also ground too many beans within the timer setting waisting much coffee. The rating is as much for the fact that We can not return it or replace it than the malfunction of the product.

Wow, I didn't expect a coffee grinder to make such an impact. Now granted, I did expect a difference from my blade grinder...otherwise I would not have spent $119 to experience a conical burr grinder.
What I did not expect is that before the grinder arrived my coffee maker was tasting a "bit tired", like it needed the vinegar flush that I periodically do to freshen things up. Well I didn't get around to it...the grinder arrived, and of course I needed to check it out!
Not only does this grinder perform as others have stated, ie: consistent, uniform grind, fairly quiet (you are grinding coffee folks). But it completely (and surprisingly) altered the taste of my coffee!! Same beans, same maker, same process, different flavor!! So smooth and tasty it is ridiculous!
I really did not think a grinder could have such a dramatic impact on the taste. Now granted, I suppose "any" burr grinder may have me singing a similar tune...so on to the specifics of this machine.
The glass catch is very nice. I have experienced the plastic catch at a friends house which due to static cling had a "permanent" coating of coffee grounds inside. The glass catch simply needs a tap to clear. The plastic top seems to have a bit of the cling aspect to it, but it is easily dealt with.
The top loading area only holds about a third of a pound of coffee, but I was not looking to store coffee, only grind it. So it is nice to not have to load beans every time I want to brew.
The burr mechanism is "burly". Steel, solid, very nice. The upper part has a plastic outer piece that drops into place, like a collar. But the parts that are touching the beans are all metal.
I kind of wish it had a cup setting as some other grinders have. Where you just dial in the number of cups you want and it automatically delivers the proper amount of coffee. The timer took a couple of uses to dial in...but at drip grind setting, middle of the dial I get a solid 8 cup brew from the 20 sec time. The 15 second time gives me a 4-5 cup brew, and in between for my normal 6 cup brew. I like to be able to just grind and dump. I don't want to have to measure each time. So you just need to grind and measure the one time to check the settings. Then it's grind a dump...so long as you are not changing the grind type ( I would assume this would change the amount delivered, haven't tried that yet?)
I just got the grinder, I was so impressed I had to write a review. I will check back and add to this review if I experience any negative aspects, or to continue to sing praise, depending on my experience.
As of now, I will say I highly recommend this grinder!! It is fantastic! If you are on the fence, get off and buy it, it is great!!

reviews.reviewTitle: It just works, but not too loud - owened about 3 months
reviews.reviewText:
Update - Have had this for over a year now, still works great.

Original review below -

I just want to make coffee. Nothing fancy. I have tried ground coffee in the past, but the grinders that I had tried were so obnoxiously loud (too loud for before I have my morning coffee) and would wake the whole house. While this grinder is not whisper quiet, it is not obnoxious about it. Just a light grinding sound.

The glass cup is great. You do experience a bit of static each time, and it does build up over time. But it is nothing like the all plastic cups.

It does have a limit of how often you are supposed to run it in a 5 minute period, but I only make one pot at a time so this has never been an issue.

I keep the grinding level set at the same place, set the time of the grind that I want, turn on the power switch, then hit the little red button next to the timer. Grind runs (about 13s for my setting) and then turn the power switch off. Good to go.

I don't sweat a bit of coffee left in the glass grinding cup. It builds up over time. About once a week I rinse it out and lay it upside down on a paper towel. Do keep the paper towel close. It is quiet annoying to (while a bit fuzzy headed prior to that first cup of coffee) grind 13s of coffee, only to look down and see you didn't put the cup in place. ;)

Enjoy

I previously had a blade grinder and used it to make coffee with french press and it was terrible. The grind produced a significantly large variance of fine and coarse grinds. Resulted in bad coffee.

Since then, I'd been going to the store and grinding my beans once every 2 weeks. Grind was always consisent, but after a week or so the coffee didn't have the amazing flavor it did the day of the grind.

Saved up some money and bought this. Today was the first cup I made with it and it is great. Grind is fairly consistent. Variance between coarse and fine grinds COULD be better, but I wouldn't want to shell out the extra $100s for it.

Was concerned when I first saw a review of this grinder for a french press. However, this machine worked out very well for my french press. Yes, the coarse grind from this grinder compared to the one I got from the grocery was a bit finer, but it wasn't so fine that it gave me a lot of sludge at the bottom of my cup.

Will keep updating throughout the life-cycle of this device.

I love this grinder. It is value priced and does a fantastic job. I do not have any fly away issues with the grinds. I dip a fork in water and add some to the beans before grinding and it does the job. It is relatively quiet, has a stable base, and I really like the automatic timer. I set things up the night before and just turn it on in the morning and in 15 seconds it produces a perfect grind for a pour-over. I don't have an espresso machine so haven't tried to grind really fine but anticipate it will do the job.

I waited a long time to buy a coffee grinder because reviews indicated that most models were seriously flawed. The most frequent complaints were that flimsy plastic parts broke, that coffee got stuck in the chute, or that the grinder made a mess due to static electricity in the grinds receptacle. Professional models were ridiculously expensive for home use. I just wanted a competent grinder to grind beans for a coffee maker or a French press. The Bodum does the job nicely. Its quiet, produces very consistent grinds, has a glass receptacle that is free of static, and doesn't make a big mess. The metal conical burr grinding mechanism seems to be of good quality, and grinds don't get impacted in the chute. This design is also attractive and small enough to leave out on the counter full time. The only limitation is that the timer only goes to 20 seconds per grind cycle, but multiple cycles are easy enough, and two cycles of 20 seconds will fill the receptacle near the top. My wife wasn't thrilled with the idea of getting another coffee grinder, remembering the mess from ones in the distant past, but she likes this one. For the price the Bodum is a great product and is highly recommended.

I'd been using the same blade grinder for years and had never really been happy with the results. Coffee was always inconsistent and unless the planets were aligned, usually tasted like bleh. So I got used to going to Starbucks every morning for my brew.

I finally decided to take the plunge on a burr grinder, and after reading the reviews and narrowing it down to a couple of units, I chose the Bodum burr grinder. And talk about a jump in performance, going from a $20 blade grinder to the Bodum grinder is like going from a Ford Festiva to a BMW.

Here's what I like:
- The convenience of the sealed container on top for the beans. I can dump most of a 1 pound bag of beans in there and not have to scoop them into the grinder every time I want to brew coffee like I did with the blade grinder.
-There's no real mess. With the blade grinder, it was impossible to put beans in the container, grind, take off the lid, dump grinds into a container, then repeat 4 or 5 times, without spilling grinds everywhere. With the Bodum burr grinder, there is hardly any mess. I might notice some after a week of use, but it's pretty small. The beans are in a sealed container, and whenever I want to brew coffee, I just push the button and coffee grinds right into the glass container. The container lid effectively holds the grinds until I'm ready to pour them into the coffee pot.
- It's simple. You've got 2 adjustments you can make: the grind size and the timer. Once you get a few pots brewed you'll figure out pretty quickly what settings work for you. And the settings are mechanical (not electrical) so even if you unplug the machine, the settings will remain where they are so you dont have to change them. Ever. (unless you want to)
- And most importantly: Taste. So I didnt think a burr grinder would make THAT big a difference in the way coffee tasted, which is why I put off getting one for so long. But man, it makes a world of difference. Coffee just tastes much noticeably better. There's no real other way of saying it. I can even downgrade to cheaper beans now because they taste good too.

The one negative that you'll read about in a lot of people's comments is the 5 minute wait time the instructions tell you to give before grinding a 2nd helping of beans. With only a 20 second grinding timer, I can see why this would upset people. 20 seconds, in my opinion, is not long enough to grind enough beans to brew a full pot of strong coffee. And nobody wants to grind for 20 seconds, wait 5 minutes, then grind again. That totally destroys the convenience of the product. However, this is not a problem for me, as I am the only coffee drinker in the household. I have yet to need to go anywhere near the 20 second time limit, so this is not an issue for me.

There are several reviews that offer advice on dealing with this issue though, my favorite being "just brew a half pot at a time." It's still not perfectly convenient, but if I need a full pot, that's what I'll do. That said, if you constantly brew full pots of coffee, then this grinder might not be for you.

So that's it. If you can deal with the 5 minute wait in between grinds, then this grinder is for you. I have nothing bad to say about it at all.

Two caveats:
(1) I don't own an espresso machine, so I can't comment on the espresso grinding ability of the grinder (I only grind for brewed coffee). From most reviews though, it seems to do espresso grind pretty good.
(2)The only other grinder I've ever owned was that $20 blade grinder, so I have nothing else to compare the Bodum to. Keep that in mind. While I might consider this a $50,000 BMW, I'm sure other reviewers on here have owned the 6-figure "lamborghinis", "bugattis", and "Bentleys" of the bean grinder world. It's all relative.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent value for the devoted coffee lovers
reviews.reviewText:
I used to buy beans by the pound, have them grounded at the store and just brew it later. I drank it with cream and sugar, and usually I can't tell the difference between a good cup versus a bad one. But when I finally started getting into coffee drinking: taking it black, savoring all the flavor differences between different roasters and bean origins, I knew I need to beef up my coffee supply and equipment to match my new-found hobby. So I set out to get a burr coffee grinder after being recommended by EVERY coffee tutorial. The problem is, I don't want to pay the price tag the pros pay, and yet I still want a decent quality grinder.

My requirements:
- Electric grinder. As much as the non-powered ones are great quality and all that, it's just not very practical to ask someone who's barely awake and under a time crunch to do all that work early in the morning
- sturdy built, will therefore last a while (a long while...)
- small in size, since I don't have that much counter space nor do I need a lot of coffee storage space
- can be easily taken apart for cleaning
- decently priced (looking at half of the price tag of a high-end model)

Bodum definitely fits most of the criteria. After reading a lot of the reviews, I placed my order. And now, more than 9 months later, I'm happy to report that I'm very pleased with my purchase.

A few comments regarding some of the common complaints people have:
- the timer setting on the grinder: if you're a serious coffee drinker (read: coffee snob), then this should not be much of a problem, because you'd be grinding beans fresh for every cup instead of brewing up a big pot (or grinding beans ahead of time for storage)

- small bean storage chamber: again, if you tend to buy the 12oz single origin roasters type of beans, you would not be storing it in that chamber anyways (you'll want to store them in a air-tight container) and let the beans go rancid that way. So all you'll be doing is putting a few scoops in right when you're about to grind. The chamber space is really not an issue in this case, as a result

- Cleaning of the grinder: the burr grinder can be taken apart easily to a certain extent, but not all the way. So you'll need to buy separate cleaning pallets to remove the coffee grind residues. If there's anything I'd like to see improvement on, this would be my request.

All in all, the grinder is sturdy, does its job, grinds very well, and I've been enjoying excellent coffee every morning. And the fact I didn't break my bank doing so, it's totally a good buy.

What sold me on this product is the glass container which collects the ground coffee. Other companies use plastic and the ground coffee becomes magnetized during the grinding process and is difficult to remove. Bodum solved the problem by using glass. After the coffee is ground I invert the container over a coffee filter and lightly tap the bottom and presto all the coffee lands in the filter. The design is also very European and fits right in with a modern kitchen.

reviews.reviewTitle: Well-made. High quality and consistent grind
reviews.reviewText:
Well-made, high-quality and consistent grind, which is selectable from coarse to very fine, the latter for espresso.
It takes a couple of runs to set the red timer switch on top to get it to grind just the right amount for your use.
As many/most know, espresso coffee makers require (for best results) that the coffee grounds section be filled, but not over. or under-filled. 16 seconds (the dial stays put unless you change it) is perfect for my brewer.
And, indeed, even finely ground beans don't stick to the glass jar.

I bought this grinder about a month ago, and I really like the design and ease of use. It's not too messy, since the ground coffee ends up in a glass beaker that you can remove and replace. The receptacle for the unground beans is fairly airtight, and the grinder is easy to adjust. I liked it so much that I bought a second one as a gift for a family member. Of course, I now need to use it for a few more months to see how it holds up.
Update 2 years later: The grinder is still working as well as it did when it was new.
Update 2.5 years later: the drive gear inside is broken. I really thought it would last longer. I only use it for 10 seconds per day.
Worked fine for 2.5 months. Now, won't grind. Avoid.

reviews.reviewTitle: Garbage - 15 months of once a day use was total lifespan
reviews.reviewText: Purchased on November 17th, 2017 and today, 2/18/2019 it died. It was used to grind once for 10 seconds a day on average 6 days a week, about 360 times. The internal gearing is plastic and the grinder is metal-- which do you think will win when a tough bean gets jammed in there too fast and jams up the grinder? I'm not sure if the 7 year old who engineered this will get fired or not, but they should be.

Had to change the burr assembly after a couple years. Sadly, the burr is held by a plastic fitment that breaks in time. Some time later and it has now completely failed. The start button won't work anymore and we will have to throw it away and spend at least another 100 dollars. A coffee grinder like this could be built to last a lifetime, but then they wouldn't get repeat sales. A sad fact in the modern world.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use grinder, not super consistent
reviews.reviewText: This is a decent grinder which I use with my Flair espresso maker. Overall it does well, but the timing of how long to run it to get the same amount of coffee varies. Also, if you are looking to really dial in your exact grind, this is not the machine for you as the coarseness setting is somewhat approximate rather then a set click.

reviews.reviewTitle: I should preface this review by saying that I have ...
reviews.reviewText: I should preface this review by saying that I have worked in the coffee industry for over 15 years, so I am very familiar with what certain settings produce which results. I use my grinder to grind for pour over coffee mostly, and the grind is dead on. I have used it to grind for French press, and I find that the grind is a bit off; much too course. For me, this is unimportant since I rarely use it and I know how to adjust it, but for the customer that prefers a French press, I might pass on this one.

This grinder was great until it died 3 months after purchase. Kaput. Nothing. Tried cleaning it. Tried everything. No warning. Dead.
So it's back to my trusty 7 year old blade grinder.
Customer service was absolutely no help. I really wish I had read the one-star reviews first, then I would have known. Will never buy another Bodum product.

It is good for us. design is really simple but has a modern style for minimalism. Working good with very verious grade for grinding a coffee bean. It makes a wide band of powder of coffee bean from espreso to just drip. Meaning that it has a ability to grind a coffe bean like a dust to peaces. Most of all, its delivery was really fast. I ordered last night and took it today noon. what a great dwell time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect espresso grind for a fraction of the price
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this grinder back in January and I am so happy that I did. Most of the reviews said that this grinder was not good for espresso grinds. Fortunately, I ignored the reviews. The Bodum Bistro Electric Burr coffee grinder is perfect for espresso grinds. Moreover, I read complaint after complaint about it not being able to handle oily beans. This is Absolutely false! I use very oily french roast beans and it has no problem grinding enough for at least 2 or 3 pulls in the 20 second limit. By the time I'm done making my latte (my preference) 5 minutes have passed and I can grind more beans as necessary. People complaining about having to wait 5 minutes need to wake up and smell the coffee! This grinder is over $100 cheaper than the cheapest "better burr grinders". At that price difference, I can wait a few extra minutes. I purchased my grinder on sale at Amazon for $74.50. I did have to spend several weeks checking amazon to get that price, but it was worth the wait to save money. People experiencing problems with not getting enough ground beans for a pull need to READ THE INSTRUCTIONS. It tells you how to calibrate the grinder for first use as well as re-calibrating when you change settings. If you don't follow the directions you will have trouble. Also, Eventually, the grinding gear will clog and you will need to remove and clean it and re-calibrate for use. I have only had to do this once in the last 9 months and I use my espresso maker daily, so my grinder gets heavy use.

I bought this 5 years ago to replace the Hamilton Bay grinder that finally kicked the bucket. For 4x the cost of my old grinder, it worked like a dream... for about a year. Since then it has steadily decreased in usefulness. It used to grind enough coffee for an entire pot with one push of the button. Now I have to hit the button 5 times to get the same amount of beans. It still works, technically, and I still use it- but it's a pain in the neck, and for the price, I don't think it's worth it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes A Total Mess. Extremely Disappointed.
reviews.reviewText:
I'd give it one star based on how much I despise this grinder, but I'm trying to be fair. It does *technically* grind coffee. But this is a TERRIBLE grinder compared to other options for the same price range.
Biggest complaint is how messy it is. If you enjoy coffee grinds being spread through your kitchen from this poorly designed product, go for it.
And it's not even that good at grinding. Worse, it offers virtually no control over the grind and certainly doesn't provide any type of precision. I'm probably going to stick this in a cabinet and use as an emergency backup, because I can't even, in good conscience, sell this to someone to get rid of it. Extremely disappointed.

I purchased this for my Mother since I didn't want to see her walking to a local grocery store every day just to use their (free) commercial grinder. As a reference, at home, I have a Capresso Infinity Grinder Capresso 560.01 Infinity Burr Grinder, Black and a Gaggia Coffee Delux espresso machine.

Honestly, I am a bit disappointed. First off, the finest setting won't be enough for some of the pump-based espresso machines. It also comes with a very wide "bean reservoir" on top, which makes storage a bit difficult. Next, I'm not very used to the combination of the power button, timer, and the start button. On the Capresso, it's very simple, plug it in and set the timer and the grinder will start automatically. For this machine, you will need to first power on, then set the timer, then press start. While it's grinding, the timer doesn't count down - so it's a bit hard to predict when precisely it's going to stop.
