Bottom line: if you're deciding between the Capresso and the Bodum... just go for the Capresso. The name brand just isn't worth it.

This is a great little grinder -- I bought one 3 years ago and liked it so well I bought another within 6 months for my office. The second one died recently due to a stone in the coffee. Upon disassembly I found that the motor drive shaft connects to purely plastic gears and the inner gear shattered under the load. But I really can't fault the machine for this, especially given the price range. I was shocked to see the price had increased from $80 in 2011 to $139 in 2014. I guess Bodum realized they had a hit on their hands.

I recommend this grinder for those who like standard drip to expresso -- it excels at these levels of courseness. For french press folks, this grinder might be a bit fine even at the coarsest setting. However I used it this way just by adjusting the brew time to about 3.5 minutes rather than the more usual 4 - 4.5.

I liked it when it worked but like other reviewers, the grinder eventually stopped working. Maybe this is due to the plastic parts but I’m not really sure. I only used it occasionally for the past year and a half. Perhaps I got a lemon. Either way, I don’t think I’ll go with Bodum anymore.

You are warned!

I find this grinder to be extremely easy to use when grinding either for my drip automatic coffee maker or my French press.

I find that I have minimal grounds spreading around due to static electricity; but maybe that's because I grind the beans first, then unplug the machine. Then, I fill my hot water kettle (for the French press) and let it reach a near boil before I pull out the grinder's glass grounds container to scoop out my coffee into the press.

It always grinds more than enough coffee within the 20 seconds for me to make a full 12-cup pot for my automatic drip coffee maker, and certainly more than enough when I grind for my French press.

It's not too loud, either. I don't know why people are complaining about that in other reviews.

I like the white color more than I thought I would and am glad I chose it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder at a reasonable price.
reviews.reviewText: Great grinder at a reasonable price. If you are REALLY SERIOUS about making the best shot of espresso, this grinder ALMOST grinds fine enough for proper espresso. If it only went one click finer it would be perfect!!!! For all other coffee purposes, it's a GREAT grinder, but if you want perfect espresso, buy a Baratza or something else more high end. You can get an OKAY shot of espresso out of this grinder, but tamp it real tight!

It’s very cute (I got the white one), but feels cheaply made and isn’t nice to use. I followed the on-lid instructions and it left me with far to many grinds and spillage all over my countertop. The grinder bit was packaged separately and there was no instruction on how to install it. And it’s super loud.

I swear by bodum’s French presses but this product is a sad miss. There are much better burr grinders at a comparable price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Loved it for one week then went from 5 stars to 1 star
reviews.reviewText:
I received the product a week ago and was most satisfied with the fine grind it produced for my Espresso machine and would have given it 5 stars but had not taken the time to do a review.
The appearance is good and I particularly liked the way they designed the grinder and how easy it is to use.
However after only using the machine around a dozen times, for 15 seconds each time it stopped working.
I then discovered that the user manual was very limited in trouble shooting advice. I tried everything they suggested but still could not get it working.
As always Amazon was good about taking it back but were unable to offer me a replacement which I would have been prepared to try and now the price has increased so I will be exploring alternative grinders.

I'm no coffee connoisseur, but just someone that grinds beans and makes a pot of coffee everyday. This is a fantastic grinder. I've used small, hand-held grinders and larger tabletop burr grinders. The Bodum Bistro grinds consistently even every time. With grind size set and grind duration set, all you do is turn on the power and press the 'Grind' button. The glass receptacle and soft lid reduce static clinging so you don't need to clean the grinder and countertop every time you brew a pot of coffee. I've been using this grinder for over a year and still love it!

reviews.reviewTitle: great product while it works....but then it stops.
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this for 15 months, and for 15 months it reliably ground my coffee for me, and then it just stopped working. If I had paid the current $69 price, I may have given it 3 starts but I paid almost $100 and I expect more service for that. I get it that things break, but this just stopped working, I can't even get it to turn on now.
Update: after writing this and ordering a new grinder, I took a screwdriver to the old one and got it to work. No telling how long it will work, and I'm not unhappy that I will now have a back up. Not having coffee in the morning, I might as well not get out of bed!

reviews.reviewTitle: Worth the extra dollars for the quality
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this based on the other reviews and am glad that I did. The quality and sturdiness of the grinder is better than others that I have had and is worth the extra cost. Once the grinder stopped working, but it was because I had overworked it. All I did was let it cool down and then took the top off to brush the blades and the area where the grinds got clogged up, after unplugging the machine, of course. I reassembled it and it has worked like a charm ever since. It would be nice to have a larger catch for the grinds, but for a residential grinder, one pot of fresh coffee at a time, this works really well.

I LOVE this! I was not so sad when my former coffee mill (that I'd used for several years) died because it was messy and loud. When I started looking for a new one I assumed that I could find a better one for around $40, I was wrong! After looking in several local stores including Target, Wal-Mart, Bed Bath & Beyond & Shopko I found nothing worth buying! I finally picked up a $12 coffee grinder to tide me over until I could find a better one. (That coffee grinder was junk and even more messy than my previous one by the way!) After a lot of research I chose the Bodum Bistro and it is the best! I don't make anything but regular coffee but I have made a few adjustments and found the perfect grind for me. It is not overly loud and VERY easy to use! Not messy compared to the other ones that I've used. I now have great tasting coffee from home ALL the time with my BUNN BT Velocity Brew and this coffee grinder. I also noticed Starbucks sells this on their web-site so I assumed it must be good since they want their coffee to taste good.

reviews.reviewTitle: We've liked our first one enough to replace it with the ...
reviews.reviewText: We've liked our first one enough to replace it with the identical unit when it died after five years. For this price it's a solid unit. It's not perfect though. It has clogged and few times unexpectedly and generally prefers to not grind extra fine despite that capability existing. We've used mostly dark roast beans that are a little oily so that probably shortened the life of our first unit. Another disappointment is that it is easy to accidentally leave the jar slightly out of position, which can then result in the grounds backing up and clogging the unit. But, if the jar is pushed all the way in there isn't a problem. Bottom line is I'm satisfied for the price. But clearly there are better units out there for more money.

This grinder does not have the convenient 'cups' setting to set the amount of cups you intend to brew. Instead, it goes off a 'seconds' timer with the range being from 5 sec to a max of 20 seconds. I found this a little inconvenient at first but I quickly adjusted...

Grinding at the maximum setting (20 seconds) will yield an 8 - cup pot of coffee at medium strength. I like my coffee a little stronger, so I use a few drops less water. If you're the type who hosts guests, or enjoy making a 10-12 cup pot of freshly ground coffee, I recommend looking for another grinder.

The grind catcher/container does leave a little mess, otherwise I have no further complaints. Hence my 4 - star rating

Worth the money. Only downside is you need to grind it into the provided cup; if you try to be a barista and hold the espresso thing underneath you'll end up clogging the grinder and producing superfine oily coffee sludge that takes forever to clear out with long tiny tools. So use it per instructions and it'll be fine.

This electric conical burr coffee bean grinder on the coarse setting works excellently for the 2 to 4 cups of French press brewed coffee I make only on weekends. I haven't tried its other grind settings. It is very easy to keep clean and its mostly static free glass ginds container keeps the grind dust from going everywhere. For someone who has French press brewed coffee only on weekends I feel that it is an easily affordable and quality electric conical burr grinder given that top quality electric grinders are very expensive ($200 or more).

reviews.reviewTitle: 6 years and running of flawless grinding (for drip)
reviews.reviewText:
6 years of everyday use, this grinder has out performed and outlasted my expectations. I’ve used a medium grind daily for a chemex, once in a while fine grinding for a stovetop espresso. Simple to use, easy to take apart and clean.

I was surprised to see many reviews of failing gears, and wonder if they were mostly fine grinding (which would put more stress on the machine), though it should be designed to handle that, 6 years of a drip grind has not caused any failure.

<Update: We're at the 3-year anniversary for this product, and it's still going strong. We love it!>

We've had ours for over a year--it's our first burr grinder--and we've had nothing but good experiences. A little secret... We sometimes need more time than the timer allows for--big batches require more grinding time--but we don't wait the recommended five minutes between runs; we just do it. And, you know what? We haven''t had any problems! No overheating. No burning motor smell. No problems. Are we shortening the lifespan of the productt? Maybe. Maybe not. As they go, this is a very affordable burr grinder, with little of the muss and fuss sometimes associated with cheaper burr grinders. I'm willing to replace it a little sooner, if that's what it comes to. Then again, we see no indication of needing to anytime soon.

After going through 3 Starbucks "Barista" $130+ grinders few years ago, and recent Krups grinder, settled on the Bodum after reading reviews. We absolutly love this one! Quality grind, low noise, very little mess, and reasonable capacity! Sure it could hold more beans, but this is small nit compared to other grinders I have had. The Starbucks did hold more beans and was nice, but footprint was a bit larger and the selector switch kept breaking with no replacement! The Krups is a joke...low capacity, loud noise, very messy, and inconsistant grinder...gets stuck. We purchased Bodum in black originally last summer and are very pleased. We recently purchased a second "white" model for our cabin, and saved $40 over the black model. Highely recomend if you are looking for quality grinder.

I've owned two of these. They tend to last about a year. My main pet peeve is that the timer isn't long enough. I brew 12 cups and when it's all the way up, it grinds about enough for six cups and only 1/2 the jar is filled. The second one I just bought a few months ago, the timer is degrading so it now runs for about 5 seconds and I have to hit the button 4 times to finish. I suggest a Baratza Encore instead, it cost a little bit more though, but on the other hand, you have to live with it, if you're a coffee drinker.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinder worked fine for eight months then quit
reviews.reviewText: Grinder worked fine for eight months then quit. Bodum " customer service " was a nightmare! I will never buy a Bodum product again !

reviews.reviewTitle: Lasted about a year and a half.
reviews.reviewText: This Coffee Grinder lasted us about a year and a half. It worked quite well during that time, although it generated quite a bit of static electricity and spilled some grounds on the counter top every day. It also didn't quite hold a pound of coffee, which is awkward. It has a glass coffee receptacle, and we never broke ours, but looked for places to order replacement receptacles just in case, and there weren't any. The reason we had to eventually get a new one was that the motor burnt out, and there was no way to repair it.

Recommended.

Overview: Grinds coffee beans effectively, reliably, and looks good while doing so. A burr grinder is necessary for anyone looking to make espresso, but also works great for other types of coffee preparation such as pour over, drip, french-press, and cold brew. Big step up from rotary-blade herb grinders.

Details: I have one of these at the office, one at home, and just bought a third for my girlfriend's parent's Christmas present. I've had mine for almost a year now, the one in the office has been around even longer. They work great for fine-grinding beans for espresso, but can also switch to corser grinds for pour-over, drip, french-press, and cold-brew.

Burr grinders have, what I'd describe as a spindle that evenly grinds beans. This is a huge step up from rotary-blade herb grinders which is what I grew up on. Of course, either option is better than pre-ground beans. Did I mention I am a bit of a coffee snob?

reviews.reviewTitle: Save your money, do not buy this product.
reviews.reviewText: I will simply refer to the many other 1 star reviews for this product and spare everyone a long read. This is my second one and I won't be making this mistake a third time. Same issue, the enclosed gear box makes a loud stuck sound and plastic pieces eventually break off. I tried calling their warranty support line (800) 232-6386 and it just hangs up on me. The email option from the warranty PDF on Amazon's site also links to a broken page. Worthless.

I have been using the grinder twice a day for about a week. I wanted to comment on some of the reviews I have read.

I have been using a blade grinder for convenience for quite a few years. I owned an Italian hand burr grinder that mounted on a table or on the wall. It was messy and to keep the wife happy I stopped using it. I liked the rhythm, working a little for my brew (it required some force to turn in a vertically oriented circle, but not intolerable). I lost it in a move and, upon reading up trying to improve the taste of my coffee, I discovered that the burrs are highly recommended.

So after a friend accidentally damaged the lid on my whirlybird, I decided to invest again in a burr grinder. Not having the expendable income to purchase a high-end grinder, I decided to try the Bodum, with some reservations.

I am so far very satisfied. I don't know where the complaints about grinds flying around are coming from. I roast my own beans, drinking both decaf and regular in many varieties, and there is virtually no mess, I have never considered wiping anything up. I grind between drip and espresso on the machine, about three-fourths of the way toward the finest grind. Perhaps the problem with others comes from the coarseness of the grind, or maybe just different production quality. The glass vessel into which the grinds fall seems solid and fits snugly in my hand.

The grind seems exceptionally even. There is no comparison whatsoever with my last grinder. The quality of the coffee has improved greatly, I am again tasting flavors I remembered from the days of the old hand grinder. I was skeptical but I imagine the extraction is so even that you maximize the flavor. I am loving it so far.

The 20 second issue is problematic. At the above setting, I can grind four coffee scoops of beans (one tablespoon each) in 20 seconds. But sometimes I grind five and I run to a stop with beans left. I have decided to wait maybe fifteen seconds and then hit the start button for another six to eight seconds and then stop it to grind the remaining beans. It is mostly just finishing up bits and pieces at that point. I will see how this affects the motor.

If the motor lasts, then this is an awesome deal. I have not tried the espresso grind, don't have a machine. But the 3/4 fineness is very fine. There is a video online from a Seattle store that demos the machine. I would imagine that a better quality machine would cost three times as much. The lack of a mess is such a big advantage, and the flavor is unquestionably better. If this is in your price range, I highly recommend you try it.

Update: After nearly 18 months the grinder is working as well as ever. I make coffee twice daily, no sign of slowing down, no strange noises. I am very happy with this purchase!

Update #2: After four years of grinding, making coffee at least twice a day, this Bodum is still going strong. No problems whatsoever, no mess on the counter, still an even grind.

I have no issues, it works like new. If I exceed the 20 seconds when making a larger pot I always let the grinder rest for a minute or so to give the motor a break.

Since I purchased this grinder I have had to replace both my automatic drip coffeemaker and my coffee roaster. As expenditures go in this throw-away society, this has been an excellent investment,

Gary

I bought this on a friend's recommendation. My old grinder would get coffee grinds all over the wall due to the static charge. I think the fact that the top of the grounds receptacle is rubber really helps alleviate that problem in this grinder.

The one drawback would be that it only grinds for 20 seconds at a time. For me, that's not really an issue, as that will produce 6 "cups", enough for a travel mug full for both me and the wife each morning. The manual suggests you must let it sit for five minutes before grinding more; I have on occasion (when we had visitors and needed a full pot) almost immediately ground some more. Conceivably doing that every day could shorten the life of the grinder, but I have not had any problems with my typical usage.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very Happy with the New Grinder!!
reviews.reviewText: I was very upset that my local supermarket discontinued offering an in-store grinder (when I was a teen, I worked at an A&P in NY that had a grinder at every other check-out - how times have changed, lol!) Anyhow, the time had come to finally get an in home grinder. I actually have a much more in-expensive "blade" type grinder that we use for grinding dried spices, but I heard that the "burr" kind is the best for coffee grinding and I wanted one with control to make a course grind for percolating. The Bodum Bistro Electric Burr grinder is fantastic! I was originally going to purchase a more expensive machine, but this one has a real glass hopper to catch the grinds, unlike the pricier one with a plastic hopper. Also, it has easy to use controls, clean up is easy and the bright red color adds a nice "pop" to my kitchen - great to see they offer a variety of colors! Our coffee is more delicious than ever now that we can grind in small batches and brew right away! :)

Hours of reading reviews and watching videos for multiple grinders, and I decided to go for this. IGNORE THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS. Those people are either crazy or super picky. You can spend $600 on a grinder, and it will probably be better. But this sucker works plenty fine, as good as a $200 machine. I wanted to spend $90 to $150, and this fit the budget.

I use a Bialetti 6799 Moka Express 3-Cup Stovetop Espresso Maker ($30). This grinds plenty of super fine espresso for my maker. It was even more fine than the grinder at the grocery store. It grinds to the consistency of flour! I also tested it for my french press and it does great. Enjoy!

I purchased this 4 years ago and decided to review it from my experience with it. This grinder was used daily, typically multiple times a day. I liked the grind settings. The first few years it performed flawlessly and I was very happy with it. Over the past year, the timer for how long it grinds began to act up. At this point, 4 years later, I can only grind for 5 or 6 seconds. No matter what time setting I choose, it only grinds a tiny bit of coffee. I have to grind 5 or 6 times to get enough for my coffee cup.
I got good use out of this and am very happy with it while it worked properly. I drink 2 or 3 cups of coffee a day so it got a lot of use. I assume I hit the useful life and will be looking to replace it within the next 2 weeks.

I use this coffee grinder about once a week and have done so for the last few months. Overall, this machine has a consistent grind no matter what setting it is on. It is very quiet compared to other coffee grinders but does require a hand to be put on top to help keep it steady when it is on a fine grind setting. The static build-up with the grounds in the glass container is very noticeable especially when going to get the grounds out of the grinder.
In terms of cleaning the grinder, you can look inside and see the coffee grounds built-up and there is no good way to get them out.
If you are looking a grinder with a quiet and consistent operation, this is the one to go with.

Yes - it grinds coffee well. But you are warned that you must give it several minutes to cool down after you have ground enough coffee for 6 cups. For a ten or twelve cup coffee maker you need to make two batches, and wait in between. HOWEVER - that is if you do not break the fancy hand blown glass container. We dropped it. Then you discover that Bodum spare parts are perpetually out of stock. I have waited for six months - and I can still not buy a replacement! I guess you are supposed to be so enamored with Bodum that you buy a new grinder just to get the beaker. I am disgusted and advise against this product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Company says item not covered under warranty so this very poor quality item is your problem
reviews.reviewText:
Do not buy! Glass grounds catcher is flimsy and Will break. Company is totally unresponsive. Item has been backordered forever,. So many requests for replacement that they can't keep up. Check out internet complaints. Company says item not covered under warranty so this very poor quality item is your problem. You only option is to search on your own for a replacement.Target has removed from display because of this
issue. I will never buy products from Bodum again.

reviews.reviewTitle: It does a great coarse grind for my french press and also does ...
reviews.reviewText: Some other grinders cost in the hundreds of dollars. I have used this for over 3 years and it has shown no signs of slowing down. It does a great coarse grind for my french press and also does great fine grinding for espresso...plus everything in between! Very easy to use and set up. It comes in a variety of colors to match your kitchen. It is attractive and looks nice just sitting on the counter. It is fairly easy to clean and the container is anti-static so the grinds shake out nicely. It says you should wait several minutes between uses so the burrs cool down, but I have done 2 - 20 second grinds consecutively with no issues. I have not done more though, so I can't say what will happen.

At first we loved it but our first one lasted less than a year. The burrs dulled and grinding time increased from 20 seconds a small pot to well over a minute. Spare parts not available. Based on good reviews, we purchased a second and this time included the extended warranty. After 6 months the burr was dull. The extended warranty company never returned my emails but Amazon stepped up and gave me a refund.

This is a great Burr grinder but I was seriously disappointed to find that the "chrome" grinder was actually just plastic painted grey. It's not even chromed plastic, it's just silver paint. I'm returning it to get back the extra $20 I spent expecting chrome.

reviews.reviewTitle: No need to be so careful about wait between grind cycles
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this now for over 18 months, and still like it. Every morning, I run two 20 second grind cycles back-to-back to make a half-pot for my wife and I (we like it strong). I've on occasion done as many as 4 full grind cycles within five minutes or so to make full pot when have company over.

Using this grinder has made for much more enjoyable coffee. While the glass container helps with static, static is still an issue when using darker-roast beans - not so much in terms of making a mess but with more grounds sticking inside the container. It will struggle and clog if try to grind dark-roast beans on finest espresso settings, but I almost never make espresso and when I do, have a Starbucks Barista which uses a pressurized portafilter, so doesn't need to be so fine anyway. Since I'm partial to light/medium roast coffees and normally use for drip machine, these things are non-issues for me.

The marked settings for drip and espresso could be better. For drip coffee I use just a notch or so coarser than the preset to prevent fines in my coffee using mesh filter while still getting good strong taste, and you will likely want to grind a little finer for french press than the marked setting. But given its price, overall functionality, good looks, and continuing endurance despite my flagrant flouting of Bodum's usage guidelines, I give it highest marks.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder - plastic gears - bad customer service
reviews.reviewText: I really liked this grinder. Very consistent grind size and no clogging. That was until a pebble jammed it and stripped one of the plastic gears. Customer service ignored me. That changed my opinion from five stars to zero.

I got this to replace a manual grinder and have been entirely satisfied with it. The little details (like the quick reference guide under the hopper lid for what to set grind coarseness and time to for various types of coffee maker) really make this one of my favorite kitchen appliances (also, it makes coffee :) )

I would not hesitate to recommend this to anyone or everyone.

reviews.reviewTitle: nice grinder, makes a heckofa mess!
reviews.reviewText:
I read a lot of reviews on grinders including this one prior to buying this, and was particularly interested in how it was billed as one with minimal static cling, no muss, no fuss. Even watched a video by a generous buyer who showed how clean it is.

Well, apparently that's not true everywhere. Maybe it's cause I live in a climate like Seattle (seems like that help, not hurt); but when i grind beans and remove the decanter, coffee ground FLY EVERYWHERE. I make such a mess with this thing. I haven't found that the glass decanter helps one bit.

so, as a grinder, i love it. as a grinder that is clean and doesn't make a mess, i'm afraid it sure doesn't live up to my expectations. All that said, I'm keeping mine but I have to clean the counter after every cup of coffee.

Hope this is helpful.

I haven't had a burr grinder since the heating element in my grind & brew coffee-maker died years ago. With just a little experimenting, I was able to match the timer & size of grind to the amount of coffee I usually brew.

reviews.reviewTitle: Beats a blade grinder, fine for espresso for non-snobs, but makes a mess.
reviews.reviewText: I like this grinder, and it's a fine entry level model if you're looking to upgrade from the inconsistency of a blade grinder. My wife and I have been using it with acceptable results with our Gaggia Classic espresso machine. I like that the catch container for the grounds is glass, but this does not totally eliminate static as some reviews have stated. I also find that whenever I remove the container with fresh grounds, an additional dusting of coffee falls out from the grinder onto the counter. This is annoying to clean up, and difficult to avoid in regular use, so I'm knocking a star for design. Overall though, this is pretty cheap for a burr grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just get this, don't waste your time!
reviews.reviewText: I'm glad I got this. Too many picky reviews kept me from getting this grinder sooner. After trying others out, this one ended up staying on the counter. It's small enough of a footprint and looks nice.

I've used this grinder for several years and just love it. I like that the coffee collector (beaker?) is made of glass. I like that the glass container is totally round (unlike a competitor's model that turned out to be crescent shaped once you removed it from the grinder). It is relatively quiet. I grind a day's worth of coffee once in the morning. It did stop on me once. I figured out how to take it apart and clean the grinder. (see photos by other reviewers). I would recommend getting the black model if it can match your décor. My white machine is coffee stained from powdery coffee residue.

I would recommend this unit without reservation.
I did a lot of research on coffee grinders and selected this one because of the glass grounds container. The last couple of grinders we've had were plastic and the static electricity was a MAJOR problem trying to scoop or pour the grounds from the container.
The glass container removes 99% of the static. The grinding selector (course to fine) makes the grounds perfect for your choice. I like espresso and the fine setting is perfect.It is very quiet when grinding and the only draw back is the timer setting. It will grind enough for a small press or 3 espresso shots on the 20 second setting. But then you are supposed to wait 5 minutes for the motor to cool off before grinding more. If you are planning to make several cups at once, I'd suggest pregrinding what you'll need and storing it in a glass container.

reviews.reviewTitle: Compact, Efficient with One Annoying Feature
reviews.reviewText: I have limited counter space, so the compactness of this unit is great, particularly since it shares the area with a coffeemaker and espresso machine. It does a nice job on the grinding, and I like the glass cup. The only issue is the 20 second limit on the grinding time before you are advised to wait 5 minutes. I pretty much ignore this unless I'm making 12 cups for guests, and then I plan ahead. I don't know, maybe my unit will burn out early as a result, especially since I prefer a finer grind. Overall, I'm happy though, in spite of the poor motor design...no one else I know has to consider a 20 second rule! Update June 30, 2016: This thing is a little work horse, and is still doing a great job. I've been ignoring that 20 second "rule" everyday that I've used it, and I can report that it hasn't blown-up or stopped working. I still appreciate that it is compact, and I would definitely buy this model again.

It grinds super fine on the espresso/fine setting... also, i LOVE that I can grind right into my portafilter (I don't use the glass cannister at all). Yes, as with any burr grinder, if you are grinding super fine, it's going to need to be 'de-clogged' once in a while. For espresso, I fill the grinder with beans only 1/4 to 1/3 of the way or less, and each time run a handfull of rice through. I also give it a nice 'tap' with my portafilter, to help knock out some of the grinds that might be hanging out into the portafilter. I'm not sure about the motor burning out- we use ours quite often- probably averages out to daily, but often are doing more than one espresso. We are about to start using it for regular coffee and will likely not wait 5 minutes in between grinds to get enough for a pot.

reviews.reviewTitle: I've had 3 different burr grinders and this one is the best. The grind is consistent
reviews.reviewText: The condo we rent in Hawaii has this grinder. We've stayed in this condo 4 weeks each of the last 2 years using this grinder every day. I've had 3 different burr grinders and this one is the best. The grind is consistent. My other grinders had various size grounds after grinding the beans. I believe the taste of my coffee is smoother due to the consistent grind. I've had this grinder for 2 months using it every day. The grounds fill the glass container from the top, while other grinders fill their plastic container from the side causing the grinder to clog up which can cause the motor to over heat and burn out.

reviews.reviewTitle: but couldn't get a good cup of coffee from beans I grinded myself
reviews.reviewText: A burr grinder does a much more effective job at grinding coffee. I have a keurig, and wanted to use the "reusable" k-cups, but couldn't get a good cup of coffee from beans I grinded myself. After some research, I realized that how the coffee is grinded does a lot to determine how the flavor will be extracted during brewing. This one does a great job, and now get great cups of coffee using my "green" and reusable k-cups and coffee of choice that I grind with the Bodum. One other tip, turn your reusable k-cup upside down so that the coffee is not packed down before putting in your brewer.

The cup doesn't fit well, so ground coffee falls behind it making a mess and making it even harder to fit. I used to have a different one with a rubber lid for the cup that had a hole in the center. Was a much better fit and worked much better.

My automatic espresso machine died for the last time... Tossed it. It was a $1200 brewer at full price. At our farmers market there is a guy who sells fresh dripped coffee and it is great. I wanted to make coffee like he does and a burr grinder is a key piece of that system. Read lots of reviews and chose this one on sale and am very happy with it so far. Some of the complaints about it in the reviews have not been a problem for me. I brew one cup at a time so the timed grind provides more than enough grounds for me. The grinder looks good, feels well made and is not very loud. Oh and the other parts of the drip system, good beans of course, reverse osmosis water, ceramic drip cone, brown paper filters, no sugar but half and half ok. No plastic. I now have a much better cup of coffee than the espresso machine made.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder does a wonderful job, but be advised that the grinder motor ...
reviews.reviewText: This grinder does a wonderful job, but be advised that the grinder motor runs for about twenty seconds before shutting down. If you are making coffee for two people, this is not an issue. If you prefer to make larger pots of coffee, just be aware that you will need to allow time for the motor to cool down (five minutes) before grinding the additional coffee beans you will need. If you plan carefully, this is not an issue.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder
reviews.reviewText: I like this grinder! I was hesitant because of the feedback regarding the 20 second max grind time, but figured I would give it a try. It has taken me a little bit of trial and error to find the best settings but nothing too difficult. I typically make less than 8 cups of coffee in my drip coffee machine, so I started by putting that amount of beans in the Bistro. I set the timer to the max and the grind to "medium" let it go; it took about 19 seconds to finish the job. I thought the grind was just a little too fine at that setting, but the coffee was tasty! With the hopper full of beans they grind a little faster, likewise with the setting midway between medium and coarse. So I get 8 cups worth of grounds in about 17 seconds. The time-quantity curve seems to be fairly linear, so if I want less I dial accordingly. The max my coffee maker will do is 10 cups and I expect that 20 seconds will do the job. If not, I will will just hit the button and grind some more; the motor doesn't get hot at all and I think a 20 second grind followed by another 5 or 10 seconds would, on an occasional basis, be fine. Bottom line: easy to use, solid construction, very little in the way of mess and best coffee ever!

I liked this grinder while it worked well. Unfortunately, that period of time only lasted about eight months. After about eight months of daily use, I began to notice the volume of grounds produced from a given time setting was getting less and less. It seems that it is getting dull or something. Anyway, I expect an expensive coffee grinder to last longer than eight months. Also, using this grinder is pretty messy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broken gear. does not work. Lasted four years under medium/light use.
reviews.reviewText: Bought in May 2013. Worked OK until today Nov 2017. Four years is not long enough for a $120 (at time of purchase) single use coffee grinder. I would rate it 2-stars if I could buy replacement parts but Bodum does not support this item even though it is still currently in production.

We had this a while before we realized we could determine what amount of grind would give us the pot of coffee we wanted so we could set it, leave it and just push the button every morning and dump the cup into our coffee filter. DUH!! It has generated ZERO static, which is why we bought it. A great change from our other very pricey grinder that was a static factory!!! Thanks for making a great product without all the static. Yay!

reviews.reviewTitle: 7 years old and working very well.
reviews.reviewText: I think that this burr coffee grinder is a fantastic value for the price. I spent time looking at all the burr grinders out there and you quickly get into several hundred dollars. The complaint about the 20 seconds worth of grind time, that requires a 5 minute wait time to allow the motor to cool, is a valid one for those that want to make large (6 or more cups) amounts of coffee. For the Pourover crowd, this will grind 51 grams of coffee in the 20 second grind time. I think the grinder is very well made, and the grind size is VERY uniform in size and their is minimum static. In summary, a great choice for 1 to 2 people (perfect for the pour over crowd), but for larger groups either grind ahead or look elsewhere and be prepared to pay quite a bit more.

This is the first real coffee grinder I have owned. I had previously had a blade "chopper." The Bodum Burr Grinder is more convenient as the beans are stored witht he grinder ready to grind. The amount of coffee to be ground is deternined by the timer. This doesn't take long to figure our how long for the amount of coffee you need.

Cons: Noisier than previous reviews had lead me to believe. Static free ground coffee is just a cruel hoax. The glass receptical was supposed to be near static free. Nope! The ground coffee jumps around just as it had in the blade grinders plastic receptical.

Summary: Not a bad piece of equipment for the price. A little "plasticy", but sturdy enough for weekend use. Size is just about right for the counter.

I love this mill!! I have had it for several months. Previously I had a less expensive grinder in which I had to stop grinding, shake, and continue. YUCK! And yes, when people say the right grinder makes all the difference in the world with the flavor of a coffee, its true. Buy it!

I gave this product a 3 but I would like to clarify the rating. First of all the product did not work for me. I bought this because of all the other great reviews but perhaps I received a bad machine. It did not grind to espresso. And personally, even if it did work properly it is not worth $100. I would say $75 at the most. It is all plastic except for the grinder and it does not seem like it would last long anyway. So I would actually give the product a 2 star rating. However! Their customer service is fantastic! I called them and they immediately sent me a return label at no cost to me and I have already received my refund. Their staff was very apologetic and polite! So their customer service is definitely a 5!!! Too bad it did not work. I was looking forward to a nice burr grinder.

I specifically got this one because it stated you don't have to deal with coffee ground and static (all over the place) with their special container. The coffee ground go everywhere when I use it and stick to everything. Getting it out of the container is not too bad, but cleanup is a bear.

reviews.reviewTitle: I've figured out how long to grind to get the perfect pot of coffee
reviews.reviewText: We use this grinder Monday-Friday, two to three times a day. I've figured out how long to grind to get the perfect pot of coffee. Starbucks is 20+7. Lavazza is 20 + 15. Cafe Don Pablo is 20+10. We've had this two years and it's still working great. I do a thorough cleaning about every month.

I have a cutting grinder for many years and I thought I was happy with it. Eventually I decided to upgrade to a burr grinder. After researching a while and not being able to find that a) was reasonably priced, b) had good reviews, and c) appealed to me asthetically I stumbled upon this guy.

I've had it for a couple weeks and have used it roughly 15 times and I'm very pleased. I have the grind set about 2/3 of the way to the finest setting and it works like a champ. I regret not finding this grinder sooner.

reviews.reviewTitle: An otherwise well-designed grinder with cheap plastic gears that will fail within two years.
reviews.reviewText: Lasted only two years because of cheap plastic gears. Grinding speed is a little too fast, causing heat buildup in the plastic gears. Otherwise a very good grinding quality with little static buildup in glass grind container with minimal mess. My previous Cuisinart grinder also died because of cheap plastic gears. Don't buy any machine that requires you to wait five minutes between each grind.

We've had the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Grinder for about a week. It just has not worked properly. This has been a problem with both oily and less oily beans. And it's been problematic both for espresso grind and drip grip. It constantly clogs and requires removing the bean hopper to get to the burr grinder to unjam the machine. Very messy and frustrating. Given the generally positive reviews of the machine, maybe we just got a lemon. But I don't want to take the chance of exchanging the unit, so we are returning it for a refund.

The machine looks really good. And it has less of a static electricity flying bean dust problem than other machines. But that doesn't make up for its poor performance.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good unit and great customer service
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this unit a couple of years ago and in that time it has worked wonderfully for me. Sure, if you need to grind a huge quantity of coffee at once, this isn't a great choice, but if you're making a normal batch of coffee, this unit is perfect. The grind is consistent and the unit seems well made. I needed to replace a part (through my own fault) and Bodum helped me out even though I was a couple months past the two year warranty. They answered my email quickly and resolved the issue perfectly. I've always had a good opinion of Bodum products but this was my first time interacting with their customer support and now I'm even happier with my choice.

We love this grinder - it's our first burr grinder, and it's great. Easy to use, no maintenance (we've had it for 6 months now) and easy to clean. I was concerned (based on reviews, and the product description) that the timing of needing to wait in between grinds would affect us but it turns out to be a non-issue. We use an 8-10-cup Chemex for our coffee, and so we set it on 20-seconds, and it's the perfect amount of coffee for us. Overall, this grinder is a great value, not too large, and easy to deal with. One tip to deal with static/grinds is that we leave the lid of the canister on when emptying the grinds out, it helps reduce grinds getting all over the place.

reviews.reviewTitle: I really wanted to give this 5 stars
reviews.reviewText:
I really wanted to give this grinder 5 stars, but there's just one pet peeve I have with it.

PROS:
* Consistent grind
* Very good fine grind
* Quieter than other grinders I have owned
* Excellent overall design
* The collector container is outstanding: keeps grounds from getting all over the place and allows one to dispense grinds cleanly. I directly transfer the ground coffee into my Moka pot funnel from the container through the hole in the plastic lid

CON:
* The one con is that leftover grinds stay in the top of the grinder. I have learned to tap the back of the unit to get those out of the machine before starting a new grind.

Overall, I would say it's well worth the money.

Love this thing!!! Bought it to try French press coffee. We have had it for almost 2 years and it keeps going. Tried some dumb idea I read about cleaning the oily coffee residue with pistachio hulls. Big mistake... the hulls made it sound sick and like I broke the motor. Ran two cycles through of coffee beans and it finally dislodged the last of the pistachio hulls. Worked fine after that, has worked great ever since and the motor noise returned to normal as well.

Fresh ground coffe tastes SOOOO much better than auto drip. Also would recommend Bodum French press as well (Just note cup size is 8 oz and medium size mugs take roughly 2 cups. We use the 12cup Bodum and get 4ish cups of coffee for our mugs).

reviews.reviewTitle: makes a mess every time you remove the glass coffee catcher
reviews.reviewText: great, nice looking grinder, but makes a mess every time you remove the glass coffee catcher. The price has also gone up to the point that a consumer can opt for the Capresso burr coffee grinder which grinds slower meaning your coffee will taste better due to using less heat.If you can get it for less than $25 in comparison to the Capresso, get this burr grinder. It works well, it's just messy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder for low demand kitchen
reviews.reviewText:
I love this grinder.

I use a small press to make my 2 cups of coffee each morning, and this grinder could not be more perfect or easier to use for that situation.

However, if you need to grind enough beans to make 16 cups from a drip machine, this is probably NOT the grinder you want, unless you're willing to grind a 20 second batch, wait 5 minutes, then grind the remainder.

I could probably get enough coffee ground in one 20 second run to stoke a 6-cup press or an 8-10 cup drip machine, but that's about the limit, then you need to let it cool.

I could not be more impressed with the quality and operation of this neat little machine.

PS - The trick is that after you run it, but before you remove the cup, tap the side of the machine a couple of times to dislodge the tiny bit of ground coffee that might otherwise drop out when you remove the cup. It's by FAR the cleanest grinder I've owned.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just what I was looking for
reviews.reviewText: I use a french press every morning. I used to pregrind on the weekends and fill a container and when take from that every morning. I finally decided to go for this when I had some extra money. My biggest problem with the old grinder was you had to do so little at a time. I used to use 4 1/2 spoons of this spoon I had to make the right strength coffee for my 4 cup french press. I just found a timed grind length (10 seconds) that made the same amount. It's pretty cool that you can change the grind and how long to grind for. I haven't tried the espresso grind yet but the coarse grind is just what I wanted. I wish I had the tasting ability to say I noticed a difference between grinding it everyday and once a week but I honestly don't. In any case, it's great!

reviews.reviewTitle: Good Conical Burr Grinder, But Fails After 4 years and 9 months of Light Use
reviews.reviewText:
Pros
+ Very uniform coffeee grind size
+ One of the best burr grinders for the price
+ Very little static and coffee mess, unlike other burr grinders
+ Easy to use and grind small coffee porcions
+ Compact design fits easily on the kitchen counter

Cons
+ Limited continuous grind time of 10 seconds

UPDATE MARCH 5, 2018
- Now the start/stop button does not properly control the start/stop cycle. I suspect something failed on the integrated circuit board. The grinder is out of warranty and I may attempt to repair the unit in the future. Any suggestions are welcome. I am downgrading the review from 4 stars to 1 star for this failure.

reviews.reviewTitle: I bought a 2nd one for my cabin
reviews.reviewText: I've had 1 of these for 1 1/2 yrs. I fine grind for a dbl espresso 3/ 4 times each morning. I use the darkest beans can buy. When I 1st used it, the grind wasn't fine enough 4 me. I rotated the bean hopper 180 degrees, perfect grind for me. I had also bought a $250 grinder for my cabin. I forget the brand. It lasted 9 mo. I just received & used my 2nd Bodum grinder. Works great for me. I was able to find a time setting that is exactly the amount of grinds I need for a dbl espresso, about 7 seconds. I saw some complaints of broken grinder, It seems to be people that grind for a 10 cup coffee maker.

love being able to set the grind to our desired preference, it's really upped the level of coffee/espresso brewing in the house, coming off of a series of standard coffee grinders. Not sure why some reviews complained about it looking dirty and stuff sticking to it, we've had it on the busiest part of the counter for 3 months, and it's black and has not accumulated anything. Really like being able to grind up a small container-full, and then pull shots from our Breville espresso machine for the rest of the session. Very convenient being able to store the beans in the hopper, saving us the trouble of constantly pouring into something - it cuts out a step in the process for you. It's high quality materials and looks like it'll last for a while. The various 'time-to-grind- settings make sense, once you get used to how long you need to grind, for how much coffee you're making. Not a deterrent at all. The grind is exact. If you know what you need to grind for, you can pull it off with perfection with this thing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Even grind and easy to use.
reviews.reviewText: So far I am loving this grinder. Every grind is evenly grinned and adjusting the amount is pretty easy once you have figured out your preferred setting. They give some suggestions on grind times in the instructions and I slightly adjusted from there to get to my perfect cup. Cleaning is easy and the grinding mechanism comes in and out easily enough.

works as described, but two things to note. I have poor luck using the grinder on finest setting (with the arrow over top of the little portafilter icon). This clogs my machine. One dot to the right (or one dot coarser) and it does not get clogged.

also the coarsest setting of the machine (arrow over the french press icon) does not seem to be "coarse" enough. Compared to higher* end machines found in stores or even compared to my hario mini mill (on french press setting).

lastly, there is quite a bit of residual grinds left in the container due to static after each use.

i am still happy about my purchase though and will continue to you this grinder!

reviews.reviewTitle: I am very disappointed that it broke after such little use
reviews.reviewText: This grinder broke after less than six times use. I bought it ten months ago and a part in the grinding mechanism broke causing loud noise, intense vibration and course grinds when I attempt to use it. When it worked, it worked well. I am very disappointed that it broke after such little use.

This is my second Bodum in 10 years. This 10903-73US is super fast. Two 20 second grindings and I can make 10 cups of coffee. The machine is very messy. It leaves coffee grinds under the glass cup and grindings stick to the sides of the glass cup and the rubber top has to be cleaned every time you grind. I place a paper towel under the front foot to catch the excess grindings otherwise it goes on the counter top.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great durability - Eight years and going strong!
reviews.reviewText: I've owned this for eight years now. Still working perfectly without any issues. I clean it every couple months with a mix of soap/water and rubbing alcohol on parts that can't get wet. No complaints.

I just got this yesterday and have used it to produce three shots of espresso (each ground separately) and one batch from my french press. The grind is consistent over the range of settings. I had very little brown sludge from my french press this morning, and my espresso had a nice crema, and formed a solid puck after proper tamping and pulling. I have to dial in the exact grind setting I want for the extraction time I am looking for, and so far this grinder has allowed me to get close on my third try. That said, the smallest grind setting sounds like it is rubbing the burrs together. I will not use it because I don't want to grind them down prematurely. Maybe in a few months once they dull it will be necessary to use this setting for my espresso, but right now it is fine on the second to smallest setting.

Cleaning is easy, you just lift off the bean holder with a quick twist and the top burr is easily removed from the lower one, allowing you to brush them both off. The only "problem" is that the exit shoot from the burrs to the holder is slightly hooked, so you're going to get some grounds that stay in there. You can tilt the grinder forward and knock the grounds loose while the container is still in place, but you're still going to have a few grounds. That said, the hook is much slighter than I've seen on other grinders and ultimately does allow you to blow out the grounds with fairly little work. I can do this after each grind in 30 seconds while my coffee is brewing.

In short:
Easy to clean
Consistent grind

I purchased this Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder to replace an older blade type. After reading some poor reviews regarding the motor, I must say I had some doubts. I've now been using my Bodum Bistro daily for several months. I usually use two 20 second grind times, using the built in timer. I do not wait to grind the second time, only a few seconds. So far, this unit works flawlessly, while keeping the mess to an absolute minimum. This is a very nicely crafted high quality unit with a glass container with rubber gripping and sealing surfaces. The grind consistency is very adjustable and comes out perfectly every timeBodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder, Black. I highly recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder is one of the best grinders on the market
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is one of the best grinders on the market. Yes there are other more expensive ones. However why pay more when this grinder consistently puts out espresso ground fines making a perfect cup every time. I love this grinder!!!

I don't know why I waited so long to purchase a burr coffee grinder. I chose the Bodum after asking a coffee bean seller what his recommendation was. Even though the company sold a different brand grinder, he recommended the Bodum as the best. We have enjoyed using the Bodum and grinding our own coffee.

The Bodum was easy to learn to use, though it did take some experimentation to learn how long to set the timer for to get the amount of coffee to make the amount we drink. I already knew about how fine we like the grind, though this would be easy to figure out if you did not know.

I would definitely recommend this coffee grinder.

It worked well enough for a while, but it is now having electrical problems, outside of the 1yr limited warranty. Given this, and other reviews, it's clear these things aren't built to last. I think I'm done w/ Bodum for good since this isn't the only item I have that is giving up. They are too expensive to justify just a few years of usefulness.

So, I am a coffee snob. Roast my own and the blade grinders we have always used burn out after a year. This grinder is easy to use, like the glass collector even though there is a little static cling for the grind it is much better than plastic. Well built machine. After about 20 grinds it stopped working properly and I had to clean it. So, get a good brush and be prepared to clean it.

Is there a difference between this and the more expensive conical burr grinders? Yes, but for me this does the job and the coffee tastes better than the old blade grinder. I am sure I can tell the difference between an $800 grinder and this one, but not worth the extra money for me.

reviews.reviewTitle: Glass receptacle plus tile floor yields no coffee.
reviews.reviewText:
I got this grinder and tried it out with some grounds...it ground them beautifully. I carried the grinder over to the kitchen counter and dropped the glass container on the tile floor. It blew up really impressively. Ah well.
But Amazon doesn't sell the replacement glass container! Oh no! So I went to the Bodum site, found the container, and ordered it from them for $9.95 plus 5 bucks shipping. Darn. Then they (Bodum) denied my charge card. I now have a really nice grinder but I can't grind any coffee.
Don't buy this till Amazon stocks the parts.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stopped working in the second year
reviews.reviewText: I have had this grinder for about a year and a half. It recently began locking up unless I resorted to trickling the beans into the hopper a few at a time. The beans were the same ones I had always been grinding in the machine. Bodum has offered to replace the machine under its two-year warranty, but I have already replaced it with a Baratza Encore. When I bought the Bodum, it cost $85. It's now up to at least $129 and in my judgment that prices it out of contention. The Baratza for the same price is leaps and bounds better. Even when the Bodum worked, it was noisy and jumped around like a bad imitation of a Latin dance.

First of all, let me caveat this review by stating that I only use this grinder for my espresso machine, and I don't make more than 1-2 cups at a time, so the 20 second grind time limit mentioned by other reviewers is not an issue (I usually grind for 10 seconds and it's enough for 1 cup). This grinder replaces a cheap burr grinder (which I now use for drip coffee as it doesn't grind fine enough), and the difference is dramatic. The build quality is excellent. In the finest setting, it will grind extremely fine, actually too fine for my machine (DeLonghi EC-702), so I use it on the third notch from the finest (between the 'espresso' and 'drip' marks). I have had this grinder now for a couple of months and use it daily. Works flawlessly and grinds very consistently. The only complaint I have is about the white finish, which can be easily stained by coffee grounds (my fault for resting the tamper and coffee scoop on the cover), but that doesn't warrant lowering my rating.

One more thought: being a pretty thrifty person, I was hesitant to spend $70 on a grinder since I only spent $125 for the espresso machine, but this is really only about $20 more than much lesser grinders, and it produces a much better drink. Investing an extra $20 on the espresso machine would not make much of a difference, so the extra $20 on the grinder will give a much more significant upgrade.

I don't like to review products right away, granting at least a bit of time for them to fail completely or just 'fail to please.' But, for the price, this unit has been quite satisfactory. I've only used it for coarse grind for my press. I suppose its only limit is that one should only grind for 20 seconds max at one time or it will overheat. After that 20 seconds, the unit should be allowed to rest for a couple of minutes before doing another 20 seconds of grinding. Thus it is limited to grinding just for a smaller pot, but it has plenty of capacity for my use. Seems like an even consistency; I like the removable container for the ground product. I bought it because of all the other positive reviews, and I agree.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's ok but there is a better option.
reviews.reviewText:
It does a good job with fine to medium grinds. But the coarse grind isn't good at all. Very uneven. I own both this Bodum and the Capresso model 565.04 and i recommended going with the Capresso. It's the best overall home burr grinder in my opinion.
The only thing i like better than the Capresso...like the stop and start button...and that it's about 30 or so dollers cheaper.

The grinder does it's job well. Bought to replace more expensive grinder, do to excessive static chaft all over. This grinder gives a uniform grind and traps the fine chaft in the glass container. Being glass, little static cling.
4 not 5, because it is loud.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very nice - made a big difference with Solofill
reviews.reviewText:
This unit made a big difference with our Keurig machine and the Solofill cup as compared to a cheap blade grinder. We are now saving money and being better on the environment by not using so many throwaway k-cups, though we did lose some of the convenience of the k-cups.

The grinds from this machine are perfect and you can choose from many different grind sizes (course to fine). You can freshly grind coffee every day by leaving beans in there and pressing a button. The beans and the grind are stored air-tight.

UPDATE: 2019-03-01: Still like this grinder overall but the outside gets nasty and it's really hard to clean so I don't bother. See photo. Reducing to 4 stars because of this.

reviews.reviewTitle: I have been relatively satisfied with this coffee grinder
reviews.reviewText:
Well i mean it works... sometimes... I have been relatively satisfied with this coffee grinder. It grinds up most everything i throw at it. But there are some beans that it just wont work on. It gets stuck even when perfectly clean.

Another thing that bothers me is the timer. Most of the time it cuts off before the time you set it for. Sometimes only running for a second or two. I have had to push the grinder button sometimes 8 times to get my coffee ground.

Cleaning it is fairly easy so i guess that is a plus and it looks nice.

reviews.reviewTitle: I love it but it’s loud
reviews.reviewText: It’s a great grinder with lots of adjustability...butter it’s really loud. Still a great product and I do recommend it for anyone that prefers to grind whole beans.

I was in the market for a burr grinder to replace my krupps blade grinder and also to simplify my morning routine of making coffee. With this setup, I don't have to weigh my beans and take them out of a separate container to grind every morning before putting it into the Aeropress. Saves me a few minutes everyday, that alone is quite worth it! It works as advertised so far and it operates at a much lower volume than my blade grinder.

The amount of static generated is tolerable (I live in a dry place), nothing a simple rinse won't fix. The rubber lid is a very smart piece of design, keeps the grounds from flying around and reduces the mess. The lid is probably the best design feature of this grinder. I haven't used a more expensive grinder before ($300) and I don't have an espresso machine as the Aeropress is serving my needs quite well so this grinder is perfect for the kind of coffee I make.

After a year, I can report that this grinder works great. Consistent, even grounds. A bit noisy, but hey, it's only 10-15 seconds. And for a hundred bucks, in the world of grinders, this seems like a very good value. I'm now giving these as gifts.

UPDATE: 7 years later, it finally died (I thought). 7 years of daily use seemed fair to me. I got all ready to order another one, but first I watched a Y-tube comparison review of the Bodum and 2 other budget burr grinders. That's when I learned that you can remove the top grinder and clean it. Huh. Quick clean and it works again. By the way, the grinders are still really sharp. Bravo!

I just grind coffee beans and make a simple Melitta cup of coffee in the morning. I don't do espresso nor anything else but brew a good cup of coffee. I've suffered through the Braun and Krups spinners, the Mister Coffee grinders with plastic receptacles, and finally ordered one of these Bodum's despite the reviews about "only 20 seconds". I'm happy as the dickens with this new Bodum. It is quieter, grinds coffee better than anything I've owned before, and there isn't a pile of coffee dust all over the counter top where this puppy sets. It make more grounds at one time than I will ever use, and I figure I can wait a few minutes if I just have to grind a second batch!

reviews.reviewTitle: Inconsistent, gear slips at fine grinds
reviews.reviewText: Does okay at coarse grinds, but anything finer than a drip setting and the nylon gear slips and makes a terrible noise without actually grinding anything. The grind seems inconsistent even when it does grind. Not awful for my purposes, but I would not buy this grinder again, and it would be completely unusable for anyone wanting a fine grind - e.g. for an espresso machine

reviews.reviewTitle: I like it, but I think I'd try a different one next time.
reviews.reviewText:
Pros: This grinder makes very nice, consistent, course ground coffee. That's the only application I've used, and no complaints there. The jar is a nice touch, and overall the design is very attractive.
Cons: I had a bean get stuck in the grinder near the top of the hopper, producing a cringe worthy sound and bringing all grinding to a halt. Getting the bean out was surprisingly difficult and involved a screwdriver and elbow grease. I feel the motor is underpowered if a single bean can wreak so much havoc. Secondly, the instructions state that the grinder can only work 20 seconds at a time (using the timer) and then the little guy needs a five minute break. That wouldn't be a problem except 20 seconds does not grind enough coffee for a full pot. This may again be due to the underpowered motor.

Overall, I think it's a good grinder but keep the shortcomings in mind before swiping that credit card.

reviews.reviewTitle: 5 stars -- after I figured out the secret!
reviews.reviewText:
I bought my Bodum grinder 11 months ago. Like most reviewers I find it easy to use, easy on the eyes, reasonably quiet and absolutely reliable so far.

Until a couple of months ago, I would have given the grinder 4 stars. My only quibble would be the jar. Though I haven't broken mine yet, it is certainly a little on the fragile side. Also, sliding the jar in and out of the grinder would always result in a few grounds being spilled onto the counter-top. Fiddling with the silicone rubber cap would often create another small spill. It's easy to throw the jar and cap into the dishwasher but cleaning them is still another minor chore to deal with.

The Secret:
Don't use the jar! A couple of months ago, it dawned on me that I could just hold the coffee filter under the grinder when I hit the button. The grounds go directly into the filter which I then transfer directly to the coffee maker. There's rarely any spillage at all in this process. Not having to deal with the jar makes a significant impact on the effort to brew a cup of coffee. This is especially appreciated on early mornings when my energy level is low.

The only time grounds escape is when I sometimes bump the grinder. This causes a few grounds which are stuck in the top around the burr to fall down to the base. This can happen whenever the jar isn't inserted.

Great coffee every time. Our old one died when a stone got caught in the gears, and so I bought a new one. There's supposed to be something that prevents a stone from destroying it, but I guess it didn't work. Tech support on that was not great, but we got a number of years of great usage from the first and hope for the same from the second.

reviews.reviewTitle: It works great as far as I am concerned
reviews.reviewText: I'm no connoisseur, bought this to go along with my first espresso machine. It works great as far as I am concerned. The finest grind setting is perfect for pulling espresso shots on my DeLonghi EC702 machine. A few grounds escape when removing the cup, but not much, much less than on other cheap grinders I have used.

Do NOT buy this product. If you lose or break the container (and you will, the glass is paper-thin), the replacements do not come with a lid, the old lid does not fit (the top of the container is now slightly wider), and coffee goes absolutely everywhere. A $100 coffee grinder, and the company is not supporting it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Coffee Beans Won't Feed Down from the Hopper
reviews.reviewText: I bought this coffee grinder on 12-27-2018 and it already doesn't want to feed the coffee beans down. They just get hung up in the hopper. Already cleaned everything out 5 times, and it still keeps happening. Maybe I just got a dud.

My first burr grinder and wow, what a difference (compared to the blade grinder). The price can vary wildly depending on color and I wasn't picky, so I snapped up the first one that fell below $70. Works like a champ and the design is great. No mess because the coffee goes right into a covered glass container. Unlike the picture, I keep my coffee in a Coffeevac to maintain freshness.

I highly recommend a burr grinder for consistency in your grind. It's a significant contributor to making great coffee. Make sure you have a scale to measure your coffee by weight (can be had for under $30), too.

Great value for money!

Won't do as fine a grind as needed for Turkish coffee, imo (which more expensive grinders can easily do).
But I use it to make Indian filter coffee, espresso, and french press, and this nifty little grinder is adjustable for all types of coarseness I require.

reviews.reviewTitle: clean, no static mess so far and a good quallity of coffe
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this because the reviews about no static, and I really hate the static (I'm a kind of psyco that touch with the elbow the doors of the cars etc.. in order to offload the static) but it is not my concern so far!

The final result is a good coffee for my Mukka Express Cappuccino, so I'm happy to share this grinder makes my coffee preparation very cool. The beans repocitory is really beautifull and makes your kitchen as a professional coffee factory. I read this grinder detects the stones in order to avoid brindger failures so it makes valuable.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great burr grinder--recommended (but the white color is beige)
reviews.reviewText: We've gotten "into" coffee lately, big-time! It started with a gift subscription of Bean Box coffee that we received (great little packets from top Seattle craft roasters; I've since bought several as gifts). We all of a sudden felt we should "up our game" and get a burr grinder, Chemex, etc.--and we've had a lot of fun tasting different coffees. When it came time to buy a burr grinder, my husband did a fair amount of research and we chose this grinder. We're very happy with it--easy to use, no problems. There is one bad thing, though: we ordered the white color, which I thought would be only slightly off-white, but is really very beige. (might be a good choice if your kitchen is dark brown and beige, but ours is bright white)

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great and does a nice job for grinding beans for ...
reviews.reviewText: Works great and does a nice job for grinding beans for French press and drip coffee makers, but I took off one star because I wish that at it's finest setting it would be sufficiently fine for espresso or Turkish coffee. At its finest setting, it's still too coarse for either of those.

This is my second Bodum Grinder. The first one was exactly the same. Like other reviews state, this won't last you forever. It did last me about 4 years with no issues. It is an awesome grinder and easy on the eyes, but it's not going to last you a lifetime.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very disappointed. Beside this failure it is also very messy
reviews.reviewText: I’ve had this grinder for a year now and it just broke. I have only used this to grind coffee beans and did not misuse it at all. Very disappointed. Beside this failure it is also very messy. The grind to the cup system is not very well engineered. The gears inside are plastic which I suspect caused the machine to break over the course of this last year. Do no waste your money, there are better grinders for $100!

Even grind and not too loud first thing in the morning :)
Had to tape the cord to the bottom of the grinder because it wouldn't sit level on the counter. Also the top cover is oval and doesn't always fit properly. It's pitch black in color with no "Front" marker to help you seat it properly, so that doesn't help. Other than these two obvious design flaws this grinder works great :)

Does a poor job of containing the grounds; I've taken to using in the sink to facilitate cleanup. The bit about the borosilicate glass container reducing static cling is nonsense.
After 8 months of use, it has started to jam occasionally on the coarsest setting, but so far twisting the hopper to a finer setting and back clears the jam.

A great step up from my old cuisinart grinder. Perfect sized grind every time!

I would buy it again, but I can't give it 5 stars for two reasons:
1) you can turn it on when the container is not present. this just makes a mess....
2) timer dial can move easily causing too strong or too weak coffee. dial can be easily moved by accident and you don't notice it until your coffee does not taste right.

reviews.reviewTitle: Everything about this product is great so far....EXCEPT....
reviews.reviewText:
Everything about this product is great so far....EXCEPT....

I use the french press setting which is to the far right. Well, once I begin grinding, the vibration of the grinder begins rotating the dial ever so slightly. And since the setting I use is at the very end, it eventually turns to a point that causes the grinder to shut off. I set the timer to 15-20 seconds, but the vibrations only allow the grinder to operate until it reaches that cutoff point, typically about 5 seconds. Love this grinder otherwise, but this is very frustrating. I'm having to hold the reservoir in place as it grinds.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good burr coffee grinder and no issue with flow and jamming
reviews.reviewText: I have had a good experience with the coffee grinder. It is well-made and has never jammed, using it almost daily for 6 months, even with more oily beans. Assembly is simple, as is adjusting the grind coarseness. This is done simply by twisting the bean hopper, which is much easier than my old grinder, which involved disassembling the whole thing. My only real problem with the grinder is that (as far as I can tell) only the outer ring of the grinder comes out, making cleaning the inner cone somewhat difficult (since it is stuck in the machine).

reviews.reviewTitle: I love the way it goes about its job relatively QUIETLY-- ...
reviews.reviewText: It's everything as advertised. The grind is perfectly even and there is no powdery residue collected at the top of the hopper, as was the case with my old Cuisinart burr grinder. The grind and time settings make it quickly adjustable to any type of coffee preparation -- my household uses both drip grind and a coffee press. I love the way it goes about its job relatively QUIETLY-- the Cuisinart would wake the household. I highly recommend this product.

This is my second Bodum Bistro grinder. My first one was used every day for 3 years and I replaced it with a Cuisineartburr grinder that drove me nuts...it was so messy. I've put it away for crowd use and I'm happily back to my Bodum. Actually this latest version is even better than the first one...not as loud.and totally reliable.

reviews.reviewTitle: and it works fine until next time
reviews.reviewText: We bought our Bodum grinder in 2011 and use it daily. It does a consistent job and has given us almost no problem. The one thing that happens every few months is that it won't grind when turned on. Apparently a coffee bean gets caught somewhere and causes the burrs to jam. Fred empties it, turns it over, and bangs it on the deck to dislodge the bean, and it works fine until next time. No other problems have occurred and it seems to give a consistent grind for our French press.

After each grind, coffee dust gets on the stainless and is very apparent. Save money and go with the black model which works just as well.

Otherwise, this is a nice grinder and cheaper than most conical burr grinders.

reviews.reviewTitle: Looks good, does a good job usually
reviews.reviewText: This appliance definitely was designed to be pleasing to look at and the matte finish is a nice touch as well. Cosmetics aside, this grinder mostly does the job when it's working. I've had no problems with most beans I've used with it so far, but there was one bag I got from Philz Coffee that gave this device issues. It would seemingly not want to grind anything as if it was clogged. And I must say that cleaning this thing is fairly messy. Anyway, I ended up finding out that merely tipping the grinder to its side and forcing the beans out of the grinder parts did the trick in getting it going again. I'll see if this continues to happen with other beans. This was my first burr grinder, and I'd say I'm pretty happy with it overall.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is excellent with two exceptions
reviews.reviewText: This is excellent with two exceptions. (1) a lot of static electricity builds up during the grinding process and grounds tend to scatter and stick to the container (2) it uses seconds to determine how much to grind per pot, but this isn't totally reliable. Lighter roasted coffees tend to grind faster so you may overdose your coffee if you only rely on time. Do a practice grind and measure whenever you change coffee to get the perfect ratio.

Got this grinder a couple of weeks ago so I cant comment on long term yet, however the grinder works perfectly for my needs. I use it on the grind that is one level courser than the setting for auto drip and the grind is perfect for my Cuisinart automatic drip machine. A 20 second grind makes about 6 cups. The machine seems very high quality and it is fairly quiet. I like having the glass rather than plastic cup. There is very little cleanup with this grinder. Everything is sealed and well contained. Easy cleanup

I don't have a lot of experience with grinders. This is my first try with one, however I doubt there is much better out there for the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does everything it claims (and brings joy to my morning)
reviews.reviewText:
Nothing beats fresh coffee from the French press -except fresh coffee from the French press when ground at home. The foam that forms at the top when the water is added to the press is supposed to be indicative of how fresh the coffee is, and w/ home ground, it's maximized -and the aroma is awesome.

The only thing stopping me from rating a full 5 stars is that I wish it were capable of a slightly coarser grind. Still it works great -far better than using off-the-shelf, both in freshness and coarseness that is desirable in the french press.

I would absolutely buy it again.
Love this thing. Previously used a Magic Bullet because I'm tight in the wallet. Decided on this product because of the grinding mechanism and the ability to course grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: I love it until it suddenly stopped working after 2 months
