reviews.reviewText: I love it until it suddenly stopped working after 2 months. I researched this issue and it seems not uncommon. My red light still comes on but the product will not come on even after solid cleaning. Frustrated! I can't see that I have done anything wrong.

Prior to getting the Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder, I used an inexpensive blade grinder to grind my beans for my french press. I thought my custom blend of beans produced a better than average cup of joe, but it wasn't always consistent. After reading about the superiority of burr grinders, decided to splurge on one. After reviewing my options and not wanting to spend an arm and a leg, went with the Bodum, which had a lot of positive reviews. To be honest, my wife and I were not prepared for the degree to which burr grinding made a difference. All I can say is, "Wow - what a revelation!" The coffee is consistently much smoother and reveals more of its complexity than our old blade grinder. For us, setting it at the next to coarsest setting, and for about 16 seconds, produces just the right amount for our 8 cup press. Like others, we appreciate that the receiving cup is glass, which minimizes "static cling". After a month or so of everyday use, we haven't found a single negative about this product!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great performance; questionable stamina (that's what she said)
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder does its job extremely well. The grind size is extremely consistent and is easily adjustable to pretty much any desired consistency. The unit as a whole is very sturdy, and there are some excellent engineering touches like the grippy rubber body and static-free grind collector.

I would give this item 5 stars, but I have a slight issue with the grind timer. Bodum recommends that you only run the motor for 20 seconds every 5 minutes. I usually grind 42g of coffee beans each time I make coffee (enough for about 20 oz. of coffee by Chemex method), and the maximum 20 second grind time seems about right for 40g. So, sometimes I can grind all the coffee I need, and sometimes I can't. I'm not a super coffee Nazi, and don't mind having the grinds sitting in the collector for 5 minutes for the next grind cycle, but sometimes I just want coffee now. Like RIGHT now.

To summarize: this thing is great. It's grinding abilities are about as good as you can find at this price point, but the grinding time limits can get a little annoying. So, as much as I'd love to aggrandize a German product (and Bodum's tea/coffee stuff is usually superb), this device gets 4 stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... reading lots of reviews I thought it was the best choice for grinding dark roast
reviews.reviewText: After reading lots of reviews I thought it was the best choice for grinding dark roast. Although I know the darker roasts are oily and gum up the gears, I didn't think it would happen so often and cleaning it is a pain. It's also incredibly messy after grinding - coffee kinda of gets all over the place.

Likes:
* Looks nice
* Glass container for the grounds
* Relatively Quiet

Dislikes:
* Still get plenty of dust in my French press grind (grr)
* The hopper lid is awkward and should be redesigned

Overall, it's a nice entry level burr grinder. If I had the money, I'd buy a better one but this works well. I've been using it for a year or two now with no major issues.

Does a great job. I was using a manual grinder before I bought this only because I didn't want to use a loud appliance in the morning. I'm usually the first one awake. This one is not quiet, but it's not too bad. Haven't used others so I can't compare. Otherwise, it looks nice and does the job. Be careful attaching the top to the base. This is a bit confusing and it looks like you could damage the plastic if it was forced.
If you want a big mess buy this!

i'm not a nose in the air coffee person, but I CAN APPRECIATE a very good cup of coffee.
i mostly order special beans. either mail order or from locals that have very fresh product.
i don't do expresso, but i will use my french press setting, and a press when i have time. and yes, i can appreciate what pressing can bring to the cup, as opposed to drip.

i've had this grinder for quite some time now, and i absolutely love it! it has always worked perfectly for me. i love the compactness and small footprint. and i don't like to, nor do i have any need to load a huge bean hopper full of a weeks worth of beans, because i like to store my beans in a vacuum to keep them fresh. i also change coffees every few days anyway just to keep things fun.
the unit is pretty quite compared to others i've used and heard. and it rarely leaves grinds in the grinding chamber, unless the beans have more residual moisture then others. and if that's the case, i just lift the whole unit up a bit off the counter and gently bump it down to dislodge and stuck grinds.
SO IT'S A FIVE STAR FOR ME!!!

I used a Krups grinder for years with no complaint. It finally gave up the ghost so I bought a new one. Krups changed the design, however, and though better looking it made such a mess that, despite preferring to use things until they're defunct, I bought this one. I love it. The grind is even. The amount you grind is very easy to control. It is relatively clean.
Searched for a burr grinder w/glass output bowl. Got what I wanted. VERY happy after 2 years. Have gifted copies to friends.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for Coffee Lovers on a Budget
reviews.reviewText:
I love my coffee, but I'm not a coffee pro or a coffee geek. After hearing and reading all of the pluses to grinding your coffee beans just prior to brewing I began searching for a grinder to meet my "entry level" needs and budget. Having read that blade grinders are inexpensive yet inconsistant and burr grinders being the "best", I began searching different sites and types. Deciding a conical burr grinder was my wish list item, I checked Amazon to see what was available and compare prices.

I chose the Bodium Bistro in Red. Bodium, because I've used their products before and have been pleased and, because the price was the best for a conical burr grinder on a limited budget. It's fairly easy to figure out how to use. As thick as the instruction book is, it leaves something to be desired. It tells what the parts are, what the symbols mean and that is it.... in a ton of different languages It doesn't explain length of time grinding or have any such tips. The good thing, the grinder is easy enough to figure out and much can be learned by trial and error.

It's quiet for an appliance that grinds, clean up is not difficult, consistency of grind is good, it's sturdy, larger than I expected, but not overwhelmingly so and in red, <grin> it's pretty. I am pleased.

I am so happy with this grinder, wish I'd bought it sooner! It provides a nice even grind and it pretty quiet (I have two small kids who nap while I want coffee). It looks good on the counter. I love the small container the grinds fall in to, very easy to work with. I haven't had an issue with grinds building up in the machine as other reviewers have, but I don't use the finest grind setting. I doubt this would be suitable for espresso as it'd be difficult to get the setting just right. It tends to get bumped somehow and I must reset the grind often. This is not at all an issue for drip coffee but I'm not sure it has the precision required for espresso. That being said, I haven't actually tried to use if for my espresso machine. I would highly recommend this grinder!

Pros: Excellent coffee grinder overall. Offers a consistent grind, is very fast, and quiet relative to other coffee makers I've had in the past.

Cons: The grind container is relatively small, regularly spills grind dust on the counter when transferring, cannot store beans in hopper if switching between grind sizes often.

Would recommend overall, but especially be aware of the spillage and switching concerns.

I did some research before buying this product, and my only concern was that it wouldn't perform as described. I'm happy to say it does. The half a bag of beans container nicely balances the hassle of filling it up with the need for an every day fresh grind. I like the quiet motor, and the lack of any mess ( I think the rubberized top and its fit on top of the ground coffee account for that}. Contrary to criticism of some, I think the 20 second timer is spot on for my needs, and I never have had to run it twice to get a needed amount of coffee.
This product is easy to use, easy to clean and is one half of why I'm enjoying the best home made cup of coffee in my life.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Burr grinder but breaks easiely.
reviews.reviewText: Great little machine but the burr blade holder came loose and now it will not go back in nor grind coffee.
We bought this grinder in April of 2012, and almost seven years later it's still going strong! Isn't it nice to buy something once, in good faith, and have it last?

reviews.reviewTitle: No idea why people complain so much
reviews.reviewText:
It is so frustrating when you're trying to choose an item like, say, a coffee burr grinder, and the reviews are:

- Awesome, best ever, 5 Stars!
- Piece of crap, don't buy! 1 Star.
- This makes the finest cup of coffee and no burrs all over my counter! 5 Stars!
- This thing makes a total mess and my coffee tastes like crap! 1 Star.

etc. etc.

So here's one more to confuse the hell out of you:

I love this little guy. It's not too big, it makes no mess at all, the grinds are great, and one more thing: I almost didn't buy it because someone (erroneously) wrote in their review that you can only grind for 20 seconds every 5 minutes. Well, it does recommend in the manual that you let it sit for 5 minutes between grinds, but you don't have to if you don't want to. 20 seconds seems like enough to make a big pot of coffee, especially because this little guy is pretty fast at grinding, but if you need more, just hit the start button again and it will do it again. I have not tried to do this more than twice as I have no need to grind a giant quantity of coffee. I suppose that like with all grinders this big, you probably don't want to do that because the grinding cones will get hot and affect the taste of the coffee.

So overall, just get it if you like the way it looks. I did because it was the only one at this price range that had a glass container, and now I grind my coffee fresh every day because it's so damn easy to use and clean.
Looks great and works great. However, actuator button completely broke after only 4 months of use. Very disappointed. Very cheaply made.

This grinder gives you a wide range of grind size, keeps the chaff produced to a minimum, is fast, and is (relative to other grinders) somewhat quiet.

My one drawback is that it will let you grind even if there is no hopper to catch the grinds, or the hopper is not attached correctly. This can lead to some spills.

However you would need to spend a lot more money to find a better grinder

We use this to grind for stovetop espresso. The ground coffee gets clogged inside the grinder very frequently, which causes the grinder to malfunction. It's very messy to take apart and dig out all the jammed grounds out of the machine. It's very irritating to do this several times a month. I would not recommend this grinder at all. I'm looking for a replacement.

Purchased this years ago and still using it! It comes in a lot of colors and small enough to leave out on the counter.
I've broken the glass piece once and it was not exactly easy to replace. Bodum is hard to get a hold of, then the first time they shipped it, it was unwrapped and slipped into an envelope. Arrived in shards. It was that ridiculous I had to laugh.
I'd probably order another cup to have on hand just in case. It won't be a waste.

I have had the grinder for 4 months and it was working great until yesterday and then it started to make a louder noise and the power light went out. I called Bodem and they told me to send them an email with my receipt at sales@bodum.com and they would send me a new one. There is a 2 year warrenty on the motor. I will update if they do not replace.

They reason I gave it 4 stars is because the coffee grounds make a mess because of the static, but I am going to try slapping the unit on both sides as it says in one of the other reviews.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... this grinder was a bit expensive I am very happy with it
reviews.reviewText: Although this grinder was a bit expensive I am very happy with it. It fits nicely on my counter and is very easy to use. It doesn't make a mess at all compared to the mini grinders. It evenly grinds just the right amount of coffee for one serving every morning. The glass container is easy to open and close and doesn't spill coffee grinds all over the counter. Overall I am satisfied with my purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: A dream machine in all ways
reviews.reviewText:
When I first unwrapped this coffee grinder and checked out its little parts, I had the same happy chill I had on seeing my first iPad. Esthetically, it's a total pleasure to look at and feel.
Bonus, it is stunningly easy to operate and makes such fine coffee for my French press, I could not be more delighted.
I see it as a little work of art that does what it was designed to do while being a feast for the eye. Why not?

I purchased this item on November 30th, which means I rec'd it sometime in early December. As of about 2 days ago, April 3, 2012, the motor has all but completely died. I'm not sure if this product has a problem with clogging (I grind on the 4th finest notch) or if it's just this one unit that is defective. I've had two other coffee grinders of this type in the last 12 years, both lasted approx 5-6 years. And I only grind about 1/8 lb. per week, enough to brew one cup per day for the week. So, it's not as if I'm overusing it or pushing it to the limit. Now, Amazon is telling me the return expiration date for this product was Jan. 31st, 2012--just 2 months after the purchase date. I'm not at all happy with Bodum or with Amazon. For the price of this grinder and the reputation of the name,Bodum, I expected better back-up of the product. Since I can't return it to Amazon, I suppose I'll have to try getting Bodum to replace the unit. Somehow, I get the feeling I'll be confronted with another brick wall since I didn't purchase their product directly from them. We'll see.... :-/Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder, Black

reviews.reviewTitle: First one didn't work. Second one fine after 3 months of daily use
reviews.reviewText:
The first one of these we got would show the power light on, but "light's on, no one home" was the result. We sent it right back and got a replacement. Everything about the replacement unit is good, however it is quite loud. My wife who is an early riser grinds the coffee the night before so she doesn't wake everyone in the house who are still sleeping on the second floor.

Consistent grind and ease of use is what is important, however, and this unit does both well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Let's be honest, it looks better
reviews.reviewText:
Excellent grinder. Looks incredible. Very easy to clean. Timer function is wonderful. Any grinder is noisy, this one isn't bad.

I use this for brewing on the V60 and Chemex platforms, and this grinder sure does the trick. Got a much nicer bloom, and much more even grounds from this grinder than my older Cuisinart burr grinder. Did a side-by-side taste comparison with this grinder and a friends Baratza Encore, got equal results.

I use this thing a minimum of once a day, and it works great every time. No criticisms.

I had a DeLonghi grinder for years and it finally just quit. I researched different brands and types of grinders and decided that for my use, a conical burr grinder for a reasonable price was the way to go. I read reviews and this one was very reasonable when compared to other conical burr grinders and had favorable reviews - with only one negative mentioned and that was the timer being limited to 20 seconds. I make a small pot, so decided to take the chance and am not disappointed. I can make a full, large pot with the coffee that is ground in the 20 seconds, it is evenly ground, quickly and quietly when compared to my old grinder. A big thumbs up! I love it and love the red sitting on my kitchen counter, too.

reviews.reviewTitle: Failed after 3 years of daily use.
reviews.reviewText: The grinder stopped feeding beans after about 3 years of daily use. It takes about 1 minute to grind 20g of beans which is very very slow. I would recommend the Baratza Encore if you are looking for a burr grinder.

Perfectly grinds the beans for my daily coffee the way it's supposed to be. Fresh ground coffe maintains its essencial oils up to the moment when it meets hot water, resulting in a full favor beverage without artificial flavors added by some brands of ground coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: White turned sticky and yellow within a year
reviews.reviewText: I really liked this grinder. I probably would have kept using it until it broke, but the white version has turned yellow and sticky with that degraded-rubber coating rot that some products get. It's so gross. I feel like i'm throwing away $100 replacing it. Maybe other colors don't get sticky and gross in a few years. Other than that, the grind is acceptable, it's a little loud, and the look is better than most professional looking devices.

It takes a little bit to learn the nuances of the machine, but once you figure out ratios and quantities and the time it takes to grind specific amounts, it proves to be a very quality burr grinder. The grounds are much more uniformly-sized than my old blade grinder. Better quality coffee grounds lead to better tasting quality. Highly recommended.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good Grinder - Especially for the Price
reviews.reviewText: Does the job. Great for small batches, but if you have to grind a lot of coffee, it can be a bit of a pain. The glass container and rubber top tend to hold ground coffee, so they have to be tapped to get everything out. But in all it is a really good, little grinder.

Overall this is a great grinder.

Pros
Looks good - so my gf lets it stay out on the counter
High quality steel conical grinder parts
Well put together and thought out
Easy adjustments to time and grind size

Cons (just being picky)
The matte finish is like static cling for coffee grounds
The glass container is nice, but the plastic top is also a ground magnet - it gets all over the top and eventually your counter
The grounds make their way into the dial on the top for setting time - not usually a problem you just turn it over and rotate during cleaning, but a sealed knob would be great

This works very well with Keurig k-cups. The opening for the grinds is just a bit smaller than a reusable k-cup, the settings are short enough to not over-fill. It can also be manually timed by just holding the start button down.

Otherwise it seems to work as expected from a burr grinder.

Great grinder. The years will tell how well it lasts considering its design is similar to my previous one that broke.
It is almost impossible removing the glass receptacle without spilling ground coffee, even after slapping it on the side a bit to loosen grounds left in the grinder.

Purchased this coffee grinder 1/2011 and enjoyed it for 2 years. Then it started to not grind on the finer setting. Then it stopped grinding at all. Took it all apart, cleaned it, etc. The motor works, it just doesn't grind coffee beans.
Contacted Bodum by email asking for service info. No response. Contacted Bodum by telephone and was told that they do not service their products. No kidding. If the product is in warranty, they'll replace it with a comparable product. This one, of course, was 2 months outside of warranty.
So I paid over $50 per year to grind coffee beans. It's a nice looking grinder, but I don't have room on my kitchen counter for a cute decoration.
In the end, I feel that it was way too expensive for the 2 years that it worked, and that the Bodum brand is not one that I will purchase in the future.

Very pleased with this product. I use this to grind for an espresso machine, a delonghi EC 155, and a drip, Bunn HG Phase Brew, and it grinds for both flawlessly. Simple to use and clean and almost ZERO coffee dust! This grinder is really worth the price tag. If you're planning on spending less on a grinder save your money and have your local coffee shop grind your beans for you. Cheaper grinders produce too much coffee dust (resulting in a bitter cup) or cannot grind fine enough or consistenly enough.

Like most of the reviews on here, I am very impressed with the consistency of the grind produced by this grinder. It is MUCH better than the blade grinder I own. The grinder is attractive on the countertop, relatively quite, easy to operate, and mess-free. The glass receptacle is also a nice touch, compared to the plastic ones offered by other grinders in this price range. My only complaint is that this grinder is primarily aimed at people that use drip-machines. In other words, the finest grind is not really fine enough for espresso, and the coarsest grind is not as coarse as desired for french press. I am primarily a french press drinker, and the grind is manageable (the plunger is not terribly difficult to press down), but typical brew times need to be shortened to get an equivalent taste. Overall though, I'm much happier with this grinder than my old blade grinder, the coffee is noticeably better, and I would definitely recommend it to others!

Works well and looks good sitting on the counter.
I wish it had automatic shut-off based on motor load, so when it senses no more beans are being ground, then it shuts off after a second or so.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grind...but leaves a mess behind
reviews.reviewText: Grinds great....but leaves a huge mess behind. Grounds all over the counter as you remove the carafe. Tried to find solutions because I do like the grind, but sadly, none were found and we just missed the return window. Now have an $80 paper weight. :(

The best grinder I've had. (Not wanting to spend over $100) Love the adjustments I can make with this. My coffee tastes so much better using this grinder. I had a hand burr grinder that could not grind coarse to save its soul. This one - perfect in seconds!

After struggling with a hand burr grinder but being impressed with the resulting coffee, I broke down and invested in this electric burr grinder. The results have been wonderful, and once you find a setting that works for you, you can leave the grinder at that setting, for consistent results. I purchased the black version and it's very attractive with the red highlights. Besides the price, the size of this item appealed to me, taking up less counter space than many burr grinders. FYI: replacement glass containers can be purchased on the Bodum website.

I've had this grinder for 18 months now and use it once daily. What used to take 25 seconds to grind, now takes 60 seconds, so something has gone wrong. Of course, their warranty is 1-year. And no way to call them. Also, this grinder is super loud.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good everyday burr grinder with some very good features.
reviews.reviewText:
This a the 3rd burr grinder from Bodum I have purchased. My last two( an older Bistro and Antigua) reside at my office and still are operating under heavy use.
The glass collecting container does indeed work well to reduce static for those dark roast coffees which will translate to less cleaning up after the grind.
I also appreciate the rubberized surface on the main housing and on the glass collector as I am known to be a bit of a clutz.
The primary power switch and the instant on/off switch paired with a timer switch are a good combo. No longer will I grind way too much and have to pull the power plug for it to stop as with past models.
The grind seems to be consistent for espresso through French press grades, though I find the espresso (extreme left setting) in all of my Bodums seems too fine.
Hopefully this new Bistro will have the longevity of the previous burr grinder models.

reviews.reviewTitle: so good! Grinds beautifully to our specifications
reviews.reviewText: So far, so good! Grinds beautifully to our specifications. The glass container which catches the grounds does not have a static charge like my previous brand's plastic one. It has a rubber-like gasket lid. It doesn't make a mess! - it has a timer (20 sec, max)which yields about 4-6 cups worth of ground coffee. I like my coffee strong, so it usually gets another 5 second run.

Some of the reviews and the directions for use scared me at first but I am glad I bought this grinder. It works well, a little different in the button and measuring mechanics from your typical grinders. You will have to run 2 grinds for larger pots of coffee. I have only done this once and did not have any overheating issues. For my daily 2-3 cups its perfect. And best of all no static! Once again no static! You won't have grinds all over your counter and sticking to the everything. The size of the grinder is nice too, it's not to bulky on the the countertop.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'm glad I found this grinder
reviews.reviewText: I had a few bad experiences with other grinders before using this one at a friends house. I bought one for myself and I couldn't be happier. Its a little loud, but it WORKS. The other grinders I bough failed within 30 days!! (I brew a pot a day).

So far, so good! I've used it for the first time this morning and put it on the most coarse setting available (for a french press). It seemed to work beautifully. The grind size did not plug up my french press nor was it too small and get grinds into my coffee.

This thing works great and produces a Extremely Consistent Grind! I was amazed at how well it grinds. I have had local coffee shoppes grind mine before and to be honest was very disappointed with the result but this thing easily out does any grinder I have been exposed to.

I am using it for my presso espresso maker and love it. It grinds perfect for it and they make a great pair. The timer is also great because it acts as a dose meter for just the right amount of coffee each time. simply love it.

First, the bad. As others have noted, the switch feels flimsy, and the whole 20 second time limit deal... what can I say about that? 20 seconds is probably sufficient really, if this thing didn't get its clock from some alternate universe. Counting the seconds in my head, and hitting the button again every time it stops after 1 to 8 seconds, makes enough grounds for 8 cups ground slightly finer than the middle setting - which is perfect for my maker. It's not that loud, it grinds coffee very well, and will grind it anywhere from coarse to talcum powder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love it! My first burr grinder and it works ...
reviews.reviewText: Love it! My first burr grinder and it works great. Like the other reviewers have mentioned, it gives off a great just-ground coffee aroma. There is static cling on the glass cup and cover, but easy to rinse and dry. Not a big deal for me. Easy to fill and use. Makes great grinds that even I have been able to tell the difference, and I'm not a barista or coffee snob.

I'm a self-described coffee aficionado, so it was time to get a nice burr grinder. Very happy with this Bodum. Absolutely enhances flavor profiles of my bulletproof coffee vs. a blade grinder. It's not even as loud as the blade grinder. Get this item!

reviews.reviewTitle: Only used two days so far but very pleased
reviews.reviewText:
It seems to be very high quality. Grinds coffee perfect. A little static but grounds don't go everywhere. Is fairly quiet. The white I ordered is kind of an almond color though so does not match the rest of the white kitchen appliances exactly. Overall very happy so far and if it lasts a long time would buy another.

Edit: Well, It's now May of 2015 and grinder is still going strong. Must be made very well. Used 2 or 3 times a day now for years and works the same as day-1. Some brands of coffee are more prone to static than others. Adjusting the fineness of the grind can help that issue some.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quick and clean, but could use a coarser max grind
reviews.reviewText:
This device is nice, quick, and clean. Having used several other of the $100-200 burr grinders, I've had trouble with the wasteage of grounds. This device has no such troubles. If you are mainly using it to grind for drip +/- a bit, you will be very happy with it.

I also have french press often, and I've found that the maximum coarseness setting is not quite large enough for use with my Bodum 3-cup press. I get significantly more ground pass-through with this than with the french press grind setting from a commercial burr grinder.

I waited to do a review for this grinder, so I could see how well it worked and how long it lasted. I have had my grinder for about a year now and it still works like a charm. I love this grinder! I like that it holds quite a few beans for future use. It works well if you follow the grinding instructions enclosed. For me, it is not messy at all. I have had grinders in the past that made a huge mess, but not this one. I have had no problems with it whatsoever. For the price, it is a nice burr grinder and makes great coffee.
Love this little thing. Works super well and actually uses burrs to grind your coffee instead of claiming to be a burr grinder and using blades.

I thought I was investing in a product that I would have for sometime. The grinder was not able to grind for a French press brew. Regardless of range it came out the same. It has never been the smooth working product I hoped for or thought it would be. Today, it totally wouldn't grind at all. I purchased this on October 17, 2013 so it worked about a whopping 6 months. There is no return on this item. Very disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: A few flaws in an otherwise good product...
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this grinder because I was looking for a simple, electric burr grinder. At home I have the Breville BCG450XL, but I wanted to try a slightly cheaper option for the office so I got this grinder. It produces a consistent grind as I expect from a burr grinder, which is good. However, it has several downsides:

One significant annoyance is that all of the ground coffee doesn't drop into the catcher -- there's usually a little left in the machine which falls out after you've removed the catcher. The end result is that there are always bits of ground coffee beans on my counter.

Another annoyance is that some of the grounds always stick to the walls of the glass catcher. With the plastic catcher of the Breville grinder, this never happens.

Finally, as others have noted, it can only run for 20 seconds as a time (which isn't usually a problem for me personally).

Overall, I would say that this grinder is not worth the ~$20 savings compared to the Breville grinder. I would suggest that grinder instead.

I've been using this machine for almost 2 years. Grinding coffee for 2 people every morning. Build quality and construction is excellent. I try not to ever let the machine run without coffee going through the grinder. The machine is loud but not as loud as the previous blade grinders I've owned. I hope this machine provides many more years of service. I highly recommend it!

reviews.reviewTitle: I've had a few and they have only lasted a couple years
reviews.reviewText: Good grinder for the money but they don't last as long as I would like.

Bottom Line:
-I am getting into coffee.
-You need a burr grinder to get into coffee.
-This one works great, has multiple grind settings, provides a consistent grind for each setting, isn't too expensive, and looks good (at least as far as appliances go).
-Buy it!

Con:
-Only con is some of the coffee "sticks" to the bottom sides of the glass grind container.
-If you always want fresh grinds, you are constantly having to rinse that cup out after every grind.
-For the plus sides of the appliance I deal with it, and you most likely will too.

Any questions just let me know.

reviews.reviewTitle: Big difference from a blade grinder
reviews.reviewText: For years I have been using a Braun blade grinder. On a whim (and at a very discounted price) I bought this burr grinder and I'm amazed at the difference. The drip coffee I make seems richer and tastier grinding the beans through this machine. Also find I need to use way less coffee then before. Still haven't tried espresso yet but will soon. The enclosed directions could be better but it's a pretty straight forward machine to operate. Since this is the only burr grinder I have ever owned I cannot compare it to others.

I like my coffee and roast my own beans. I'm the only coffee drinker in my house, and have been using the Bistro daily for 5 years now. It usually takes a couple 20 second cycles to grind the beans for a large mug of pour-over coffee, and I don't wait between cycles as recommended. Yet I haven't burned out the motor. Easy to clean, well made. Ground coffee doesn't stick to the grinder. Every so often I think I should upgrade to a better grinder, and will read reviews of other grinders on Amazon, but then decide there is no need. Still happy with the Bistro...

I had been shopping for a new burr grinder for my husband to replace the Capresso we had for almost 7 years. While we liked the grind of the Capresso, the mess it made was very frustrating and we decided to look for another brand. I was hesitant when I purchased the Bodum grinder, as many had complained about the small amount of grinds it produced in one setting. However, we could not have been more pleased! While the grinder only grinds for 20 seconds, it is sufficient for a full 12-cup pot of coffee (and my husband likes it strong). The grinder is infinitely more quiet than the Capresso, and the ingenious design of the glass container greatly reduces static cling and leaves virtually no mess. Overall, we are very satisfied!

We now get a finer grind than does Fairway's commercial grinder! For this price range, I'm impressed with the eveness of the grind. Also, I appreciate the small amount of static - due to the glass beaker...as well as the the lack of mess to clean up. The burrs clean easily with either rice or a medium bristle tooth brush. If this machine lasts the test of time, then it's an outstanding buy.

awesome and good looking grinder! I still get 'static' grinds on the glass (some other reviewers claimed no static) but I've yet to own a grinder that does't cause static... grinds accurately and looks great on my counter:) I've been through many grinders over the years and am very happy with this one. Now we will see how long it lasts!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder after doing the mods
reviews.reviewText:
Since the reviews are so mixed for this grinder, I resolved try it as is, and if it gave me trouble I'd try the mods I read about here. Out of the box it's just ok; a bit loud but not bothersome if everyone's up. My biggest complaint is the mess it makes. Grinds spew out all over the counter, stick by static cling to the inside and outside of the jar; it's next to impossible to get all the coffee out of the jar and into the pot.

So, I came back looking for the instructions to do the mods and for the life of me, I can't find the post I originally read about it. As best I could recall it involved tracing a part and cutting out a shim out of business card stock. I disassembled the grinder and found a metal plate that looked like a likely candidate. The plate was too big for a business card so I cut it out of a manila folder, poked all my holes and reassembled the grinder. There were three screws that hold the grinder assembly to the plastic housing and I could only get one of them back in. As long as that one screw was tight, it didn't look like it would drastically affect anything so I left the other two out.

Plugged it in, loaded it up, switched it on and held my breath ... WOW!!! It works enormously better! It's a bit quieter, and the sound is more ... I dunno ... it sounds better engineered, I can't quite describe the difference. And the finest grind setting is powdery, consistent, aromatic, and it doesn't fly around the counter, it doesn't cling to the jar, it doesn't leak out of the grinder in a pile after removing the jar.

If I'd been working instead of tinkering with this all afternoon, my consulting billing rate would have purchased a $300 grinder, but I don't think it would have been such a satisfying experience.

My thoughts are that these things are inconsistently assembled at the factory - some of them work right, some don't. If you get the good one, wonderful. If not, get out the screwdriver and exacto knife and have some fun!

Didn't last beyond one year. I'm a pretty serious coffee drinker- and I'm very handy. These consumer grinders are not serviceable so I bought an expensive commercial grinder. Pretty much what you'll see at a coffee shops. Love it. I keep it in the basement cuz it's so big. Also, if it breaks, part are available.

I can go on about this: consumer products like this Bodum grinder are built as cheap as possible. I don't fault them, I guess. That's what consumers want: inexpensive. Typically this all works out, but coffee is complicated. Too fine of a grind and the filter clogs and spills over. Too course and you miss out on flavor, or use too much coffee. So, a burr grinder is a must. $100 is not enough money to get you a durable burr grinder. I found a used commercial machine for $325, retail of $900. It's dreamy. It's a beast. It does exactly what I want and does it well. I looked and I know I can get a new power supply, a new grind wheel, a new power switch, any part. Love that.

reviews.reviewTitle: last year he was convince that the best way to grind coffee was using a manual grinder
reviews.reviewText: My husband is a purist of coffee, last year he was convince that the best way to grind coffee was using a manual grinder, yes a manual grinder, it took 10 min to prepare a cup of coffee, with after doing it for almost 2 years he decided to research for a most effective way. Voila! this is the best grinder for a modest budget.

Grinder is easy to use, grind quality is excellent, and the metal collector dish is much better than the plastic dish that comes with most other grinders. This is an upgrade for me from an old cuisinart burr grinder that finally gave up the ghost, and I am very happy with the purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: Unfortunately, it can't grind very fine.
reviews.reviewText: I guess you get what you pay for when you choose a cheaper grinder. My Bodum burr grinder will not grind finer than the pourover setting without getting stuck and stripping the gears. It's really disappointing to have spent this much money on something for it to not get the job done.

Most bang for your buck. I don't need 500 different grinds- several, but not more than 10. It is super easy to use. I purchased it on the advice of a coworker when I was done with basic electric grinders and wanted to switch to a burr grinder for consistent grinds. I am not disappointed!

When my old coffee bean grinder died I did a bit of research to find out what kind of grinder is recommended for a french press coffee pot. The burr grinder won hands down. This grinder works as it should and helps me make a really good pot of coffee. The price is right and the size is perfect. Highly recommended.

This is the first electric grinder I've bought since getting into higher-end coffee prep at home. It has a good range of settings for adjusting the grind, and I've never had any issues with it. It is a little hard to clean the inside, but I think that comes with the territory.
If your significant other grinds their own coffee beans _every morning_, then buy this. You will score MAGOR POINTS which will be redeemed at bedtime. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

this machine lasts just as long as the warranty and the company does not do repairs. my wife liked it...while it lasted. myself? I found it miserable when it comes to leaving dust in the machine!!! give me 3 small hand held grinders and with no dust after grinding I will be happy. the machine is not made to last. plus the company is frivolous and doesn't do repairs. give me a break for the money it is just not worth the cost of two or three small hand grinders.

We have been pleased with our little grinder! The coffee is evenly ground and tastes delicious! The sound is about what you expect from a grinder. Not the quietest and not the loudest. We've been pleased with it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke after few months of use
reviews.reviewText: The machine worked fine for 6 months and then its just gave up. The motor stopped working and its just a display piece sitting in the corner. I tried to reach out to Bodum and its been a week and still no response. Their customer service is horrible and the 3rd party support center reps dont give a f@#$ about your service.

Never had a coffee grinder until this one... love it. Once you get the coarseness and time set... easy as pie. Normally have it set for about 10 seconds with the coarseness we like best and every morning just hit the button and it kicks out the perfect amount of coffee for the pot... love it.

UPDATE: December 2015
My grinder just died on me. I bought it June 2001 so it lasted me for about 4.5 years of daily use (using it between 4 and 5 times per day). It still grinds however the coarseness can no longer be set and it grinds everything very fine regardless of how I have it set. I opted to replace this one with a Breville BCG820BSSXL The Smart Grinder Pro Coffee Bean Grinder, Brushed Stainless Steel. It's a big bump up in price however I decided that this was something I wanted to try (after much research).
I still think highly of the Bodum Bistro (I even just bought my son one for Christmas in 2015). It served me well and did a great job grinding my beans.

I have thus far been using a blade grinder to grind my beans. I had been using a drip coffee machine but have since migrated to the Aerobie Aeropress to brew my coffee. I had read a lot of reviews about the burr coffee grinders and was preparing to spend up to $200.00 for a good one. I wound up reading the reviews of this grinder and saw that there were many reviews and they were for the most part, highly positive. So, I ordered this and it arrived within a couple of days. I could not be happier with the results! Here are my observations:

- Very consistent grind. I noticed some people complaining about this but I have had no issues at all. I suppose there may be some irregularities now and then but none that I have observed.
- Very clean. I read that there is often an issue with the static charge buildup on the coffee grounds when using this type of grinder. I have not had any issues with mess.
- Simple to use. Set the grind type, pour in some beans, power it on, set the timer, press button to start / stop. The timer makes sense as it prevents the grinder from running too long if it gets turned on accidentally some how.
- Not too noisy. It's certainly quieter than my blade grinder. I don't know how it compares to other burr grinders however I have no complaints about the noise level.

- I noticed that for three scoops of coffee that it takes about 25 seconds to fully grind. This is how much coffee I use for a venti sized cup of coffee. It's no problem as I simply push the button to run it again and push to turn it off once all of the coffee has been ground. I imagine that this is also affected by how fine the grind is set for.
- I am easily able to transfer the coffee from the container to my Aeropress without taking the lid off. I place the container on my Aeropress and tap to get all of the coffee out.

I do strongly urge you to try this if you are in the market for a burr coffee grinder. The price and performance are excellent!

reviews.reviewTitle: Major static creates a nasty mess with every grind
reviews.reviewText: Does a good job grinding and pretty consistent but the amount of static is ridiculous. Automatic grinders often have issues with static, this is nothing new, but this one produces worse static than some others I've used. Also be prepared for a lot of noise - nature of the beast with an auto but boy it is loud.

This is the first grinder I've used that's over $30 and it is SO worth it. I know that a good quality grinder is one of the biggest indicators of how your coffee product will taste, but honestly, I don't think it can get much better than this.

Some reviewers complained that 20 seconds wasn't long enough to give them enough ground coffee but I don't have that problem. I set the time for 5 seconds and that is the perfect amount for my double shot in my DeLonghi espresso machine. I have it set to the third from smallest grind which seems to be great for my machine.

It's fast, relatively quiet, and grinds evenly and consistently. I love that the container is glass so there's not a static issue (there's a rubbery piece that goes over top of it that a few grinds can cling to, but this hasn't been a big deal to me).

This is a great machine but one of the messiest grinders I have ever used. There is always mess after every use. Every time you remove the container of fresh grinds to use there is spillage and coffee dust. And the glass container still gets static. That said it works great and looks good on my counter. Would recommend but keep a rag close by for wipes

reviews.reviewTitle: We've had ours for several years now and love it, we use it every day
reviews.reviewText: We've had ours for several years now and love it, we use it every day. Sometimes we have to play with the size of the grind before it will grind but it has worked every time.
Same as others, after two years it died.
very good product. consistent grind, easy to use, not too noisy, wish had longer cycle but not too inconvenient.

reviews.reviewTitle: This definitely produces very fine powdery type espresso
reviews.reviewText: I bought this specifically for my espresso machine. This definitely produces very fine powdery type espresso. I also use it for coffee beans just by rotating the top, you change the consistency of the grind. This was the cheapest burr grinder I could find that works well with espresso beans. Highly recommended if you're looking for an espresso style grinder.

This replaces our former burr grinder from another company. While the other was cranky and unpredictable in whether or not it would work, this one has been great! Much less mess than the previous grinder as well. Easy to control and to clean. Highly recommend!

i am now drinking the best cup of cappuccino that i have ever made! i brew my espresso with a stove-top style espresso maker, and getting the right grind for it took a couple of tries. the finest setting on the bodum bistro grinder proved to be TOO fine for the stove-top espresso maker. but half way between the finest and the medium setting, seems to be about right.

i only make a couple shots of espresso at a time, so i only need 2 tablespoons of ground coffee. i set the timer on the the bodum for about 10-15 seconds and it make plenty of ground coffee for my espresso maker. however, if you need to make a lot of coffee, say for a house full of people, this might not be the grinder for you, as the catch cup is not really large.

please note: the instructions say ONLY CHANGE THE GRIND SETTING WHILE THE MOTOR IS RUNNING. not sure why that is. i wish bodum would explain why. that would help me remember to follow this instruction.

overall, great brinder so far. love the coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: EXCELLENT GRINDER - YOU WILL LOVE IT!
reviews.reviewText: What a great grinder! I drink a lot of coffee and grind French Roast or Italian Roast (oily from the roasting process) beans at least twice a day, and this Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Grinder works perfectly! It is easy to use, the ground coffee falls smoothly into the glass storage container, and the glass storage container minimizes the static so that the ground coffee doesn't fly all around the counter. True, I've only had this grinder two weeks, but it is by far the best grinder I've used. Bravo, Bodum!

LOVELOVELOVE this grinder! My son was the one who suggested it. I had issues with the first one they sent and they sent me a new one right away. I returned the defective one. YES...I would definitely buy again, definitely well worth the money!
This grinder delivers the exact grind density you require. Strong motor, easy to clean

reviews.reviewTitle: It grinds coffee great but the one feature that drew me most to ...
reviews.reviewText: It grinds coffee great but the one feature that drew me most to it was that the glass would have less static electricity but it actually has way more than I have ever experienced. You have to tap and shake the glass coffee holder to get the coffee out and it still statically clings to the entire glass surface. This is annoying but it still does grind coffee very well.
Used this grinder about 100 times over the course of 1 year and 3 months and it quit working. We aren't everyday coffee drinkers so we really expected this to last a few years. Very disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Solid grinder that lasted over 5 years
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this several years ago and use it daily. It produces a consistent grinds for both French press and my automatic drip machine. The only downside (which causes the 4 out of 5 stars) is that you have to kind of tap the lid and bang the side to get all the coffee out of the shoot after grinding. Also, after 4.5 years, the plastic part that holds the upper grinding ring broke, but a phone call to Bodum and I had a new, free grinding ring a week later. I would have purchased one (the plastic part), but they don't sell it. Regardless, they get a big thumbs up for service - I would not have been very happy if I needed to purchase a new grinder over a piece of replaceable plastic.

As for cleaning, it's pretty easy to take everything apart and clean out old coffee residue.

On a side note, I don't know why they make the hoppers so big on these devices. It's generally not recommended to store coffee beans in the hopper (I only use ~1/4 cup of beans for a 3 cups in a 4-cup Mr. Coffee machine).

Update: May 2016
After nearly 5.5 years of near daily grinding (1/4 cup of beans, once a day), the motor seems to be in its death throws. Whenever I press the button to grind, it grinds for maybe a second before shutting off. It even does this when empty and after cleaning it out. I suspect something has finally gone wrong on the inner parts. So, this grinder is being retired after its faithful service and being replaced with a Capresso Infinity 560.01 (because it was a little cheaper, but also gets very high marks).

I also noticed that the replacement upper grinding ring has some issue. The plastic ring that holds it looks like it's supposed to clip in place, but one of the clips is bent, so coffee grinds can get between the plastic and the upper part of the ring. Overall, it seems like a design flaw on how that ring is designed.
This replaces one that had served me well grinding espresso fine coffee for a decade or more. All around great device.

The grinder is surprisingly nice. I've had for about a year and a half now, and the burrs are pretty straightforward to clean and works great and fast. No chipped and cut coffee, spits out verve beans just the same as some of my nice hand grinders.

reviews.reviewTitle: After 2 months and we continue to be very happy with our Bodum Grider
reviews.reviewText: After 2 months and we continue to be very happy with our Bodum Grider. It's very handsome and well built, and is also much quieter than several other burr grinders that we've used in the past. I like that the container that receives the ground coffee is glass and not plastic. There's still a bit of 'static cling', but not nearly as much as with plastic cups. So far, so good. UPDATE: after two years, it's still working perfectly. We love it.

reviews.reviewTitle: could not get past the mess
reviews.reviewText: I couldn't wait to get this grinder...after I used it I was very disappointed.this grinder was so messy. Even with the glass containing the grind still stick inside of it . when you remove the container coffee grinds fall from the top of the machine.coffees even comes out the bottom where the cord is coming from.

This is the best coffee grinder I've ever had and I've been buying them for 40 years. Every other grinder made a mess. Mostly because of the static and plastic combination. This glass jar and the way the lid "seals" seems to solve the problem. I've been able to set the time so that it grinds just enough for one cup and the consistency is excellent. I highly recommend this grinder.
Also, check out [...]
to buy excellent beans directly from farmers coops and cut out the middle man.

I have had this a month and it has worked flawlessly. Regarding some of the other comments. I have a small 8 cup coffee maker and I have found that 10 seconds provides a sufficient grind for this maker. I have had no problems with mess, in fact it is cleaner than my old blade grinder. Noise, well yeah I would like it quieter but its obvisously part price point versus performance design issues but hey its only on for 10 seconds. If I had to do it all over again, this would be the one to get.
Way too many problems with it. Adjustment chamber gets stuck, most of the time it won't turn on and when it does a lot of times it doesn't shut off. I finally fixed it with a hammer.

I use this grinder every day. The grind setting doesn't change (as I have experienced with other grinders) and I get perfectly ground coffee for my espresso every day. It holds a good quantity of beans. It is perfect for a couple of lattes each morning. Excellent quality and nice design Small footprint so it sits on my counter top.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hi quality construction but it's weird to have to run ...
reviews.reviewText: Hi quality construction but it's weird to have to run it for 10 seconds and again for 15 seconds to make a standard pot of coffee because the dial only goes up to 20. It should have had a timer that goes to 30. Much more than 30 would overt fill the grind container.

reviews.reviewTitle: The best! This is a replacement for my previous Bodum ...
reviews.reviewText: The best! This is a replacement for my previous Bodum coffee grinder that died after an errant pebble in the coffee beans. They really are the best. Just keep it out of the sun, as after several years the plastic gets sticky.

We bought this grinder 4 years ago. For the most part it worked well. It ground and fed well as long as we occasionally removed the hopper and grinder wheel for cleaning. About a month ago, the timer started getting flaky. We called Bodum to find out if it can be repaired, they replied it cannot. While the warranty is 2 years and it has been 4, a $90 grinder should last longer than a $20 grinder and at least be serviceable. Too bad it did not hold up. We'll find another brand this time.

I have used a $15 blade grinder for years. Recently I switched to the Bodum "3-cup" French Press coffee maker. I couldn't make ground coffee with a consistent coarse grind with that grinder The distribution of particles was too broad and there were too many "fines." I got tired of drinking slurry.

So I ponyed up $80 and bought Bodum's rotary burr grinder. It does the job, though I still grind some "fines." I know if one uses a French Press coffee-maker they are not supposed to gripe about grinds in your teeth, but I do.

It's easy to set to maximum grind size, and set the volume of grinds one wants. What I really like is that I can store un-ground beans in the top conical cavity and (for the most part) they don't draw Oxygen and water and grow stale. I didn't think this feature would work as well it does - better than storing coffee beans in bags and freezer bags.

My only drawback for this device is its price. I know, others opine that this is a bargain for a rotary burr grinder. But, the price is so far above that of the blade grinder that it just seems excessive. But, it does the job and I would buy another.
Love this grinder. I had the last one of the same model for 5 years!!! The grind is consistent and it's easy to work with.

This grinder is a replacement for my first Bodum grinder that worked everyday overtime for about 20 years. It finally wore out. This one is smaller and on a timer rather than number of cups you want to grind. I love it even more that the first grinder. It is fast, efficient and if it is anything like the other one, I will be using it for another 20 years.

reviews.reviewTitle: So far so good. No more thick layer of coffee at the ...
reviews.reviewText: I assumed the "Borosilicate glass catcher" would reduce the amount of grounds that sticks to the sides, but it doesn't. I use this for french press. So far so good. No more thick layer of coffee at the bottom of my cup in the mornings.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bought in July, dead by November.
reviews.reviewText: Bought this in July. Today is November 2 and it died on me. It was not an inexpensive item. Went to return it and was told the option to return expired in August. No more Amazon. If I had bought this in a store, I would be able to return it for one that works. BUYER BEWRE

reviews.reviewTitle: ... second grind every morning and the grinder does a great job. Watch out for oily beans as they ...
reviews.reviewText: I do a five second grind every morning and the grinder does a great job. Watch out for oily beans as they will clog the unit. I wish it was easier to select a grind time but hitting the button again will stop it if you've overestimated.

I've used this thing about twice a day for almost a year I think. It is the perfect system for on-demand grinding. Fresh ground coffee. I love it. Good quality, even size of grounds, easy to adjust and calibrate. I like the glass receptacle because it almost eliminates static, a major problem with other grinders I've had (makes the grounds fly all over). But I'm afraid I'm going to drop it and break it someday and pay a small fortune to replace it.
Nice product - it has a nice big hopper.

I purchased this grinder based on the reviews that indicated the grinder was less messy than grinders with plastic bins. My experience is that this grinder is every bit as messy as my old one. Coffee sticks to both the rubber collection bin lid and to the glass sides. It also sticks to the part of the grinder where the coffee enters the bin. Overall it works well, but don't buy it to get a mess-free product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Can grind coffee in the morning again!
reviews.reviewText: We've had this now for a month and I'm enjoying the flavor of fresh ground coffee again! Our previous burr grinder was so loud we had to grind the evening before so as not to wake the whole house, but this one is quiet enough to grind in the morning. It's not silent mind you but MUCH quieter than the other grinders we have had. Overall it's grind is consistent and I really like the glass receptacle as the coffee just slides right out. Overall very happy with the quality of the product and the color adds a nice pop to the kitchen.

The grinder works well. As reported here, it is relatively quiet and leaves no mess. And the multiplicity of settings make it adaptable for any palate. I am using it with a Technivorm drip coffee maker. But I have a problem. Like most of us, I am still trying to determine the proper amount of coffee beans to add, as well as the optimum time settings. So far I have been unsuccessful in determining the best settings for me. At first I added 4 1/2 oz of beans (including a pinch of salt to retard bitterness) to the hopper, with the timer set to 10 seconds. I added enough water for 1/2 pot of coffee. When the end product was too bitter I increased the time to 15 seconds, as suggested by some reviewers. No improvement.

What annoys me is the fact that when I follow the exact same procedures with pre-ground coffee vice coffee beans the end product results in almost no bitterness. So I assume my problem is with the grinder settings.

I have another issue with the grinder. Many people pour more beans into the hopper than they will need at any one time. The unused beans will be used at another time. For myself, I prefer to add the exact amount of beans that will be necessary at that particular time. I find that, when the grinding is completed, I still have some residual grounds residing in the grinder. Does this indicate an error on my part? Are 100% of the beans supposed to be utilized, indicating a perfect match of coffee measurement and grinding time? Should I start the grinder again to dispense the remaining grounds into the ground coffee container, should I increase the time setting to allow all the excess grounds to empty into the dispenser, or should I just discard the excess grounds?

I love this little grinder. It isn't too loud. If this is to be your first grinder you might not understand how loud most burr coffee grinders are, most comparable to having a small lawnmower running in your kitchen is the only way to describe it. This one would be like having an electric yard trimmer, much quieter. This grinder I use a few times a day. I am very impressed with how well it performs, usually for this type of performance you have to spend several hundred dollars more on a high performance machine. Well worth the buy.
I freakin' love this grinder. It has enough grind size settings to be versatile for a variety of brewing methods, it's fast, it's easy to use, and grinds are really consistent.
Love it! Works well, consistent grind ever time. My husband uses it every morning!

reviews.reviewTitle: Not so in love with this grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I love this grinder, I wish I would have bought one a long time ago. I was using one of the top loaders before. Now making that pot of coffee in the morning is a breeze.
UPDATE!: Major issue the top and the ring around the glass container is some type of Silicone rubber. The coffee sticks to it like a magnet, you have to wash it after only a couple of uses. I ordered white it is already stained after a few months. I wish I could send it back.

reviews.reviewTitle: Consistant grind without too much noise.
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder is much quieter than the Calaphon I had before.
We grind beans twice a day and have had this unit almost two years without a problem.
My daughter has a top of the line unit that was twice the cost and doesn't work as well.
Also like the size, it fits easily under the kitchen cabinets.
This was a gift to my son in-law and he loves it. He says it helps make the best tasting coffee.

i love this for my drip machine, very consistent, but it won't pull the beans through at all when i go finer. which sucks as i want it for both.

design is very nice. glass jar does get stacic but from other reviews i've read of plastic bins i think this is probably better. clips in snugly to unit so spillage is minimal.

not sure if they changed the design, but mine allows me to re-grind straight away after the 20sec cutout (others have said it won't go again for 5min). 20sec on drip setting is good for a strong 4-cup brew.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke after a few uses; company said they would replace then never sent it
reviews.reviewText: I used this at an apartment where I would stay about one week a month when traveling on business. I was the only one who used it. It saw extremely light use and broke after a few months, after I could no longer send it back to Amazon. I had to contact Bodum. They had me do several tests and then said, "Yes, it is defective. We will send a replacement." We waited and waited. No replacement arrived. I wrote back a number of times and received no response.
It’s lasted 5 years so I have to give it stars! Works great and we make a couple pots a day!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great way to start the day
reviews.reviewText: I don't have any real complaints about this product. I spent the extra money on this conical burr grinder after my standard inexpensive grinder died and my coffee tastes great. Also takes less beans to achieve the flavor I want.
So much better than a chopper blade. Love the options of different grinds

I've purchased (and returned) burr grinders from other brands, and I'm most happy with this one. Nothing new here-- I'm just cheerleading the statements made by others: it's cute (I got red!), relatively quiet, comparatively cheap, easy to clean, grind settings are pretty true to form. Compared to plastic containers v. the glass of the Bodum, the latter definitely has less static.

I'm going on a month or so of daily use now, and it's a great machine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best electric burn for your money
reviews.reviewText: Best electric burr I had ever bought. I love it

Had this for about 3 years now and it is still working as good as ever. It took about a bag of beans to figure out the right cycle time and grind, and I have not touched my settings since. I use it every day, once a day at minimum. Yes, it's a bit noisy but not too bad. I press the button and walk away. Could put it in a pantry/closet I suppose....

Great grinder. Only minor complaint is the static post grinding... the cup is lined with coffee powder that you really need to whack the side to get out. I think this is common with all grinders during low humidity months. I find that if you grind and pour it out 5-10 minutes later it comes out easy (the static charge obviously discharges)

reviews.reviewTitle: ... years of daily use this machine still produces a perfect espresso grind
reviews.reviewText: After four (4) years of daily use this machine still produces a perfect espresso grind, which I had previously despaired of getting from a reasonably priced grinder. It's compact, not too loud, and fairly easy to clean. What's not to like?
1 month in and loving it compared to my last grinder. Burr is the way to go from french press to espresso and everything in between.

Own it for about a week. Everything work fine.
Pros
1. Grind
I'm doing only french press (coarse) and aeropress (finer than drip)
Both grind come out pretty. Not much left at bottom of my mug.
2. Fairly quiet
For a grinder at this price. It's quiet enough for my expectation.
3. Design
Bodum always have its product look nice. This is important for keep my non-coffeedrinker female roommates shut up for setting it in shared space.

Only con I can complain so far is that cable kind of too short

reviews.reviewTitle: One quirk, but overall a good value
reviews.reviewText:
The grind quality of this matches much more expensive grinders, but it does have one flaw. When using the french press setting, since the hopper is what you turn to adjust the coarseness, it can wobble during use until it reaches a position where it shuts off.

I just hold the lid for the 5 to 10 seconds that I'm grinding and it's not a problem, but I can't give it 5 stars since it's not perfect.

It grinds just fine, but it's very messy. Coffee grounds get everywhere. It seems like a lot of waste. And the machine isn't very sturdy so you have to hold the funnel in place while it's grinding or the knob will move to a different grind setting from the vibration.
...the finest values in burr grinders. I love everything about this grinder. Will buy another if it ever becomes necessary, but I have had this one for years.

reviews.reviewTitle: Way better than a blade grinder
reviews.reviewText: We were using a Braun blade grinder for years and tried this burr grinder. Wow! What a difference. Amazing how the correct grind can make such a huge difference in the taste and texture of our coffee. It seems to make every kind of coffee taste better, whether it's supermarket whole bean, or high end, expensive beans. If you can't tell from the above, this unit is strongly recommended.
I really like this grinder. I don't use the small lid for the ground coffee. It just gets in the way. Perfect espresso grind

I love this grinder. It was annoying to have to wait five minutes after each grind (which lasts about 20 seconds), but now it's part of my zen practice as I move around the kitchen in the morning. It's pretty quiet and very aesthetically pleasing.

reviews.reviewTitle: So disappointed, had this grinder about 16 months
reviews.reviewText: So disappointed, had this grinder about 16 months, using it 4 times a week and it just stopped working. No wierd grinding sounds, no notice just stopped. Our old grinder worked for 15 years and it was $9.00 not 95.00 like this one. What is the recourse?

I love using this. I would spend more money if I have to but it was not necessary. This appliance looks cool, works perfect, and is very easy to clean. No need to spend more money. And, this actually looks better on your counter top than many much more expensive ones.

reviews.reviewTitle: We've owned two of these and both have broken. This last one broke within the year.
reviews.reviewText: This is the second one of these I have bought and it broke within a year. If you're planning to use your grinder every day I'd recommend a different brand.

reviews.reviewTitle: the performance is worse, twenty seconds only gives about a tablespoon of ...
reviews.reviewText: works well for the first month or so, the performance is worse, twenty seconds only gives about a tablespoon of coffee then wait 5 minutes, it took forever to make enough ground for 6 cups of coffee

reviews.reviewTitle: great looking burr grinder that works
reviews.reviewText: This burr grinder is reliable and it looks great on my countertop. I am a repeat customer, having bought one for my vacation cottage.

Using it right now, grinds well. Not fine enough for espresso but it is decent and to be honest I wouldn't be able to tell the difference between this grind and a finer one. Coarse is a little inconsistent though. Nice design, everything fits smugly and has instructions on how much time you need for each cup you're making.

I love this thing. The grind is fairly even, I would bet there are more expensive ones that have a more consistent grind, but for my purpose this is great. I like the rubberized coating, it is easy to handle without fear of dropping it.
Wife loves it
Large container for beans and grounds. Beautiful red color although is more orangy red than apple red. Quiet and quick grind compared to other grinders in the past.
Great when it worked. Just stopped cold after 13 months.

reviews.reviewTitle: Garbage gears break way too soon for a > $100 grinder
reviews.reviewText: After just under 2 years of use, I pressed the grind button this morning to hear a terrible crackling noise. For the amount of money this grinder costs, I would expect it to last at least 4-5 years. Bodum's poor quality product (really! read the other reviews for this POS) has lost this customer forever.

I am a huge coffee fan. So when I was stationed in Italy, I was thrilled with all the quality coffee I'll get to try. After becoming friends with some of the Italians, they suggested I purchase this for home use. I am really glad I did. It's solidly built, powerful, relatively quiet for a grinder, easy to clean, and extremely easy to use. In addition, it's dual voltage rated, meaning I can use it here and back in the States without any issue. Highly recommended!

reviews.reviewTitle: Love love ❤️ my new grinder and I had a ...
reviews.reviewText:
Love love ❤️ my new grinder and I had a great one before that I owned for 13 years, it is still going but I wanted to try a new grinder. I'm so glad I did.
I think the little extra goes a long way! My suggestion is get this coffee grinder and get the copper one.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'm not sure what washing the "catcher" is good for, exactly
reviews.reviewText:
We purchased this unit back in 2012 because we wanted to try french press coffee, and we needed a coarser grind than you can get in the pre-ground store-bought coffee bags. We needed to up our coffee game in prior to our newborn, as all parents can relate. Since 2012, we have used it multiple times a day, almost every day. We have NEVER waited any significant amount of time between grinding before pushing the button a second time. Our unit has continued to work and work and work and has never shown us any issue whatsoever. Solidly reliable.

I'm not sure what washing the "catcher" is good for, exactly, but we still do it on occasion. Washing seems pointless for the following reasons: (1) The hopper seems to accumulate plenty of coffee residue, and we rarely clean it (as it is so rarely empty). (2) The burrs seem impossible to clean well, so we almost never do that, either. (3) The chute in the interior of the unit (below the burrs but above the "catcher") is almost impossible to clean, as it is virtually inaccessible. I smack the side of the unit to encourage "stuck" coffee grounds down the chute and into the "catcher" regularly, but that's about it.

Pros:
- Reliable workhorse
- Produces a consistent grind quality & size
- Stylish design looks nice on the countertop
- Glass "catcher" feels like high quality

Cons:
- Loud enough to wake the dead. Or your babies while they are sleeping, as it has done for ours.
- Plastic hopper seems to get greasy quickly, and does not feel like high quality. Most of the rest of the unit is hard to clean, if you'd want to.
- Lid hard to close completely
- Coffee flecks still manage to get everywhere when removing the carafe. Mysteriously, random coffee flecks build up beneath the unit.

If ours ever breaks (god forbid), we'd buy it again, mostly because ours has been so reliable.

This model broke only a couple months after buying it. It simply stopped in the middle of grinding (was not grinding for longer than the recommended time), and would never start again. Its very pretty, but unless I just got a singular dud, not reliable at all! I bought a different brand for my next one, and its been going strong for a long, long time.

I bought this grinder almost 4 years to this day. This morning it died, but not without grinding beans perfectly multiple times a day, every day, for four years. This guy is well priced for the life span you get.

reviews.reviewTitle: No need for Starbuck's after this baby...
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is very stylish and makes the perfect cup of coffee. My only complaint is the mess. You will want to put a tray underneath to catch the "grind runoff".

My wife and I are Coffee Lovers, and we must have at least one large cup every day. Before we purchased this grinder we had trouble getting that Starbucks and Pete's Coffee taste at home. Our drip coffee is much better than before but our French Press coffee is off the chart with our new grinder. One more thing that I love about this burr grinder is that it is nice and clean (very little grounds on the counter). Many burr grinders are very messy but not this one.

After reading many reviews on other coffee grinders I bought the Bodum. I grind a half cup plus of beans each day for my Cuisinart On-Demand 12 cup drip coffee maker. The 20 second timer runs out just a little short for my needs, I just restart it again for about 5 seconds and it is finished. The grind is consistent every day. It does a great job of keeping the dust and grounds in the collection container. Noise level is good as my wife is often asleep in the bedroom when I grind the coffee and it does not wake her. I really enjoy having fresh ground coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great modest priced home burr grinder
reviews.reviewText: Exceeded our expectations. Really like the glass container as it is static free and makes the entire process mess-free. There is no comparison to our blade grinder....consistent grind, quieter and cleaner. Easy to adjust grind size. Nice looking on countertop. No complaints!

I've been using this grinder several times a week (sometimes daily) for over two years. It's not a completely flawless piece of machinery, but it gets the job done. You have to kinda shake it and hit it to get all of the grounds out, but it's not really a big deal. The 20 seconds of grinding is perfect for the 32 oz. bodum french press. For doing pour-overs i remove the glass beaker and stick my HarioV60 right where the grounds fall in, the size is perfect. I have recommended this grinder to many people.

Some issues with the first grinder I received (would not adjust grind at all), but Bodum was very nice and sent me a replacement. The new one works perfectly. Make sure you only adjust the grind when the machine is running and has beans in it, I've had some issues with jams if I didn't follow that direction.

Sometimes the top burr will be slightly misplaced in the plastic bit and you have to push it back in, but this isn't too much of an issue.

Grind quality is great for this price. Coffee seems to be getting better and better as I tune the grind to my liking.

This wonderful machine is an excellent grinder.

I am someone who goes from French Press to Espresso depending on my mood, and this grinder is fully accommodating.

It is reasonably easy to clean, and there is some static electric buildup in the cup, but it's not a huge problem.
Produces and incredible fine grind, and an even coarse grind.
This is the best coffee grinder ever! It has met all my expectations and I extremely enjoy using it. It does a great job with any grind that I require. I love, love, LOVE using it❗️

cute and pretty quiet! Pinon coffee will jam it on fine ground, makes a coffee butter due to nuts in the grind. Easy to clean so not a big deal. My boyfriend has grinder envy. His Cuisine Art sound like a jet engine. This one purrs. Doesn't take up much space on the counter. Will buy another if it ever konks out.

When my Braun grinder finally wore out, I thought I would order another, but to my dismay it was not available. Based on other reviews, I ordered this Bodum which thus far has been fine. I do wish, however, that the ground bean container was larger as when I want to make more than 6 cups of coffee, I have to grind more beans. Not much of a complaint I will admit,so I definitely will give it five stars.

After two months of use, I can say that this burr grinder is great. It's easy to use, holds enough beans for several cups and grinds evenly and quickly. My only reservation is that I wish I had gotten the black instead of white as the few grounds that escape do show up on the white surface! I recommend this product.
Second unit, EZ, compact, quiet

Great consistent grind every time! This is my favorite grinder so far. The glass catch container is great too because of the reduced static. It is much easier to get all of the coffee out versus plastic containers!

reviews.reviewTitle: Cheap Burr, Loud, great price, dumb buttons, cheap!
reviews.reviewText:
Update:
After 2 years this thing is hunkin' POS. The "start" button works 10% of the time, some interlock is clogged with shavings. The timer is the most inconsistent timing in the universe- always at 30 sec., this runs 9, 13, 22, or 3 seconds, always different. I have never gotten 30 seconds out of it.
It clogs constantly. Right after you clean it, it will get gunked up somewhere.
The plastic is ultra clingy, shards and coffee dust every time you retrieve the hopper.
Outer plastic rubbery crap has turned into goo, just like those 90's cameras.
I hate this thing.
