For a coffee grinder, this is a horrible investment.

Old Review:
it's not the quietest thing in the world. Especially after the first few months, the plastic seems to get more brittle or something and the WHINE of the motor seems to reverberate thru the house. Once small childrens can sleep through this, they'll sleep through anything.
Not really for espresso, but perhaps if you mod the grind chamber and shim it a little tighter. It can get pretty small grind- almost there.
Overall, it works well, nice sized hopper. My only gripe is the tiny start/stop button, and the reversed On/Off button. Please make a 'start' button i can find BEFORE making coffee. duh! And one must hit that thing 7 times before it goes, regardless of the laws of nature- it just wants you to keep jamming on that tiny button till it goes.
for the power toggle - Here in 'merica we flip UP for on, get with the program 'rest-of-the-world'. jeez. Flip that thing in the same factory location where you put the 110v household plugs and the steering wheels on the left.

reviews.reviewTitle: Died in less than a month
reviews.reviewText: I was pleased with this purchase but disappointed at the extremely short shelf life. I mostly used the grinder on the weekends and it was gently used. Item was delivered to me on October 27, 2011 and within less than a month, unit died. I tried all the obvious steps to determine what went wrong but could not find anything. Calling the folks at Bodum was a total waste of time .. I'm being kind when I say that they were totally incompetent. End of story .. I returned unit to Amazon for a full credit and bought another burr grinder [different brand altogether] at a local store.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good for coffee grind, not espresso level quality.
reviews.reviewText: I have used commercial grinders for espresso drinks and this grinder does not produce that level of fine grind or consistency....but for the price it does a nice job at a very intro level. The timer on ours did not work but we just use the on off button. We purchased it as a travel grinder for coffee only.

reviews.reviewTitle: Maybe 6 years is good, but I expected it to last for 20
reviews.reviewText: Daily user since 2011, this week it died. Over the last week, would grind for shorter and shorter time, today just quit. Maybe 6 years is good, but I expected it to last for 20. Worked fine over the years, but will find a different one this time.

This does a wonderful job of grinding coffee beans. It's easy to use and clean. It's sooo quiet. I couldn't be more pleased. My first grinder was a Krups and it did a fair job, but didn't always grind all the beans and was terribly noisy. I am very pleased with the Bodum Bistro Burr Coffee Grinder and I know you will be, too. Thanks to all you reviewers who helped me make a great decision.

I had the older version of this grinder, the Bodum Antigua, which after 12 years started showing signs of worn burrs. It was a reliable, consistent grinder that was also staticy and noisy. The new Bodum Bistro is very much the same. Very consistent and so far reliable, and also very noisy. The static is less though not quite gone. The new timer is a little more useful than the older model though I wish there was a way to bypass it completely. I also like the smaller footprint and overall look. With all that in mind, for the money I'm thrilled with this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does not grind fine enough for espresso
reviews.reviewText: Does not grind fine enough for espresso. Unfortunately had to return. Love the design and look of the product, wish it would have worked out for me.

Worked fine one month. Then acted haywire. Grindes various amounts of coffee on same setting. Have to grind, then put in other container, then use spoon to measure right amount. Very messy coffee dust all over place. Only use once a day. Piece of junk.

reviews.reviewTitle: This thing is loud. If you bought this because ...
reviews.reviewText: This thing is loud. If you bought this because you are tired of coffee grinds clinging with static- this has static.

reviews.reviewTitle: The grinder part was great for about 2 years
reviews.reviewText: The grinder part was great for about 2 years...then the outer casing around the whole grinder got goooy and sticky...would not clean off...wrote to Bodum and they basically said tough luck...said I had cleaned it wrong. It was like the outer shell started to disinagrate...a mess. Also the gears finally broke after three years....would not buy it again.

reviews.reviewTitle: It is fast and allows to set the powder granulometry.
reviews.reviewText:
The box is enormous, but the grinder itself has the right size. I was really happy that is relatively fast to grind coffee grains.

The design is simple but manufacturing is well finished, definitely a perfect fit with a Bodum Coffee Maker.

Just pay attention that if you are used to make coffee with pre-ground coffee, maybe there is a need to adjust the amount of water X coffee powder.

Had this for 1 year and 15 days and the thing started smoking and smelled like some electronics were burning. It was a mediocre grinder, maybe worth $35 at the most. I personally am going to stay away from Bodum products after this experience.

In my quest to find the "ultimate" cup of coffee, the Bodum Bistro burr coffee grinder was my first stop. I like the many choices of grinds offered. I like the container that catches the ground coffee...not a lot of static electricity. I can grind the exact amount of beans I need, have a wonderful cup of the "golden stuff" and go about my day.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Grinder, i like that it comes with the ...
reviews.reviewText: Great Grinder, i like that it comes with the handy cheat sheet under the hopper lid. The glass container itsn;t 100% anti static, but WAY better than my previous version that had a plastic container.

I've had my grinder for 9-months and I like. It grinds beans to the texture that I want. The bin holds a good quantity of beans and delivers ground coffee from fine espresso to course/very course. I tried a cheaper one before this and it just didn't grind like this one can. A good quality product.

Couldn't be happier with this grinder. It's much quieter than my former burr grinder and the design is both efficient and attractive. The glass container is the best improvement over my old, plastic container, unit that cracked early in use.

After trying many coffee grinders over the years, we decided to give the Bodum Bistro a try. In 3 words, IT IS GREAT! Finally, a grinder that grinds coffee uniformly without making a lot of dust and other odd sized particles. The glass container for the ground coffee is brilliant as the ground coffee does not stick with static to the container like it does in grinders with plastic containers. By far, the best of perhaps 10 coffee grinders we have tried over the years.

It looks great, and does a fabulous job grinding, when it doesn't jam. I am constantly having to flip it and try to remove a jam. Dunno what they tested with but the motor is not strong enough to grind up coffee beans reliably.

I really wanted a burr grinder since the grinder I had been using was the simple blade type that you find everywhere -- it did a very poor job of evenly grinding the beans, leaving big pieces of bean. This Bodum Bistro grinds the beans very evenly and I've never had a problem with it. I use a French press for making coffee and it works perfectly for that. I just choose the coarsest setting. I have heard from some that it does not grind beans fine enough for espresso so you might want to consider another grinder if you make espresso -- but, I suspect you'll pay a lot more money. For the price, this is a great buy.

Bad power switch. Switch is flaky and has to be held down during grind operation. mine is a lighted switch not the same as pictured. Going to try and jumper out switch as soon as I figure out how to open bottom of unit. This grinder is great otherwise.

My old Baratza Maestro crapped out after 10 years - ordered this one in white based on specs, reviews, and price. It would not turn on - I'm a tech and there were no problems with the power source. Ordered a replacement, same problem. Bodum obviously has some quality control issues. Ordered the Capresso, which works as spec'd after a month.
No complaints. Looks super cute on counter. Best grind so far and I’m a coffee LOVER!

reviews.reviewTitle: I hated getting the grounds out of my old grinder with ...
reviews.reviewText: The glass catcher makes a huge difference. I hated getting the grounds out of my old grinder with a plastic catcher. I have been using this grinder for a few months and I love it. It works very well and looks nice in the counter too.

Worked okay for about 10 months, and then the motor died on me. Outside warranty window so I will have to buy a new grinder - buyer beware. One other minor annoyance about this grinder - the cup that collects the grounds tends to drift out of place during the grinding process due to the vibrations, which ends up spilling them unless you make sure to use your hand to keep it in place.

Oh well, time to buy a Baratza.
nice grinder easy to use easy to clean.

We purchased this grinder in September of this year and the motor is already "slipping" and not grinding the coffee. Now it is July - less than a year old and it is broken. This is the second Bodum to break in a short time - funny thing is we have a black one that still works and we've had it for several years. The red ones are breaking on us!

I use this to grind coffee for my french press and it works perfectly.

You can set the type of grind from coarse to fine, and the best part is you can set how long to grind so you always get the same amount of ground coffee to always brew a consistent taste - highly recommend this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: We use it on the finest setting. Upgraded from a basic Krups blade grinder ...
reviews.reviewText: I look forward to using this every morning with our Mocha Express. We use it on the finest setting. Upgraded from a basic Krups blade grinder and would not go back.
Much more quiet than typical coffee grinders. Very simple to operate. Never heard of this company before.
So loud it scares the cat, and my spouse, and makes the neighbors nervous.

I got so tired of using the manual hand grinders and decided to get this. Been using it for 3 weeks now about 2 to 3 times a day. My son likes his fine grind and I like mine more coarse and we are both happy with the results. We do pour over coffee so we like our coffee fresh with lots of flavor. This is a great little machine and I hope it lasts.

Just bought this for my new espresso machine. I love it! I was very surprised to hear how quiet this machine is. Just wanted to chime in and say that it only takes 15 seconds to make enough grounds for a double shot of espresso which is all you need. That being said it goes up to 20 seconds which is more than enough.

The only con I would say is that this machine doesn't have an alarm to grind automatically. It would be nice to wake up to freshly ground coffee. If added it would be a 5 star.

A really nice mill. Slow speed, durable. I like the grind timer, rubber exterior, the glass container, thumb on-off master switch, grind adjustment is excellent. Used almost daily for the past year with zero issues. Best mill for the money. I have a friend who has a $180 slow speed mill and this is just as slow and smooth for less... you decide.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is by far the best burr grinder in its price range
reviews.reviewText: This is by far the best burr grinder in its price range. The grind is uniform and consistent, and the glass receptacle works wonderfully in reducing static. We've had it for over a month and use it at least twice daily. Not even a hiccup. Great buy!

reviews.reviewTitle: It is much smaller than i expected and you can ...
reviews.reviewText:
It is much smaller than i expected and you can only grind 20 seconds of coffee at a time and then you have to let it sit
for 5 mins. When grinding a LB of coffee this takes quite awhile.

reviews.reviewTitle: Keep looking, this one is crap.
reviews.reviewText:
Lasted 7 months. Ridiculous, cheaply made.
Plastic in the gears will break, only a question of when, 90 bux down the drain.

I have owned this grinder for about a week and like it very much. I grind directly into my paper filter and tap the grinder on the side gently to remove any residual coffee grounds. It grinds the beans very consistently, is simple to use and is very quiet. I do not keep my beans in the hopper but rather weigh them to get the same grinding results each time. I used to use a blade grinder but find that a burr grinder produces much better coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: I like the many adjustments that can be made to the ...
reviews.reviewText: I like the many adjustments that can be made to the grind and the grind itself. However, the little jar that catches the grinds creates a mess. It's a rubbery plastic and the grinds stick to it. They get all over the counter, the coffee grinder itself and your hands when emptying it. Creating a smoother plastic around the jar would remedy this.

reviews.reviewTitle: How many to grind is on the underneath of the lid
reviews.reviewText: Grinds beans wonderfully

Does a great job of grinding. My only hesitation is that the motor seems to be a bit under-designed since sometimes I notice an "electric" smell. I grind 2 scoops of beans at a setting for drip coffee. If I use a coarser grind as for the French press, I am sure that the motor could handle the load.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great, only reason why I removed a star is ...
reviews.reviewText: Works great, only reason why I removed a star is because there is still static in glass container. I expected that prior to purchase as other reviews stated.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinding quality- very uniform grounds
reviews.reviewText: Great grinding quality- very uniform grounds. If grinding for >3 servings, it will take at least 2 grinding cycles with a recommended 5 min motor rest time between cycles, so grinding for large batches is not very convenient.
No complaints. Easy to use, cleaner than other brands, average noise level. Dependable. Easily fits under cabinets in kitchen.
Does a good job. Easy. Glass receptacle reduces coffee grounds from going everywhere. Look under the lid for grind time/volume ratios. That's our secret. Bon appetit.

reviews.reviewTitle: A bit loud but great value ... and kudos to Bodum's customer service
reviews.reviewText:
This is a stylish and well-designed grinder capable of delivering everything from medium drip grinds to super-fine espresso powder. It's a little louder than expected, but maybe that's because it's the first big noise of each day. As advertised, the borosilicate glass seems to keep static manageable, and the coffee tastes even better with the knowledge that we got as good a grinder as some of the fancier Italian models, and at half the price.

We've had one problem that revealed a technical vulnerability of this grinder (and of burr grinders generally) but also showcased some excellent customer service at Bodum. A small pebble was in with the coffee beans -- this apparently happens occasionally -- and jammed the mechanism. The grinder stopped as it should have (it has a self-protection mechanism) but the pebble was REALLY wedged in tightly ... and a clumsy technician (me) broke an internal plastic retaining ring while dis- and re-assembling the gizmo. Although the grinder could still be used, the burr surfaces were no longer being held in alignment and it sounded unhappy.

A phone call to Bodum made it all better. They took our name and address and shipped us a replacement part without charge, despite the fact that the retaining ring comes with the machined-metal burr already attached. (Meaning: This was NOT a cheap part to have sent to us gratis, and they were generous to have done so.) This saved everyone the cost of shipping and kept us limping along -- but able to make coffee! -- while the part was in transit. Call us very satisfied customers.

This grinder started out working well. It has a large number of settings for fineness of grind and it seemed consistent. Over time, however, it seems to have lost its grinding ability. I used to run it for 20 seconds for a full pot. Now it takes more than 60 seconds on the same setting. I'm not sure why this is happening, as I've inspected and cleaned the burrs and they seem fine. I would not buy this again.

This may be the perfect grinder. From the glass bowl with sealed lid, the incredibly-adjustable grind settings, and the impossibly easy operation to the small footprint and consistent results - it's hard to say what they could improve. Static was a problem the first time we used it, but we cleaned it out well and it's worked perfectly every since. Highly recommended.

I don't have much experience with burr grinders, this one replaced my blade grinder. when I compared grind of both the blade and this burr grinder it was a night and day difference on consistency. this burr grinder made my coffee taste better and after a year of using it everyday it still grinds consistently. Love it..

reviews.reviewTitle: I have had it now for three weeks and it works beautifully. The grind for my AeroPress is consistent and ...
reviews.reviewText:
After extensive research, I decided to purchase the Bodum Bistro. I have had it now for three weeks and it works beautifully. The grind for my AeroPress is consistent and nothing sticks to the glass jar nor flies out over the counter as some other brands are purported to do. It is also a quiet machine.
I highly recommend this grinder. I might add that a local kitchen supply store uses it at their coffee counter to make a variety of coffee for their customers.
This is my second Bodum grinder over probably eight years. Works great for the price. I highly recommend the metal finish of this one over the rubberized finish of the original.

reviews.reviewTitle: A Perfect Way To Treat Your Coffee Beans!
reviews.reviewText: I bought this coffee grinder to compliment my new espresso machine. I wanted the beans to be treated right. This does a fantastic job, is easy to operate and clean. I love the glass jar, which allows me to save any unused grounds too.

I had other burr coffee grinders - but they were very heavy and their bean container did not last very long. It was hard to place the bean contain in the unit after awhile. This Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder is the best. Very light weight, not hard to clean and it has an on and off switch that is nice to have on the unit.

I love the way this grinder works. I was using the cheap ones and I see a big difference in the smoothness of my coffee, less bitter. You use less less beans and get more grounds. Still working with all the different settings. With my organic coffee from Java Planet, the smell after grinding is wonderful! I am enjoying my coffe a great deal more. Get a conical burr grinder if you are using the little cheap kind.

This is my first grinder, and i'm very pleased with it.
I was worried about only using it for 20 second's at a time, but
it turned out not being a problem since i only grind 6-7 tbsp
each time.
I've only had it for a month, but have used it 70-80 time's trying
out different bean's and grind's.
Opened it to clean, and there was only some dust that was easily brushed out.
Stay's firm on the countertop, easy to pick up, and won't slip out of
your hand if they are wet.
Well constructed product and worth the money!

At first I was hesitant about spending so much for a coffee grinder, but after a month of use I am so glad I did. It really does make a noticeable difference in the taste of the coffee. The grounds are perfectly even and it's very easy to use. You can leave it on the perfect setting our switch around for varying degrees of espresso, drip or French press. Totally worth it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best inexpensive burr grinder...now with a metal copper body!
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this as a replacement for a previous Bodum Burr Grinder that I got in 2011. I used that grinder upwards 4 -5 times a day, it still worked but the burrs are getting dull and the front plastic piece that holds the grinds catcher snapped off.

Obviously with such good results I went with another Bodum grinder, this time I opted for the Copper (aluminum body copper colored) over the Rubberized Black one that I have previously. The rubberized body is quit impossible to keep clean everything stuck to it and I had to end up covering with a huge zip-loc bag to keep it from looking like a lint brush :/
I'm not sure if it's becuase it's newer, the metal body, or some kinda of revision...this new copper model is a lot quieter and seems they have sped it up a bit over the first model I had. I always worry if the grinder is too fast it could scorch the beans but so far, so good. I do also notice more static over my old model, so after grinding I don't pull the catcher out immediately. Being glass I wasn't expecting so much static, my old one didn't do this.

The Bad: Even though this has a metal body, the bottom and most import part is still cheapy plastic..I'm not sure what they where thinking with this design. Obviously if someone is paying more for a metal body they want durability.
I just worry about it breaking in the future like my previous Bodum, I still used it for last year and a half 2 years just had to keep taping the bottom back together.
Was a gift. My son says its great.

reviews.reviewTitle: broke after about 1 week of use
reviews.reviewText: broke after about 1 week of use. button to grind coffee broke off and fell into the machine. ordered a replacement, hoping it was a rare defect with this particular machine and won't be an ongoing issue.

It's a nice product, works great...a little messy, but efficient. However, I bought this for my bf for Christmas in 2011, and it's August 2012 and it is broke already. For the money I spent to get a nice grinder, I would expect more from it. Planning on returning it to the manufacturer for a replacement, hopefully, they don't give me a hard time. I'll let you know.

reviews.reviewTitle: So sad I really wanted coffee this morning
reviews.reviewText: This thing finally died after 6 years of use. So sad I really wanted coffee this morning.

I bought this grinder as one to take with me when I travel by car. I have a more expensive and capable, but large and heavy, burr grinder I use as my daily. For what I use it for... its hard to tell the difference between the two grinders. Theoretically there is less dust with my more expensive grinder, but I can't really tell the difference. The one big issue is for chemex and french press coffee the grinds still end up pretty small; the coarse setting isn't nearly coarse enough. I haven't tried the fine settings with the Bodum, but I imagine I'll have less control.

Pros:
- It grinds coffee!
- Has a bunch of different grind settings
- This is the best low end burr grinder I was able to find.
- Aesthetically pleasing
- Reasonably compact

Cons:
- I'd only grind coffee with these; I destroyed one trying to grind flax seeds. The flax seeds gummed up the works and I threw it out in frustration.
- While it looks nice, and works great, you are getting a grinder for around a hundred bucks... the quality isn't as nice as the multi-hundred units out there. On the other hand, if you're used to the push grinders, this one is a HUGE upgrade.
- Grinds on a timer; if you have a lot of coffee you have to keep resetting it and running it again. However, you likely shouldn't do this as they warn in the manual that they have the timer to avoid burning out the motor.

I like it, and am glad I bought it.

It is unbelievable how much static there is inside of the canister. I lose coffee every time, that part kind of sucks. Maybe it should be made out of metal? Or plastic? Or a different kind of glass? I've purchased an anti-stat gun, and will update when I learn if it works to fix the problem.

reviews.reviewTitle: excellent grinder. It's down shoot is much better than ...
reviews.reviewText: excellent grinder. It's down shoot is much better than brands with a side discharge. And the glass container is vastly superior than plastic containers.

reviews.reviewTitle: Second one bites the dust!!!!No support persons.
reviews.reviewText: My second Bodum grinder has died. I was stupid to not look at the reviews. No replacing the gear that I have found. I am switching brands now. Wont get duped again. I will find one with stainless steel gears.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not too loud. No annoying coffee dust.
reviews.reviewText: Much quieter than my old grinder. Looks nice. Good size. No problems.

Yes, it's pretty, but after little more than a year, mine stopped being able to choose a grind. It had only one grind, of rather mixed size.
After 2 years it stopped working altogether.
I recommend you don't buy this item.

I like this grinder a lot. The look, finish of the materials, and my coffee definitely brews more smoothly because of the detailed/refined grind texture I can choose, and of course my coffee tastes better as a result.

I'm going to buy more Bodum small appliances as a result.

If I have any hesitation it's with the on/off switch, it feels a little cheap, and that worries me a little bit over time with this product.

This product grinds very well and evenly. I chose it because another reviewer said it was superior in terms of static electricity. However, I find the static quite aggravating, as the particles of ground coffee stick to the inside and outside of the glass beaker, and also fly all over the inside of the coffee maker. Another problem: instructions say to wait 5 minutes after a 20-second grind, but I find I need a good 30 seconds to grind for 2 people. The morning grind has become more time-consuming with this grinder.

Was great while it lasted. About 15 months in (used 2-3x a week) it stopped working (electrical problems, not gears like most). Bodum just seems to have serious build quality issues. I'll be getting another because my credit card's extended warranty will reimburse a replacement, but otherwise I'd be looking elsewhere for a new grinder.
This is a nifty little machine. The grind is consistent and the directions are very helpful.
Works great and gives a uniform size grind.

I bought this grinder to replace my Capresso burr grinder. I liked the idea of no static electricity and no grounds flying around. However this is not really the case. There are quite a few grounds on my counter top. I found one way to limit this problem is to "burp" the machine by gently slapping it on each side of the motor housing. This helped to clear the burrs and dump the left over grounds into the glass jar and release the static electricity. The quality of the grinder is first rate. The flying grounds are a minor inconvenience. I also turn off the toggle switch after each use. This way I can run the machine for 20 sec. twice to grind the amount of coffee I need. Leaving the toggle switch on creates heat in the motor, thus the recommendation to wait between grinding intervals. I've done this for months now and have had no problem with the motor overheating. You will save energy costs by not leaving the toggle on.

My hubby is the coffee drinker and loves to grind his own beans. Have worn out two Kitchenaid grinders and one Bodum Bistro. He really likes this grinder best of any we have tried, so went back with this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works very well. Only gripe is with spilled grounds ...
reviews.reviewText: Works very well. Only gripe is with spilled grounds. Bump it a few times before removing the cup holding the ground coffee to prevent loose grounds from falling out of grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: This has performed excellently at a pretty high usage rate (for home/personal use
reviews.reviewText: This has performed excellently at a pretty high usage rate (for home/personal use.) I highly recommend additionally because it looks excellent on the counter! Performs quite well for French Press, drip, and espresso, which I have tested.

reviews.reviewTitle: Looks nice and works well otherwise
reviews.reviewText: Constant scattering of coffee grounds around the machine. Looks nice and works well otherwise.

Have always used Krups grinders. Saw Bodum at my brother's house over Thanksgiving. This grinder is UPTOWN all the way. No more bitterness in the coffee, just good smooth coffee. Where have you been all my life?!? Luv it,luv it,luv it!

No difference in grind between "espresso" and "frenchpress"...which means a very unacceptably course grind for espresso.

Attached a photo of the "espresso" grind. Would have sent a "French Press" grind photo...but that would have been redundant.

If the unit had worked, I could have gotten along with it. The glass container, meant to lower static, did NOT. But I suspect this would have gotten better if I used the u it longer.

It is easy to disassemble and clean, it basically falls apart after you remove the hopper; but I suspect this is what made for miserable tolerances and grind quality.

So, in less than 12 hours from reciept...its on its way back.
This is a great mid-range burr grinder. I spent a lot of time reading reviews for grinders and this seemed to be the best value grinder I could find in the ~100$ price bracket.
This is my first grinder so I have nothing to compare but no problem so far.

Love this.
Use for fine grind.
Works as well as more expensive similar grinders.
Attractive on countertop.
Coffee does better kept in dark, so wish an equally atrractive cover were available.
Fantastic grinder and is very consistent. I use it constantly. Only gripe is I now need a 2nd one so I can more easily alternate between beans! :)

Easy operation. You set the type of grind and how long you want the grinder to run for and push the start button. Produces a great medium grind. I've only used it for drip coffee so I cannot attest to how it works for other settings.

My only grief with this grinder is that the hopper will not hold a full pound of beans. It holds about 3/4 pound. You have to fill it and keep the other 1/4 pound in a bag until later.

After using a blade grinder for years, I decided to give a burr grinder a try because of the affordable price on this Bodum unit. I'm most impressed with the disappearance of bitterness in the coffee using the same beans as usual. The consistency of the grind seems to be perfect and the grinder is simple to clean and operate.

This unit worked OK at first, although even the coursest grind setting seemed pretty fine to me. It only took about 12 seconds to grind coffee for 4 cups so the limited grind time wasn't an issue. During grinding one day, a month into use, the unit made a lot of noise and jumped around on the counter. After that it seemed to run ok but would take 3 twenty second grind intervals to grind enough coffee for my morning coffee. I returned it to Amazon for a refund and purchased a Capresso. I've had it for almost a month and it does a very nice job grinding coffee for my cone filter pot.

I have to say. As a coffee connoisseur, I have been increasingly impressed with the quality of this grinder. Coarsely grinds French press style coffee perfectly and find me grind espresso coffee better than any home grinder I've ever seen. Highly recommend.
Very nice product, works great.

reviews.reviewTitle: Customer Service Leaves Something To Be Desired
reviews.reviewText:
I was very pleased with this product until one day it just stopped working. I contacted customer service and they confirmed a 2 yr warranty was in effect. The needed proof of purchase was provided on March 11, 2013. Follow up email and phone call to NYC Headquarters unsuccessful.

This was not a cheap product and I'm disappointed at how easily they are able to ignore their customers.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very compact and well contructed burr grinder
reviews.reviewText: This is a very compact little guy, so no worries about a large footprint on your countertop. The construction is first rate and perfect for the regular coffee drinker. The seals are handy so you can keep some ground coffee available at all times and not have to store in a separate container. A must buy in this price range. The grind is also very even and so far works well with our dark waxy roast.
Effective efficient coffee bean grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice grinder. It does still build some static in ...
reviews.reviewText: Nice grinder. It does still build some static in the grounds but if you shake it side-to-side a bit, the static break down mostly.

reviews.reviewTitle: If only it was a bit more durable
reviews.reviewText: Wore out after just a small amount of use. Pieces of plastic gear deposited in coffee bin. It seems like, with a touch of better engineering in just a few critical spots, they could have a really great product.
I’ve had one of these for nearly 7 years now, and it hasn’t skipped a beat. Easy to clean, durable, looks good, and well worth the price.
I only use it for French Press, and it does a great job. Doesn't walk around the counter, is quiet compared to other grinders, looks nice.
This thing is great. I've been using it for months with no needed maintenance. It's never faulted or clogged and is so easy to use. Would recommend for anyone getting into French Pressed coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinder did not last long enough
reviews.reviewText:
Be aware that this rather expensive coffee grinder may work for a short time, it is not a robust unit and is prone to motor burn out.
I used mine only about once a week for only two cups at the medium grind and it stopped working. Although this unit was purchased
less than 3 years ago, it was past the two year warranty. I would expect this kind of unit to last much longer with light usage.

I bought this because I like coffee from auto drip, chemex, and French press; three different grinds. It looks great and works perfectly. I've had it about 6 months and used it every day with no trouble. 15 secs (it will do 20 secs) is perfect for 8 cups.
I have been using this grinder for several months. It works great! You can adjust the amount of beans to grind as well as the coarseness. It's very easy to use.
Great coffee bean grinder....easy to use with quality results of your choice of grind... recommended.

I have used Bodum grinders for over 10 years and have always found them to be competent. This one does excellent drip and espresso grind but unforntunalty will not do a grind course enough to use my siphon/vacuum pot. In reality it is just a better drip grind that coarse. I am sure it will clog a french press too. Still, It it will work for most of what I need it for. I will be looking for something different in a year.
Awesome grinder. Very versatile and easy to use

I have been using this grinder for a month now, and it is as good as I hoped it would be. I had a little trouble tweeking the timer to get it to give me just the right amount of coffee, but now that I know the proper time, this little grinder gives me what I want every time. There is no mess, and it looks good on the counter.

Does an excellent job. But, the plastic it's made of reacts with the oils that are in a kitchen during the cooking process (at least I think that's it). This produces a rather gummy coating that is nearly impossible to remove. Recommend keeping it covered.
A perfectly good burr grinder at a fair price. I have paid a lot more for an Italian grinder that worked no better and lacked the features this one has
Very big surprise. Quality fantastic.

I prefer my Capresso Infinity burr grinder (I give that one five stars). This one has a lot of static to the holder, and the lid gathers grinds. The result is more of a mess. Also, the Capresso just feels a little more solid - lids and parts fit together more snugly. One nice feature with this one is the on/off switch.
Finally! A grinder that doesn't cost a fortune, and delivers a perfect grind every time. Surprisingly quiet and almost no mess to clean up.

This burr grinder works like a charm plus it looks great on my counter. It keeps relatively clean too without too much coffee grinds escaping after grinding. This is the first burr grinder I have owned and it is a definite step up over my cheaper blade grinder. I'm very happy with the purchase.
Love this little grinder! Works well and looks cool in my kitchen. Only grip is the big flat top has some sort of rubber coating which tends to attract dust.

This item is still working as well as the first day I purchased it. The only complaint I have is that when you remove the container of coffee that some coffee grounds fall down from above and make a (small) mess. Otherwise perfect.

Very happy with this, after 2+ years of use. I use it nearly every day to grind coffee beans for my french press, and it's still working very well and looks good on a kitchen counter. I've also bought a second one for a gift, and the recipient is very happy with it.
This coffee bean grinder is the best! I use it everyday and love the way it looks on my counter.
Your search is over! This is the one! Price is right, preforms as indicated. For the money, Bodum is the one I trust! I would buy again, but probably wont have too...

I was looking for an affordable burr grinder that wasn't bulky, and this is that and more! Love the color, relatively quiet, and attractive enough to leave up on the countertop. Overall, good quality grinder. It does leave a bit of ground powder along the sides of the glass container but not enough to complain about.

cheers!

reviews.reviewTitle: I love it! The time and grind settings are user ...
reviews.reviewText: I've had this grinder since end of November 2015 and I've used it every weekend since. I love it! The time and grind settings are user friendly and it's nice plus easy to clean. Basically push a button and wait for it to stop grinding, can't get any easier than this.
Looks pretty but it won’t work

Works great and the settings allow for the perfect grid. The only things I don't like is that the glass cup where the grounds go is staticy, even though it suppose to have an anti-static coating or something.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good performance for a bargain price
reviews.reviewText: When our old Italian burr grinder failed after 7 years, I was tempted to replace it; however, I found this Bodum grinder for half the price and so far (8 months) it performs flawlessly. Only drawback is a 20 second maximum grind time with a 5 minute interval required to grind again.

Bought it as a gift for the S/O and he loves it. Much more quiet than old one. Love the different options of grind type for coffee. Looks great so I don't mind him leaving it out on the counter. Couldn't be the price, cheaper than BBB w/coupon!
Easy to use little grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best burr grinder we have owned so far
reviews.reviewText: Best burr grinder we have owned so far. Glass receptacle for the grind. Grind volume by timer works like a charm.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great buy for anyone serious about coffee
reviews.reviewText:
Great grinder, we've had no problems with it and have used it every day for months. My only issue with it is that it only can make enough coffee for about maybe 4-6 cups at proper strength, which might not be enough for when you have company over and you'd have to run it twice.

Works fine for me and my wife, though, we get fresh ground coffee every day.

Only other negative is that it's kind of noisy, it very well can wake up anyone who is still sleeping when you do the grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect coffee grinder for my application; reliable and well made
reviews.reviewText:
Follow up after 6 years: Still going strong.

This grinder got such mixed reviews that I really struggled to decide on buying it. Well, I am glad I did. It grinds coffee beautifully for brewing both in a french press (fairly coarse) as well as in an espresso machine (fine grind).

It does not heat the coffee when grinding; no more bitter coffee (unless you buy coffee that is over-roasted).

The 20 second limitation on the motor is conservative - I've run it for 40 seconds at a stretch - but in 20 seconds it grinds enough coffee for at least 4 cups.

Yes there is some static - just let it sit for a couple of minutes after grinding. And yes, it gets a bit messy from time to time - nothing a quick wipe won't solve.

Awesome piece of kit. Using it a few months now. One or two grinds a day.
A bit noisy, but not annoying. More of a dull grinding (ha!) than high pitch whine.

I have had this product for about 4 months now and really enjoy it.

Pros:
Consistent grind every time.
Durable and cool looking product.

Cons:
Can't grind a full bin without overheating, you have to let the motor cool down.
Can be messy to clean (as like most grinders).

reviews.reviewTitle: not a quality product like I thought it was going to be when I ...
reviews.reviewText: engine wore out after only 6 months. light to moderate use and was stored and up-kept/cleaned properly. not a quality product like I thought it was going to be when I bought it.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder grinds the coffee perfectly fine for that
reviews.reviewText: We are espresso drinkers. This grinder grinds the coffee perfectly fine for that.

Got this as a gift for my boyfriend who is obsessed with coffee. It's our first one and we absolutely love it! It has a ton of grinding settings, from coarse to super fine, grinds evenly and is very easy to clean out with the right brush. Nearly 4 months later of using it daily and still going strong :)

reviews.reviewTitle: Best burr grinder for the price
reviews.reviewText: we all know you can pay as much as you want to for coffee stuff. This is one of the best priced burr grinders for the money. It was a gift for a fellow coffee grinder. She drinks a lot of espresso, and she is really happy with it. I bring this up, cause when I was reading reviews no one knew what it would do for espresso grinds.)

Works quite well. Does a nice drip grind. Coffee tastes great, too. Removable grinder stator makes cleaning easy. The 20 second grind limit time limit might be a nuisance for folks grinding enough coffee for a full pot, but most of the time I only grind 6 tbsp, which finishes in 17 seconds. Sometimes I grind 10 tbsp, which takes 23 seconds, but I don't think the extra 3 seconds without bothering to wait the 5 min rest time is going to smoke the machine.

This is my first grinder, and so far its amazing! The espresso setting is perfect for a Moka Express (Bialetti), and for drip coffee I like the medium grind +1 (towards espresso). Unfortunately, now I'm addicted to fresh ground coffee, and I need to upgrade my drip machine.
It grinds to the setting just fine, but I lose a lot of ground coffee inside the machine. I shake it out weekly. It really makes a mess...and wastes coffee.
Bought this for my daughter for Christmas - nice compact look. Works well. She told me it still has static she has experienced with other burr coffee grinders, but not as much.
This was a replacement for the same grinder that was 5 or 6 years old that suddenly stopped running. I wish it would've lasted longer for the price I paid but it is amazing!

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice product but a bit expensive
reviews.reviewText: Quality is in same range as other grinder half the price. It keeps dropping residual coffee grind after you have lifted the glass container even after shaking it to make sure all the coffee is out. As the result do not buy the White model, it will have coffee smudged on it after a few grinds making it difficult to clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: This worked so good the first time 3-4 years ago
reviews.reviewText:
This worked so good the first time 3-4 years ago, we went and got another. I just wish it would last a little longer. This burr grinder does an excellent job. I did a lot of research, and for what it offers, it is great for the price.
Super fast delivery from this company. No problems.
Perfect for the price. Grinds whole beans to size for french press or espresso. Very satisfied so far.

Excellent burr grinder. You can adjust the coarseness to your tastes/needs. The glass fill container is slightly on the smaller side so you need to fill it more than once for larger groups. Otherwise, I've had zero problems in two years. Great, great product!!
Coffee clogs up inside after a few weeks use and must be dug out.

reviews.reviewTitle: HUGE difference in the taste of my cofee.
reviews.reviewText: I can taste a huge difference between beans ground in a blade grinder, and beans ground in this burr grinder. They say to empty the hopper after every 20second grind to cool the motor. but i'm not going to do that. Way too much work. and why would they make a airtight hopper if it wasn't meant for storage.

My Coffee Grinder broke because a small part inside broke, and the company was not very accommodating about fixing it. Poor customer service. Good coffee grinder while it worked, but overall a bad experience.
I love the grind on my beans and it couldn't be easier to operate.

reviews.reviewTitle: I’ve had two of these. Both broke before the ...
reviews.reviewText: I’ve had two of these. Both broke before the 18 month mark. I’d be a fool to buy another.

Worked very well for 6 months (though it grinds only a small amount at a time). But then it quit entirely--after just 6 months. I would have been delighted with it if it had continued, but at that price I expect something to last for quite a while longer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do not purchase - broke just after return window closed - poorly made.
reviews.reviewText: This item stopped working just after the return window closed. Do not purchase this item.
Great grinder , just not for espresso

reviews.reviewTitle: The bodum grinds nicely and is easy to operate
reviews.reviewText: The bodum grinds nicely and is easy to operate. This morning however we wanted to grind some coffee and discovered that the grind button on top had fallen into the machine never to be retrieved. Something of a design flaw.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does the job and looks good
reviews.reviewText: This is a great grinder, bottom line. It gives all the control over the grind and time as you could ever need and the components are pretty easy to clean. It gets a little messy, but what grinder doesn't? It looks so good too, I got the white with the red buttons. Highly recommend.

I use a french press every morning to brew my coffee. Of course I grind the beans right before brewing but my blade grinder was producing way too much fine dust that turned into sludge in the bottom of my coffee mug. The Bodum conical burr grinder produces uniform sized grains, perfect for my french press. The air tight hopper holds almost a pound of beans making my coffee routine fast in the morning. I should have gotten one sooner.
Produces a very consistent grind, and is much quieter than any other grinder I've used, I love it.
Best coffee grinder I've ever had. I really like the glass beaker-like carafe, too.
I had to change this grinder every other year.
The Bodum Bistrio Electric Burr Coffee grinder is a great grinder. Works perfectly and is quiter than the old blade grinder that I have used for years. For the money, it is the best coffee grinder.

Works great for french press. Minimal coffee dust. Its a bit loud but thats notmal. It also looks great on the counter and looks to be well made. Ive had it for about 3 months now and use it every day.

I do love that this is a quality burr grinder and holds the beans. It annoys me how most of the time static in the glass jar causes a huge mess. I'm not sure if it's just dependent on the oiliness of certain beans. I have wiped the jar with a cloth napkin and it helped slightly. This does do a great job of consistently grinding the beans. It does take some trial and error to get the grind and time settings down.
I don't think the timer is working. Would like some feedback.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good so far (only been using it for a few ...
reviews.reviewText: Good so far (only been using it for a few weeks). Works great and not too loud. Only annoying thing is that the 20 sec. limit isn't enough time to grind beans for a full pot of coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Truly one of the greatest purchases I have ever made
reviews.reviewText: This is the only coffee grinder you will ever need. Paired with a french press and a hangover, this will change your life and more immediately, mood.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good Grinder but makes a serious mess often
reviews.reviewText:
Good Grinder but makes a serious mess often.

It retains grinds and you have to smack it over the sink or garbage to get them out.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stylish and functional. It holds a lot of beans ...
reviews.reviewText: Stylish and functional. It holds a lot of beans up top. No sure about the claim of being quiet. It's quit noisy in my opinion.
so far so good... I went from the Budum blade to this burr grinder.. easy to use and very effective
Used for a long time now. This grinder deals with two coffee fiends. It has survived. It is the best grinder for the money.

reviews.reviewTitle: Choose this over burr grinders with plastic receivers
reviews.reviewText: Love this grinder. The best feature is the glass receiver. Grinds are easy to transfer from grinder to coffee maker with no static cling.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grind control not the best, but it gets the job done.
reviews.reviewText: My only complaint is that the grind control isn't the best. Plus, the unit could do a better job producing more uniform grinds. Still beats a blade grinder though. Not sure it's worth the large price.

reviews.reviewTitle: The best grinder I have had
reviews.reviewText: This is one of many better burr grinders I have had but it is the best by far. It is relatively quiet, very easy to work with and easily adjusted for the one huge cup of coffee I make at a time. The hopper is easy to fill and holds enough beans. The chamber that the ground coffee goes into is just right, easy to remove and grip and empty. Look no further, this is a great value.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect for a small french press
reviews.reviewText:
For a small french press, this is absolutely perfect. I only have to run it for 7 seconds to get the amount I need (two coffee scoops). The grind is perfect, the coffee tastes fresh and delicious. The footprint is small, too, and it has an elegant look on the counter. It's a bit loud, but otherwise, I love it.
6 months later: still love it.
Has worked great for about five years now. I have ground it course for my percolator, and more fine for my coffee machine. I would recommend this product as reliable.

Whew, I FINALLY found what I've wanted in a grinder. It is quiet, grinds the beans just as desired and in uniform pieces. The best is how the grinds end up in my french press and not all over my counter. What used to be a messy procedure to make coffee is now a simple process. I love it.
We use it for French press and it is amazing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love it, but fragile glass catcher
reviews.reviewText:
First: the list price is not $185, it's $120 (see Bodum's website).

I really like this grinder. It's the only burr grinder I've had, so I don't have much to compare it to. I really like timed grind feature. I just give the start button a quick press each morning and it shuts off after 10 seconds. I also like the large hopper.

It's louder than the Baratza grinder, but that's not much of a con because it's only on 10 seconds a day.

Unfortunately, the glass catcher only lasted a little over a year. I normally give it a knock on the bottom -- with my knuckles -- to get the bulk of the remaining grinds out. One morning that was too much for it and it broke. Also, it's not much of a negative, but the plastic cover fits too loosely on the catcher.

I'd buy it again, but be careful with the glass catcher.

reviews.reviewTitle: Had it for 6 months. Grinds evenly on all ...
reviews.reviewText: Had it for 6 months. Grinds evenly on all settings.

Never any problems. Adjusts for type of grind I need. Easy to use. Small footprint and very stylish. Have had other brands but they were messy to use, bulky, not as efficient. Highly recommend the Bodum Bistro Coffee Grinder.
My second one, the first is on my sailboat. This BISTRO grinds really fine it's improved over my 4 year old model.

You can spend a ton of money on a grinder but as long as you're not using an expensive espresso machine that requires one this Bodum grinder is great. I mainly use it for french press and the aeropress and it works great for both. Looks nice on the kitchen counter too.
Below average grinder and advertised as less mess but it is worse than my cuisinart.
Pretty quiet. Looks great. Very happy. Love the glass jar.
This is the best economical burr grinder out there. If you are serious about coffee grind, but are not ready to spend a fortune, here is the solution!

i've owned this grinder for a few years. I do not recommend it.

1. over time it develops a sticky residue on the outside. according to bodum they responded to my complain and said one of the causes for this is when it's placed next to a heat source and there was nothing i could do. serious? OBVIOUSLY it's next to a heat source. how else am i supposed to make coffee? also, you can do something about it... lots of elbow grease.

2. once you put beans in you are instructed not to change the grind setting. bad design if you ask me.

3. you are instructed not to grind for too long otherwise you will burn out the motor. this is fine if you only grind for one cup. there are alternative grinders in the same price range that do better than this one and do not have this limitation so why would you buy this one?

4. this unit get clogged more easily than i think it should. subjective on my part. turns out grinding rice is the trick but if you didnt know that it's a big pain to clean the innards because it's hard to reach inside.

5. after you remove the container, leftover grinds fall to the bottom. messy.
Works pretty well, but PUTRID PINK, Not RED
It worked well for the 7 years it lasted. But then it died.

reviews.reviewText: I really like this. Seems sturdy. I espessially appreciate the glass container which does not collect static electricity. With regular cleaning I figure it'll be several years till it breaks down

Pro's
Great grinding consistency when set on very fine. Other settings might be good, too, but I always had it on fine.

Cons:
1. Inconsistent yield - i.e., quantity of coffee.
Consecutive grinds of the same time (e.g., 15-seconds) yield VASTLY different quantities of coffee. Ground coffee piles up in the discharge chute little jog required because the receiver is not immediately below the burrs. This piled up coffee breaks free sporadically. The only way to get consistent yields is to smack the mill repeatedly to free the grounds so they will fall into the receiver.

2. Only 20 seconds of grinding for every five minutes allowed.

3. Short-Lived
Perhaps because I had to smack it so much, it broke this morning, 09 Apr 2012, 147 days after I ordered it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Save you hours of research - this is the one - read on
reviews.reviewText:
I have researched these things for hours before deciding to buy this unit. Here are my findings:

There are three units that were in the running (ordered by price):

a. Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder (the unit on this page and the one I ultimately bought and am very happy with) - $89.99
b. Breville BCG800XL Smart Grinder - $199.99
c. Rancilio ROCKY Rancilio Burr Grinder with Doser - $359.99

Now, if price is not an issue, by all means go with the Breville BCG800XL (really can't go wrong with that one). Also, notice that all of these are burr grinders (blade grinders are NOT the way to go) and all are excellent machines; all other machines researched under $400 have serious drawbacks - trust me - I've done the research.

Okay, now let's take a look at each one.

--- a. Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder, Black - this is an excellent unit all around and the one I bought:

-- Grind:
Very consistent and perfect size for drip on drip setting; I have tried this with a drip coffee maker and it is excellent. Some say that it can't quite match the best machines out there for a cappuccino grind (i.e. very very very fine for very very picky machines) but I do not have a cappuccino machine and so this does not really concern me all that much.

-- Mess:
Awesome, no mess at all. The glass catcher reduces the static on the grinds so that they do not jump (no idea how some complain about mess); no mess here.
After catcher is removed, no excess coffee spills out.

-- Noise:
Not very loud at all; I thought it would be louder. Two scaredy cats in my house and both did not even wake up (same room as the appliance).

-- Cleanup:
Super easy; just rinse the catcher and you are done.

-- Features:
Timer -> 5-20 second; set it once, and it stays from grind to grind. 10 seconds was perfect for my mug (4 cups).

-- Build Quality:
Excellent all around with a glass catcher and plastic hopper. The burrs are very well machined.

-- Looks/Size:
The machine is on the small size but very good looking (I have a black one).

-- Cons:
Motor "should" (at least that is what the manual recommends) rest for 5 minutes before every 20 second grind. Really, for me, this is not an issue as 20 seconds produces about 6-8 cups of medium strength coffee.
Bean hopper is not tinted so leaving beans in it (especially in the light) may not be a great idea but you should not leave beans in the hopper in any case as suggested by all of the other machine's manuals.
Some claim that very very fine cappuccino grinds are not acceptable for very picky cappuccino machines; go figure.
Adjusting the grind size can only be done with the motor running (or so claims the manual). Not a big deal for me since I do not plan to adjust it ... well ... ever after the initial setting (doesn't have to have beans in it but just running motor while adjusting).

--- b. Breville BCG800XL Smart Grinder - if money is not an issue, why not - I could find really nothing wrong with it except the price.

-- Grind:
From doing much research, this thing really gets it right for anything you want; even the pickiest cappuccino machines like this thing. French press is also no problem.

-- Mess:
No mess; static is eliminated by their special technology that slows the coffee grinds before they get to the catcher.

-- Noise:
Very quite.

-- Cleanup:
Cannot comment on cleanup but people have said that it is not a problem.

-- Features:
Built in doser - very nice; will auto grind correct amount based on your cup and strength setting.
Nice LCD screen.
Bean hopper is tinted.

-- Build Quality:
Customers claim that it is very solid and well built.

-- Looks/Size:
Looks very nice.

-- Cons:
Price.

--- c. Rancilio ROCKY Rancilio Burr Grinder with Doser - if you want the best, this is it for a reasonable price (reasonable to some, all depends).

Specs:
I am not going to go into detail about this one but needless to say that those very serious about their cappuccino grind, etc. and for whom money is no issue should probably get this machine. Frankly, for this much money, I see no reason.

Conclusion:
- The Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder is an excellent all around machine with very minor (at least to me) drawbacks and if one is to consider the price/performance ratio, simply cannot be beat. Best of luck and hope this review saves some hours of research.

HOWEVER, when I put it to its finest setting, for espresso, it just doesn't quite get the coffee fine enough. As I tried to adjust for a perfect espresso shot from my Breville 800ESXL, the water flowed through the grinds too fast, no matter how hard I tamped down the grinds. It gets VERY close to the fine grind needed, but just not quite fine enough. I'm so disappointed!!
I guess I have to buy a burr grinder that includes a Turkish coffee setting (which I have never tried to make), so that I can have the latitude to bring the grind to its correct size.

I would be curious to know if other people have had the same experience, or maybe I just got one that happened to be calibrated slightly incorrectly. Now I am considering buying a Capresso grinder, which is not as beautifully designed, and has more plastic, but maybe it will get the grinding done correctly for espresso.

Update: I purchased, and am loving, for all espresso grinds: Capresso 565 Infinity Conical Burr Grinder, Stainless Steel

reviews.reviewTitle: FRENCH PRESS Coffee Lovers - Please Read!!!
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this burr grinder based on the reviews, price point and look - which I really love. My coffee of choice is French or Pot Press - for me it brings out the best flavor and full body and I love a big mug each morning, usually a darker roast. The problem is the coarsest setting from this machine is still too small to make great French Press - see my pictures showing the largest ground size from this grinder vs the coarse setting on a supermarket grinder set to Coarse. That picture shows the average size of the Bodum is roughly half that of the standard size coarse grind.

For French Press here's the thing. First, we all know to start with good, nearly boiling, water and freshly ground, quality beans. The rest is in the preparation - the ratio of water to beans, size of the ground, and steep time make a huge difference in the taste. To get that full flavor takes time but too much time makes for a bitter cup. A small grind needs less time to avoid the bitterness. For myself it took close to week, reworking my recipe once each morning until I got a cup good enough that I wanted to finish but none have come close to the best French Press brew I've tasted with the same beans. My longer 4, sometimes 5 minute total time resulted in a bitter taste. Reducing the time too much give a weak taste so changing the ratio of water to beans will help compensate. I pretty much have that finally worked out now using 3 - 3 1/2 minutes time before it turns bitter but the body is a bit less than what I learned to love. A coarser ground and about 4 minutes or so would do the trick but the coarsest setting is not that coarse - see my customer pictures.

Aside for that I do love this grinder, the design, including the glass receptacle - which is much better than plastic for static, the ease or use... and it does make a very nice fine grind - for that I give it 5 stars. However, if you are looking for a burr grinder that does coarse grinding for French Press then look further since for that I give it only 1 star. I will likely return it since my morning cup/mug is not as special as it used to be. That said, the best affordable replacement for my needs is not obvious - my research frequently turns up comments like `most inexpensive burr grinders don't do well for French Press.'
Didnot last long

Used a total of 5 times or about 100 seconds and while the motor continued to run all grinding action ceased. Have returned to Bodum customer service in NYC. They have had over a two weeks and have yet to hear from them.

Well Since I wrote above a Bodine has sent a new replacement unit. Don't know how long this one will last. Will update this shortly.

This grinder is very difficult to use. The maximum grinding time at any one use is supposed to be 30 seconds, but it always shuts off after only 5, or 10 seconds. And sometimes pushing the grind button does nothing. So you have to keep twisting the bean holder to get it to grind again, and then it only will grind for a few seconds. Very frustrating. Not to mention that the grinds end up all over your counter, and you are forced to clean every element of the machine after every use, or else the grinds will be everywhere.

We purchased this since we wanted to finally get a higher quality grinder compared to the one we purchased in the store. It is expensive so we figured it would work better than the cheaper ones. Unfortunately we ended up hiding this away in our cabinets since it doesn't work well. It does grind but it has terrible static issues. It makes an absolute mess of our kitchen every time we use it. We contacted Bodum but they said we were doing something wrong and it was our fault. They would not give any suggestion besides you different coffee. We tried cheap and expensive coffee brands and nothing seemed to work. We even tried spray oiling it and even rubbing static sheets on it with suggestion from forums. Nothing worked. It's a simple device and look sharp but if you don't have the time to clean the static coffee grinds off your counters, the machine and your coffee maker, then I would definitely go with another brand.

The first one lasted days before it stopped working and thanks to Amazon we exchanged it for a new one, which has lasted 2 months and now won't grind anymore.

This is total junk. Find another grinder.
to early for rating.

I may return this item, if it hasn't been too long. I've been struggling with trying to reduce the static it produces. The grind is good, the unit is easy to use, but - it sprays ground coffee everywhere as soon as the container is removed from the grinding part. Then you have to take the rubber lid off, and more coffee flies. Then you put the coffee into your machine and guess what? more coffee grounds all over the place. This is not a minor drawback. My coffee area is a mess from all the flying grounds - counter, floor, everywhere. This product is not worth it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very quiet for a burr grinder. Small grounds container. Has plusses and minuses.
reviews.reviewText:
This is a really nice burr grinder with plusses (++) and some noteworthy minuses (--).

++ Very quiet operation when compared to two other burr grinders I've had. Very important if you don't like loud noise in the morning.
++ Does a good job producing evenly-sized grounds. No big chunks of beans get through. The consistency of the grind seems to produce more consistency in the brewed coffee, at least in my experience.
++ The hopper lid has a silicone ring that creates a seal. This might be a factor in how quiet the grinder is, but is possibly for keeping beans stored int he hopper fresh. I typically do not store beans in the hopper, but I suppose this ring could make that a possibility since it would limit the amount of air the beans are in contact with.
++ Easy to set up and use.
++ Attractive enough to keep out on counter.

-- The grounds container is small. If you are grinding enough coffee to brew a big pot of coffee (8-10 cups), you will have to empty the cup halfway through the amount of beans needed for that. This is the biggest drawback, imo.
-- The grounds container is narrow. I can't fit two of my coffee measuring scoops into it and have to pour the grou0nds into them. It's a bit messy to do that because of the next point.
-- The grounds container is very static-prone. This makes pouring the grinds out of it a little trickier than it should be. The status may abate somewhat over time, but initially there is more static than usual and it causes some of the grinds to go AWOL when pouring them out and also to stick to the grinder.

+- It's difficult to read the grind level indicator. You rotate the red ring under the bean hopper to choose how coarse or fine you want the grind to be, but the indicators for those grinds are in raised icons and hashes on the ring, so you have to be in the right light for that to be visible. If you consistently use the same grind, this is not a problem. But if you change grinds depending on what coffeemaker you are using, you are either going to have to get a feel for this or put the grinder in a place where you can see the markings.
+- The initial product description says there is a timer. There is not. That is fine with me since I prefer not to keep beans in the hopper and grind only what I intend to use at the time.

The Bottom Line: Even with the minuses, I prefer this grinder over the others I've had primarily because of the lack of noise. I really hate loud noise in the morning and noise this grinder makes is very tolerable. The consistency of the grind is also very good and I think that contributes to better brewing. The small capacity of the container may be the biggest problem for those who brew large pots of coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: The plastic has a weird smell
reviews.reviewText: I bought this model because there were so many positive reviews. Nobody thought to mention that the plastic has a weird, very strong smell, that makes the unit unusable.

The first two weeks of using this grinder was like Nirvana. Then I was a small snapping sound and the extremely fine grind went to a small, but more regular grind. It was built so that I couldn't take it apart far enough to actually get at the problem.

Fast forward another year, another sound, and suddenly it was barely working at all and making it is noises. I decided to take it apart and fix it no matter what and I discovered the assembly process of this grinder is such that you literally cannot take it all the way it apart to fix things because the case plastic is welded together after assembly. Some of the power cords just don't pull out far enough for you to get at some of the screws you need to. At this price there is no way in heck I would recommend anyone buy it. In fact at any price. Something that could be a 10 20 30 or even 40 your product is reduced to a single year. I won't be buying Bodum again and I suggest you avoid buying from them as well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Update: It has died, not a great warranty** Going strong after of 4 years of daily grinding
reviews.reviewText:
*Updated review*
The grinder has now stopped working. Sometimes it won't turn on and when it does it makes an awful metallic grinding sound. I reached out to customer service to see if anything could be done to salvage the machine, but they were unable to help. Because of this I'm going to try the OXO Brew grinder this time around, it has a better warranty and Bodum didn't earn my loyalty for a repeat purchase. I took off a star for this.

**********

My partner and I use this grinder at least three times a day and have done so for over four years. I make two pour overs and he has a morning espresso. . I love that the grind settings are easy to change. I do not store beans in the hopper, but in a cabinet in an airtight container. We've moved three times since owning it and the grinder has held up wonderfully to movers tossing it about. I brush it out probably three times a year using a straw cleaner. I bought this after returning a grinder that was double the price because of annoying static cling. This grinder's glass container doesn't have that problem. As a side note, it looks like there are a lot of fake one star reviews of this product, not sure why.

reviews.reviewTitle: It does the job and frees up your hands while working in the kitchen
reviews.reviewText:
This grinds great coffee and is easy to clean. However it is also easy to get dirty. The grounds accumulate underneath the collection piece for some reason, maybe loose design tolerances. This creates a need to clean it more than I would like to. It would also be nicer if the collection piece had thicker plastic and felt more durable

One perk of this grinder compared to my other Bodum grinder is that I can start this and walk away for a couple minutes while it works, rather than holding a button down the entire duration.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice design, good grind, some plasticky parts
reviews.reviewText:
I own and have used this grinder for several years now, and it's going strong without any of the problems reported by other people. I think proper setup is crucial to make sure you don't prematurely wear/stress components, especially some of the plastic ones surrounding the steel burrs.

The actual metal components are hefty and durable, I've noticed no change in performance over nearly four years. But the burrs sit in white plastic fittings that feel a little fragile. They also only fit in one way, though they look like they would fit a couple of different ways. I still get confused when I remove things to clean them, which you will need to do every few months to keep everything moving smoothly. The hopper comes off the top, which acts as a tensioner on the "male" part of the burr, which sits atop the "female" part. Those two components need to have the dust and grit cleaned off and for the male section to be set back the correct way. There are two small lugs which look the same to my eyes, but one lug is apparently different than the other. As I mentioned, if you assemble it the wrong way the grind will be way off (way too fine for brewing coffee). Unfortunately it requires a bit of re-cleaning to reassemble it.

This grinder definitely requires a little bit of patience. If you're careful, though, it will obviously last well beyond the time that I have had it. The styling is certainly a high point. We have the lime green model and it looks classy and unique.

reviews.reviewTitle: Solid, affordable conical burr grinder with a few minor annoyances
reviews.reviewText:
I received the Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder as a gift, and it's my second burr grinder - the other being the Capresso Infinity I use in my office. Between the two, I think the Capresso is a better overall product, BUT the Bodum retails for about $20 to $30 cheaper, is relatively compact, and seems to get the job done nicely.

If you're bothering to read a review of an electric burr grinder on Amazon, you probably already know that a quality, consistent grind is right up there with water quality and temperature as the most important things you can control in brewing a perfect cup of coffee. Steel blade grinders, while cheap and small, tend to pulverize and heat coffee grounds. While maybe 60% of them look to be properly-shaped coffee grounds, the variation in grind size and particularly the pulverized powder/dust generated by blade grinders will result in a bitter brew, more often than not. That's where a quality conical burr grinder can help, and the Bodum is arguably the most affordable genuine electrical conical burr grinder on the mass market.

I believe it has roughly a dozen different grind size settings, which is a few less than the Capresso Inifinity, and significantly less than the Baratza Encore (which is a partial step up in quality from the other two, from what I hear). But I find that it does a passable job at covering the range from fine grinds to a coarser setting you'd use from a steeping method like French Press or maybe AeroPress.

The Bodum Bistro operates differently than the Capresso in that it has both a timer and an on/off button. Actually, the Bodum allows you to shut off the grinder at any time by pressing the button again. Otherwise, it runs for the length of time you set it at. While this is a slightly higher degree of control than the Capresso, I don't find that it adds much of benefit. The key for both machines is how long they hold up, and I haven't had either long enough to know the answer yet. But the Bodum seems to be solidly built for its price point.

One thing I read in countless reviews was that the glass receptacle of the Bodum was larger and less static-prone than the other grinders, but I haven't found this to be the case. In fact, it seems like it attracts more grinds than my Capresso, though it is easier to wipe out given it is a perfect cylinder with no jagged shapes to navigate. The inner gear mechanism is decently easy to remove and clean out, though it is very hard to clean thoroughly, even with a long handle soft brush (which I recommend, as it does not come with one).

The upper collection bin for receiving whole beans opens up wide like a funnel for convenience. This is nice for adding beans, but also adds to the storage size of the device, which is otherwise quite compact. If noise level matters to you (in an office or home setting), I do think that the Capresso is notably quieter than the Bodum, though it's a minor gripe.

I'm generally happy with the Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder. The only reason I'm rating it 4 stars is that I felt like the grind consistency is not quite as good as similarly-priced devices, and it isn't quite as easy to clean and maintain as I'd anticipated. But it's good see a decent conical burr grinder well below the $100 price point.

UPDATE (04/10/17): Definitely standing by my 4-star review. By and large, it's a great value. The top coffee gear review sites seem to agree that this is the most affordable burr grinder that more or less produces burr-grinder consistency. That being said, the more that I use the Bodum versus my Capresso Infinity at the office, the more clear it is to me that the Infinity is noticeably better. And that's me noticing both a visual and a taste difference despite being relatively new to this stuff. So, if you really need to save another $25, or you end up with a Bodum Bistro as a gift, don't fret - it's a good machine. But, ideally, given the choice of picking between all the options in this price tier, I think there are some better options.

UPDATE (06/26/17): Rating unchanged, but I have figured out over time that my particular Bodum Bistro burr grinder requires a much coarser setting than corresponds to the pictures on the grinder and suggestions in the manual. I was getting a lot of bitter/overextracted brews initially, but I now use a setting of 2.5 or 3 "dots" to the right of the center "drip" position, and a full 4 "dots" to the right for Chemex, which requires a medium-coarse grind. All grinders vary from unit to unit, and you just need to experiment with yours, starting with settings that are too coarse and working your way finer until happy. Still prefer the Capresso Inifinity to this model by a fair margin, but much happier with the Bodum after finding the proper settings.

reviews.reviewTitle: Mine has worked 3+ years no issue.
reviews.reviewText:
There are several reviews here talking about how their Bodum Burr Grinder broke down after only 1 or 2 years, etc. Just be wary of this because the vast majority of people have enjoyed many years of function from this machine, including myself. I had the original one in black, purchased in 2014 and it has functioned for 3 years, with at least every-other-day use without issue. Unfortunately I lost it in my last breakup, as my partner had also grown extremely fond of it and wanted to hang onto it. I am now purchasing the new aluminum (chrome) version.

IMPORTANT. Please note that this is a CONICAL burr grinder. Burr grinders are NOT made the same. A mechanical/FLAT burr grinder is essentially USELESS for making fine grind for ESPRESSO. This is therefore, the CHEAPEST, highest quality CONICAL burr grinder for the money. It has very nice touches, such as the glass catcher, which is essentially much better than all of the competition because plastic has a magnetic draw to coffee grind and it is very difficult to empty out the coffee you grind. It is also annoying to have to frequently clean a plastic catcher. Having all of the grains come nicely out of this glass receptacle is very nice since you don't have to rinse/clean it as often. The silicone top of the hopper is also reassuring that less air gets in and degrades/oxidizes the beans that sit there for days to weeks.
