Competitors hoppers have a PLASTIC top that does NOT seal air out as well.

Do your research, this is hands down the best conical burr grinder you can find in the $100 range.

reviews.reviewTitle: Unreliable Electronics (Button) - Expect to Replace Unit
reviews.reviewText: With conical burr grinders purportedly yielding the best results, you can expect to make a modest investment in a decent bean grinder. I have owned two of these Bodum bistro grinders and have found the grind button to be unreliable at best. Eventually the red 'start/grind' button fails. I have found that I either have to keep the button depressed until the right contact is made, or I have to depress the button multiple times until proper contact is made and the 'engine' kicks in. I will not be buying a third from Bodum. This review was solely based on my experience. Your individual mileage may vary.

Build quality: 5/10. It seizes up and makes a horrible sound with about half of the beans I put in it. I started realizing it was the small beans not grinding. It has a "feature" to not grind small "stones" in coffee, I believe this to be related. Not sure how you end up with a stone in your coffee beans but "feature" is far too sensitive. Ended up returning due to this.
Grind: 8/10. I was getting pretty consistent ground size with large beans. I like the grind fineness selector by style (french press-->espresso) rather than number.
Ergonomics: 10/10. The glass container allows you to get 99% of your coffee out cleanly after the grind which is far better than the static-y plastic containers. Settings are intuitive and easy to clean.
Style: 9/10. Looks purdy, lots of color options.
Loudness: 7/10. Compared to three other burr grinders I've used, it's about average- which is loud (~90 dBA at 1 meter). You're probably going to wake the house up when you make morning coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poorly designed electronic control will fail.
reviews.reviewText: The last one of these I bought lasted 5 years. The failure mode in my case was a 5W power resistor that runs current as long as the power switch is on -- very poor design. However I am buying another one. Why? Because of all the coffee grinders I tried in a million stores, this one was the quietest. Unfortunately, its predecssor, the Antigua was more reliable, using an electromechanical system, not poorly designed chinesium electronics. In any case, turn off power switch when not in use. Then the failure mode will be the power switch, not the resistor. Oh well.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'll be looking for a different brand
reviews.reviewText: Color me disappointed. I got this almost exactly one year ago for my birthday (July 1) and today (July 6), it died. RIP. I am a big fan of Bodum products and have three French presses by them, along with a glass tea pot and warmer. I expected good quality from Bodum, not to have to replace after just one year of light use (one grind per day, maximum).
Horrible, don't waste your money on this...

reviews.reviewTitle: Plastic parts gave up after 5.5 years
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this model on clearance (thankfully) from a department store in Nov. 2013. It just gave up the ghost last week. The motor still works fine, but obviously one of the plastic parts inside broke, preventing the grinder from operating. Now I have to make due with an old, reliable (if imprecise) blade grinder that has been collecting dust these past 5.5 years while I shop for something more reliable (i.e. all-metal parts). It was good while it lasted.

Thanks for contributing to our planet's waste, Bodum; this kind of planned obsolescence drives me nuts. It's the last product of yours I'll buy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Cheap ruberized plastic housing disintegrates into a sticky mess
reviews.reviewText:
It worked well for about a year then the grind coarseness would slowly adjust itself while it was grinding. This meant you had to sit there and baby sit the grinder by holding the courses dial in place instead of prepping water or whatever else. After around 2 years the rubberized coating began break down and take on a tacky texture as if the entire grinder was covered in half dry glue. I cant really fault the grinder for this but it finally met it's match when a bag of Costco brand coffee had a stone it that went unnoticed and the plastic gears pretty much ground themselves to nothing before we knew what was happening.

All in all it worked pretty well and I would buy it again if it weren't for the rubber coating disintegrating to a sticky mess

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great after it breaks in.
reviews.reviewText:
After years of getting my beans ground from the local Starbucks, something changed and their ability to grind espresso correctly went downhill. So, for Christmas, I asked for one of these based on the glowing reviews.

First impressions where good. The glass receptacle is great and the overall build quality doesn't seem too bad. It looks pretty good on the counter too.

I make a latte every morning and was counting on this to make constant espresso grind. It DOES do that very well, if you can get the beans to go through it. Setting the dial to French Roast feed the beans pretty well so it seems. But turning it down close to the finer espresso grind caused the motor to emit a high pitched whine and the feeding of beans to, um, grind to a halt.

No amount of cajoling could get the beans to feed again. I took it apart and cleaned it only to have it happen again. Only dropping the beans into the hopper a few at a time by hand seemed to work. This, of course, doesn't grind fast enough to get enough to fill the espresso filter in one "session" so multiple grinding (with sometimes a 5 minute wait between) is needed.

To be fair, this MAY be attributed to the very oily Starbucks espresso beans. But, IMHO, a good grinder should be able to deal with such beans. I will update my review though as I find out more (only on my second grind attempt).

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

UPDATE: After using now a little over 2 months, and running several pounds of beans through, I can say that I really like it. It took a little patience at first but once it broke in, it feeds really well now. Even new and oily Starbucks beans it grinds well. Took a little to find the exact setting that my espresso machine liked but now it's consistent, easy to use, and not too messy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good and bad stuff, but has been a 5yr workhorse for us.
reviews.reviewText:
I've owned it for 5 years and used at least once a day making V60 pour over batches.
Positives: Great burrs, just now noticing after 5 years the machine is taking a little longer than it used to to clear the grinding hopper. Glass reservoir is a nice alternative to static inducing plastic. Very consistent grind quality throughout setting range, a huge strong point of this grinder.

Negatives: Holds at least Tbs of grounds that get trapped within burr chamber, and dumps on counter when you pull out the glass reservoir. Annoying. If the feed went straight through to the cup below it would be far less. Needs a sharp rap on the side to help shake it free so it drops into the glass cup.
The rubbery red coating on mine is now tacky and sticky and feels gross. Reminds me of our early 2000 VW Jetta interior that used the same type of coating that also got sticky and peeled.

reviews.reviewTitle: Have had mine over eight years and love it.
reviews.reviewText:
I have used one of these every weekend, holiday, and vacation day for more than eight years. I recommend it because it does a great job, but you need to know a few things:

I have always observed the 5 minute wait between 20sec grinds. It needs this because heat builds up inside during the grind an it needs to cool back down. Harder beans or finer grinds will make it heat up more.

I use Sam's Club whole bean coffee which is quite oily. It does make the grounds tend to stick and a little messy after the grind, but not a big deal. Gently tapping the glass Coffee Catcher and lid after a grind reduces static sticking.

As far as cleaning, I marked the setting for my drip grind and clean the burrs a few times a year. Otherwise it's just a wipe with a paper towel. I have never had a clog, and would never grind rice to clean it because rice is quite hard.

reviews.reviewTitle: Before I had a Hario hand grinder which worked great if you don't mind taking the time to grind ...
reviews.reviewText:
So this is my first electric conical grinder. Before I had a Hario hand grinder which worked great if you don't mind taking the time to grind your beans by hand.
From my point of view, this product does have both positives and negatives.
Positives: I love the look and the size, as well, as the amount of beans it can fit in the hopper. Also, as it's a timed grinder, I appreciate that they give you a guide on the underside of the lid to tell you how much ground coffee your going to need and at what setting. Speaking of, it's incredibly easy to change the grind setting. Just turn the hopper to change the grind setting. I also like the glass, hand blown ground container which the coffee gets ground into.
Negatives: in my review there's really only one and I hear that Bodum has done what they can to mitigate the problem. That is the static electricity which causes the grounds to stick to the container after grinding. I've heard it's worse with plastic receptacles so that's why they've decided to use a glass container. Plus, the glass container just looks nicer, more of a quality product.
And one thing which I just thought of, it is a little noisy, but as I read reviews before purchase, I've heard this is a quieter one than average.
All in all, a great product. Would definitely purchase again.

reviews.reviewTitle: A burr grinder that brings out coffee's true flavor
reviews.reviewText: There's a lot to like about this burr grinder. First, the design is stylish and it feels like it's very well-made. The surface has a rubberized feel so it's easy to grip or move around without slipping. It's bigger than the typical blade grinder, but is still compact enough that it doesn't take up too much counter space. The lids seal well on the coffee bean grinder and the ground coffee holder. I've been using it for about a month with a variety of whole bean coffees and have noticed a positive difference in flavor. I'd say the true flavor of the coffee comes through stronger than with my blade grinder. Especially with the finer grind settings, such as espresso. It can grind the coffee into superfine powder and the taste is amazing. It grinds a little quieter than the typical blade grinder which is a nice feature. There's a hidden cord-wrap on the bottom of the base so you can hide most of the electrical cord. A little detail, but helpful. There were a few issues I've found that made me give it 4 stars instead of 5, despite the great tasting coffee I've been enjoying. Like others mentioned, the instruction manual says to you need to let the motor rest for 5 minutes in between 20 second grinding sessions to prevent overheating. If you're someone just grinding enough coffee for a few cups, this shouldn't be a problem, but if you're grinding more, obviously it takes more time because you're waiting in between grinding sessions. The manual also mentions that you have to empty the coffee bean container after grinding for 20 seconds in order to prevent the motor from overheating. Again, this will be another step if you grind more than enough coffee for a few cups. For a coffee grinder that looks so big and sturdy, I guess I'd expected it would be able to handle grinding more coffee easily at one time. Since I don't usually grind all that much at once, it hasn't been too much of an inconvenience but for someone who plans to grind enough for 8-12 cups or more, it could getting a little annoying having to wait for 5 minutes between each 20 second session. Still, I'm happy with this grinder because my coffee tastes better than ever and I like having the convenience of the automatic settings that do course, medium or fine grind.

The five stars are for value for price. I’ve used this grinder (purchased from another vendor) every day for about four years and have had a mostly very good experience. The only issue I had was with the machine shifting from a fine grind to a coarser grind on occasion, but that was corrected by emptying, removing and refilling the hopper (plus it stopped doing this after a few times). Since then it's been smooth sailing. Every few months I run some cleaning pellets through it to remove build-up, and it continues to function quite well. Of course one can pay a lot more for a very high quality machine, but for a budget burr grinder I think this is pretty great!

reviews.reviewTitle: It is a good grinder, but life span may be too short
reviews.reviewText: I have had mine for about two years, It still works but I can tell I will need to replace it soon it is starting to make a disconcerting noise and I feel (although it has not happened yet) it may be ready to fail. I am going to buy this model again because for the two years I have had it it has worked wonderfully for me and I do not mind replacing it since for the price I am not under the impression it is going to last forever. I give it 4* because I feel it does a very good job and I have been very pleased with it's performance.

I had contacted the company for a concern I had and the company responded quickly. I use an older Bodum and now am experimenting with this new one. I like that the Cone Shape cup for placing the beans is nice and large. You can put more into it for grinding. The older models offer a smaller area.

Then, I can see when my coffee has grinded. The only concern to me is that the red wheel is hard to move. But, I enjoy this Bodum grinder. I still have my older bodum and will use this one more.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just so you know -- Great grinder, until it's not
reviews.reviewText:
This is an elegant grinder that gives consistent ground coffee, even very fine for espresso, keeping everything sealed and fresh in both the bean hopper up top and the little carafe below. It's not loud, and sits very solidly on the kitchen sink. Then one day, it quits working. No warning. I bought it from a seller on April 22, 2013, and it worked until July 11, 2013. I paid $120 for it.

In researching my return options, I find that the coffee seller from whom I bought it (Mystic Monk Coffee) only guarantees their coffee products. I turn to Bodum. The pamphlet states, "Bodum guarantees the BISTRO electric coffee grinder for two years from date of purchase against material defects or malfunctions which can be traced back to defects in manufacturing or design. Repair is free of charge provided all guarantee requirements are fulfilled. No refunds can be made."

And what, you ask, are the "guarantee requirements"?

Bodum states, "The guarantee certificate must be completely filled out by the seller at the time of purchase. Only agents authorized by Bodum may perform guarantee services." If you don't get one of these, apparently you are SOL.

My hearty congratulations to all those whose grinder served them well for years. Mine did not last three months, and there's no support from the company. Bodum has seen my last dollar.

I was not expecting much for the price. If you are torn between a basic blade grinder and the higher-end coffee grinders that cost several hundred dollars, then I would highly recommend considering this unit.

I almost exclusively make espresso-based coffee drinks and have done so for over 10 years. I would never consider using a blade grinder. The grind is just too inconsistent. Also, I have yet to find one of the commercial "in-store" grinders to produce a satisfactory grind no matter what the setting. Not wanting to spend several hundred on a top-rated burr grinder, I had to try different pre-ground coffees such as Peet's, Illy, and Lavazza (which are excellent coffees BTW) and are offered in espresso grinds. Still the grind was never just right.

So, along comes this inexpensive Bodum burr grinder, and I am making the finest, most consistent coffee grinds I have ever experienced. And, it comes a a terrific price. The burrs are conical steel and do an excellent job. I don't know how long they will last or how long it will take before they go out of calibration, so I can't speak for long-term durability. Disassembling it and reading the manual do not indicate any adjustment or replaceable parts.

The unit comes with a somewhat rubberized coating which helps it avoid looking/feeling cheap. The parts seem sturdy enough, and the hopper lid seals surprisingly well. The grounds container is glass with a silicone lid with a hole in it that seals against the grinder chamber. A first nit is that there is no separate cover, so you can't remove the jar and just keep that around if you still have coffee grounds left. (I typically pull 8-16 espresso shots throughout the day.) Thus, the grinder takes up permanent counter space. However, I am the type, whether it's a mixer, a soda maker, a blender, a juicer, or most other appliances, to try and put it away after use. The best compromise I've found is to transfer the grinds to another sealed container for short-term use.

The only major flaw I can find (outside of unknown long-term durability which can be considered fair in any case due to its low price) is the 20 second grinder limitation. According to the very terse manual, after running it for 20 seconds, you should let it rest for 5 minutes to cool off. Similar "Engrish" instructions say, "Warning: [...] Empty the coffee bean container [not the grounds container] after every grinding operation (20 seconds) to avoid overheating the motor." This does not make much sense and seems overly restrictive. I have ignored both these warnings and just used common sense. You can run the 20 second timer over and over for any length you desire by pressing the start/stop button. This whole notion seems a bit flawed and costs it a star.

There is also a section to wind the cord around inside the base to minimize the excess cord flopping around which is a nice touch. So far, I am quite impressed with this product, especially considering its price. It is smart-looking and lightweight so you can put it away if you want to.

I've been looking for a good grinder to use with my French press and the fact that I thought this unit was expensive shows how little I know about grinders! When I looked around more, turns out grinders can run you a LOT more than $80.

The grinder comes in an attractive (and quite large) box, but the grinder itself fit perfectly right next to my Gevalia coffee maker. The red is very eye catching, but other colors look very fun as well!

Pros:
- I used the coarse grind for the French press, and the finer grind for Espresso, and both came out great
- I had consistent results every time, no surprises
- The glass carafe and the design of the grinder keep the mess in, and are easy to clean up
- Has a pre-set grinding time which is enough for about 6-8 cups

Cons
- A bit loud, although I understand grinder generally are
- After the pre-set time of 20 seconds, the grinder takes a mandatory "rest" of several minutes. So if you're looking to keep grinding, this can be quite annoying.

Overall, I'm very pleased with my first grinder experience. I think this grinder is also a great gift for coffee drinkers.

reviews.reviewTitle: A Few tips I've picked up...
reviews.reviewText:
After awful experiences with a cheap burr grinder, I did some research, decided to spend a little more money, and chose the Bodum Bistro. I've had this grinder for about 6 months... I use it every couple weeks to grind my home-roasted coffee beans. It's the best grinder I've used... only complaint is that the plasticy-rubber lid collects static... so the the grinds and the husk bits can go jumping when you pull the glass catcher. I use the grinds for my french press and also in my Keurig, using the "My K-Cup"... works wonderfully. Make sure to read the instruction booklet... it helped.

A few tips I've been learning along the way:

1. Put the grinder and everything on a cookie sheet when you're going to grind... that'll contain any spillage, dust, and bean grinds that go ballistic.

2. Go to one of those big-box home stores and get the 97 cent, one inch bristle paint brush. It really gets in the nooks of the burr assembly to get out the stuck grinds. Just be careful as the metal part of the brush can scratch the plastic.

3. Grind half a hopper of uncooked white rice through the grinder every two weeks, or so, to keep the innards of the chute and assembly free of grinds. The fresher the coffee, the more oily the beans are, so you have to be diligent to keep things from getting gummed up where the brush can't reach.

4. You mileage may vary, but for my french press, the coarsest setting works brilliantly. And, for he beans I run through my Keurig, using the "My K-Cup", one setting finer than the little vacuum-press symbol is perfect.

No complaints, thus far. I only use it every couple weeks, so it's not heavily used... and I also read the direction booklet. But, for the money, it's the best burr grinder out there.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great step up from a blade grinder!
reviews.reviewText:
I received this as a Christmas gift and so happy I got it. I followed the reviews and the price changes. Be savvy and look for when the price gets below $70. That being said burr grinders can range from $40-400, so I would imagine you get what you pay for.

Pros:
Consistant grind on every level. The Espresso grind is fine enough for my Aeropress and has the same consistency Lavazza I've purchased from amazon. Drip pot grind is nice and French press does well, too.

The hopper holds a good portion of beans with an air tight seal.

It's pretty compact on my counter.

And the most important- Better tasting coffee with grounds are even size and texture for steeping. I've started using less beans in the same pot size with no loss of taste.

Cons:
It's not quiet but for 20 seconds at a time I'm okay with it. If you're used to a blade grinder and it's pulse this will make you take notice.

Like others said the grind timer is a bit short. 5 seconds will give you about 7 grams (one cup of 6oz coffee). So if you do the math and brew 6-8 cups you'll need to wait 5 min. Not a deal breaker with me but something to mention.

Static free? No, but compared to my Black & Decker blade grinder it was pretty clean. Some grounds do come out of the glass jar but not enough for me to care. It's a kitchen and when you make good things you make a mess, duh!

Finally, what last surprised me was the amount of vibration produced when grinding. I put the grinder on it's most coarse setting for a french press pot I wanted to brew only to have it vibrate enough to losen the hopper off the base and tripped a safety setting. Turning it one notch finer kept it locked.

-----

I roast my own coffee beans and so I've been pleased how a good grinder can make your roasting taste better. It's just one more step in controlling variables form bean to cup. Good bye, blade grinder! I guess now I need an espresso machine. Now where can I buy one of those....

reviews.reviewTitle: The Perfect Solution to a Fresh Grind Everyday
reviews.reviewText:
My husband and I used a basic coffee grinder for so many years the cord was breaking apart. It was loud, awkward to measure, count and grind and brush out. So we had a choice to either buy preground coffee or buy a new grinder.

After looking at many models, some cheaper, some more expensive, this is what we decided on. We are very happy so far and have found it to be the right solution for us.

The hopper holds a lot of coffee - not perfectly sealed but good enough - enough for two for 5 days or so. The controls allow for grind settings from coarse (press pot) to fine (espresso) with a variety of settings in between. There is a timer for up to 20 seconds of grind. It takes a few tries to find the right grind and the right time frame to get the perfect amount of coffee without measuring. We just grind and dump it now without scooping out and counting.

It may be important to note that the 20 second grind is as much as you can do and then Bodum recommends letting the motor 'cool' for a period of time before grinding again. This is important if you are trying to make a large pot or multiple pots and need a lot of coffee ground at one time.

In comparison to the traditional Krups 203-42 Electric Coffee and Spice Grinder with Stainless-Steel blades, Black, this is half the noise level and offers a much more even grind. The coffee ends up in a glass container that is as static free as possible. Does coffee still cling to it? Sure, but it's not bad and it washes easily - although we don't wash it out every day.

So far, we are thrilled to have fresh ground coffee every morning without the hassle of scooping, counting, brushing, etc. A highly recommended purchase.

Worked extremely well and was the grinder of my dreams. Then one day it stopped responding to when I would push the go button. I have to spam the button 80-200 times to get it to go again. Really strange behavior. I feel like I can't throw it away because it still works on the 80th button push and performs really well when it does.

Edit: I have just opened the thing up to see what the issue is. Coffee dust had coated the circuit board. I do a lot of espresso grinds and I think they blew up to the PCB and caused the issue. Lowering my rating from 4 to 3 stars because that seems so preventable. The issue was resolved by spraying canned air on the PCB.

I like my coffee. And I like my Bodum Bistro Burr Grinder.

Typically, I'll use ground coffee when I make my coffee on weekday mornings in an automatic drip coffee maker. On weekends, when I have more time, I'd grind whole beans, using a pretty old and not terribly good little grinder. For that I'd use my French Press or a 30-year old stove-top percolator that I'll keep using as long as I can. All in all I prefer the flavor of fresh ground beans.

So, once I received and set up the Bodum I was pleased for a number of reasons:

First, it looks good. I like the design and it is attractive enough that I don't feel the need to shelve it out of sight after using it. Second, it works very well and very quickly. I've used it to grind for my drip, press and percolator and I've always been satisfied with the grind. Third, my ability to grind and use quickly has now allowed me to use whole beans for my weekday cups of coffee. This may not seem like a big deal but when one gets up early to rush to work the ability to savor a nice cup of freshly ground coffee before facing the day is a nice treat.

All in all I am very happy with my Bodum Grinder. My only complaint, one mentioned elsewhere, is that the 20-second time limit does make preparing coffee for a larger group a but more time consuming than I would like. Apart from that, consider me very pleased.

I didn't quite know what to expect; I mean, aren't all coffee grinders more or less the same? As it turns out, they are not. Though my little Pavoni grinder continues to work diligently, the Bodum Bistro is clearly a notch above. This is certainly an "enthusiast" caliber machine. If you never really stopped to think about different types of grinds and their relationship to different ways of making coffee, then this may seem like overkill. The Bodum allows you to select varying levels of coarseness for your coffee; from very fine (typically used in espressos) to quite coarse (used in french press coffee), with numerous settings in between. This unit also has a timer, meaning that you can grind your coffee for an exact amount of time. This may seem useless to some, but to coffee enthusiasts, there is a big difference between a 10 and 15 second grind. This is all fine and good, but the bottom line is that the Bodum does an excellent job at grinding coffee. The design of this unit ensures that it remains cleaner than other grinders (no packed grounds at the bottom, like in other units), and it is exceptionally quiet. The grounds are cleanly deposited into the glass receptacle, ensuring no spills. Overall, this is a terrific little machine, and it looks great to boot!

reviews.reviewTitle: A little workhorse, that doesn't leave coffee grinds all over the counter.
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using my Bodum Bistro once, usually twice, every day for either 3 years now, on the drip coffee setting.
So I've ground hundreds of pounds of coffee with this workhorse, with no complaints.
I jammed the burrs once with some foreign debris in my beans, cleared it, and right back to grinding.
Compared to my Kitchenaid A10's (The noisy modern incarnation with the circular spout cover, and the quieter vintage ones, with rectangular hinged flap which btw I also love.) The Bodum's just not as messy, it's easier. The A10 always leave a little coffee in the spout, and due to the static build up that occurs during the grinding process, coffee would always collect on the exterior of the spout. The design of the Bistro is better suited to deal with the staticy coffee grounds. My only issue is that it's a little stiff, when you try to turn the hopper to adjust the grind setting.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder, but it ain't anti-static!
reviews.reviewText: The sole reason I cannot give this product a 5 star rating is the false anti-static claim in the description. They claim this grinder's catch jar is a special anti-static glass that allows grind to slide right out without sticking. This not true. Not only do they stick to the inside, they somehow make their way to the outside after grinding. That's really the only bad thing about it though. I got this grinder because i like to make coffee different ways. I got rid of my coffee maker with built in burr grinder, picking up this guy and new drip maker. The great thing about this product is that it stores a good amount of beans and has a wide array of grind settings that allows you to make coffee anyway you like, from French press to espresso. Overall, I would recommend this product, and had they not claimed the glass was anti-static, I would have given it a 5.

Found this item on clearance at Marshall's. Really wanted to love it, but leaves half to a whole teaspoon of grinds stuck inside. I have to bang on the top of the grinder to dislodge them. It is quiet and quick, but it really needed to be cleaned before and after each use.

Update February 2018: 6-7yrs old. Not a single issue. Would totally buy this brand/grinder again. We LOVE it!

Update Dec 2016: I've had this grinder for about 5 years. Still going strong! Still love it! Still a perfect grind!!!!
------------------------------
I got this grinder at a super deal during one of Amazon's holiday specials. I have had it a little over two months, and use it daily. The grind settings work perfectly and the unit itself is easily cleaned. I got the orange color, which really pops and looks fantastic in my kitchen. I use a French press, and the coarse setting is ideal. I sometimes also make espresso, and the fine setting for this works beautifully as well. I realize some reviews say the problem is that you cannot use it more than 20 seconds at a time, but I use 8 scoops of coffee generally and it takes only 10 seconds to grind. How much more coffee does one need? I think it produces plenty of coffee grounds in 20 seconds..so no worries there as far as I am concerned. Buy this, and you won't regret it!

This is so far my favorite coffee grinder! The grind is even at all levels and makes the best espresso grind I have had from any of the grinders I have tried! I love the sealed lid on the bean storage for freshness. My only negative is the basket the grounds drop into -- it is difficult to get a scoop into so I am pouring it out into the scoop and dropping some of the grounds.

This is the best coffee bean grinder I've ever used. Been looking for a grinder like this for a long time. Bodum's Bistro Burr Coffee Grinder is quiet (compared to most), found a way to keep static to a minimum, and perfectly grinds coffee beans. The coffee comes out perfectly each time - from a course grind to an espresso powder. It is a small unit that still grinds enough beans for a pot/press of coffee. Simply a great appliance.

So then why only 4 stars? Because the instructions and controls are lacking. You have to experiment to find the combination between grind size and time. The instructions are not very helpful. Once you grind a batch you have to wait for several minutes before grinding again. This makes finding the perfect grind for your brewer will take some time and mistakes. Bodum could have easily fixed this with some suggestions in their manual.

That said this is a great machine. For those of us who love coffee this is a must have. Burr grinders are so much better than blade cutters that burn and chop coffee. The resultant grind from Bodum's grinder is perfect with all of the oils and flavor intact.

For years, I have used Krups 203-70 Fast Touch coffee grinder, white. coffee grinder to grind Indian spices. How finely ground spices are depended on how long you grind. So you never really get perfect grind despite all the experimentation. Black pepper and Cardamoms needs a coarse grind, Coriander semi-coarse and Cumin really fine etc. etc.

With its 14 grind settings, Bodum Grinder is perfect for grinding Indian (and perhaps others) spices. Another great features is much less spill and mess with its Borosilicate glass catcher. Noise is not bad, definitely a lot less than my earlier Krups grinder. Having two buttons to turn in on and off is also a nice feature.

So why am holding one star back? Waiting 5 minutes after 20 second grind is annoying - really annoying when you have lot of spices to grind. And I have not used it long enough to assess longevity. in the past I have had a bad experience with Black & Decker grinder that that died after 6 sessions of grinding.

With my short experience with this Bodum grinder, I think it is perfect for grinding spices.

reviews.reviewTitle: Extremely weak components and absurdly terrible customer service.
reviews.reviewText: The on/off button broke after around 50 uses. This is the most basic piece and it clearly is flimsy and weak. Customer service just replied and said if you do not have proof of purchase then we cannot do anything. This was a wedding gift so I didn't have the proof. They never replied to any further emails. They clearly know their products are terrible and just ignore most of their support requests. Do NOT BUY.

I got this grinder back in November 2011. I use it about 5 times a week (maybe more), and I make French Press, Drip and Espresso using this grinder.

Build quality seems pretty good for what it is. From the pictures online, the thing seemed to look much more heavy, but it's construction is plastic and its fairly light weight. Everything seems to go together well, and it looks spectacular, especially when you load it up with beans - every bit as cool at home as it looks in the pictures online.

The only minor issues with build are:

1.) It seems very light (but my expectation was that it would be heavy).

2.) I cannot use it on the most coarse setting. I have to set the dial one tick in. The coarsest setting is one tick away from the "release" position where you can remove the hopper. There is apparently a safety mechanism that causes the motor to stop when the hopper dial moves to the "release" position. The vibration causes the dial to gradually move over to the "release" position and cause the unit to stop. I thought this was going to be a serious issue at first, but to be honest, I haven't even thought about it 'til just now.

The instructions say to let it cool 5 minutes for every 20 second grind, I have to say, I have exceeded this almost every time I've used it. I usually grind two, 20 second batches, back-to-back. While I never recommend disregarding the manufacturer's instructions, I wouldn't be too paranoid about it.

As far as grind quality, you can't ask for much better. The grind is consistent throughout each run, and consistent from run to run. The coffee is very good from any of the 3 methods I use. The espresso grind is very consistent in texture, and you don't see any bits of chaff or anything other than a nice silky brown powder.

As for cleaning, I give it a good once-over every week. I bought a couple cheap paint brushes (<$1) and cut the bristles shorter (1 med, 1 short). I use the stiffer one to clean the burr, and longer to get into the crevices inside. I turn it upside down and give it a few pats on the back to dump any excess grind. A little bit of the grind lands on the inside of the machine, but no more so than other grinders. I usually give it a couple pats on the side after a grind too to try to get as much of that into the receptacle. Invariably, as with any grinder, some of the grind will spill out onto the counter. It's not as spotless as some reviews here have you believe, but this thing is still miles ahead of other grinders.

Overall, I gave the grinder 4 stars because of the issue with the coarsest setting causing the unit to stop and the fact that you are supposed to stop and wait 5 minutes after every 20 seconds. A machine like this should be designed to run steady state. ...And, I still think it should be heavier.

Hope this review is helpful.

--DanG

This is such a great little grinder. I'm able to grind beans for my moka pot and my french press and the grind is even throughout.

Some tips:

1. Starts to pick up static after lengthy grinding. I usually grind up enough beans for 2 shots so that's not a lot, but be warned if you're making french press for 12 cups...

2. Give the top part of the unit (where the dial is to set the time) a little tap after you're done grinding. This will expel the grinds that are in the nooks and crannies, and is important if you're doing more than one grind.

3. You might get a little spillage when you remove the cup after the grinding cycle is complete. Again, tapping the top part of the unit will help this.

For the price, this is an excellent grinder, especially for the newbie. It doesn't take up a lot of space on the counter and it's fairly quiet for a burr grinder.

This is a great grinder... ended up buying it elsewhere, but wanted to give it a review. It is very quiet, for a coffee grinder, and very efficient. It took a couple of tries to select the right amount of time to select for grinding the correct amount of coffee, but now I have it set perfectly. I am slightly concerned about the glass container with my horrid tile countertops, but it seems to be pretty resilient. I replaced a Cuisinart burr grinder and really love the smaller size of this grinder and it's simpler design. This grinder does not make anywhere close to the mess the Cuisinart made, just a bit of grounds that stick to the lid of the container..

Metal drive shaft vs plastic gear

The drive shaft is shaped like a drill bit. It physically turns the teeth on a - plastic - gear wheel. Think about what a steel drill bit does to plastic over time. That's right. It chews it up. And when the gears teeth are worn down, the motor just spins around and around and doesn't grind a thing.

Mine self-destructed right around warranty time.

Apart from the stupidity of mating metal to plastic, it is very, very LOUD. especially in the morning. Otherwise I liked it. :)

reviews.reviewTitle: Simply the best grinder out there.....
reviews.reviewText: I'm a coffee purist and have tried just about every grinder out there and the Bodum is clearly superior. Not only does it have the look and feel of quality, it works with a precision that others lack. Many reviews here are just invalid based on some of the comments (about 'freezing' coffee, or *gasp!* microwaving it before grinding to remove oils). The Bodum quickly and efficiently grinds to a uniform consistency with a minimum of the dreaded static dust, and the result is really superior tasting coffee, if you're used to store ground nonsense or the dreaded blade chopper, you'll really be surprised. And if you really want to blow your buds off, use any small batch roasted coffee and one of the two drip makers that go to the recommended 200 degree brew (Newco and the utterly overpriced Dutch!), you'll taste coffee like you never had, the combo of good beans + proper conical grinding + 200 degrees = coffee heaven.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great, but only good for two years
reviews.reviewText: I got this coffee grinder as a gift about two years ago. At first I loved it. It produces a nicely ground coffee for my drip coffee maker when set at the coarsest setting. The 20 second timer is just the right time to grind 8 cups of coffee. That being said, this is a very loud grinder. It's about the volume of a vacuum cleaner. After two years, the grinder now only grinds enough coffee to make 3 cups of coffee. So you have to set the maximum time (20 seconds), press the button, wait for it to stop, press the button, wait for it to stop, press the button, wait for it to stop, done! I contacted the manufacturer and they recommended cleaning it. That didn't fix the problem. When I tried to find replacement parts I found out there is no way to service this grinder. Just throw it away and buy a new one. Wow!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for drip coffee, medium amount
reviews.reviewText: I've had this grinder for about a year, use it daily and think it is great for what I do. I only make five cups of drip coffee and this thing works perfectly. I cannot review any of the other grind sizes since I don't use them. Also, this thing grinds for ~20 seconds, and the manual says that you should wait 5 minutes (!) before grinding again. This is apparently to save the motor from burning out. The reason I point this out is because you will need to grind twice to get a full 8 or 10 cups of coffee if you have a large coffee maker. I can grind 4 scoops of beans in that 20 seconds, which is enough for my purposes. If you are just making a medium amount of drip coffee, then this thing works great and is cheaper than the alternatives. If you need more versatility or want to make a lot of coffee, then you may want to pay more for a different one.
Got as a Christmas present. Used 3 times to grind for siphon coffee maker. Now it won't grind. Just dead.

reviews.reviewTitle: Although we like our grinder and find it quite durable
reviews.reviewText: For some bizarre reason, Bodum seems to have stopped making the canister ("catcher") that goes with this coffee grinder. Since it is breakable, it is strange that they have been unavailable for months at least. So it becomes a very messy proposition to use a cup that does not deal with the static electricity that tends to splatter coffee grounds in all directions. Although we like our grinder and find it quite durable, we wouldn't recommend it until this replacement part becomes available again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Reliable and easy to use. Can't ask for much more than that!
reviews.reviewText:
We can talk a lot about gourmet coffee and the benefits of grinding over chopping and the materials of the containers used...but let's be honest. When I'm making my first cup of coffee at 6 AM, my eyes still full of sleep and my pre-caffeinated movements clumsy and sluggish, I really want something that's simple and reliable. I don't want to have to think about too much when I'm making coffee in the morning.

Does the Bodum Bistro burr grinder satisfy this need? After a little trial and error, yes it does.

Overall, it's an excellent grinder, and very easy to use. Whole coffee beans go in the cone at the top, with a tight lid that keeps them sealed in and fresh. The cone fits about half a pound of coffee at a time. The timer at the front sets the time of grinding, up to a maximum of 20 seconds. Once the timer is set, you start grinding with a simple push of a button next to the timer. A small, snugly-fit glass container receives the grinds.

And it does make a consistently good cup of coffee. The ground coffee smells wonderful and looks good, no large chunks or missed beans that you sometimes get from a chop grinder. I've been using this almost every day for a month, and so far it's been a delight.

My only quibble with this grinder is that there's nothing to indicate how much you're getting when you grind the coffee. The timer tells you how long it's working for, but not how many cups you can expect to get, and there's no measurement on the glass receptacle either. It took some trial and error with the first few attempts to figure it out. A full 20-second grind gets you about enough ground coffee for 7 to 8 cups in a drip machine. Once I figured this out, it works reliably, but it would have been helpful to have this somehow indicated on the machine itself somehow - seems like an easy fix, and is the only feature I miss from my old grinder.

These days, though, I'm pretty happy just to have a grinder I can depend on. One I can find with blurry early morning eyes and get running with sleep-clumsy fingers, and one that will still give me a great cup of coffee every time.

The Bodum Bistro is definitely that grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Home roasters beware. Does NOT work on city (light) roasted coffee.
reviews.reviewText:
If you either A) roast your own coffee and do a city (light) roast or B) buy coffee locally that is of a very light roast, it will not work. The machine simply does not have enough torque to chew threw light roast coffee that you typically won't find at the store. It will jam CONSTANTLY and eventually break the weak plastic gears.

If you don't EVER grind light roast coffee, this will work wonderfully for you. But for me, and anyone else in my situation, it's unusable.

I've had a bunch of low-cost coffee grinders over the years--the latest being a Black and Decker burr grinder--but recently got Bodum's Bistro grinder as a present, and what a great present it is (especially for a cheap-ass like me)! First, the grinder is so well made, I'm certain it will last much longer than cheaper products. So over time, the dollars will come out similar. But more importantly, my coffee (I use a French press) is much better, with a consistent grind easily produced to the right amount, since this grinder has a timer on it. Very easy to get just the right setting (or settings, since it's easy to get the right times for one, two or four cups). It's easy to clean, relatively quiet, has a nice build and look. This is a product you'll be happy to have and use in your kitchen. I know I am.

reviews.reviewTitle: Now THIS is a coffee grinder
reviews.reviewText:
Executive Summary: For grinding coffee, buy this. For grinding spice, still looking.

This little machine does a superb grinding job. I've used it at least daily for over a month now and have really come to appreciate it. It is extremely consistent and the timed grind thing makes for very consistent quantities. This is my first burr grinder and it is certainly a step up from the spinning blade type. Anyways, it is a nice reliable tool that does its job well.

So, why not for spices ... because of the clean-up and tinkering. I really don't want to mess around with this thing's operational bits. I've seen reviews of other bodum grinders that indicate that it might not be up to constant tinkering. Spice grinding does require a lot of manipulation to get things clean, get the grind right, then get things clean again. This grinder could well be up to it, but I'm not willing to experiment because it does such a good job on coffee. I'm not willing to risk breaking it without really good cause.

Finally, does it help produce a better cup? Somewhat. To really go far down the coffee geek path you've got to be able to repeatably produce the same result. Otherwise you're just buying stuff to show off. Consistent water temp, a press, and a timer are better incremental improvements than moving to a burr grinder. So, it isn't critical to replace blades with burrs unless the other stuff is already under control. If the blade grinder is broke or being repurposed then going to a burr (especially this one) is a solid move.

This grinder works above and beyond expectations!
As a coffee enthusiast, I am well aware that the quality of the grind influences the quality of the coffee. The consistent, even grind produced by the Bodum Bistro is fully adjustable, as advertised, and produces the full range of particle sizes- now that's high quality. Going above and beyond consistency, the machine is also incredibly convenient: the airtight hopper kept my beans fresh tasting for weeks, the borosilicate catcher eliminated the annoying cling of ground beans, and you can even grind straight into an espresso portafilter. It blows my previous Cuisinart blade grinder out of the water.
As a college student, I was skeptical of the high price, but this grinder has held up to the tests of time and daily use, and works just as well as it did a year ago at unboxing. It is well worth the expense.

reviews.reviewTitle: Motor dies after a couple years of use (see video)
reviews.reviewText: This product worked great.... until the motor randomly wore out. Removed top burr to clean out unit. There is no obstruction, but the motor now only activates for a second before turning off.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best yet - see info on reducing static in review...
reviews.reviewText:
Love it... Way better than the Cuisinart I had previously. Fast and low static. Bought at Target on sale. Doesn't do a very fine espresso grind but it's fast and consistent. OK - STATIC PEOPLE READ THIS:
Here is how you fix it, called the Mikey Method - you first take the glass receptacle, leave the lid on but cracked a bit, then blow a breath into it so it escapes out. Then, grind away. Swirl the coffee a few times before you dispense it. The moisture will kill the static.

Grinding coffee beans is not a grind with the Bodum Bistro. It's quiet, compact, attractive, efficient and less messy than other burr grinders I have used. I use small brushes to clean the grinding mechanism and then use a Dyson vacuum to suck the finer coffee powder. I like the size of the Bistro because it can be handled with one hand and turned upside down for cleaning.

I almost gave up grinding my own beans because of the mess with other grinders, so I'm glad I came across the Bistro. This grinder makes my coffee fuller and richer tasting and combined with my Bonavita BV1800 coffee maker, I'm able to make a consistently good cup of coffee.

What a piece of art! First of all, the design is just stunning. It's a beauty just sitting on the kitchen counter. People will ask what it is and guess that it's a grinder at the same time. The compliments you receive is just wonderful.
The different grades of blending is also quite nice.
I've tried different blends with the Bodum french press to find out exactly which level of grind is my favorite.
Makes up to 8 cups each time.
I will try to blend other stuff next time like peanuts and sesame seeds to see how they turn out.
But I think at $50-70 range is the right price range. It's a bit pricey for the $100 range, thus the one star reduction.

Highly recommended.

While the Bodum Bistro is an attractive Grinder, it doesn't hold up well in use. After less than 3 months of average use (1-2 grinds a day) the power button completely broke and pushed into the unit and was unretrievable. I even tried to open the unit to repair but the build doesn't allow that. This product seems well designed aesthetically, but poorly manufactured (in China).

Other issues I found:
-The grinder occasionally would lock up and needed beans to be cleared out of the grinding teeth to be fixed - which requires removing the bean funnel at the top. But removing that WITH beans in it will cause all the beans to funnel out and spill all over the place.

-The grind canister is fairly loose in its position and gets coffee grounds everywhere - overall this is a messy grinder.

Even if the switch hadn't broken I was disliking this grinder. I am attempting to return this and will get a different brand. I love Bodum's product design overall but the build on this item is a major let down. I will try other products again from them perhaps, but avoid this particular model.

reviews.reviewTitle: I want to marry this coffee grinder and have like 10,000 of its babies
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder takes the guesswork out of my Bodum French press.

Pros:
It has grind settings for presses, drip machines, espresso machines and several settings in between; I use the second-to-highest setting. The grind is very consistent.

It grinds on a timer. I use 12-14 seconds' worth, or 5-6 tablespoons whole beans, for a full press pot.

Because it grinds on a timer, you can store your coffee in the hopper. The cover seals it airtight.

Quieter than my old blade grinder.

Cons:
Only one I can think of: As other reviewers have mentioned, you can only grind 20 seconds' worth of beans at a time, so if you make large pots of drip coffee, this may not be the grinder for you. But if you make coffee in smaller amounts, it's a decently priced grinder that yields consistent results for smooth, better-tasting coffee.

I purchased this grinder for making espresso a cup or two at a time so the 20 second limited grind time did not bother me. This grinder is compact and nice looking. The problem is that beans will not feed through at all on the espresso setting, only about two notches down from espresso. So don't buy this for espresso.

UPDATE: After several more attempts this grinder started working perfectly well. It grinds on the finest setting and grinds enough in 15 seconds for a double espresso. On coarser settings it grinds enough for a full pot in 15 seconds. No complaints at all. There is virtually no electrostatic scatter with the glass container.

reviews.reviewTitle: The intermittent operation got worse over time
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this unit based on the reviews, I am sorry to say that I do not share the positive feedback from others. A couple months after I received the grinder I started to experience problems with the red switch on top of the unit (not the power on/off switch), this is the switch that starts the grinding operation. The intermittent operation got worse over time, since the warranty was still in effect we called the compagny which provided a replacement. Within a month the new grinder exhibited the identical problem than the first one.

reviews.reviewTitle: I like that it is light weight because I can't leave ...
reviews.reviewText: I have had mine for 1 year and I use it everyday. I like that it is light weight because I can't leave it out on the counter so it is easy to move around. It is the first coffee grinder I have ever had and fresh ground coffee is so much better than store bought ground- no matter what the brand. It is not that loud and I like the glass receptacle. I have had no issues and if the price drops - I will get a second one as a back up. I paid over $100 for the one I have but I feel it was worth it. I think the people who have had issues are either not cleaning it often or are grinding large amounts. It's a home grinder - not a commercial one.

It does a decent job with grinding due to the conical burrs. I don't like how you have to wait for it to cool down after 20 second of continuous grinding, tho. I've had it for 2 yesterday and it's still working fine. I grind rice at the medium setting every so often to keep it clean.

I've never owned a grinder prior to this one and never thought I would. Always satisfied with purchasing pre-ground coffee but not anymore. I received the red one and love the color. Each time I bring it out, it becomes a conversation piece. I'm a firm believer (now) that freshly ground coffee takes on a whole new flavor than coffee that is pre-ground and sitting in a bag. The design of this grinder is also intriguing as the beans are fully visual and the outcome is a delight. The after product is perfect in size too. Cleanup has been easy. I'm not a fan of leaving kitchen electrics sitting out but I'm thrilled to pull this one out and show it off!

Visiting the site to buy another. We like it well enough to do that, even though it broke after 2 or so years of consistent use. For us the problem was overfilling the vessel which caused it to back up and break. The manual warns not to grind over 20 seconds because of potential overheating but no mention of this back-up breaking potential. It's still one of the best value electric burr grinders available so another hundred bucks it is.

Plastic gears were a bad call, Bodum. My grinder made it about 1 1/2 years before letting us down but it did and in a disappointing way, who thinks missing out on the morning coffee is a good way to start the day? Buyer beware, this grinder is playing coffee roulette. It'll work fine for awhile but it will let you down when you need it. Will it work for a year? 6 mo? Buy it if you need some counter candy and you like the looks of it. Don't buy if you need a reliable daily grinder to keep your sauce fix game strong.

Just got the Bodum and wanted to love it. However at the grind does not seem consistent to me. I've attached pic of the grind which shows that there are specks of thin larger pieces in the grind.

I'm surprised to see an inconsistent grind since that's what most people raved about this machine. I had a Capresso Infiniti as well and I find the same coffee tasted better (less bitter, more full bodied, more aromatic) with the Infiniti, and the Infiniti definitely doesn't produce these larger pieces in the grind. However I love all the other functions of the Bodum much better (timer, low grind retention in burr).

Not sure if this grind quality is what I should expect from this machine, or is mine a defect...?

I got this fella for christmas this past year (2011) and have been using it for my morning joe. I drink French Press, and I looked and looked and looked for a grinder that would grind consistently coarse for FP and not leave a lot of sludge in the bottom. Now I'm not a rich man. I'm not a Carl Weathers, par example. So I haven't been able to experiment with this and that grinder, this and that bean, make espressos, and all that. But what I can tell you is that if you are using a blade grinder and want to step it up a little, this is an awesome replacement.

Some have said that it cannot go coarse enough for FP. Now maybe I'm doing it wrong, but I actually think that one step in from the coarsest is the best. The coarsest lacked body and two in from that was over-extracted, so the second-coarsest is what I use. There's a tiny bit of dust in the bottom of the cup at the end, but nothing like what I got from my blade grinder. So if you want a good grinder to get a better consistency to replace a blade grinder, you'll be pleased as punch with this one.

It's not too loud; in fact, I'd say compared to a lot of blade grinders this thing is, if not quieter, at least a lot less annoying. Think of Barry White screaming in your kitchen instead of Gilbert Godfried.

Worth it!

UPDATE: 2/11/13
Still use this bad boy about every day and have not had any problems with it. I clean it probably once a month, which takes about 5 minutes. I now use the coarsest setting for FP, which I still drink exclusively. Still works like the day I got it. Recently my son broke the grounds catcher (Grounds Catcher Willy, I call it). It is only cracked, so I haven't yet decided to purchase a replacement. But I looked, and I found them for about $9. So they are cheap to replace.

UPDATE: 3/2/16:
This guy is still running strong, and I use it about every day. I use it for Chemex, now, too, and I'm very pleased with it. No troubles.

I bought this burr grinder nearly 5 years ago and used it twice daily, nearly every day, since then. Amazing workhorse consistently grinding beans from Guatemala, Costa Rica, Jamaica, Indonesia, Sumatra, various South American lands, wherever, without complaint and for under a hundred bucks. This morning, its sturdy little motor burned up and smoke actually came out!! What did I do? Within an hour, ordered its identical successor. Need I say more?

I got this burr grinder as a christmas present.
The first use was a little hairy but I realized it was because I had the grinder set for the finest grind. (human error)
Once I figured out which grind was best for my espresso machine, it's been nothing but lovely.
very consistent grind, amazingly fine (I had a capresso before this and the grind wasn't that fine).
Regarding the 20 second rule. I not going to lie, I've broken it. every day. I grind the beans in two 20 sec spurts.
Once you figure out how much coffee you need for your morning pick me up, it's pretty simple to gauge grind time.
I'll post back if my machine dies prematurely due to the motor overheating, but so far so good.

reviews.reviewTitle: Rubber housing degrades to a sticky mess
reviews.reviewText: The housing of the coffee grinder is made of a rubbery plastic that degrades over time and becomes sticky and impossible to clean - especially since the device grinds coffee beans to powder and powder gets on the outside of the grinder. I tried to Bodum but they don't have customer service at all! They use Zendesk to fend off customer complaints which they did. Zendesk told me too bad, out of warranty. This isn't a warranty complaint - the grinder works. It's a Bodum manufacturing complaint. They still sell this same grinder and it's still made out of the same shitty rubbery plastic. Don't buy it.

Got this for Christmas. I love the way Bodum products look, and i wanted this instead of all the other grinders. As soon as i grinded my first batch of beans, the grinder got jammed immediately. I unclogged it, tried again. Jammed another time. The parts are not very good for how expensive the grinder is. Im gonna have to exchange it for the cuisinart burr grinder which i know works incredibly well.

I really wanted to like this grinder, but a major flaw in it is that you can only grind 20 seconds worth of coffee every five minutes. I like my coffee strong, but I only make about six cups in the morning. This grinder only grinds half that amount during the 20-second time period (which is the maximum amount of grind time you can choose). According to the manual, when that 20 seconds is up, you have to wait five minutes before grinding again; otherwise, the manual warns that the motor may overheat. So, to grind my usual amount of morning coffee will take 5 minutes and 40 seconds. That's too long for my rushed mornings.

I returned the grinder for that reason.

These reviewers are crazy, and had me worried over nothing. This machine can grind beans into a fine, turkish grind that is capable of clogging the portafilter in my espresso machine. I've been buying beans ground with commercial grinders at various gourmet coffee shops for years, and I can say with confidence that this machine grinds as fine -and finer- than the "espresso" setting on those machines, which is one notch up from "turkish." Specifically, I would always ask for "the finest of the espresso grinds." In fact, the dial on my machine is set between the 2nd and 3rd notch, and this setting seems to grind around that size. Maybe Bodum recalibrated the machine, but doubtful.

The positives about the grinder was that it did produce consistent grinds and the unit had a glass cup to catch the grinds which cut back on static. However, the instructions state that you must "rest" the unit for 5 minutes for each 20 seconds of grinding. Sorry, but I don't feel the need to set my alarm clock any earlier to grind coffee! I've just sent back my third unit after an electrical burning smell occurred while grinding. At this point, I don't even want a free replacement. Odd how they couldn't put in a beefier motor.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not perfect, but a solid choice
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this grinder in January '12 after shopping around and reading a ton of reviews. I did not originally think the 20 minute 'rest cycle' between grinds would be an issue until we had family over for dinner. Had to wait 20 minutes to grind a bit more coffee to make a pot (I like it strong). However, if you plan ahead, this should not be an issue. Once the grinder is done grinding I recommend taping the grinder on the side to loosen up any ground coffee in the shoot. If you pull the glass cup before you tap it, you could end up with a small pile of grounds on your counter. I make 3 to 4 pots a week. So far it has preformed with no problems and gives nice, evenly ground coffee.

If you are like me and you order your coffee from coffee roasters on the internet and get the coffee the day after it is roasted because you want it as fresh as possible, this grinder is an excellent choice that will not break the bank. You could buy a more expensive grinder, but you will find it hard to find a better one without stepping up to a 'pro' grinder.

Have used it daily for a few months now.

- When it's clean the grind quality is fantastic.

- Grind consistency deteriorates over time. Lots of grounds get stuck in moving parts and push burrs apart after a week or two. Especially if it's used back and forth for several different grind coursenesses. Takes a long time to clean, last week I measured almost 25g of old grounds stowed away inside.

- It's annoying that there's two switches and one has a light. The timer switch isn't long enough for a single serve pour over.

- I'm worried about breaking the glass receptacle, but I suppose it's glass to prevent static?

- It looks good though!

reviews.reviewTitle: although I'm an acknowledged good reviewer.
reviews.reviewText:
My credentials: elderly retired Mechanical Engineer and Physician ... neither of whiich should cause more than the usual 'belief/disbelief' in my reviews .. although I'm an acknowledged good reviewer...
Now:
AVOID this pathethcally-deficiently designed device.. Turning 'grinding gears' on aNY mechanical device requires an appreciation for the engineering topic of: " Strength of Materials" ... and thIS sad excuse for a grinder fails in that regard .. though it's not the ONLY 'regard'....
yes .. PLASTIC DRIVE GEARS!!!!
Such an unforgiveable error in design that I'll not pursue it ..
then: 'Customer Support' ??? EASY to assess: THERE IS NONE!
After my unit (purchased outside of the Amazon system) a few years ago failed .. sO : ya I wrote to that company: what do i do ??? "the motor runs but no beans are ground!"
and here, i swear, is the essence of the singly-sentence response of "Customer NonSupport' :
"We're sorry but there's nothing we can do to fix your problem."
Need I say more?
(Why isnt there a ZERO star option ,, or , in this case a NEGATIVE 5 stars ...)
EOF ( 'End Of File' , in 'Puter Talk' )
OHH GET THIS!!! days after I complained to "Customer Support" , they had the nerve to email me
for an "evaluation" of their 'Customer Support' ... So , naturally, I told them it was easy to do so, because
THERE IS NONE!

reviews.reviewTitle: Bodum does well while it works.
reviews.reviewText: The Bodum grinder is a sturdy heavy piece and works well though it slows doen sometimes with oily beans. My has had over two years of steady use and is getting erratic on the timer. Clean the burrs often.

We drink French press coffee. Initially, we were very pleased with our fresh ground coffee. After a few months, though, it only ground very finely. We disassembled and cleaned the grinder according to the manufacturers instructions, but still, we only get super fine ground coffee. Rotating the hopper to change how fine of a grind it's supposed make does nothing.

I think this grinder is all flash and no lasting engineering. Get a better grinder that will last longer.

I've been using it for about 2 months now, and I love it. I thought long and hard before spending the money because of negative reviews, but they haven't proved to be a problem. It works wonderfully for any fineness of grind I choose (I've tried several), and the 'wait' between 20-second grinds doesn't bother me, as I grind up about half a hopper in 2-3 gos, then store the grind in a tightly sealed container in the fridge for 3-4 days of coffee. No problem. And I've been pleasantly surprised at how little clean-up there is. Everything about the grinder is just what I wanted.

reviews.reviewTitle: First step for a great cup of coffee.
reviews.reviewText:
Easy to use, great grind and quieter than our old blade grinder. Finding that we're using considerably less coffee for similar strength coffee with better taste. Several reviewers touted the glass container for the grounds as generating less static electricity for fewer clinging grounds but I don't find that to be the case. I think the burr grinders make a marked difference in the taste compared with the shredding of our previous blade grinder.

So far, so good.

This coffee grinder is amazing. Our previous grinder was a cheap one which did not really grind beans, more like mash them, but this grinder is several steps above our previous one. I could not believe how fine the espresso grinds would be; it almost reminds me of sand. The machine itself could not be easier to use, which is a plus. Also, it does not take up much space, which is a plus for us since counter space is at a premium in our kitchen. Overall, a great grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder sprays ground coffee all over the place. ...
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder sprays ground coffee all over the place. It makes a big mess. It produces a lot of static which makes a mess.

The glass container doesn't contain the grounds at all. The cap and rubber ring collect grounds, and are difficult to clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: 2 Years and Counting. Buy it for the static free grounds!
reviews.reviewText:
Glass grounds container isn't static prone like most plastic bins are. This results in a much cleaner counter. I tap mine a couple times after grinding before removing it, then tap the lid, and there's no mess at all.

Had great results with this for a couple of years of daily grinding at all settings.

Be warned though, that French Press setting for 10 seconds will go through a LOT more coffee than at the Espresso setting for 10 seconds.

I recommend this grinder to people all the time and they have enjoyed theirs as well.

reviews.reviewTitle: This has been my favorite investment, one that I'm not sure I want ...
reviews.reviewText: This has been my favorite investment, one that I'm not sure I want to live without. Unfortunately, I'll need to learn again since the button to activate the grind completely stopped responding. I'm not sure what happened, as it received light use and was only used for two months. This issue seems to be fairly common with Bodum products. I purchased their coffee maker at the same time, and it also began to break within the same time span. I really want to believe it's a fluke with my machine, but seeing the reviews (for both products) makes me think it's a common manufacturing flaw of Bodum.

I've owned this for about 5 years now, maybe more, and have never had any issues with it. Works very well, grinds the beans as I want them and is simple to operate. Don't think you could ask for more from a grinder if you don't need a large amount of coffee at once. It is an excellent machine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great! A little messy, though
reviews.reviewText: It does what it says. It grinds the beans evenly and that's what is most important. Like most coffee grinders, though, it is a little bit on the messy side. I've never found one that didn't create a bit of mess getting the ground coffee from the grinder to the basket, but that can't be helped. I've found this grinder to do an exceptional job, at least as good as ground coffee that comes pre-packaged. A bit hard to clean, though.

I've had this grinder for 7 months and couldn't be happier with it. Has all the detail you need and grinds perfectly. Pleasantly, not as loud as many other burr grinders I've heard at friends' homes. Great!

My Bodum grinder worked just fine - for about a year. Then the mechanism to change grind coarseness failed. This involves just twisting the top plastic feeder funnel from coarse to very fine. Well, it no longer works. I just get coarse, fine for when I want to use my French press, not so good when I want to use my drip machine. I'm sure not going to pay a hundred bucks for another one!

The Bodum Bistro coffee maker is awesome! It is quiet, easy to operate and clean, and the coffee tastes fantastic. Definitely an improvement over the cheap $15-20 coffee grinders. You really can notice a difference in the taste of your coffee. I often use this to grind small amounts of coffee beans for use in my Keurig (customizable k-cup insert). Works great!

I bought this for my wife, and she was very happy with it, and since it made her so happy, I was happy with it. Past that, I have used it myself, and found that it was easy to use, easy to clean, and did what I expected of it. The only reason that I am not giving it five stars is the 20 second on / 5 minutes off operating cycle.

ADDENDUM: REVIEW REDUCED FROM 4 STARS TO 1 DUE TO TOTAL FAILURE OF PRODUCT UPON 4TH USE

I know some say it doesns't grind long enough....but.. I only drink one to two cups at a time so I have no problem with it at all... I used to drink Yuban (from the can) and thought it was good coffee (and it was) but now.... I drink great tasting coffee.. I've only had it about a week but no problems yet and can recommend it!! If that changes... I'll add to this later.... Now, back to my coffe.

I bought this grinder about a year ago for $85. That was the standard price at the time. Many of the reviews here on Amazon are written with that in mind; "good value" etc. This is a good burr grinder but not for $175. If you're looking to spend that much you would be better off buying one of the lower tier Baratza grinders.

Don't do it. Horribly inconsistent grinds. Gums up almost immediately after cleaning. We replaced it with the Kitchen Aid KCG0702CU (great machine, awesome price). The old one went out in a back alley and we went office space all over it with a baseball bat.

reviews.reviewTitle: The glass does not attract static electricity like my old cheap plastic one
reviews.reviewText: Worth the money and gives me a consistent grind every time! The glass does not attract static electricity like my old cheap plastic one. Still will occasionally have a few grinds that get on the counter, not as bad as my old Mr Coffee burr grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great deal on a great product
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this grinder at a JC Penney's on clearance for $38USD on 11/9/13. I couldn't be happier with it. On the auto-drip setting about 7 seconds gets me enough for one large (16 oz.) travel mug of strong coffee. I find that the grind is very consistent and the single button operation is quite convenient. I had to play around with it to find how long to set the timer to get my desired amount of grounds, but now that I've got the setting, it's basically effortless to use.

I don't review many products but this one is a good one.

At first I thought that a timed grinder was absurd. I was wrong. Just perfect! Set the grind, set the time for the output; this takes practice.

Perfect amt for the cup every time! Just push the button and get a perfect grind for the perfect amount every time.
Buy it from Bodum, you get the original and it's only $69. Easy.

Worked great at first, but three months later it died. The light turns on, but nothing happens. I assume that something is clogging the burr, but I can't figure out a way to take it apart to fix it. Sadly, I can't return it as it died after thirty days.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fresh ground beans are the difference maker
reviews.reviewText:
Used to have this on my desk at my old job and it was a casualty of my quick dismissal. What a bummer, because I really miss this thing. It was pretty messy and loud as hell, but it was fun seeing my coworkers come running when they heard the sound of fresh coffee.

Once you have fresh ground beans you'll never want to go back to pre ground coffee. Coffee loses most of its aromatics so quickly that it's practical for a real coffee fan to insist on fresh grounds.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not a good buy - broken after 1 year and 1 month
reviews.reviewText:
Giving this a low rating for two reasons:
- design is poor and the grinds usually back up inside the unit.
- cheap plastic feel
- after 1 year and 1 month it stopped working. sounds like some kind of internal gear or shaft proble

Always cleaned this after each use. Probably used less than 12 times in the period. Each time I ground about a pound of coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: The best that is on the market
reviews.reviewText: Got this as gift I been looking for some time . Quite and easy to use This is it !!!!!! The best that on the market . The grind is right on .Easy to clean,and to take the canister out. Do not look any further

This coffee grinder looks very nice. Mine is the bright red model which looks pretty nice in my kitchen

Because it can't grind beans to the finest consistency,(like my older grinder). I have found it very disappointing. I've refilled the chamber over and over trying to get a fine espresso texture to no use. While the product claims to and has an espresso icon, it really fails to produce coffee of appropriate "espresso" texture.

I'm used to using Illy coffee in my espresso machine and this product's performance makes it impossible to really enjoy espresso.

While it's fine for making coarser coffee, very quickly too, it's not right for espresso and I couldn't recommend it for espresso drinkers..

We bought this (well, previous model to be precise) based on the rave reviews on Amazon and elsewhere. We've enjoyed using it for a little over a year now. This morning, though, while routinely grinding coffee it broke; the motor runs but the blades no longer turn. I presume the belt broke or something, but couldn't explain why. Unfortunately, it's not made to be taken apart (by the owner, anyway), so I haven't been able to further diagnose the problem (or attempt to fix it).

reviews.reviewTitle: Used daily for over a year, still works great!
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this last February for my husband. We've used it almost every day since without complaint, so it's pretty hardy. We use it with what's called an '8cup' french press (it really only makes 3 or 4 normal sized mugs) on the coarsest grain size for about 12 seconds. It's perfect for us, but if you are planning to use it with a large drip grinder, which requires more coffee, you might consider something else because it doesn't grind a lot at once. I love that you can click the button and walk away from it rather than needing to stand there and hold the button while the coffee grinds.

Update: We've now used this daily for 2.5 years. Grinder is still working perfectly. We've switched up our brewing system since the original review, and been using the grinder on it's finest setting for about six months now. Still no complaints. Fantastic purchase!

I had never tried grinding my own coffee before and usually buy my coffee already processed. When this came across on Vine I decided I would try it.
